HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Loss Widens at British American Tobacco

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: LONDON, March 9

 BODY:
British American Tobacco P.L.C. said today that its loss in the fourth quarter had widened, reflecting costs to the company of the $206 billion settlement between cigarette makers and 46 American states, and it warned that operating profit in the current quarter was likely to be below the level a year earlier.
The big cigarette maker has been hurt by the settlement in the United States and by the economic problems of emerging markets since it was created in September when the predecessor company, B.A.T. Industries, split its tobacco activities from its financial services interests. 
 "It's clearly going to take a year or two for their earnings growth to get back on track," said Trevor Moss at Robert Fleming Securities.
(In Switzerland today, Zurich Financial Services, created by the merger of the B.A.T. financial operations and the Zurich Insurance Company, said it would take a $2.4 billion charge to integrate the operations, nearly double its previous estimate.)
In the fourth quarter, British American Tobacco's loss grew to £171 million, or $275 million, from £163 million a year earlier. About £463 million of settlement costs were recorded in the quarter. The company's Asian-Pacific operations incurred a loss of £21 million.
The performance in the quarter pushed full-year profit down 16 percent, to £346 million.
On the American Stock Exchange, the company's American depository receipts, each of which represents 2 shares, declined 25 cents, to $18.375.

HEADLINE: Fluor to Cut 5,000 Jobs and Reorganize Operations

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: IRVINE, Calif., March 9

 BODY:
The Fluor Corporation, suffering from the Asian economic crisis and its own bloated cost structure, said today that it would cut 5,000 employees, reorganize its operations, and narrow the range of construction projects it undertakes.
Fluor, the nation's largest engineering and construction company, said the moves were expected to reduce overhead costs by $160 million annually but would require a $130 million pretax charge against earnings in the current quarter. 
 "We have a cost structure that is unsustainable," Philip J. Carroll, the company's chairman and chief executive, told shareholders at the annual meeting here today. He said a reorganization would have been needed even if business conditions had been better.
But those conditions continue to deteriorate. The company said today that it expected only $6 billion in new construction orders this year, about half the level of two years ago and less than the $8 billion it had previously been forecasting for this year.
Fluor said it expected to record net income this fiscal year of $107 million, or $1.42 a share, after the restructuring charge. That is less than half the $235 million, or $2.97 a diluted share, it earned last year on revenues of $13.5 billion. Even excluding the charge, which amounts to $1.23 a share, expected earnings of $2.65 a share are below the $2.99 or so that analysts have been estimating.
Fluor shares closed today at $34.3125, down $1.75. The shares, which have traded as high as $52.50 in the last year, are near their 12-month low of $33.25.
The construction industry has been buffeted by the Asian financial crisis, which derailed many large projects. The Asian crisis also helped precipitate a decline in oil prices, slowing capital spending by oil companies, which are prime Fluor customers. Fluor's A. T. Massey coal production subsidiary, meanwhile, has been hurt by weak domestic steel production caused in part by an influx of cheaper steel from abroad.
The 5,000 job cuts amount to about 9 percent of the nearly 57,000 employees the company had at the end of last fiscal year. The cuts are coming mainly from salaried employees in the engineering and construction division, and constitute nearly 20 percent of that group. Some 1,000 of the cuts will be in staff-support positions, which constitute overhead, and 4,000 will be of people working directly on construction projects. The company will also close 15 of its roughly 75 offices.
The reorganization bears the stamp of Mr. Carroll, who came to Fluor as chief executive last July after serving as the president of the Shell Oil Company, the American arm of the Royal/Dutch Shell Group. Mr. Carroll, 61, who had reached Shell's retirement age of 60, replaced Lester G. McCraw, who resigned as Fluor's chief executive at the end of 1997 after being diagnosed with bladder cancer.
Under Mr. McCraw, Fluor, which is based in Irvine, south of Los Angeles, expanded into many different types of construction in an effort to boost its revenues.
"We would have poured your driveway if you wanted us to," James O. Rollans, the chief financial officer, said.
But much of the new business was not profitable. Mr. Carroll, aiming to double construction profit margins within five years, said Fluor would now focus on sectors in which it had a strong expertise and could command better profits, such as in petrochemicals and mining. It will phase out construction of office buildings, paper mills and other low-margin activities.
The company will also reorganize into four units, each with profit-and-loss responsibility. They are Fluor Daniel, the construction division;A. T. Massey, the coal producer; Fluor Global Services, which combines businesses such as equipment leasing and temporary staffing that the company sees as fast growing, and Shared Services, which will sell computing and administrative services to the other divisions.
Alan L. Boeckmann was promoted to head the construction division, which accounted for the bulk of revenues and about 40 percent of profits last year. That puts him in contention to succeed Mr. Carroll, who is expected to stay for several more years. Another contender is John Hopkins, who was named today to head a new global business development, sales and marketing group.
Fluor bucked the recent corporate trend of divesting noncore businesses by deciding to keep the coal division, which historically has been a strong performer. Mr. Carroll said there was some synergy between coal and construction, but that Fluor would continue to evaluate whether selling the coal business made sense.
One person close to the company said Fluor believed Massey, still financially strong, would be able to acquire some weaker rivals during the current hard times. That would make it more valuable if it were spun off in future years.

HEADLINE: END OF AN EMPIRE: THE HISTORY;
Writing the Last Chapter of 'Barbarians at the Gate'

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

 BODY:
Yesterday's move by the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation to break up and spin off its tobacco business is a nonevent for consumers. Oreo cookies, Life Savers candies and Planters peanuts will continue to roll off Nabisco's production lines and Camel and Winston cigarettes will come out of the R. J. Reynolds tobacco factories.
But the news is fascinating for Wall Street and business historians. 
 RJR Nabisco was born in 1985 when R. J. Reynolds Industries bought Nabisco Brands Inc. for $4.9 billion, one of many giant diversification moves by American companies in the 1970's and 1980's that have failed to reward shareholders.
"I see this as the undoing of another dumb merger," said Thomas Lys, a merger and acquisitions specialist at Northwestern University's Kellogg School of Management.
But RJR's story included an unusual response to Wall Street's distaste for the Nabisco merger. RJR followed the lead of hundreds of smaller companies that had been put in private hands during the 1980's by groups of financiers and insiders who borrowed vast sums of money to buy out shareholders of publicly traded enterprises. The leveraged buyout strategy hinged on selling pieces of the company to reduce the debt piled up in buying it, rapidly streamlining the rest and then selling shares back to the public at prices that produced huge profits for the buyout investors.
By October 1988, when F. Ross Johnson, RJR's brash and high-living chairman and chief executive, joined with investment bankers from Shearson Lehman Hutton to propose a $75-a-share buyout, the leverage strategy was already controversial for its disruptive effect on employees. The ensuing soap opera of greed and clashing egos, recapped in the best-selling "Barbarians at the Gate," ended in a $109-a-share, $25 billion buyout organized by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company.
It also left Mr. Johnson's successors saddled with nearly $19 billion in debt, most of it junk bonds paying punishing interest rates. It is not clear whether RJR could have dug out from such burdens and prospered if everything had gone perfectly in the decade that followed, but it did not.
The 1990's were marred by marketing missteps, including goading Philip Morris into a cigarette price war, management strife and recessions in key overseas markets. The company's financial straitjacket and limited strategic options made it impossible to hang on to high profile executives like Louis V. Gerstner Jr. and Charles M. Harper, whom Kohlberg Kravis had recruited to lead the turnaround. And hanging over everything was increasingly expensive and uncertain tobacco litigation.
When Steven F. Goldstone became chairman and chief executive in 1996, he said that the company was in better shape than other companies with shares trading at such a low multiple to earnings but that he still had "to demonstrate we're through punishing shareholders."
Yesterday's change in course was a final concession that RJR never quite managed to do that and was unlikely to in its present form, inherited from the 1980's.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Chinese Raise Interest Rates on Dollar Deposits

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: BEIJING, March 9

 BODY:
China raised interest rates today on United States dollar deposits in an effort to stem a flow of hard currency out of the country that has come as international banks cut credit lines to Chinese borrowers.
The Bank of China, acting on orders of the central bank, raised the rate on one-year dollar deposits in Beijing to 4.66 percent from 3.75 percent. It also increased one-year rates for deposits denominated in the Hong Kong dollar -- which is linked to the American currency -- to 5.25 percent from 5 percent. 
 The rate increases "will encourage repatriation of hard-currency earnings by Chinese exporters," said Fred Hu, executive director of Asian Economic Research at Goldman, Sachs in Hong Kong. He called the increase a "correction" that brought Chinese bank rates more in line with international rates.
Other Chinese banks typically follow the lead of the Bank of China, a large commercial bank here. The new rates will vary among Chinese cities and banks.
Despite the higher rates paid on deposits of dollars, local currency rates "still have room to go lower," Mr. Hu said.
Seeking to rekindle economic growth, and to lower the interest payments that state-owned companies must make, China has cut interest rates paid on deposits of the local currency, the yuan, five times since November 1996. The economy is projected to grow 7 percent this year; although that is much faster than the growth expected in other Asian countries, it would be the slowest expansion in China since 1990.
Chinese banks currently pay 3.78 percent on one-year yuan deposits.
In 1997, China's foreign-exchange reserves rose by an average of $3 billion a month. But last year, despite increases in the trade surplus and in foreign investment, exchange reserves rose about $400 million a month.
The concern over currency reserves comes as foreign banks have instituted a near-freeze on new loans to Chinese companies. The foreign banks curtailed lending after the collapse in October of the nation's second-biggest trust company. Many of them are also demanding early repayment of loans to minimize further losses if more Chinese companies fail, bankers say.
Still, the $5 billion gain in reserves last year brought China's total to $144.96 billion at the end of 1998, second only to Japan's.
Today's interest-rate increase will narrow the gap between Chinese and foreign rates. The Bank of China's rate of 4.66 percent for one-year dollar deposits in Beijing is below the average of 5.23 percent offered by banks in the United States. The 5.25 percent rate offered for Hong Kong dollars is still below the 7 percent that Hong Kong banks are paying in Hong Kong.
Still, the increases may prove to be an incentive for Chinese exporters to repatriate some of their foreign funds. Exporters are permitted to retain 15 percent of their foreign-currency earnings, much of which is believed to remain outside China.

HEADLINE: Small Liberal Arts Colleges Facing Questions on Focus

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN 

 BODY:
Endowments are up, and so are applications. At the nation's 550 small private liberal arts colleges, times have seemingly never been better. So why do many educators fear for their future?
In the winter issue of Daedalus, the quarterly journal of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, to be mailed to subscribers this week, several scholars warn that these institutions face a serious quandary in the next few years. 
 One, Eva T. H. Brann, a former dean at St. John's College in Annapolis, Md., goes so far as to call these institutions "an endangered species." And Paul Neely, a trustee of Williams College who is publisher of The Chattanooga Times, writes that "there may simply be more pure liberal arts colleges than we need."
About half a dozen small private residential colleges close their doors every year, and many others survive only by merging with larger institutions. Furthermore, the number of accepted students who eventually enroll -- a critical percentage that educators call "yield" -- is as low as 30 percent at even some of the most admired of these campuses, against well over 90 percent for the Ivy League institutions.
As a result, educators -- and not just those writing for Daedalus -- are posing a long-term question for the small liberal arts colleges: Should they shift their focus from a high-minded, education-for-its-own-sake approach to a more down-to-earth, job-oriented curriculum featuring programs in subjects like computer science, the global marketplace and accounting?
More than a few have already made the shift. "Pre-professional programs are a definite trend in our schools," said David Warren, president of the National Association of Independent Colleges and Universities, which represents most of the nation's small four-year residential liberal arts colleges.
But others warn that the shift to a heavily pre-professional curriculum will blur the distinction between the liberal arts colleges and their less expensive competitors -- publicly supported colleges and universities -- and thus weaken the private colleges by drawing students away.
At least two-thirds of the 550 colleges are almost unknown outside their local communities, while a few -- like Williams, Swarthmore, Haverford, Kenyon, Amherst and Wellesley -- are among the best-known names in American education.
Their principal selling point in the educational marketplace is that their diminutive size -- most have only 1,800 to 2,000 students -- permits faculty members to devote themselves to being teachers and mentors; research and publishing are preoccupations mainly at the big universities.
The claim is only partly valid, since small-college professors, like those at universities, are well aware that throughout academe, professional advancement is largely based on research and publishing and therefore are ignored at one's peril.
Furthermore, universities argue that good researchers are usually good teachers, and that students are energized by association with professors working at the cutting edge of their disciplines.
On the other hand, universities from Harvard on down assign small-section discussion leadership to teaching assistants (graduate students), a practice the small colleges generally avoid.
But small classes and one-on-one instruction are expensive -- maybe too expensive. Writing in Daedalus, Michael S. McPherson, the president of Macalester College in Minnesota, and Morton Owen Schapiro, a professor of economics at the University of Southern California, report that the almost explosive growth of public colleges and universities in recent decades has led to a steady shrinking of the small private college customer base that is "willing and able to cover the costs of the enterprise."
Mr. Neely, the Williams trustee who contributed to Daedalus, blames "vocationalism, credentialism or even dollarizing" on the part of students for the financial stress.
The small colleges most vulnerable to failure, he writes, are the handful in the lowest economic tier that "have not had the resources to develop an additional, career-oriented curriculum" that many students and their parents are now demanding.
But paradoxically, Mr. Neely writes, most of the several hundred small mid-level liberal arts colleges that have been able to provide specialized, career-oriented training have done so at the expense of low tuition, small classes, close faculty-to-student relationships, competitive faculty salaries and painstaking campus maintenance -- characteristics that have traditionally distinguished these colleges from public ones.
Even the small private colleges with national prominence are in jeopardy, Mr. Neely warns, unless they can present themselves as alternatives to a culture that chooses "trends over permanence, image over substance, money over values, and the market over meaning."
In agreement with Mr. Neely, Richard H. Hersh, president of Hobart and William Smith Colleges in Geneva, N.Y., warns against "Mc Universities -- learning malls catering to the whims of their customers," and urges his liberal arts colleagues to provide students with "a coherent body of knowledge."
Whatever the dangers faced by the small private liberal arts colleges, most educators who have studied them conclude that their special contribution to higher education is inextricably related to their size.
In a personal essay in Daedalus, Geoffrey Canada, president and chief executive of the Rheedlen Center for Children and Families, told how he as an African-American student was transformed in the 1970's by four years at the almost all-white Bowdoin College in Brunswick, Me.
"There is something about the smallness of Bowdoin that brought about an intimacy that I will never forget," Mr. Canada wrote.
"A student who left school because of poor academic performance, although a rare occurrence, was felt to be a real loss," he continued. "The faculty seemed to feel the same way."

HEADLINE: Support Is Pledged for Republican Budget

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 9

 BODY:
Republicans pledged support today for the budget outline worked out last week by their leaders but acknowledged that turning the plan into legislation would be fraught with political risks and difficulties.
After separate briefings on the plan, House and Senate Republicans said they expected to adopt a tax and spending guideline in the next several weeks that would set aside all money generated by the Social Security system, increase spending for the military and education, cut taxes and remain within the tight spending limits in current budget law. 
 Eager to present a united front as they head into another season of battles with the Clinton Administration over fiscal priorities, Republicans said they were willing to put aside their long-running internal divisions and to suspend for now their doubts about the plan's political viability.
Republicans appear to have resigned themselves to limiting the size of their proposed tax cut for next year to a much smaller level than they had initially envisioned. But several influential Republicans said the party would ultimately have to confront the hard choices their plan would force on them, most notably its requirement for deep cuts in domestic programs outside the Pentagon and education to remain within the spending caps.
Senator Ted Stevens, the Alaska Republican who heads the Senate Appropriations Committee, said there was little will in the Senate for cuts in nonmilitary spending but a strong desire for an increase in Pentagon spending. As a result, Mr. Stevens said, the appropriations committees, which draw up the bills that finance specific programs, would inevitably come under heavy pressure to break the spending caps.
"I can live with them," he said, referring to the caps. "But I'm not sure Congress can take the actions necessary to live within them."
Mr. Stevens and other Republicans said they wanted to avoid a replay of last year, when Congress and the Administration agreed on a spending plan during a flurry of last-minute negotiations that got around the spending limits by designating $20 billion in expenditures as "emergencies" that are not subject to normal budget rules.
Senator Don Nickles of Oklahoma, the Republican whip, said: "To stay within the caps will require fiscal discipline. We broke that discipline last year."
The Republican plan, which has been endorsed by the party's leaders in both the House and the Senate, is an effort to claim the high ground in this year's budget battle by promising to go further than President Clinton in saving projected Federal budget surpluses for Social Security and preserving fiscal discipline.
The plan will be the basis for the budget resolution, a nonbinding measure that guides the appropriations and tax-writing committees in both chambers. Because it is not legislation, the budget resolution cannot be vetoed by the President, although White House officials have already attacked the plan for requiring deep cuts in domestic spending and for not earmarking part of the projected budget surplus to shore up Medicare.
Budget politics this year are particularly complicated, in part because they are caught up in the related question of how to shore up Social Security and in part because of the eagerness in both parties to position themselves for the 2000 elections.
But if the ideological divide between Republicans and Democrats appears especially deep this year, the size of the projected budget surpluses could provide a useful bridge. This is because the strength of the economy seems likely to make the surplus even bigger than projected for the next year or two. Members of both parties said the prospects for a compromise improved with each increase in the pool of money available to them, in much the same way that the 1997 bipartisan budget agreement was built on the improving fiscal outlook.
The potential for a larger-than-expected surplus is already playing into Republican plans. Representative John R. Kasich, the Ohio Republican who heads the House Budget Committee, told House Republicans today that he expected next year's tax cut to be $10 billion to $15 billion.
But Mr. Kasich later told reporters that if the Congressional Budget Office increased its estimate of next year's surplus in coming months, the size of the tax cut could expand. Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader, said the tax cut next year could be as much as $25 billion, and would grow rapidly in subsequent years as the non-Social Security budget surplus increased.
The budget wrangling also continued to ensnare a $1.9 billion supplemental spending bill that includes disaster relief aid for Central American countries hit by Hurricane Mitch. The White House has proposed paying for the spending by dipping into this year's surplus, all of which comes from Social Security. But Republicans insisted again today that the aid be paid for by offsetting spending cuts in programs including welfare and food stamps, a condition the White House has rejected.

HEADLINE: John Atwood, Aviation Executive, Dies at 94

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
John Leland Atwood, an engineer who rose through the executive ranks at North American Aviation as it built the P-51 Mustang, the most powerful fighter plane of World War II; the F-100 Super Sabre, the first supersonic fighter, and the Apollo capsule that took men to the moon, died on March 5. He was 94 and lived in Los Angeles.
Mr. Atwood, who was known as Lee, retired in 1970 as chairman of the North American Rockwell Corporation, a company formed three years earlier by the merger of North American Aviation Inc. of Los Angeles and the Rockwell-Standard Corporation, an auto parts maker in Pittsburgh. The company became Rockwell International in 1973. 
 Don H. Davis, the chief executive of Rockwell International, said Mr. Atwood's contributions "helped the United States to attain aerospace superiority."
Mr. Atwood was assistant general manager of North American Aviation in 1940 when he persuaded the British Government to pay for development of a new plane instead of modifying the Curtiss P-40. Pilots flying the new plane, the P-51 Mustang, were responsible for almost half of the enemy aircraft downed in Europe.
Luther Smith of Villanova, Pa., one of the Tuskegee Airmen, a unit of black fighter pilots, flew 50 of his 133 World War II combat missions in a P-51. He said yesterday that the Mustang "could outmaneuver all of the German fighters."
"The P-51 was so powerful, with its Rolls-Royce engines, and so maneuverable, that we would give Germans 10 seconds to parachute out once we got behind them," he added. "They knew, and we knew, that we had them and we would have our gun cameras on, and as soon as we got a picture of them bailing out we would shoot down the plane and let the pilot live."
Mr. Atwood also played a key role in designing the B-25 Mitchell, a medium-range bomber, 16 of which were used by Gen. Jimmy Doolittle in the raid over Tokyo in 1942, an attack that had little military value but helped raise American morale.
In 1953, Mr. Atwood disclosed that the F-100, which his company built, had become the first production jet fighter to operate at supersonic speeds in level flight. He also helped North American Aviation win the contract to build the X-15 rocket plane, which Capt. Pete Knight flew at more than 4,500 miles an hour in 1967.
Mr. Atwood was born in 1904 in Walton, Ky. He graduated from Hardin-Simmons University in 1926 and two years later earned a master's degree in civil engineering at the University of Texas. He then went to work as a junior airplane engineer for the Army Air Corps at Wright Field in Dayton, Ohio.
In 1930, he was hired at Douglas Aircraft in Santa Monica, Calif., and in 1934 he moved to North American Aviation in Los Angeles as chief engineer and vice president. He was promoted to assistant general manager in 1938, to first vice president in 1941, to president in 1948, chief executive in 1960 and chairman in 1962.
Five years later, when the company merged with Rockwell-Standard, Mr. Atwood was named chief executive, a post he held until he retired in 1970. In 1996, Boeing acquired the aerospace operations of Rockwell International.
Mr. Atwood is survived by his wife, Patricia, Rockwell International said.
For many years after World War II, North American Aviation was the biggest military contractor, relying on Washington for virtually all of its revenue. Mr. Atwood was called to Washington several times for hearings by Congressmen about how well the company spent taxpayer money, as well as its relationship with Robert G. Baker, the Senate Democratic secretary whose outside business dealings were the subject of a 1964 Congressional inquiry.
In 1962, North American Aviation abruptly reduced by half its contract with a vending machine company to make room for another company, U-Serv, in which Mr. Baker was a major shareholder. The deal was valued at $2.5 million, the equivalent of $13.6 million today. Mr. Atwood told the Senate Rules Committee in 1964 that he was unaware of Mr. Baker's role or that his company's lobbyist was also a major U-Serv shareholder. Ten days later, Mr. Atwood announced that he had dismissed the lobbyist.
In 1967, Mr. Atwood was again called on the carpet after a fire killed three Apollo astronauts during a pre-flight test of the space capsule. Mr. Atwood said that in designing the capsule no one had considered the possibility of a fire on the ground.
The Government's own inquiry found shoddy work that was not caught by inspectors of North American Aviation, including a socket wrench left inside the Apollo capsule. The moon project was not only a huge political issue but also an economic giant that accounted for almost 1 percent of the gross national product at its peak.
Mr. Atwood told a House committee that "overconfidence" was behind some of the problems, which he vowed to correct without delaying the national goal to put a man on the moon before the end of the decade. He installed new managers on the project and made other changes. On July 20, 1969, Neil A. Armstrong put his boot into lunar dust and later that year the National Aeronautics and Space Administration gave Mr. Atwood its Public Service Award.

HEADLINE: Eric R. Wolf, 76, an Iconoclastic Anthropologist

BYLINE: By ROBERT McG. THOMAS Jr. 

 BODY:
Eric R. Wolf, an accidental anthropologist whose cultural studies of Latin American peoples and European peasants helped enrich an already eclectic field even as he challenged some established cultural assumptions, died on Sunday at his home in Irvington, N.Y. He was 76 and had taught at Lehman College and the Graduate Center of the City University of New York.
The cause was liver cancer, his family said. 
 For someone who had had an intense fascination with the sometimes striking cultural differences of diverse peoples since his grade school days in polyglot Vienna and his teen-age years in strife-torn Sudetenland, Dr. Wolf -- whose father was Austrian and mother Russian -- did not immediately see anthropology as his natural academic outlet.
Even after he came to the United States with his parents and settled in Jackson Heights, Queens, Dr. Wolf, whose father had operated a textile factory in the Sudetenland before the 1938 Nazi takeover, saw biology as the best bet to explain human differences.
But after enrolling in Queens College planning to major in biochemistry, he stumbled into an anthropology class one day and realized that the broad field embraced just about everything he was interested in, which was just about everything about every aspect of the human experience.
After interrupting his education to serve with the Army in the Alps in World War II, Dr. Wolf received a degree in anthropology in 1946 and went on to Columbia University on the G.I. bill, receiving a doctorate in 1951.
Before joining City University in 1971 as a distinguished professor, he had brief teaching stints at the University of Illinois, the University of Virginia, Yale University and the University of Chicago and nine years as a professor at the University of Michigan.
By then he had already established his reputation as an innovative and iconoclastic academic, whose credentials included helping to organize one of the earliest Vietnam teach-ins, at Michigan in 1965.
His 1959 book about Mexico, for example, "Sons of the Shaking Earth," raised eyebrows among established anthropologists -- even as it established a fertile trend -- by drawing on archaeology, history and other alien fields to trace the diverse cultural development of Mexico. It is a reflection of the book's power, as well as of Dr. Wolf's clear and graceful writing style, that it is still used in introductory anthropology courses.
In writing the book, Dr. Wolf not only made unorthodox use of scholarship from other fields but also refined some of his own unorthodox ideas about the very nature of culture. Long seen by anthropologists as a stable set of attitudes and practices that defined various peoples and differentiated them from others, culture, as Dr. Wolf came to see it, was a far more dynamic process that involved endless practical, psychological and other reactions to changing economic and other conditions.
To Dr. Wolf, who outlined his position in a 1964 book, "Anthropology," the notion of unified and unchanging cultures amounted to little more than misleading ethnic stereotyping, sweeping generalizations that failed to notice or account for the variety of differences within a single culture.
Having concluded that established cultural anthropologists tended to neglect many nonconforming elements of a given society, Dr. Wolf helped rectify things with his 1966 book, "Peasants," which traced the common threads of peasantry in otherwise diverse European cultures.
In 1982 he developed another favorite theme, the sometimes cataclysmic impact of colonial capitalism on indigenous cultures, with "Europe and the People Without History," which tracked the impact of colonial economic expansion on less developed societies.
If Dr. Wolf was a champion of the idea that all people, even tribal societies and peasants, are equally important, he also practiced that philosophy in his life as a teacher or, as he saw himself, as a perpetual student for whom life was an endless and delightful field trip.
A brilliant man known for his charming and uncanny ability to make even ordinary people feel he was intensely interested in them, as indeed he was, Dr. Wolf was such a nurturing teacher that he was the preferred go-to guy when his students came up with brilliant but untested ideas. While other professors, they knew, might dismiss such brainstorms as harebrained, Dr. Wolf could be counted on to become as excited as they were.
Even after his retirement in 1992, Dr. Wolf, who was awarded a $375,000 MacArthur Foundation "genius grant" in 1990, continued his quest for new answers to old questions, among them the explanation for the Nazis' rise to power.
Finding parallels between the rise of Nazi Germany and both the widespread human sacrifice by the Aztecs and the development of a frenzied tradition of Potlatch feasts in the Pacific Northwest, Dr. Wolf examined them in his last book, "Envisioning Power: Ideologies of Dominance and Crisis," published this year by the University of California Press.
Dr. Wolf, whose first marriage ended in divorce, is survived by his wife, Sydel Silverman; two sons from his first marriage, David, of Burlington, Vt., and Daniel, of Los Angeles; two stepdaughters, Eve Silverman of Wilton, Conn., and Julie Yorn of Santa Monica, Calif., and three grandchildren.

HEADLINE: END OF AN EMPIRE: THE OVERVIEW;
RJR NABISCO SPLITS TOBACCO VENTURES AND FOOD BUSINESS

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS 

 BODY:
Burdened by debt and the persistent threat of fresh lawsuits over smoking, RJR Nabisco announced yesterday that it was splitting its food and tobacco businesses and selling its foreign tobacco company to a Japanese buyer.
The moves will effectively remove RJR Nabisco from the tobacco business, while the money from the sale will reduce its debt. The actions will also unravel one of the biggest mergers and most fought-over leveraged buyouts of the 1980's, a battle that became a symbol of the decade's excesses. 
 The original merger between R.J. Reynolds and Nabisco in 1985 was intended to enhance the tobacco company's increasingly negative image. Then in 1988, eager to raise the company's share price, RJR Nabisco's management announced a plan to take the company private for $17 billion. That move attracted other would-be owners, including the Kohlberg Kravis Roberts investment firm, which ultimately bid the price up to $30 billion.
The deal was financed at high interest rates, leaving the company with a mountain of debt. The battle for the company and the huge fees it generated for investment bankers inspired a best seller, "Barbarians at the Gate," which became a television movie. In early 1991, Kohlberg Kravis sold stock in the company back to the public.
With the changes announced yesterday, Steven F. Goldstone, the chairman and chief executive of RJR Nabisco, acknowledged that mixing the maker of Oreos and Nilla Wafers with the maker of Winston cigarettes had not worked out.
"There's no reason for these businesses to be under the same roof," he said. "They are very different enterprises, with different problems, different challenges and different investor groups."
People should have "the opportunity to choose whether they want to invest in a tobacco company or a food company," he added, acknowledging the "tobacco taint" that many analysts say has hampered the stock performances of Philip Morris and RJR Nabisco.
Domestic tobacco will become a separate company, which will be responsible for any smoking-related claims in the United States. The holding company will continue to own the food business and could be liable for claims if the domestic tobacco company were to go bankrupt.
The international tobacco division, perennially smaller and weaker than its rivals, is being sold to Japan Tobacco, which is controlled by the Government, for $8 billion, considered a hefty price by even the most optimistic stock analysts.
The efforts are intended to perk up a chronically depressed stock price. Wall Street responded cautiously, sending RJR's share price up a mere 75 cents, to close at $29.375, although it initially rose nearly $2 after the announcement.
Shares in Philip Morris also rose slightly, by 62.5 cents, with some investors betting it would separate its tobacco and food operations as well. A spokesman said Philip Morris had decided against that option in 1994 and had not changed its mind.
RJR's foreign sale, which is expected to be completed by mid-May, will shore up the domestic tobacco company, which will be known as R. J. Reynolds Tobacco.
Most of the $5 billion in after-tax proceeds will be used to pay down that company's debt, now about $6 billion, said Marc Cohen, who follows tobacco companies for Goldman, Sachs. "It will then have a very conservatively managed and strong financial position," he said, calling the spinoff "a very bold move."
Current shareholders of RJR Nabisco will receive one share of the tobacco company for each share they own, in a transaction that will be tax free to them and the company.
RJR Nabisco will remain a holding company, with its sole asset the 80.6 percent of Nabisco that it now owns. Since it will no longer own any part of the tobacco company, it will be renamed Nabisco Group Holdings. Most of the 90 or so employees at its headquarters in New York will be laid off.
Plaintiffs in smoking lawsuits would be able to sue the holding company, several experts said yesterday, should the tobacco company be unable to meet its obligations. But with a reduced debt load, the free-standing tobacco company will be in a stronger financial position.
John Coale, a lawyer in Washington, who is involved in lawsuits against R. J. Reynolds, said he did not foresee the new corporate structure interfering with his cases.
"For all past conduct and present litigation, they are not off the hook," he said. "We would try to put Humpty Dumpty together again and then we would collect."
How much potential liability the holding company faces will be reflected in the stock price. RJR Nabisco now holds 80.6 percent of Nabisco's shares, and the remainder is held by the public.
While the food operation's shares were trading at $45 yesterday, the stock price of RJR Nabisco was less than $30. When the tobacco companies are spun off and sold, Mr. Cohen predicted, shares in RJR should rise closer to $45.
Carl C. Icahn, the corporate takeover specialist who has repeatedly bought and sold big stakes in RJR, re-entered the picture this winter and threatened to nominate his own board by this Friday if the company did not spin off the food unit. Pressure from Mr. Icahn was not a motivating factor, Mr. Goldstone said. "It would be Carl's third attempt up the wall," he said.
Once the lawsuits brought by the attorneys general of dozens of states were resolved last year in a $206 billion industrywide settlement, Mr. Goldstone said his priority became "finding a home" for the international tobacco business.
"We wanted to find a value for our shareholders that was high enough to fix the balance sheet of our tobacco business," he said.
Japan Tobacco agreed to pay a 33 percent premium for the international tobacco division, which had been valued at about $6 billion. Japan Tobacco's chief long-term strategist, Yasushi Shingai, said in an interview that he did not feel the price was too high. "These are very strong and prestigious brands, and there is a lot of potential to grow," he said.
With the deal, Japan Tobacco will vault from fifth place to third in the global cigarette business and gain a presence in Western Europe and Russia. Its revenue last year was $27.2 billion, and it is also involved in pharmaceuticals and food. In addition, it controls Japan's largest vending-machine company, a key asset in a country where many products are sold that way.
Formed in 1985 after privatization, Japan Tobacco owns Japan's biggest-selling cigarette brand, Mild Seven, and makes Marlboro cigarettes locally for Philip Morris.
Asked whether his company was concerned about liability from smokers' lawsuits, Mr. Shingai replied, "We have three pending litigations, but the law system and the culture are very different than in the U.S."
There was some speculation yesterday about a possible sequel to the story, particularly if Nabisco becomes a takeover target again. "Somebody like Philip Morris may find them appetizing," said Gary M. Black, who tracks tobacco stocks for Sanford C. Bernstein & Company.

HEADLINE: 20 Journalists, Including 2 Times Writers, Win Polk Awards

BYLINE: By ANDREW JACOBS 

 BODY:
Twenty journalists whose work documented corporate deceit, political impropriety and ethnic bloodletting have been chosen as recipients of the 1998 George Polk Awards, the awards' sponsor announced yesterday.
Among the winners this year are two writers for The New York Times. Russell Baker, who for 36 years wrote the "Observer" column in The Times, won the George Polk Career Award. It was the second Polk Award for Mr. Baker, who retired last year. He won the prize for commentary in 1978. 
 Clifford J. Levy, the Albany bureau chief of The Times, won the local reporting award for his exploration of political fund-raising in the state government. His scrutiny of candidates' donor lists exposed conflicts of interest and led to continuing criminal investigations.
This year is the 50th anniversary of the awards, which were established in memory of George W. Polk, a CBS correspondent who was killed in 1948 while covering the civil war in Greece. The awards, which are administered by Long Island University, will be presented April 14 at the Roosevelt Hotel in Manhattan.
Other winners this year included Alix M. Freedman of The Wall Street Journal, who won the international reporting award for her investigation of efforts to sterilize women in the third world, often without their consent.
Juan Gonzalez, a columnist for The Daily News for more than two decades, won the commentary award for his writings on New York's poor and disenfranchised.
The award for foreign reporting went to Tracy Wilkinson of The Los Angeles Times, who wrote about the struggles between ethnic Albanian separatists and Serbian nationalists in Kosovo.
The other categories and winners are:
Economic Reporting -- Mary Jordan, Keith Richburg and Kevin Sullivan of The Washington Post, for their eight-part series illustrating the human toll of the Asian economic crisis.
National Reporting -- Donald L. Barlett and James B. Steele of Time magazine for their series on wasteful government subsidies to corporations.
Book -- Philip Gourevitch, for his account of genocide in "We Wish to Inform You That Tomorrow We Will Be Killed With Our Families: Stories From Rwanda" (Farrar, Straus & Giroux).
Environmental Reporting -- Gardiner Harris and R. G. Dunlop of The Louisville Courier-Journal for their investigation into how illegal practices among coal mine operators lead to the death each year of 1,500 workers from black lung disease.
Radio Reporting -- Amy Goodman and Jeremy Scahill, producers for Pacifica Radio's "Democracy Now" series, for their documentary on Chevron's role in the murder of two environmentalists in Nigeria.
Television Reporting -- Brian Ross and Rhonda Schwartz of the ABC News program "20/20" for a report on the labor practices of American clothing manufacturers in Saipan, a United States commonwealth where sweatshop conditions persist.
Medical Reporting -- Robert Whitaker and Dolores Kong of The Boston Globe for their series on how mentally ill people are harmed by federally financed drug trials.
Legal Reporting -- Joe Stephens of The Kansas City Star for a report that exposed widespread conflicts of interest among Federal judges.

HEADLINE: COLLEGES;
N.C.A.A. Decision Creates Confusion

BYLINE: By JOE DRAPE with LENA WILLIAMS 

 BODY:
Now in his senior year at St. Patrick's High School in Elizabeth, N.J., Jamal Jackson has a 2.4 grade-point average in the classroom to go with his 11 points and 8 assists a game on the basketball court. He has received inquiries from Division I schools like St. Peter's and Fairfield, but in two attempts at the S.A.T, he has failed to make the National Collegiate Athletic Association minimum score of 820 required for an athletic scholarship.
Now he, as well as hundreds of high school athletes across the country, may not have to. On Monday, a Federal District Court judge in Philadelphia struck down the N.C.A.A.'s minimum test score requirement, or Proposition 16, saying that it discriminated against African-Americans. The ruling removed from the N.C.A.A.'s control the issue of college athletic eligibility, and for now placed it with the individual schools. It left college administrators and the N.C.A.A. in limbo yesterday, with many officials acknowledging that in the absence of guidelines, confusion would reign. 
 "It does present somewhat of a chaotic environment," said the N.C.A.A. president, Cedric Dempsey. "It leaves a lot of unanswered questions."
For Jackson and other students, the window of opportunity may be brief. The N.C.A.A. will ask Judge Ronald I. Buckwalter today for a stay of his decision, saying the chaos among its member schools would be counterproductive. In the mean time, it will prepare an appeal. Elsa Kircher Cole, the organization's general counsel, said she expected a response from the judge "within a day or two."
N.C.A.A. officials said they have been studying eligibility standards since last summer and are prepared to move quickly in establishing a new standard. Charles Wethington, the University of Kentucky president and chairman of the N.C.A.A. executive committee, said that coming up with an acceptable standard from more than four options has been difficult. He said the N.C.A.A. has not strayed from its goal of having initial eligibility standards in an effort to improve graduation rates and insure that student athletes are prepared for college work.
"We are greatly concerned at this moment with the effect this ruling will have on academic preparedness of prospective student athletes," Wethington said.
On a day when N.C.A.A. officials conceded they had more questions than answers, they also announced that the N.C.A.A. would pay $54.5 million to about 2,000 Division I coaches who had sued over the restricted earnings rule, which had capped their salaries at $16,000 for a calendar year. It is the settlement of a $75 million judgment against the N.C.A.A. in a case challenging its decision to limit the earnings of entry-level coaches.
But it was Buckwalter's ruling on one of college sports' most enduring challenges -- how to improve graduation rates without excluding economically disadvantaged students -- that left coaches, administrators and college presidents uncertain of who is eligible for scholarships. Without Proposition 16, there are no guidelines by which to decide if incoming freshmen are academically eligible.
It poses immediate problems in the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament, which begins tomorrow. The N.C.A.A. estimates that 500 to 1,000 athletes have been affected by the existing test score minimum requirement. Until a stay is granted, the N.C.A.A. said yesterday, athletes sitting out their freshman year because they failed to meet the minimum requirements are free to play -- including the Temple basketball player Alexander Wesby, who was one of the four plaintiffs in a class action suit in Philadelphia. He won't play in the tournament, said the Temple sports media director, Brian Kirschner.
Wethington said he wouldn't approve an ineligible player if the situation arises at his school. "I think this situation is too fluid, too undecided and there's too much at risk," Wethington said, emphasizing that he was speaking only for himself. "I think it would be sending the absolute wrong signal."
 The ruling touched on an issue that resonates among coaches and athletes. If it is upheld, the ruling could restore a lost year of eligibility to athletes like Rasheed Brokenborough, the Temple senior guard who sat out his freshman year because of the S.A.T. cutoff and ran up $15,000 in debt because he could not qualify for a scholarship.
"Everyone in coaching has been affected by the N.C.A.A. test rules," said Lute Olson, the Arizona coach. "There are a number of kids we would have recruited had they not had test scores standing in their way. This particular kid pops into my mind -- he is from southern California and he's playing in the pros now. He did not have high enough test scores in the initial period that we needed them to make the decision. We went with the kid with the test score. We would have opted for the southern California kid. Later, he got the test score at the end of the year. His first choice was us, but we couldn't wait and take the chance on him getting the score."
New York high school coaches, athletic directors and school administrators applauded the judge's ruling. Wade Williams, for 10 years the basketball coach at Bronx Regional, an alternative high school for students with academic problems, remembered the players who didn't meet the requirements.
"A lot of them were intimidated by the S.A.T. because they hadn't had academic success," said Williams, who has placed at least 40 athletes on scholarships at junior colleges or Division III schools.
But Williams, who is black, also worried that the ruling might have a damaging effect on those it aimed to help: black students.
"I'm very concerned that kids will think they don't have to do anything," Williams said. "It also exposes kids to unscrupulous coaches who will accept them for their talent, then cast them aside."
That situation , with embarrassing admissions by college students that they were not being educated or even had trouble reading, was what prompted the N.C.A.A. to institute minimum test scores in the first place back in the mid-1980's.
For St. Patrick's Jackson, a change in the requirements for athletic eligibility would bring an opportunity to be rewarded for the hard work he has done in the classroom. He is the second oldest of five children and would be the first in his family to attend college.
"I hope the judge's rule stands because I'd get a lot more offers," Jackson said yesterday by telephone as his team prepared for the state sectional tournament. "Right now, schools are scared to take me because of my S.A.T. scores. They're afraid they may have to park me on the bench."
His coach, Kevin Boyle, said Jackson has steadily raised his grade-point average over his four years. "He came in not as a great student," said Boyle. "But he stayed on the straight and narrow, worked hard and we made sure he didn't slip through the cracks. He's really tried to improve his S.A.T. scores, but he doesn't test well on big tests. This is a kid that deserves a break."

HEADLINE: Crime Is Falling, but Drug War Hurts Families

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Less Crime, More Criminals" (Week in Review, March 7): Crime is down, yet the incarceration of nonviolent drug offenders is growing at an enormous rate. We need to study new methods of treating drug offenders and to stop the growth of new prisons. The United States has the largest penal system in the world -- soon to reach two million inmates -- and as you report, 400,000 are now behind bars for drug crimes. The problem is that incarceration will not suffice as a means of rehabilitation for drug offenders. 
 Neither the economic health of businesses like the Corrections Corporation of America nor the political rhetoric of politicians should be a basis for the prison buildup. The building of new prisons does not remedy the drug war; it perpetuates it.
 
MICHAEL SOLIMAN
Morris Plains, N.J., March 7, 1999

HEADLINE: HOCKEY: N.H.L. ROUNDUP;
LaChance Gets Lost In Shuffle

BYLINE: By TARIK EL-BASHIR 

 BODY:

ISLANDERS 2, FLYERS 2
 The fire sale, it seems, has begun.
 During the first period of last night's 2-2 tie with the Philadelphia Flyers at Nassau Coliseum in Uniondale, N.Y., the Islanders traded defenseman Scott Lachance to the Montreal Canadiens for a third-round draft pick, as the team, with virtually no shot at the playoffs, cuts its payroll.
 More moves could be coming soon. Trevor Linden, the Islanders' captain, has reportedly drawn inquires from Detroit, Dallas, Ottawa, Toronto and Vancouver, and the center is likely to be traded before the March 23 trade deadline. Linden will make $2.5 million this season. 
 "The reason is kind of simple," Islanders General Manager Mike Milbury said of the Lachance trade. "There were some economic reasons involved. When you get down to the fifth or sixth spot, you have to be careful of what you're spending."
 Lachance, who has one goal, eight assists and a plus-minus rating of minus 19, had a salary of $1.1 million this season. Milbury said the Islanders were not willing to make Lachance a qualifying offer of $1.25 million for next season, so they got what they could for him.
 The fourth pick over all in 1991, Lachance never fulfilled the high expectations on Long Island, his stock plummeting this season. But a third-round pick?
 "I'm a little confused and shocked," said the 26-year-old defenseman, who was sometimes booed by the home crowd this year. "You wonder about a lot of things.
 "There have been a lot of moves over the years where I don't know if we got equal value back. I'm not going to say anything negative about the G.M. or the owners. But a third-rounder won't help this team for three or four years. I know the guys are thinking about that. I hope this isn't an indication of what is going to happen, for the fans and for the players."
 The trade leaves Rich Pilon as the lone Islander remaining from the team's previous playoff appearance in 1994, and he is also rumored to be on the trading block.
 "People say there is going to be a fire sale," Pilon said. "I don't think about it. It's out of my control."
 In last night's game, the Isles' second tie with the Flyers in four days, Dmitri Tertyshny and Daymond Langkow scored for Philadelphia as John Vanbiesbrouck made 20 saves in the Flyers' net. Scoring for the Islanders were Zigmund Palffy and Mark Lawrence; Tommy Salo made 33 stops. TARIK EL-BASHIR
 
BRUINS 2, PANTHERS 0
 Ray Bourque had a goal and an assist and Byron Dafoe made 19 saves for his seventh shutout of the season as host Boston beat Florida.
 The victory gave the Bruins a 2-point advantage over the Rangers in their fight for the eighth and final playoff spot in the N.H.L.'s Eastern Conference. They meet Friday at Madison Square Garden.
 Dafoe's stops included a glove save on Bret Hedican from the slot at 4:14 of the third period and a blocker save from the left of the crease by Robert Svehla five minutes later.
 Bourque, playing in his 1,435th game as a Bruin -- one shy of the team record held by John Bucyk -- scored a power-play goal at 9:45 of the second period to give Boston a 1-0 lead.
 The 150th power-play goal of his career came on a shot from the point.
 Jason Allison's 19th goal boosted the Bruins' lead to 2-0.
 
AVALANCHE 3, CAPITALS 2
 Sandis Ozolinsh scored 19 seconds into overtime as Colorado, winning for the second straight time without three of its top stars, dampened Washington's playoff hopes.
 Ozolinsh, with space in the left circle, took a pass from Valery Kamensky and beat goaltender Olaf Kolzig over the left shoulder.
 It was Ozolinsh's third goal of the season.
 
FLAMES 7, BLUES 4
 Rene Corbet scored twice as visiting Calgary overcame a two-goal deficit.
 Jerome Iginla and Corbet each scored to tie the game.
 Andrei Nazarov, Steve Dubinsky and Valery Bure also scored for Calgary.
 
MAPLE LEAFS 6, LIGHTNING 1
 Sergei Berezin made his 200th N.H.L. game a memorable one with two goals as host Toronto beat Tampa Bay.
 Mats Sundin had a goal and two assists, Tie Domi had a goal and an assist and while Mike Johnson and Lonny Bohonos also scored for Toronto. Robert Petrovicky scored for the Lightning.
 Curtis Joseph stopped 40 shots in the Toronto net.
 It was the second straight drubbing for the Lightning, which lost by 9-3 to Ottawa on Monday.
 Bill Ranford started in the Tampa Bay goal, but only lasted one period after giving up four goals on 18 shots. Corey Schwab, who let in the Senators' first seven goals, fared a little better, stopping 20 of 22 shots.
 Sundin burned Tampa Bay with three goals and 7 points in four games as the Maple Leafs swept the season series.
 The Maple Leafs got lucky when both Sundin's goal and Berezin's second were tipped in by Lightning defenders. Although he was given a 6-0 lead, Joseph stopped all 16 shots Tampa Bay fired at him in the first period and robbed Stephane Richer on two breakaways.
 Berezin had a strong night with four shots after two periods, including a few blistering off-wing rushes.
 The 27-year-old Russian, who has 67 career goals, leads the team with 26 goals.
 
REFEREES
 Satisfied with the way the format worked in selected games during the regular season, the N.H.L. will use two referees in all Stanley Cup playoff games this season,
 Colin Campbell, the N.H.L. senior vice president, said club executives were "overwhelmingly in support" of the two-referee system for the playoffs. (AP)

HEADLINE: Paid Notice: Deaths
MERKIN, HERMANN

 BODY:
MERKIN-Hermann. The Yeshiva University family expresses profound sorrow on the passing of a longtime friend, a distinguished philanthropist and communal leader in America and Israel who was senior vice chairman of YU's Board of Trustees and a Board member for three decades, including service as acting chairman. An honorary alumnus, he was a Benefactor with his wife, Ursula, advancing a wide range of University programs. In recognition of their major gift, YU's Teachers Institute for Men was renamed Isaac Breuer College of Hebraic Studies to memorialize Mrs. Merkin's renowned father. Mr. Merkin established the Leib Merkin Distinguished Professorial Chair in Talmud and Jewish Philosophy at our affiliated Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary in memory of his eminent father-a chair long held by the late revered Rabbi Joseph B. Soloveitchik. A founding member of the Boards of YU's Yeshiva College, Stern College for Women, and Sy Syms School of Business, he formerly served on the Boards of Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law, and Wurzweiler School of Social Work. He was an outstanding humanitarian whose benefactions covered many institutions and individuals, and he was a deeply faithful and observant Jew who was learned in the classical sources of the tradition. His life was truly a blessing. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Ursula; children, Dinah (and Andrew) Mendes, Deborah (and Nathaniel) Gerber, Ezra (and Lauren) Merkin, Daphne Merkin, Solomon Nehemiah (and Sharon) Merkin, and Rabbi David Elisha (and Rebecca) Merkin; sister, Eva Bondi; grandchildren; and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman Board of Trustees
MERKIN-Hermann. Bar-Ilan University in Israel and its American Friends mourn the passing of their colleague, Honorary Alumnus of the University and a member of the Board of the University's founders since its establishment, Hermann Merkin. We extend sincerest condolences to his beloved wife, Ursula, and the entire family. Mr. Merkin was a philanthropist of note, a very knowledgeable Jew, not only in the literature of Judaism, but also all of its happenings of the past and in the present. He had a profound command of the traditions to which he and his very scholarly wife were committed with their hearts and soulsand in its light they raised a family that is a pride and joy to our people here and in Israel. We share their sense of loss, its an overwhelming loss to our cause and many others here and abroad. We pray that they will derive comfort from continued involvement through long and healthful lives. Rabbi Emanuel Rackman, Chancellor Bar-Ilan University Professor Moshe Kaveh, Pres. HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE FOR A NEW CENTURY;
Fierce Poetry From Young Turks

BYLINE: By JULIE V. IOVINE

 BODY:
WENDELL BURNETTE'S first building, a house for himself at the edge of the Sonoran desert, has graced the covers of numerous international magazines. The British magazine Architectural Review proclaimed him "one to watch in 1998" and Metropolitan Home recently named him one of "21 Rising Stars for the 21st Century." A 36-year-old architect from Phoenix, he has arrived.
Or has he? The only job his office has right now is a small remodeling project; he can't remember when he last paid himself and can barely maintain a payroll for his one trusty employee. "The irony is that there are all these accolades," Mr. Burnette said on a cell phone last week as he drove to a potential project site at 7 A.M., "and at the same time, I'm wondering where the next meal is coming from." 
 And in Berkeley, Calif., Ralph Nelson and Raveevarn Choksombatchal, both 37, who were married in 1989, have shared an architectural practice called Loom for six years. Their combined curriculum vitae is 12 pages long, but it wasn't until they received a Progressive Architecture award last year that people began returning their calls.
"We've spent 10 years becoming an overnight success," Mr. Nelson said, adding that teaching stints kept the firm afloat. "Savings? What's that?"
Mr. Burnette's practice and Loom are among eight architecture firms selected as "Emerging Voices" of 1999 by the Architectural League of New York, a nonprofit organization that has sponsored public programs in architecture since 1881. But rising stars need more than a winning way with a T-square -- or a CAD program -- to make a name for themselves. The simplest projects require a fanatical commitment and Job-like patience. For those struggling to distinguish themselves, "the will to be independent overrides all sensible decisions" about life and gainful employment, Mr. Nelson said, gamely.
The League's winners offer a telling glimpse of the state of architecture -- a mirror of the built world of today and a window onto the next century. Drawing inspiration from sources as unexpected as the extreme shapes assumed by materials distorted by stress, or as poetic as the play of light in a Cartier-Bresson photograph, these eight firms, for all their travails, are shaping the future in ways that are strikingly individual but also surprisingly in synch.
Just about every significant architect who came of age in the last two decades, including Steven Holl, Tod Williams and Billie Tsien, Deborah Berke, and Henry Smith-Miller and Laurie Hawkinson has been an Emerging Voice.
Recalling the year he was selected (1982), Steven Holl, who comes from Seattle, said: "Here I was, an architect basically coming out of the woods to New York. And they chose me. It gave me hope."
"Emerging Voices is incredibly important, and not for crass reasons of career advancement," he continued, "because it acknowledges and respects the ideas swirling around in the heads of young architects."
An interest in the physical world, with all its warts and wonders, distinguishes one group of winners. Call them the New Sensualists: they're less interested in the eye-catching photogenic image of a building, more in how it feels to the touch, or sounds beneath the foot.
At the other end of the spectrum are the Philosophers, exploring ideas that straddle the worlds of theory and practice.
"There's an intensity of design, a commitment to new technologies and a passion about detail and materiality in all their work," said Craig Conyk, a New York architect, who served on the Architectural League's selection committee. "It's a very healthy sign for architecture."
In a multi-generational house the Loom team designed in Bangkok, for instance, a rosewood and teak staircase rings as resonantly as a music box, and concrete walls overlap to create openings that weave sunlight into each room.
For Ada Tolla and Giuseppe Lignano of Lotek in Manhattan, the future means embracing discarded industrial and consumer products, turning oil cans into armchairs, detergent bottles into lamps. In a penthouse, they've made a sun-filled bedroom on the roof out of a truck body, and they divided a loft into living and working spaces with a wall made of one sheared side of a 40-foot-long aluminum shipping container. What makes that space so intriguingly efficient is the way the sink and refrigerator are embedded in the room divider, in a manner that recalls Jean Cocteau's anatomical candelabra in "Beauty and the Beast."
And for Brian Healy in Boston, who grew up surrounded by cornfields in Bucks County, Pa., only to watch them give way to subdivisions and strip malls, that experience of transition left him with a desire to "make buildings that tap into a place," even as it changes. Mr. Healy, 42, is designing a modern writer's and artist's studio in the Catskills, with references back to the Arts and Crafts movement, a powerful design force there in the late 19th century.
Mr. Burnette, who has a naturalist's love of desert geology, applies an artist's abstraction to his designs, inspired in part by James Turrell and Richard Serra.
He based his design for a decorator's studio and showroom in Scottsdale, Ariz., on two mesquite trees in the courtyard. Instead of cutting them down, as others had proposed, he wove the trees and the building together, cutting notches in the masonry walls to frame the trees and let them grow.
A self-taught architect who went to work at Frank Lloyd Wright's Taliesin right out of high school, Mr. Burnette aims for rich spatial and textural experiences. Passage through the decorator's studio is labyrinthine: one climbs past several levels that appear to float free of the structure and, at one point, are illuminated by a scrim of Indian onyx so thin that sunlight passing through casts a golden glow on an oak staircase.
"I believe in doing many things with one stroke," Mr. Burnette said, comparing his work to Cartier-Bresson's photography, as it captures and distills a singular moment in space and time.
The tension in the work of Kevin Daly, 41, and Chris Genik, 39, in Santa Monica, Calif., oscillates between technological invention and hands-on craft. High-performance technologies get them going, but so does the chance to work side by side with woodworkers and metalsmiths. For instance, a house in Canada for Mr. Genik's parents bursts like a crystal from a massive pile of boulders. Ten years on the job and still fascinated by clients who dream of the impossible, Mr. Daly and Mr. Genik are interested in "finding the extraordinary in the very familiar." They look for inspiration in the seamless craftsmanship of the physical world -- from a World War II plywood and glue airplane to a tiny 1,000-year-old reliquary covered in gold that bears no trace of tool marks.
While an appeal to the senses and to found objects animates the work of the New Sensualists, the Philosophers, like Asymptote, Evan Douglis and Michael Bell, are investigating ways of building that seem radical today but may well become the traditions of tomorrow.
Hani Rashid, 40, and Lise Anne Couture, 39, of Asymptote utilize the most advanced computer technologies to create a kind of space that exists simultaneously in the real world -- "first-reality architecture," Mr. Rashid calls it -- and in virtual reality.
From their Asymptote office in SoHo's fanciful wrought-iron Singer Building (and their home in the loft next door), Mr. Rashid and Ms. Couture are "set on running all our credit cards into the ground" to realize the objective of designing at the edge of reality through such commissions as a computer-generated theater of operations at the New York Stock Exchange, which opened on Monday. Recently, they designed a showroom for a research company in Kyoto, Japan, to showcase new computer technologies in the hush of a museum-like setting, complete with a black box theater.
Evan Douglis has been on his own since 1991. He has yet to find a client entirely tuned int o his ideas about the poetry of architecture. "Early on, I rejected building at any cost," Mr. Douglis, 39, said at his office in a Chelsea warehouse. "It wasn't necessarily my best move." Luckily, the architect, as director of the Columbia University Architecture Galleries, has been able to commission himself to design installations. Borrowing from military technology for quick-assembly bridges, he suggests an alternative to solidity itself: why not a wall made from weather balloons caged in steel?
Mr. Bell, 38, lives and works in Houston, dividing his time between running his firm (six employees when there's work) and teaching at Rice University. He hopes to combine his theoretical interests "in the sheer brutality of economic forces" with an active commercial practice that gets things built. Most recently, he was the curator of a gallery exhibition in Houston, "16 Houses: Owning a House in the City," which has turned into a commission from Houston's Fifth Ward Community Redevelopment Corporation to build his entry in the show.
His is not necessarily a pretty house. At 900 square feet, the design reminded one local critic of two boomerangs squeezed back to back. All the walls are made of off-the-rack sliding-glass doors to make the point that we all lead transparent lives. The house, which will cost $74,000 or $52,000 with Federal vouchers, was chosen along with others in the exhibition to be built later this year.
"This is really a breakthrough I'm excited about," said Mr. Bell, who has endured seven clients in seven years who he says "chickened out" at the last possible minute. (One client, he said, lost interest when the architect couldn't squeeze the cost of a design down to $36 a square foot, from $38.)
Despite the disappointments of the past, and uncertainty that the housing project will truly happen ("Everyday, I wait for someone to say it's dead," he said), Mr. Bell wants to keep designing houses. After all, he added, houses are "how we imagine ourselves participating in the life of the city and the world."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasuries Sag As Other Debt Markets Swell

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Treasury securities fell in price under the sheer weight of corporate and municipal supply yesterday, as big companies including Lucent Technologies and Freddie Mac sold debt to the public sector.
The 30-year bond fell 11/32, to a price of 95 20/32; its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 5.55 percent, from 5.53 percent Monday. 
 Freddie Mac sold $3 billion of 10-year notes, and Lucent sold about $1.4 billion of 30-year global bonds.
Freddie Mac priced the 10-year notes to yield 5.81 percent, or about five-eighths of a percentage point more than Treasury notes with a similar maturity.
Lucent, the telephone equipment maker, raised the size of its 30-year bond offering through joint lead managers Bear, Stearns & Company and Merrill Lynch & Company by 36 percent, to $1.36 billion, selling the issue at a price to yield 6.49 percent. That is about 89 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, more than a similar Treasury issue.
Prospects of more corporate debt offerings in coming weeks are rising as higher-quality issuers take advantage of a strong economy, little inflation and low interest rates.
The AT&T Corporation plans to sell $5 billion to $6 billion of bonds in three parts as early as next week to help pay for recent acquisitions.
In the market for municipal bonds yesterday, borrowers sold almost half the $5.4 billion of debt expected this week. Among the issues was $700 million in general obligation bonds by the City of New York through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. That issue was initially priced to yield a maximum 5.26 percent for a bond due in 2029.
The Massachusetts Turnpike Authority sold $801.8 million of metropolitan highway system revenue bonds through underwriters led by Paine Webber, initially priced to yield a maximum of 5.27 percent for a 40-year bond due in 2039.
