HEADLINE: Schools Balk Over Driving Penalties for Students

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE

DATELINE: FAYETTEVILLE, N.C.

 BODY:
For 10 years now, the teen-age driver's li cense that sacred piece of plastic that confers mobility on the restless -- has been the bull's-eye of every state legislature in the South.
Drop out of high school, and 18 states, 12 of them in the South, will revoke a license. Many of those states will also take it away for poor grades or poor behavior. The laws have proved immensely popular with voters and politicians, who are convinced that they have found the trigger mechanism, the ultimate motivator of the American teen-ager. 
 But among the people who actually teach students and run schools, the license laws are increasingly seen as a waste of time and money, particularly because the time and money are usually theirs, not the state's.
Here in Cumberland County, the school board was already swimming in paperwork, busily revoking the licenses of students with poor attendance and grades, when news recently came that Lieut. Gov. Dennis Wicker had proposed revoking the licenses of disruptive students as well.
Fed up with the state's good intentions, the board voted to oppose the proposal. Using words like "unfunded mandate" and "big government," school officials say they have had enough of the state's helping hand.
"We appreciate the intent of what they're trying to do, but they don't realize the effect these laws have," said Dr. William C. Harrison, superintendent of the county's school district, the fourth-largest in the state, with about 50,000 students. "With all the issues we have on our plate, to overload us now with this kind of paperwork, asking us to do the work of social institutions and the family, well, it's a hard sell around here."
Many educators say parents and the legal system should determine who drives, not school officials, who often have to divert teachers or clerks from educational duties to enforce the law. Louisiana dropped its license-revocation law in 1997 after finding it too expensive. Florida let its law lapse in 1996, but legislators revived it the next year over the objections of school officials.
"We originally thought it would change the dropout rate, but it did not," said Wayne Blanton, executive director of the Florida School Boards' Association. "We found it extremely burdensome, and the paperwork that each principal and guidance counselor had to do was tremendous, and it did not slow down the dropout rate."
But such concerns are not slowing the momentum of the laws. Mr. Wicker's proposal recently passed the State Senate unanimously and appears likely to be enacted. Mr. Wicker said there was plenty of anecdotal evidence that the laws work, so the eventual outcome would be worth the administrative burden.
"The driver's license is a very powerful motivator among young people, particularly in the South where we don't have much mass transit," he said. "To young people, the license means everything. It's their freedom, it's a means of being able to move around and be mobile, which is very important to the life of a young person. They will do all they can possibly can to keep it."
There is no concrete proof that any of the laws have kept students in school or motivated them to work harder. The school dropout rates in many states did not change significantly after the laws were passed, and in other states, economic or educational changes were credited with improving school attendance.
"Anyone who tells you they know these laws work isn't telling the truth, because no one has done a study," said Kathy Christie, policy analyst with the Education Commission of the States, a nonprofit organization based in Denver that compiles data on state education policies.
"Up to now, these laws have been unpopular only with students, so no one has really put the money in to research it. It's politically easy to do, and it doesn't hurt."
Students are of mixed opinion, depending on their academic standing. Stephen Smith, a sophomore at South View High School here, said a license-revocation law would not bother him because he was on the honor roll, though he added that some of his friends were worried.
Barry Davis, a junior at Cape Fear High School, said the law was unfair.
"I'm no good at math," he said. "So why should that mean I can't drive?"
In North Carolina, one of four states to make academic performance a criterion for keeping a license, members of the first group of students to lose their licenses, estimated at 25,000 to 30,000, are just being notified that their grades last semester were below the legal limit.
That number is expected to double in the next two years. Under the law, students under 18 lose their license if they drop out, or if they fail to pass 70 percent of their classes.
The law is particularly popular in small towns, where the administrative burden is less and the loss of a car can be a devastating blow to teen-age freedom.
"What's not to love about it?" said Carol Weaver, principal of the small Cape Hatteras High School in the Atlantic Coast town of Buxton "When you're trying to change kids' behavior you've got to find something they want, and we use it every day in our disciplinary conferences. I ask them, 'Do you want to drive before you're an old man with a cane?' And they do want to drive."
But in larger districts around the state, school officials are less convinced. Edwin Dunlap, executive director of the North Carolina School Boards' Association, said many districts were concerned about such disciplinary tactics.
"It sounds wonderful," Mr. Dunlap said, "but the devil is in the details."
Robert T. Barnes Jr., principal of South View High School, is hardly a role model of political dissent in his Tigers school tie and positive-thinking cheerfulness. But Mr. Barnes gets angry when he talks about the secretaries diverted from scholarship searches to handle the paperwork involved in the law and the growing tension the law is causing between students and his office.
"It's placed us in a very adversarial position with kids, which we don't need," he said, estimating that about 50 of the school's 2,400 students will lose their licenses when letters go out this month. "It's real hard to talk to kids about how can we help them improve when we just told them, 'Give me your driver's license.' The two don't exactly go hand in hand."
Schools must check the grades and attendance of students seeking a license or a learning permit; check the license status of students failing one or more courses and send out warning letters to parents; notify the motor vehicles department on revocations, and hear the appeals of students who might be eligible to keep their license because of work.
The job requires half the time of the secretary to the guidance counselors, Mr. Barnes said, meaning she has less time to perform scholarship searches or send transcripts.
Inveighing against the bill, The Morning Star of Wilmington suggested in a recent editorial that perhaps legislators should forfeit their driver's licenses if they did not stop legislating after a reasonable period.
"There's a good chance," it said, "a few school principals would be willing to do the paperwork."

HEADLINE: Sears Settles Suit on Raising Of Its Credit Card Rates

BYLINE: By LESLIE KAUFMAN

 BODY:
Sears, Roebuck & Company announced yesterday that it would settle a class-action suit from plaintiffs who contended that the retailer had fraudulently raised the annual interest rates on their credit cards after it had promised not to. Sears agreed to pay $36 million in cash and issue store coupons worth $118 million to card holders.
The company's large credit card operations -- about 63 million United States households own a Sears card -- have a troubled history. Just last month, Sears pleaded guilty to Federal changes that it had illegally forced card holders who had filed for personal bankruptcy to pay their Sears debt anyway. Sears paid $475 million in fines and penalties to settle all suits related to those charges. 
 This credit card settlement was unrelated to the bankruptcy issue. From 1994 to 1996, Sears, based in Hoffman Estates, Ill., moved many of its credit card accounts to a credit card bank it had acquired in Arizona. When Sears transferred the accounts, it changed the annual finance charge to 21 percent for all accounts but said that balances accrued before the transfer would continue to be billed at their old rates.
In April 1997, Sears sent a notice that it was changing credit terms. Under the new terms, unpaid balances accrued before the consolidation would be subject to the same annual interest rate that Sears charged on all its other accounts. In some cases, that amounted to a rate increase. Defendants in the class action contended that the first letter amounted to a promise not to change rates and that Sears was breaching the agreement.
In settling the case, Sears admitted no wrongdoing. The action was taken "to avoid the litigation," said Jan Drummond, a company spokeswoman. She also said, "It is an acknowledgment that the communication we sent may have been misconstrued by customers."
Raising credit card rates without customer approval has become a national issue as the credit card business consolidates into fewer and larger hands and banks sell accounts to other banks, which are free to impose whatever interest rate the traffic will bear. But the Sears ruling is not likely have significant effect on the industry. "The issue here is specific to them and their literature," said Anita Boomstein, a partner at Hughes Hubbard & Reed L.L.P. who specializes in credit card law.
The lawsuit was brought on behalf of a nationwide class who were transferred to the Arizona bank and who had not fully paid off their balances when credit terms changed in 1997. All 11 million of these customers will get a coupon worth $7.50 -- even though not all of them had their interest rates changed. Three million customers who had their rates increased will receive a combination of cash and coupons totaling $23.80.
In addition, Sears agreed to spend $3 million for consumer-credit counseling. The settlement is subject to court approval.
Lawyers representing the plaintiffs will receive $15 million in cash.
In a separate development, Sears said yesterday that it would buy back up to $1.5 billion of its stock.
The buyback, which will take place over an unspecified time, represents about 9 percent of the outstanding Sears shares.
Shares of Sears rose $1.3125, to $45.

HEADLINE: Worse Drought Than in '98 Appears Possible in Texas

BYLINE: By RICK LYMAN

DATELINE: HOUSTON, March 10

 BODY:
Still reeling from a 1998 drought that devastated the state's farming and ranching communities, Texas officials are growing increasingly alarmed about what appears to be a potentially more serious drought looming this year.
"There's still time for it to turn around, but we are not looking good over much of the state," said Roland Smith, an agricultural economist at Texas A&M University. "People are really getting nervous." 
 The unusually warm winter and dearth of rainfall, particularly in the western two-thirds of the state, have severely damaged the winter wheat crop and stunted the growth of hay and natural grasses for cattle and other livestock. And during the next two months, a crucial time for the spring plantings of cotton, corn and other crops, drier than normal conditions are predicted for most of the major farming regions.
The Climate Prediction Center of the United States Department of Agriculture lists the trans-Pecos region in far western Texas and most of the state's Mexican border areas as abnormally dry, and the long-term drought severity index shows the trans-Pecos region and parts of the plains of west-central Texas in a state of moderate drought. If rainfall projections hold true, officials say, most of West and South Texas will experience a moderate-to-extreme drought as early as next month.
Gov. George W. Bush and Agriculture Commissioner Susan Combs are expected to unveil drought-related initiatives on Thursday, including declaring emergencies in 170 of the state's 254 counties where dry conditions have created a significant risk of fires.
"We are right today at the same point in drought index comparisons where we were when the Governor declared a drought emergency in June of 1998," Ms. Combs said. "We're three months ahead of last year, and that's what's giving people heartburn."
Despite flooding last fall in cities like Del Rio, Texas is flirting with a second consecutive year of paralyzing drought, the third year of drought in the last four.
"Certain areas of the state did have some very large amounts of rain in the fall," Mr. Smith said. "But that was rains that came so fast that a lot of the water ran off and we haven't had much rain in any of those places since."
And where rain fell over the winter, "none of it has penetrated into the subsoil, which is so necessary to make a reasonable cotton crop," said Carl G. Anderson, an agricultural economist at Texas A&M.
It has also been a particularly windy winter, adding to the problem.
"When the wind blows across the surface of the land, it actually sucks the moisture out," Ms. Combs said.
As a result, the ground is especially dry going into the spring rainy season.
"We keep hoping for three inches or so each time one of these fronts moves through," Mr. Anderson said, "but they just keep on blowing past, dropping just a half-inch here and there, and then heading out East. If it stays dry another six weeks or so, we will see some tremendous damage."
National Weather Service projections call for below-normal rainfall in Texas in the coming months. But even if the spring rains are normal, they may not be enough.
Still, officials say, copious rains might produce an adequate crop.
"There is time for a turn around," Mr. Anderson said.
A bill in the Texas Legislature would provide $25 million in drought relief, but it is intended for those suffering from last year's drought. In October, Congress passed $5.9 billion in disaster aid to farmers affected by droughts nationwide, and $2.4 billion remains to be distributed.
Ms. Combs said Texas officials would urge the Federal Government to speed those payments.
Last year's drought hit all of the state. For the moment, this year's drought threat is more localized.
The trans-Pecos areas have had just 19 percent of the normal average rainfall this winter, Ms. Combs said, and the Edwards Plateau of west-central Texas has had just 24 percent. But the rolling plains, north of the Edwards Plateau, have had 69 percent of normal rainfall, and the high plains of the Panhandle have had 93 percent.
Texas agricultural economists predicted last summer that the 1998 drought would mean a drop of $2.1 billion in the state's farm and ranch production. A report released in February by Texas A&M found that the drop was $2.4 billion, and that $8 billion more was lost in farm-dependent businesses.
Most agricultural economists are loath to speculate, but the Texas Agricultural Extension Service estimated that the 1998 drought persuaded as many as 10 percent of the state's farmers and ranchers to quit.
"People are giving up; they just can't make it," Ms. Combs said.
Calling Texas agriculture "very vulnerable," Mr. Smith said, "Another year like last year, without additional significant Federal help, and we're going to lose a lot of farmers."

HEADLINE: The Land of the Rising Outlook;
Public Spending May Have Reversed Japan's Downturn

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN

DATELINE: NAKANOJOMACHI, Japan

 BODY:
Bulldozers and tall cranes are popping up around the country like bamboo shoots after a spring rain, and this is raising hopes that Japan may finally be close to lifting itself out of recession.
No other country has ever poured as much money -- more than $830 billion the last 12 months alone -- into economic revival as has Japan, and much of that money is now sloshing around the country and creating a noticeable impact. Here in this village in central Japan, as in much of the country, construction crews are again busy, small companies are getting loans again and some people are feeling a tad more confident. 
 Japanese leaders have traditionally funneled money into brick-and-mortar projects to stimulate the economy, so the signs of life these days are interpreted by most experts as just a temporary comeback, not a self-sustaining recovery. There have been many false starts the last eight years, but the economy has always sunk back, this time into the deepest recession since the end of World War II.
To the pessimists Japan is like a vehicle being towed along the road by all that deficit spending; they doubt its engine will start without an overhaul.
Whatever the reasons for the movement, whatever the concerns for the future, though, the passengers throughout Japan seem relieved that at least the vehicle may be going forward again.
Any progress in Japan would also be a major relief for the rest of the world, since Japan is the second-largest economy after the United States and by far the largest in Asia. Optimists believe that Japan has finally bottomed out.
"I think the worst time has passed," Taichi Sakaiya, Minister of State at the Economic Planning Agency, said in a recent interview in Tokyo. "At least, there will be no further deterioration."
Even he, however, has moderated his view from late last year, when he said he saw a quickening in the economy. "We have to have growth this year," said Mr. Sakaiya, the author of 50 books, including some on the reshaping of Japanese society. "Otherwise, in the scheme of history Japan will be heading into a dark age if negative growth continues."
What is different this time is that the Government is battling the recession on many fronts. It is borrowing more heavily to finance its spending, and it is cleaning up the banking system to alleviate the credit shortage.
The next sign of Japan's progress comes on Friday, when the Government releases its report on the gross domestic product for the last quarter of 1998.
Some good news, at least, has been wending its way from the trenches. Company bankruptcies are plummeting, and orders for new homes are up. Some companies are refocusing their businesses, while others are selling off products that had been piling up in warehouses. Banks, which had slashed their lending under the burden of hundreds of billions of dollars in bad debts, are beginning to ease up on credit. Stocks, especially those of small companies, are rebounding.
The biggest stimulant has come from the Government, which has been pumping taxpayers' money into the construction of dams and bridges and setting up lending programs throughout the country. In a grand giveaway, the Government is also passing out nearly $6 billion in shopping coupons, and there are some signs that the coupons are encouraging consumers to spend more.
Fumio Takahashi, for one, is beaming heartily under his hard hat. Mr. Takahashi, a stocky man in a black suit, runs a small construction company in Nakanojomachi, and he now has several new Government contracts. Those contracts, in turn, have enabled him to borrow $400,000 from the bank.
One of his main projects is a 37.5-yard stretch of road that he is rebuilding and widening, even though the road already provides an adequately smooth car ride. There is also a project to build a 31-yard river embankment and another to build 81 yards of a new road to a dam. Other construction companies have been assigned other segments of the roads and the embankment.
"If there were no public works, this company would be gone -- bankrupt," Mr. Takahashi said as he stood on his dug-up road just a few steps away from a patch of road that a competitor is repaving. "This area is very rural, and there are very few factories, so there are very few jobs. If there is no construction work, we can't make our living."
All this is great news for Mr. Takahashi and his 20 employees. But there are doubts about whether Japan really needs all the wider roads and longer embankments. Mr. Takahashi relies on the Government for 85 percent of his business, and critics say the contracts are simply pork barrel projects created by the dominant Liberal Democratic Party to reward contributors in the construction industry.
Indeed, perhaps one reason Nakanojomachi is so flush is not just that it is needy but also that it is the hometown of Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi. Home constituencies of prime ministers have always received a disproportionate share of construction spending.
Mr. Takahashi acknowledges he is in an industry scoffed at frequently for its inefficiency, but he points out that at least the town has advanced from farming to construction. In any case, he knows his company will not last forever, not even to the next generation. His son has already said that he will not take over the business and hopes instead to find a salaried job at a big company.
A handful of private economists in Tokyo sound a bit more positive than they did a few months ago, but then again they could scarcely have become more negative. Many describe the huge Government stimulus package as having stabilized the economy rather than revived it.
"I think we're bouncing along the bottom a little instead of being in a free fall as we were last year," said Peter Morgan, an economist with HSBC Securities Japan Ltd. "Things are starting to stabilize a bit, but it's not a clear, soaring upward momentum. It's like a gigantic Band-Aid being put around the economy."
Few officials and politicians are as bold about their pronouncements on the economy as Mr. Sakaiya, Japan's top economic official. Ichizo Ohara, a Parliament member and occasional adviser to Prime Minister Obuchi, argues that Japan needs far more money flowing around if it is to strengthen the banks and revive the economy.
When asked if he thought the economy had bottomed out, Mr. Ohara, a former top Finance Ministry official, said it had. But then he reversed himself, reflecting the uncertainty among many experts as they read the mixed signs.
Prices are still falling, signaling deflation. Corporate profits for this fiscal year, which ends March 31, are expected to be dismal -- down nearly 25 percent on average from the previous year. Just last week, the index of leading economic indicators turned down, after two months of pointing upward.
Japanese politicians and economists agree that this year will be critical for the economy, mainly because the leadership is running out of options. The Government is spending so much on the stimulus that its budget deficit is running near 10 percent of total economic output and the national debt burden will soon exceed the size of the $4 trillion economy.
Many municipalities are already broke, and the Government's enormous fund-raising plans have sent shudders through the markets over the last several months and are threatening its previously pristine sovereign credit ratings.
The Bank of Japan, the nation's central bank, also has fewer tricks left in its bag of policy tools, and bank officials privately acknowledge that monetary policy will have limited influence in the near future. Short-term interest rates are already effectively zero.
That is partly why some prominent advisers, foreign economists and analysts are searching for solutions in a broad restructuring of Japan Inc., and a move away from the traditional antidote of paying for public works projects.
"We would like to create a society in which sound and creative competition prevails," said Hirotaro Higuchi, chairman of the Economic Strategy Council, a high-level advisory group set up by Prime Minister Obuchi. "I think it will come earlier than expected because the change in perceptions has already started."
That strategy may hold promise, but it can be very threatening to construction workers like Toshinobu Ichiba, a 37-year-old foreman in Nakanojomachi, which has only 18,600 people. Mr. Ichiba has been a cog in the construction of this picturesque mountainous town, which has essentially been built up with taxpayers' money. That money has paid for many of the roads and the river banks, as well as a long cement tunnel through the mountains and a suspension bridge that looks like a smaller version of the Golden Gate Bridge spanning the entrance to San Francisco Bay.
As the sun faded on his bridge project near a cliff on a recent frosty day, Mr. Ichiba and his co-workers joked about how they had nothing to do last spring except collect paychecks. Now, Mr. Ichiba and his men are building a bridge -- or rather, half of one. The Government has only financed half the bridge, so that is all they will build for now. But they profess not to worry.
"We think there will be work even if our company goes bankrupt," Mr. Ichiba said.
It is precisely this kind of outlook that has led some analysts to call for a radical turnaround in the way companies are managed. The problem, they say, is that people do not feel enough of a sense of crisis.
Still, however measured, some change is beginning to appear in the corporate world. A number of Japanese companies are selling less profitable business lines, as well as assets like buildings, resort clubs and land. While mass layoffs are still taboo, companies are edging unproductive workers off the payroll.
Some hope that Japan may be able to engineer a "jobless recovery," in which the economy can improve as companies melt the fat from their payrolls and reposition their businesses to compete more effectively. Still, while restructuring may improve Japan's economy in the long run, the initial result may be the opposite. The first consequence will be an increase in the number of the unemployed, now three million, and perhaps more of the sense of unease that usually leads workers here to save rather than spend.
"On the surface, people may be persuaded that the economy may have hit the bottom, but the speed is slow," said Teizo Taya, an economist at the Daiwa Institute of Research. "How can you expect a recovery of consumption when companies are busy restructuring themselves?"

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1406 words

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Despite Gains, Some Have Doubts

BYLINE: By MICHAEL M. WEINSTEIN

 BODY:
Have Japanese officials -- finally -- turned economic policy around?
After a decade-long stagnation caused in part by inadequate Government measures of the past, there are some promising signs. Monetary policy, for instance, at least seems to be heading in a more expansionary direction, putting it in line with a more stimulative fiscal policy as well. And over the last few weeks, key bank and finance officials have issued oblique promises to follow through on these moves, though few definitive commitments. 
 But even the American economists who follow the Japanese economy are not sure how much policy has actually changed. And there is the ominous possibility, expressed by one prominent expert, that even if the Japanese do everything they now hint at that the economy may still remain sick.
The Japanese economy had been the envy of the world throughout the 1970's and 1980's, growing faster than other industrialized economies with only a whiff of inflation. But the crash of its securities and real estate markets in the late 1980's undermined the solvency of many big banks, whose loans were tied to real estate. Bank loans to creditworthy borrowers shriveled. Last year the economy sank into recession, shrinking by about 3 percent.
Making matters worse, deflation has set in. Wholesale prices have been falling for years and now consumer prices appear to be falling. By creating the expectation that prices will continue to fall, deflation gives consumers and companies perverse incentives to postpone purchases. That can set off a downward spiral of falling spending, production, income and jobs.
The West has accused the Japanese of tolerating a decade of stagnation with barely a whimper. But Prof. Allan Meltzer of Carnegie Mellon University, who serves, along with a Stanford University professor, John Taylor, as an "honorary adviser" to the Bank of Japan, provides a plausible explanation. "The Japanese saw no reason to panic for most of the decade, confident that their vaunted economy would recover in a matter of months," he said.
But months turned into years. "It was not until Korea collapsed in the fall of 1997," Mr. Meltzer continued, "that the Japanese realized that the problem would not go away. So while the West thinks the Japanese have been dawdling for 10 years, the Japanese think they've been wrestling with the problem for only about 15 months."
And over those 15 months, he says, Tokyo has done "a surprising amount."
Adam Posen of the Institute for International Economics and author of a recent book on the Japanese economy, agrees. Japan is running a huge budget deficit -- 10 percent of national output and rising. (At its most recent peak in 1983, the United States Federal deficit reached 6.1 percent of annual output.) Though he would like to see even- larger tax cuts, it can no longer be said that Japanese fiscal stimulus is lacking.
The Japanese have also moved decisively in recent months to clean up their banks. The Government is paying off depositors at failed banks, nationalizing insolvent banks that the Government decides to keep open and pumping public money into shaky but solvent banks in exchange for stock. The three-pronged reform aims to give insolvent borrowers a fresh start and build up banks' capital reserves so that they can resume lending.
But few economists think that fiscal stimulus and bank reform alone are enough. The outside advisers have called on the Japanese central bank to pump enough new money into the economy to stop prices from falling.
Why has Japan delayed? Apart from an ideological fear of doing anything that hints of inflation, one big reason is that Tokyo might fear retaliation from the United States. Once the central bank prints more yen, they will leak into the foreign exchange market and drive down the value of the yen against the dollar. That will make Japan's goods cheaper to buy in America and America's goods more expensive to buy in Japan -- worsening an already huge trade imbalance and possibly igniting protectionist measures in Congress. Officials also worry that a falling yen will spread to other currencies in Asia, creating a contagion of currency depreciations in already fragile financial markets.
But maybe the Japanese, driven by the greater needs of their own economy at the moment, are overcoming their reluctance to offend Uncle Sam. Eisuke Sakakibara, vice minister of finance and Japan's most outspoken advocate of a strong yen, has reversed course and stated it would be O.K. if the Japanese currency fell in value. And the central bank has driven down short-term interest rates within a few tenths of a percentage point of zero. And, as predicted, the exchange rate has fallen, so that it now takes about 120 yen to buy a dollar.
But Dan Bernstein, director of research at Bridgewater Associates, cautions against overinterpreting these recent straws in the wind. The central bank's monetary policy may be more lenient, but the change is not dramatic, he says. And the Bank of Japan's public pronouncements continue to focus on interest rates, not flooding the economy with more money.
American economists point out that policy does not need to rely on driving interest rates lower -- they already are near zero anyway -- to pump up spending. The central bank can print new yen in order to buy lots of assets, from commercial paper to foreign exchange. Eventually, the extra yen should lift consumer spending. A recent statement by a board member of the Bank of Japan suggests that some of his colleagues are thinking about focusing on inflation rather than interest rates.
Paul Krugman, professor of economics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, has provocatively called on the central bank to go further, much further. He argues that consumers and companies will not start spending as long as they believe that prices will keep falling.
So Mr. Krugman has urged the Government to "credibly promise to be irresponsible." That may not be the most diplomatic way to encourage the ever-cautious Japanese. But it does drive home the point that nothing short of expanding the money supply to build in the expectation that prices will start rising for the indefinite future will prod the Japanese into deciding to spend now rather than later.
Let's take the tantalizing hints out of the finance ministry and central bank at face value. Fiscal and monetary policies will ease more and bank reform will proceed. Mission accomplished?
Not so fast, say Prof. Ronald McKinnon of Stanford and Kenichi Ohno of Saitama University in Japan. They reject their colleagues' optimism. Bank reform and monetary and fiscal easing, they agree, are not enough to solve Japan's woes.
They trace Japan's problem to decades of pressure by Washington to raise the value of the yen in a losing effort to eliminate the United States trade deficit with Japan. In fact, the yen rose, in dollar terms, by 4 percent a year from the 1970's to the 1990's.
Mr. McKinnon points out that investors who expect the yen to rise will accept lower interest payments on bonds denominated in yen compared with bonds denominated in dollars. It is no accident, then, that interest rates are generally about four percentage points lower in Japan than in the United States. But since interest rates have dropped in the United States, they have been pushed down to near zero in Japan. At that rate, banks cannot make any profit on loans and the economy cannot, therefore, recover.
The way out of this bind, Mr. McKinnon says, is to raise interest rates in Japan. That requires "wiping out the expectation that the yen will rise." He proposes that the United States and Japan agree to stabilize the value of the yen at about 130 to the dollar, the rate at which a dollar buys about as many hamburgers and computers in Japan as it does in the United States.
"The expectation that the yen would continue to rise was not created solely by Japan, and cannot be solved solely by Japan," he said.
If Mr. McKinnon is correct, then recovery in Japan depends on an accord that officials in neither country appear prepared to adopt. So a more plausible course, for now, is for the Japanese to print money galore -- and cross their fingers that the weaker yen that would be a consequence of such a policy will not touch off protectionism in the United States or worsen the financial situation across the rest of Asia.

HEADLINE: FIGHT OVER ORGANS SHIFTS TO STATES FROM WASHINGTON

BYLINE: By SHERYL GAY STOLBERG

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 10

 BODY:
The battle over the nation's scarcest medical resource, human organs, has moved from Washington to the states, where a number of legislatures have begun passing laws that would bar donated hearts, lungs, kidneys, livers and pancreases from being shipped beyond their borders to sick people elsewhere in the country.
So far, the laws have not had a large effect on the way organs are distributed. Rather, they are intended to thwart an effort by the Clinton Administration to force organ recovery networks and transplant centers around the nation to share their precious organs more liberally.
"They changed the rule, so I introduced legislation," Gov. Tommy G. Thompson of Wisconsin said in a telephone interview on Tuesday. "In this state, we go out and aggressively encourage people to be donors, with me doing public service announcements. If I'm going to do that, I want those organs to stay in the state and take care of the patients that need it in Wisconsin."
Four other states -- Louisiana, Oklahoma, South Carolina and Florida -- have adopted laws similar to Wisconsin's. In Arizona, lawmakers in both houses have approved similar bills, but they include differences that must be ironed out. Legislation has been introduced in Texas.
More than 61,000 Americans are now waiting for organ transplants, but only about 20,000 transplants are performed each year because the demand for organs far outweighs the supply. Under the current system for sharing organs, the nation is divided into 63 areas comprising 11 regions, and there are huge disparities in waiting times from area to area and region to region. For instance, for patients with blood type O, who represent 47 percent of the nation's liver transplant candidates, the median waiting time in New York City is 511 days while the median time in northern New Jersey is only 56 days.
Last spring, Donna E. Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, announced her intention to even out those waiting times by giving organs to the most sick patients first, regardless of where they lived. Dr. Shalala said the current system "put geography ahead of medical need." But the plan, issued in the form of a Federal regulation, engendered such a bitter fight among transplant doctors, hospitals and patients that Congress delayed its effective date until Oct. 1.
The debate will come to the fore in Washington on Thursday when the Institute of Medicine, an arm of the National Academy of Sciences, starts its own examination of the organ allocation system. The review is being conducted at the request of Congress; the institute has appointed a panel of 16 experts, including surgeons, ethicists, epidemiologists and a health care economist to carry out the study.
"We need an objective reviewer," said Louise Jacobbi, executive director of the Louisiana Organ Procurement Agency in Metairie, La. In 1997, Ms. Jacobbi, aware that the Federal Government was about to change its rules, was instrumental in persuading her state to become the first to enact a law putting its own residents first. That law has become a model for the other states.
"Fundamentally, we have been rationing organs since the beginning of transplantation," she said. "We have always had fewer organs than we have had patients. If we are going to change the way we practice medicine, it needs to be based on good medical data."
The institute, which hopes to finish its study by September, will present its findings to Congress, which may decide to step in and overhaul the allocation system on its own. But if Congress does not act, the entire issue could wind up in court, with Wisconsin and the other states suing the Federal Government in a state's rights dispute over which provision -- the Clinton Administration's rule or state laws -- takes precedence.
Dr. Claude Earl Fox, administrator of the Health Resources and Services Administration, which oversees the organ allocation system, said in an interview that the new regulation superseded state law. But in a suit filed in Louisiana last spring, the Louisiana Attorney General contended the opposite, saying that only an act of Congress, and not a bureaucratic regulation, could override a state law.
That suit is being held in abeyance while the Federal rule is on hold. But should the Administration's plan go into effect, Governor Thompson said Wisconsin would probably also sue.
"This rule is unconstitutional," Mr. Thompson said. "It pre-empts state's rights."
The current organ donation system is 15 years old; it flows out of a 1984 law called the Organ Procurement and Transplantation Act, which gives the Department of Health and Human Services authority to regulate the national organ distribution system. The law prohibited the buying and selling of organs and declared them a national resource.
As it stands, the system works this way: A private, nonprofit organization, the United Network for Organ Sharing, contracts with the health and human services agency to distribute donated organs. The network has divided the country into 11 regions. Within those regions, there are 63 local organ procurement organizations, whose job it is to obtain and distribute organs.
Under the current rules, organs are offered first within the local area, then regionwide, then nationally. But the system is incredibly Balkanized; Dallas and Fort Worth, for instance, share an airport and are only 30 miles apart, yet they belong to different organ procurement organizations and do not share organs. If there are extra livers or kidneys in Fort Worth, they are offered to patients in Houston, four hours away.
"It's a tragedy," said Dr. Goran B. Klintmalm, chief of transplant surgery at the Baylor University Medical Center in Dallas.
This is his solution: Baylor is about to set up a satellite transplant center in Fort Worth, so that its Dallas patients will be eligible for organs that otherwise would have gone to Houston.
"We don't want to duplicate services," Dr. Klintmalm said, "but it's the only way we can make organs stay in the metroplex."
The Clinton Administration's rule ordered the organ-sharing network to come up with a new system that would distribute organs more broadly. The Administration said that if network officials did not change the system on their own, the Department of Health of Human Services would change it for them. But the network, which is composed mostly of representatives from the smaller transplant centers, said its members preferred the current system.
In the wake of Dr. Shalala's announcement of the new rule, doctors at some of the centers, along with officials of the local organ procurement organizations, began pressing their state legislators to pass laws that would keep organs within state boundaries. Most of the laws include provisions stating that states can share organs, so long as they have reciprocal arrangements with other states. Even so, they have been criticized as provincial.
"Oklahoma has been castigated," complained Robert Turner, executive director of the Oklahoma Organ Sharing Network. "We have been called narrow-minded, self-centered, not caring for others. Actually, our law is pretty moderate. It says that we can't bypass local patients unless we get a payback for the organ."
In Ohio, the Legislature stopped short of passing a law, but adopted a resolution that urged Dr. Shalala to give greater weight to the views of transplant centers. A transplant surgeon at one center, Dr. Douglas Hanto of the University of Cincinnati Medical Center, said of the Federal plan: "If this rule goes through, you will see more and more states passing laws. And it will be a huge controversy. I don't think that Donna Shalala or Bill Clinton really understands the degree of opposition to this rule."
Federal officials, however, say the state laws are misguided.
"We know that, on average, about a third of all organ recipients go outside their state of residence to get a transplant," Dr. Fox said. "We have a lot of sharing that is going on across state lines. States, in my opinion, could be shooting themselves in the foot by passing language that restricts that."
Underlying the dispute is an economic turf war between transplant centers, which are competing for their share of the transplant business, in which an operation can cost $250,000 or more. On one side are large hospitals, which tend to have long waiting lists of patients who tend to be sicker; they would presumably benefit from the new rule by receiving additional organs now being used elsewhere. On the other side are small transplant centers, which fear Dr. Shalala's plan could put them out of business by stripping them of their supply of organs.
"It's a mess," said Dr. John J. Fung, who directs the transplant program at the University of Pittsburgh, one of the largest in the nation, and is a staunch advocate of increased sharing. "Everybody is hunkering down and protecting their own turf. It's only going to get nastier, and the sooner we get it resolved the sooner the healing process will begin. All we are doing now is making the wounds bigger and bigger."

HEADLINE: Luster of New York's Trash Dims in Virginia

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN

DATELINE: SUSSEX, Va., March 4

 BODY:
In this bucolic slice of southeastern Virginia, sturdy farmhouses command vast fields of peanuts, soybeans and cotton. Slender loblolly pines poke through the flat, wet terrain, like celery stalks wedged into a marshy bog. It seems like a Robert Penn Warren poem sprung to life.
But if this county is rich in beauty, it is also poor in opportunities. For years, the courthouse had no indoor plumbing, and so little space that defendants occasionally had to wait outside before their arraignments. No new schools have been built in 30 years, and teachers had to make do with antiquated equipment. 
 That was before Sussex County discovered garbage.
Five years ago, the county embarked on a risky, controversial path that many people believed would improve their struggling economy, even though it would jeopardize their beloved environs: a private, technologically advanced landfill that would import thousands of tons of garbage a day, much of it from New York City.
A result, so far, is that the landfill, while still far from beloved, now generates one-third of all annual local revenues -- more than $12.3 million so far in taxes and fees. It has enabled the county to hold taxes steady, build a new courthouse and wastewater plant, and break ground on a new $15 million high school.
Now, though, Sussex County has found itself in the middle of a multistate battle over trash that has once again prompted many people here to try to reconcile their economic needs and environmental concerns, pragmatism and principles.
Trash has become a hot topic in an election year, with politicians deploring Virginia's status as the second-biggest importer of out-of-state trash, after Pennsylvania. Egged on by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's insouciant suggestion that Virginia should accept New York's trash in return for the city's cultural and financial contributions, the Virginia General Assembly approved legislation last month limiting garbage imports. And Senator Charles S. Robb, a Democrat, and Senator John W. Warner, a Republican, have reached across party lines to co-sponsor a bill that would also retrict the flow of garbage.
Most Virginians have applauded such antitrash, anti-New York reflexes. But here in Sussex, one of several places in Virginia, Pennsylvania and Ohio that import garbage, the reaction has been more ambivalent.
"We'd rather not have it, but we're caught between a rock and a hard place, because the county is in bad shape and we need the money," said Bill Jenkins, 40, a peanut farmer who was eating breakfast at the Virginia Diner in Wakefield. He initially opposed the landfill; now he tolerates it.
"What else can we do?" Mr. Jenkins continued, as the diner's owners, Bill and Mary Ann Galloway, nodded. "If we don't have this dump, the next thing they're going to do is raise taxes on the land. I don't see another solution."
For years, several of Virginia's rural landfills, including the Atlantic Waste Disposal landfill in Sussex, faced no limits on importing garbage.
But under State Senate proposals, which have the support of Gov. James S. Gilmore 3d, Virginia would be able to limit a landfill's intake, ban garbage barges on major rivers and regulate waste more rigorously. The Robb-Warner bill, meanwhile, would restrict the interstate commerce of garbage as well, and allow states to collect fees on imported trash.
Sussex officials worry that any reduction in trash revenues may hamper an economy already sapped by declines in agriculture and manufacturing, said Mary E. Jones, the county administrator.
Situated 45 miles southeast of Richmond, this county of 10,000 has long struggled to get by. One-fifth of the county's residents live in poverty, almost double the state average. The school system perennially ranks near the bottom. The teen-age pregnancy rate is triple the state average.
"The work force is not that great, and you have a small working pool to grow from," said Thomas Rose, 57, a lawyer who was having lunch at the Thornton General Store in the village of Sussex. "We're not going to get anything high-tech."
To compensate, Sussex has absorbed industries that more prosperous areas would avoid: two state prisons, hog farms and, in 1994, the landfill in the county's northwest corner.
The question of whether to build the landfill sharply divided the community; the final vote by the Board of Supervisors was 4 to 3.
Some are still smarting from the experience.
"Sussex counts on the money, but sometimes you've got to think above money," said Rhonda Powell, postmistress of the tiny post office in the village of Yale. "People are tired of getting all these things to get money, instead of getting something more acceptable. You don't want to be thought as, 'All we can get is the dregs.' "
Others, meanwhile, have grumbled that the county has received less money than originally promised. But Ms. Jones said that without the landfill, the county might have had to double or triple the tax rate.
Now owned by Waste Management Inc., the landfill covers 1,315 acres, or roughly the combined size of Central and Prospect Parks in New York. Up to 50 percent of its 4,200 daily tons of trash comes from New York City; the rest is from Maryland, northern Virginia and Washington. About three-quarters of the trash comes by truck, the rest by rail, said Jerry Johnson, the site's general manager.
Inside the dump, the New York connection is easy to spot: an I Love New York bag here, a mustard-colored bag from a Chinatown noodle shop there, New York newspapers all over the place.
Outside, it is easy to find Sussex residents who feel queasy about the landfill's odors, the trucks lumbering down Route 460 or just the idea of the highest hill in Sussex (450 feet) rising in their backyard.
It was only a couple of weeks ago that a Sussex-bound truck carrying New York City garbage overturned on Interstate 295.
"It's stinking up the place," said Floyd Edward Hardy 3d, a Bronx native who moved to the town of Waverly almost a decade ago and now works at a Hardee's restaurant. "I think that every state should take care of their own trash."
To gain perspective, New Yorkers should put themselves in Sussex's shoes, said Tom Raines, the county registrar and a farmer whose family can trace its Virginia roots to the 1600's.
"Tell New Yorkers that we like this landfill as much as they would if it sat in the middle of Central Park," said Mr. Raines, who was among those eating lunch at the Thornton General Store.
It is understandable why some Sussex residents are prickly about New York. A couple of years ago, The New York Post annoyed many people when it described the county as a "dirt-poor, dirt-filled" place with a "warren of tar-paper shacks" and potbellied residents who couldn't get enough of New York's refuse.
Most Sussex people work hard and just scrape by, occupying small, well-groomed bungalows or mobile homes. They take pride in their surroundings. They pray at the county's 60-odd churches, most of them Baptist. They also make this the kind of friendly, leisurely place where a cup of coffee with a stranger turns into a few cups, then some biscuits, then maybe a full meal.
But whenever the conversation veers from hometown pride to local affairs to environmental fears, the same nagging conundrum remains: Has the landfill been worth it?
During interviews with more than three dozen people during a few days, the answer was a resounding "Not sure." On the streets of Waverly, Thelma W. Wyatt, a former English teacher who now teaches at one of the state prisons, initially voiced solid opposition, then paused to consider the other factors.
"I can't stand the smell," said Mrs. Wyatt, 54, who supports the proposed curbs on garbage intake. "We're supposed to have clean fresh air in the rural area here. But I think people have accepted it, because they definitely needed a school, and they felt that they didn't have much of a choice but to go with this."
In the peanut fields of Stony Creek, Marvin Wachsman, a farmer who harvests timber, peanuts and soybeans, also straddled the issue.
"I've got enough sense to know that we've got no other choice, but we're a little afraid about what's going to happen to the environment in the future," said Mr. Wachsman, 55, who was nuzzling twin newborn calves under threatening skies. "There are no easy answers."

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; Sports Desk
