HEADLINE: TARNISHED GOLD: A special report.;
From an Innocent Bid to Olympic Scandal

BYLINE: By Kirk Johnson; This article is based on reporting by Jo Thomas, Kirk Johnson and Jere Longman, and was written by Mr. Johnson.

DATELINE: SALT LAKE CITY

 BODY:
David R. Johnson and Thomas K. Welch were lionized in 1995 when they delivered the right to stage the 2002 Winter Olympic Games to a city that had tried and failed for 30 years. But after that it was a long, hard fall.
An independent ethics panel investigating how the Salt Lake City bid committee used cash payments and college scholarships to influence Olympic officials has identified Mr. Johnson and Mr. Welch -- two of the committee's senior officers -- as the central culprits. Federal prosecutors are exploring criminal charges against them. Their reputations are in jeopardy. And yet they have remained surprisingly steadfast in their positions: they don't regret a thing. 
 Indeed, Mr. Johnson, the bid committee's former vice president, said that if he had one misgiving about how Salt Lake City won the Olympics it was that its officials were not more open about their tactics. "They should have said, 'Of course we have scholarships,' " he said. "It was a way of winning the bid, to increase our ways to communicate."
And Mr. Welch, the former head of the Salt Lake City effort, said his lack of regret in looking back matches exactly the lack of guilt he felt when he was waging the campaign in the early 1990's.
"The whole atmosphere was, hey, you're paying homage to these people," Mr. Welch said of the lavishments he and others bestowed on members of the International Olympic Committee who decide where to hold the Games. "We don't like that, but that's the game. That's the rush, if you want to join the fraternity."
Salt Lake City's long effort to join the Olympic fraternity -- sometimes brazen, sometimes comic, and all the while relying on inside information provided by other Olympic cities -- comes to detailed life in hundreds of pages of internal bid committee documents obtained by The New York Times and in interviews with many committee staff workers and volunteers. The documents, as well as the first extensive interviews with Mr. Welch and Mr. Johnson, also strongly suggest that many Salt Lake City bid committee officials beyond the two former committee officers -- and within the Olympic family in general -- had fully accepted the coarse financial facts of what had to be done to become an Olympic city.
Other issues regarding what happened here and who knew about it are still unfolding. There are conflicting accounts, witnesses who have yet to be questioned and assertions of innocence or culpability that will not be resolved until various Federal and state investigators complete their work -- if then.
Mr. Johnson said he told Anita DeFrantz, the senior I.O.C. member from the United States, "everything" about scholarships and cash payments; she said that is not true.
An internal work paper from the accounting firm of Ernst & Young asserts that senior bid committee officials, including some leaders of major Utah corporations, were fully briefed in 1995 about questionable payments; they deny that.
Staff workers and volunteers who toiled in the bid committee's dingy downtown offices say that everyone knew which I.O.C. children were on scholarship, who was coming in for their checks and when, and who among the regular I.O.C. visitors was the greediest or most gracious; most of their bosses, excepting Mr. Welch and Mr. Johnson, say they didn't know a thing.
Last May, about six months before the scandal broke, minutes and handwritten notes taken during bid committee meetings in 1994 and 1995, including detailed discussions about the status of the campaign in its final climactic months, were destroyed by the committee's law firm. Officials with the firm have no explanation, and characterize the destruction as strange.
And it all, in the end, may have been unnecessary. Salt Lake City, which had pursued the Olympics for 30 years as part of a broad economic development plan to build a winter tourism industry, had actually pulled together a legitimate proposal that Olympic officials across the globe concede was, on its merits, unmatched.
George Mitchell, the former United States senator from Maine who led one of the inquiries into the city's effort, March 1 summed up what he called the tragedy of the episode: Salt Lake City officials, he said, "did not need to stoop to the level of this improper and inappropriate conduct."
 
New Approach
From Unsophisticated To Well Educated
In 1966, when Salt Lake City was making its first run at the Winter Games, for 1972, the bid committee commissioned a translation of its promotional materials into French, including a geographical description: Utah, the text said, is located in the "Great Basin of the West." The translator hired by the committee took the language a bit too literally, however, and used the phrase "Grand Basin," which in French meant that Utah was in the "Toilet of the West." The mistake was caught just in time when a professor at the University of Utah was asked to look over the proofs.
"It shows you how unsophisticated we were," said Walker Wallace, a retired businessman and former ski racer who was on the committee.
Mr. Wallace said the city's long shot chances at landing the Games were further made clear at a stuffy cocktail reception later in 1966, in Rome, when a salesman from Salt Lake City suddenly decided to approach one of the haughtier Olympic committee members in the room, a member of European royalty. The salesman walked up, put his arm around the I.O.C. official and started talking up the virtues of Wasatch Mountain powder snow.
Mr. Wallace still recalls the rebuke that ended their conversation, "Remove your arm from my shoulder."
Salt Lake City's 1966 effort was more than unpolished, it was cheap. The organizers scraped together $24,000 by selling Olympic pins for $1 each, raised $5,000 more in donations, and created an organization called Olympics for Utah Incorporated, which was designed to appeal to the French-tinged I.O.C. with its acronym, O.U.I. The committee even had $10,305 left over at the end, according to the two-page audit that Mr. Wallace saved.
Over the next three decades, Salt Lake City became much more serious about its Olympic ambitions. Once an isolated outpost in the scenic West, the city was beginning to feel the need to make a name for itself, local historians and civic experts say, and to shed a bit of its insular history as the central city in the Mormon religion.
But there was also a powerful momentum from within the state driving the Olympic efforts: economic development. The organizers of the first bid in 1966 did more than simply start the Olympic machine, economists and public policy experts say. They forged a kind of symbiotic relationship that fed on itself. Going after the Olympics created publicity for Utah tourism, and the growth of tourism over the years in turn reinforced the rationale for going after the Olympics and further enhanced the city's chances.
The former Salt Lake City mayor, Palmer DePaulis, said that people who question the value of the Olympics now have forgotten how tough things were -- the mining industry was sinking, agriculture and ranching were struggling, too. "The Olympics was looked at as something that would jump-start the economy and help bring jobs and investment," Mr. DePaulis said.
Throughout the three decades of trying, though, Salt Lake City never quite shook the sense that it had some inadequacy or provincialism to overcome, residents and former bid committee officials say. Mr. Welch recalled that as late as 1989, for example, Salt Lake City bid officials showed up empty-handed at an I.O.C. meeting in Puerto Rico.
"When we arrived there, the Greeks were entertaining on their yacht, with gorgeous hostesses," he said. "Atlanta had rented a mansion, shipped in furniture from Atlanta and called it the Atlanta House. Toronto had set up a whole wing out by the pool and were serving breakfasts, lunches and dinners to the I.O.C.
"Everyone was giving wonderful gifts -- I think there were crystal vases and jewelry," Mr. Welch said. "Bid cities each had limousines. We showed up with nothing -- on a bus. We called home, and they went and got some letter openers for us and brought them to us so we'd have something."
That insecurity was deepened by uncertainty over just how the competitions were being conducted.
In 1991, with a solid bid package in place for the 1998 Games, Salt Lake officials received a letter from Patrick Hickey, the president of Ireland's Olympic committee, who let drop that some I.O.C. members had contracted to sell their votes for $100,000 to the city of Nagano, Japan.
And on the eve of the vote for the 1998 Games, Mr. Welch said, he was approached by the son of an I.O.C. member who said he could help secure a handful of votes for Utah for $35,000. Mr. Welch and others refused, in part because they didn't have the money. Nagano won by four votes.
Later, in 1993, despite being the leading candidate for the 2002 Games, Salt Lake City bid committee officials were reminded that nothing was a certainty. According to the minutes of a bid committee meeting, for example, Ms. DeFrantz, the senior I.O.C. representative in the United States, cautioned against complacency.
So the Salt Lake City rules evolved: Do no harm, take no chances and say yes to just about anything.
"Everything we had was about getting the bid," Mr. Johnson said. "All our money was to get votes."
 
Strategy
'We Had to Get The African Vote'
Given how aggressively, and even excessively, Salt Lake City came to pursue the 2002 Games, it is almost quaint to examine the committee's earlier records. In March 1991, for example, during the campaign for the 1998 Winter Games, Prince Albert of Monaco, a bobsled racer and I.O.C member, arrived in Utah in jeans and a flannel shirt and with a disdain for protocol and limousines, former staffers said. But committee records show that officials did manage to buy him something. Mr. Johnson's reimbursement slip for the visit records a single stop, at a 7-Eleven store, for "juice for Prince Albert." Cost: $2.73.
Others, it turned out in the years to come, demanded more. They were not denied.
Indeed, the bid committee, working from 1991 to 1995 to secure the Games, gave and gave -- at least $1.2 million to I.O.C. members and their families and much beyond that in attention and personal favors.
Dame Mary Alison Glen-Haig, a committee member from England, got to play cards late into the night at the house of Salt Lake City's Mayor, Deedee Corradini. The children of I.O.C. members from Mali and Cameroon received more than $100,000 each in scholarships and payments.
It could all be quite matter of fact.
According to staffers at the committee, Sibo Sibandze, the son of the I.O.C. member from Swaziland, would with regularity turn up at the second-floor offices at the corner of 200 East and 200 South, open the door and ask, "Where's my check?" And the checks would be cut: $250 one week, $590 the next.
"You knew these guys, they came in weekly," said Jason Christensen, a volunteer staffer. "You saw them pick up their checks. You took them places. You didn't have to be a brain surgeon to know what was going on. It was always whispered, 'Whose son is he? How much of a scholarship is he getting? How does that work? People freaked out the first time they heard about it. Then it became second nature."
It could occasionally feel reckless, too.
By the spring of 1995, according to a list of bid committee payments, money was often being spent with no support documentation, including a $30,000 check for cash at First Security bank for unknown purposes. Gifts to beneficiaries designated as "various I.O.C. members" reached more than $150,000.
From February 1993 to February 1996, the bid committee paid installments of $500 that totaled $14,500 to a Raouf Scally, who was thought to be a relative of an I.O.C. member. Local Olympic officials still have no certain idea who Scally is or what North African country he came from.
But for the overwhelming part, the operation run out of the charmless downtown offices -- mismatched furniture, empty pizza boxes -- was targeted and relentless.
The bid's strategy, Mr. Johnson said, dictated that African committee members be pursued, not necessarily because those members had their hands out, but because they were the swing votes. The city's analysis showed that no Olympic contestant had ever won without African members' support.
"We had to get the African vote," said Johnson, who resigned earlier this year. "We had to get them early, get it done, maintain contact and maintain momentum."
But there was more than just a plan. Bid committee officials also had detailed personal information on their I.O.C. targets, from the dossiers prepared by previous bid cities such as Sydney, Australia.
Of David Sibandze, the I.O.C. member from Swaziland who was forced to resign in February, one dossier said: "Always made reference that he has a big mortgage to pay during visits to 1996 candidate cities. Bad reputation. Insincere." Sibandze and his son could not be reached for comment despite repeated efforts.
Other files offered more innocent insights: of Anton Geesink of the Netherlands, one dossier said, "Loves to get the opportunity for group sing-alongs."
Most, though, cut to the chase. "Doesn't speak much English," a scouting report said of Sergio Santander Fantani of Chile, another committee member who has since been expelled. "But managed to understand him to say, 'Salt Lake must win.' "
And bid committee officials say they were just as straightforward about their campaign when talking to people in the Olympic family. Mr. Johnson, for instance, insists he kept Ms. DeFrantz, the senior American I.O.C. member, updated. He said she would frequently ask him which way the members were leaning and what it had taken to gain their allegiance.
"From 1992 to 1995, every time we had an I.O.C. member visit Salt Lake, she either flew to Salt Lake or during their visit would talk to them on the telephone," Mr. Johnson said of Ms. DeFrantz. "She would call me and ask, 'Was he good or was he bad?' She wanted to know if someone had asked us to do something that would put us in a difficult position."
If an I.O.C. member had asked or demanded favors, Mr. Johnson said that Ms. DeFrantz's response was, " 'That's not good,' or something like that. She didn't say, 'Don't do it.' "
Mr. Johnson's charge is explosive. If Ms. DeFrantz knew of the misconduct in Salt Lake City and did nothing to report or correct it, her reputation as one of the most powerful and upright figures in international sport could be damaged.
In a series of interviews, Ms. DeFrantz emphatically refuted Mr. Johnson's claims.
"I was never asked if it was O.K., or if they should do anything, or if it was a way to win the Games," she said. "Those discussions never happened."
 
Relationships
Ties That Bind And Tear Apart
It is easy to imagine a universe where a scrappy, effusive attorney from Ogden, Utah, named Tom Welch would live a whole life and never meet a mercurial politician from Congo Republic named Jean-Claude Ganga. But given the logic and machinery of the Olympic site selection process that was in place in the 1990's, it is, in a sense, hard to imagine anything else.
For the Salt Lake City bid committee, Mr. Welch was the pre-eminent giver of gifts and cash, Mr. Ganga the pre-eminent taker. Of the $15 million that the bid committee spent in winning the 2002 Winter Games, Mr. Ganga got more than anyone -- at least $250,000, according to the board of ethics report last month.
But Mr. Welch and Mr. Ganga -- and the relationship that bound them -- were also far more complex than the dry text of ledger sheets and investigative reports have suggested. Indeed, they were much alike: both men of large gestures and appetites, both capable, it seems, of the grand impulse one moment and an improper one the next.
Mr. Ganga, 64, made his reputation in Africa as a fighter against the apartheid system. He once stood on a makeshift athletic field in Congo Republic, watching with tears streaming down his face as a group of barefoot boys tried to play soccer with a homemade ball of weeds and duct tape, according to Mr. Welch, who was there.
Within the bid committee, however, Mr. Ganga was known as "the human vacuum cleaner" for his ability to take in whatever crossed his path. When he came to town, staffers, with an effort at comic cynicism, called it "Ganga time." He took thousands of dollars of free medical care, from hepatitis treatment for himself to a knee replacement for his mother-in-law. He was put up in an apartment here, and after the family departed, the Gangas' appliances were handed out. One staff member got a toaster, another received a blender.
Mr. Welch, 54, a former corporate lawyer who resigned from the organizing committee in 1997, after a charge of spousal abuse, was singled out by the Salt Lake City ethics panel for unethical and improper behavior that ranged from handing out cash for I.O.C. votes to setting up an investment fund in which he and Mr. Ganga were to share the benefit. Mr. Welch admits he was free with other people's money. He once spent $30,000 on the street in a single night on Utah Jazz playoff tickets for 30 guests, charging the committee for marketing.
But like Mr. Ganga, he had another side, too. He spent 10 obsessive years trying to bring the Games to Salt Lake City, five of them without taking any pay. And the same ethics report that condemned his actions also conceded that he never tried to enrich himself through the Olympic process; the investment fund with Mr. Ganga existed in name only. In the strange theater of the Olympics, each man had a role. In the letters and faxes that Mr. Welch and Mr. Ganga exchanged, they circled one another, sometimes like adversaries or hagglers, sometimes like friends.
In one 1994 letter to Mr. Welch from his home in Brazzaville, for example, Mr. Ganga wrote of the war that was tearing his country apart. The city was blockaded. Food and medicines were in short supply and Mr. Ganga asked that Mr. Welch try to pressure the United States Government into a formal condemnation of the killings. Money was not mentioned.
Another exchange of letters, in April 1992, was all about money. Mr. Ganga complained that he couldn't afford to fly to Montreal to attend a wedding, and then, after a $4,700 check was sent, wrote back with effusive thanks. "As the saying goes, a friend in need is a friend indeed," Mr. Ganga wrote.
But even if the relationships that formed were simply a cover for the buying and selling of the Olympic Games, real lives were touched, a very human fact that has been buried under the avalanche of embarrassment and anger.
In the mid-1990's, for example, Bob Hunter, the director of community affairs for the bid committee, took in the son of an I.O.C. member from Libya, Suhel Attarabulsi, who had come to the United States to attend college at the bid committee's expense. Mr. Hunter said he made speeches all over the state about Suhel and his life.
"Our family became acquainted with him and fell in love with him," Mr. Hunter said. "He became like our adopted son. He spent Christmas and summer vacations -- we've got his baby picture sitting on the piano in our living room. That's the story I've told all across the state of Utah. That's why it shocks me for people to say we didn't know."
Both Mr. Welch and Mr. Ganga have defended themselves. Mr. Ganga said through a spokesman, Ibrahim Soumare, that he received cash because the banking system in Congo Republic was unreliable, and that the money was sent to various Olympic committees in Africa. Mr. Welch says he was trying to win the bid in the way he had been told it had to be done, but that he was also trying to make a contribution to poorer countries.
Through the filter of money and hindsight, however, it's hard to tell what's real. Mr. Welch, who described Mr. Ganga as a man with "a heart as big as all outdoors," also admitted he was thrilled when the I.O.C. courtship was over.
"You can't imagine the exhilaration I felt when the last member from the last visit was put on the plane," he said. "I subjected myself to more people's pompous outlooks."
 
Unraveling
As Auditors Work, Questions Arise
 The knowledge of what the bid committee was doing in chasing its Olympic bid flowed like a river with no predetermined course -- full of switchbacks and dry washes and dead ends. Information would bubble up from the ground, only to sink again without a trace.
In late July 1995, for example, one month after Salt Lake City had won the Games, auditors from Ernst & Young, who were working on their annual report to close the bid committee's books, came across some puzzling and poorly documented accounting entries. They consequently drew up a list of those expenditures, which totaled $271,000.
The Ernst & Young auditors had pinpointed the very names and amounts that have since become the heart of the Olympic scandal: The so-called National Olympic Committee program. There on their work sheet were cash recipients, including Mr. Ganga and all the I.O.C. scholarship students.
The work papers that the auditors produced as they explored the disbursements also included their handwritten notes, which apparently reflected the information that they were gathering as they tried to determine what the payments had been about. Those notes, which have been given to Federal investigators in the case, indicate that members of both the bid committee's audit committee as well as at least one of its three-member executive committee leaders approved the payments.
"We discussed the N.O.C. program with management, the Audit Committee, and certain members of the Executive Committee," one of the auditors wrote.
"Each individual disbursement is reviewed and approved by the management of the Committee," the auditor concluded.
The people mentioned in the auditors' papers as having been told about the scholarship program in 1995 say they received no such warnings. G. Frank Joklik, the former chairman of the board of trustees, has maintained that he was not aware of wrongdoing; James Beardall, the chairman of the bid committee's audit committee, said he was never notified of any questionable expenditures. "I have no recollection whatsoever of any details of this kind being brought to my attention," Mr. Joklik said of the auditor's report.
Mr. Johnson said that that cannot be.
"Even though it's being denied, we had a powerful committee," he said of his superiors. "They have run major corporations. They are good managers. They required information and justifications about everything we did."
What the work papers clearly reveal, however, is that auditors were satisfied at the time that those people knew, and thus, at least from an accounting standpoint, no one was cutting unauthorized checks.
But still the story stayed locked within bid committee walls.
Ken Bullock, a member of the board of trustees, was the next one to try to break it free. On several occasions beginning in 1995, he said he told the Board of Trustees and Governor Michael O. Leavitt of his concerns. Mr. Bullock said he also complained to the Governor's top aide, Vicki Varela, in 1998 about the scholarships.
"She thought I was a little out there, chasing ghosts," he said.
Sydney Fonnesbeck, a former city council member who worked with Mr. Bullock, recalled his distress at not being listened to, and how he often returned from meetings with the board emotionally "bruised and bloodied."
The Governor, who often participated in public functions with the very people receiving the improper scholarships and other inducements, has said no one came to him with suspicions, and that he would have done something immediately if he had known.
And so there the story appeared to stall again, until June 3, 1997, when a Salt Lake City Council member, Deeda Seed, asked a local television reporter to meet for breakfast at Lamb's, a downtown landmark restaurant. There she told the reporter, Rod Decker of KUTV-Channel 2, that she had been told -- by Mr. Bullock among others -- that children and grandchildren of I.O.C. members were getting college educations paid for by the bid committee.
Mr. Decker, a newsman in Salt Lake City for 27 years, said he would follow up. He said he went to the committee's spokesman, Mike Korologos, and asked if the story was true. Mr. Korologos said he would check it. When he called back, Mr. Decker said Mr. Korologos told him that Mr. Johnson had said there were no scholarships.
He said he was told that some people, including some related to I.O.C. members, had taken a tour of the University of Utah -- that was all. Mr. Decker decided there was no story.
Mr. Johnson has said that he has no memory of the conversation with Mr. Korologos, and Mr. Korologos has declined repeated requests for an interview or comment. But Mr. Decker's call was a knock at the door.
The world was beginning to ask questions and, in retrospect, Mr. Korologos's answer was a tacit acknowledgment that someone within the committee's leadership felt there was something to hide.
Eleven months later, something strange happened in the offices of Ray Quinney & Nebeker, a prominent law firm in Salt Lake City that was the bid committee's legal counsel. Pages of documents -- the minutes of the bid committee's senior management meetings and the handwritten notes of the lawyer who was the committee's secretary for 1994 and 1995 -- were shredded or otherwise destroyed.
The law firm's computer records do not indicate who gave the order to destroy the documents, who carried out the destruction or even how it was done, according to James S. Jardine, the managing director of the firm and the man who had for years served as the bid committee's chief lawyer. But the set of documents -- detailing the committee's actions over the final months of Salt Lake City's quest for the Olympics -- are the only files in that office to have been so destroyed.
"We've interviewed everyone who has worked on it, and their secretaries -- nobody has any knowledge," Mr. Jardine said. "It's strange. It doesn't make sense to us."
Mr. Jardine said the destroyed notes would not have added much to the record of what happened here. But others believe strongly that the notes might have helped make sense of one critical question that has hung over this city and the multiple investigations into the acquisition of the 2002 Games: who among senior management, including some of the city's most prominent and powerful businessmen, knew of the illicit campaign to buy votes?
 
Investigation
Anonymous Source Reveals Corruption
 Someone with access to the committee's files still wanted to get the story out. In late November 1998, a different local television station, KTVX-Channel 4, received a copy of a letter from an anonymous sender. The letter, stamped "draft" on its face, was from Mr. Johnson to an I.O.C. member's daughter, Sonia Essomba, informing her that her next tuition payment would be the last. On Nov. 24, 1998, Channel 4 broke the story, and local newspapers followed up with their own stories about the letter.
Committee officials, in response, portrayed the scholarships as humanitarian, and raised questions about whether the letter might be a forgery. With the letter's authenticity uncertain, the story appeared to fizzle again. But about a week later, in Lausanne, Switzerland, the No. 2 official in the I.O.C., Marc Hodler, said in an apparently offhand remark at a news conference on another subject that he believed Salt Lake City might have paid bribes in winning the 2002 Winter Games. In an interview with National Public Radio on Dec. 10, Mr. Hodler used the word bribes again in front of an American audience.
"From that moment, instead of being perceived as an aberration, it turned into a crisis," Ms. Seed said.
Since then, the story, and the list of questions it has raised, has continued to expand.
Federal prosecutors are trying to determine if anyone broke any laws.
The Salt Lake Organizing Committee has brought in an outsider with Utah roots, W. Mitt Romney, a Boston-based venture capitalist, to head up the Olympic committee with a new pledge of full disclosure.
An independent board of ethics created by Governor Leavitt has determined that knowledge was strictly limited to Mr. Welch, Mr. Johnson, and a third man, Craig Peterson, who the ethics board said acted secretly and alone.
And a lengthening list of people -- from Mr. Welch and Mr. Johnson to other staffers on the committee to officials with the national accounting firm that reviewed the committee's books to the people who served on a panel set up by the United States Olympic Committee -- have said they are not satisfied that the full truth has come out.
Jason Christensen, the volunteer, said he found it almost inconceivable that Mr. Joklik, who took over for Mr. Welch in 1997 to run the daily operations of the committee, did not know of the various mechanisms in place to influence votes.
"I can't imagine him claiming he had zero knowledge of what was going on," Mr. Christensen said. He added, "It was such commonplace knowledge among the staff."
Former Senator Mitchell, the chairman of a special investigation into the Salt Lake City scandal, said he also believes many statements of ignorance "strain credulity." "The actions of the principal individuals were not a secret," he said. "They didn't maintain two sets of books. Everything was available to anyone who inquired."
Still, bid committee officials, and perhaps the most senior members of the I.O.C., apparently thought they might be able to control the extent of the damage. In December, for example, Mr. Johnson, who was called to Switzerland after Mr. Hodler's remarks, said he discussed the trouble with a handful of I.O.C. executive committee members. He then met with Juan Antonio Samaranch, the I.O.C. president.
Of Mr. Samaranch, Mr. Johnson said: "He told me, 'You have a problem; we have a problem; we will get through this.' "
Maybe they will, but they haven't yet. As for the leaked letter that sparked the maelstrom, an ethics panel report last month concluded that it was genuine, but the source still has not been revealed.

Quest for the Games
Key dates in Salt Lake City's attempt to secure the Winter Games.
 
1966, 1973, 1985
Loses three bids to play host to Winter Games.
 
1989
Utah voters approve state sales tax to build Olympic sites.
 
1991
After losing a fourth bid, the son of an I.O.C. member tells a Salt Lake committee official that votes can be delivered for cash.
 
1998
Salt Lake City beats out nine other cities for 2002 Games. (pg. A1)
 
Photo/Chart: "The Slippery Slope of Securing an Olympic Bid"
Salt Lake City made its first attempt at hosting the Olympic Winter Games in 1966 for the '72 Games that were ultimately held in Sapporo, Japan. After a lack of success in its early attempts, Salt Lake City made an effort to turn itself into a significant winter vacation destination to become a viable candidate as a host city.
 
30 Years and 5 Attempts
The process to become the host of an Olympic Games is a two-step process for American cities. They must first be named the American bid city. Once that is accomplished, they then compete with inter 2/3nation 2/3al cities. A majority of the approx 2/3imately 100 members of the International Olympic Committee must vote for a city for it to be selected as the host. Salt Lake City has tried to become the host of the Winter Games five times. Here is how the process played out in each of its bids.

HEADLINE: Peace and Poverty in Central America

 BODY:
The last time an American President went to Central America was 1982, when Ronald Reagan visited Honduras and Costa Rica. That year was one of the bloodiest for El Salvador and for Guatemala, where a truth commission recently labeled 1982 as a peak period for what it termed the military's "genocide" of Mayan Indians in the civil war. But Mr. Reagan praised the military leaders of both nations and spent billions in lethal aid to their Governments and the Nicaraguan contras.
This week President Clinton is visiting a very different Central America and carries a very different message. His trip is a belated recognition of the region's progress and importance to the United States. But Washington's support for wars in Central America 15 years ago is not being matched by its support for peace today. 
 In El Salvador and Guatemala, United Nations-sponsored peace agreements have brought former guerrillas into politics and committed the Governments to social reforms. Mayan Indians, the marginalized majority in Guatemala, now serve in Parliament and as local mayors. In El Salvador the party of the former guerrillas lost this week's presidential elections but was able to campaign freely. The Sandinistas in Nicaragua won the war but lost at the ballot box, and stepped down in 1990.
The conflicts are over, but Central America's warring nations have essentially returned to the conditions of misery and inequality that caused the wars to begin with. While El Salvador has experienced steady economic growth, poverty in rural areas remains unchanged. In Nicaragua, the poor are worse off than at its war's end. Huge debts have kept the region from spending money to fight poverty. Nicaragua, for example, pays 11 times more in debt service than it spends on health care each year.
Many of the postwar governments' reforms -- new police or judicial systems -- have not solved the underlying problems that made these bodies responsive mainly to the rich and powerful. Even the local governments admit that free-market changes have so far mainly served the urban wealthy and middle class. Last year the region suffered its worst natural disaster of the century in Hurricane Mitch, which will set back development in Honduras and Nicaragua for decades.
That is why President Clinton's visit, important as it is, is a missed opportunity. Mr. Clinton is doling out his celebrated compassion, but little in the way of money. A billion dollars in post-hurricane aid is being held up in Congress. The Administration should allow the quarter-million immigrants who fled the wars in Salvador and Guatemala to stay in the United States. It must also forgive the debt burdens that were already crippling the countries most devastated by the hurricane, and try to persuade international lending institutions to do the same. Washington spent billions of dollars in the 1980's on wars in Central America. It should now increase its commitment to supporting peace and prosperity. 
http://www.nytimes.com

CORRECTION-DATE: March 13, 1999, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An editorial on Thursday erred in saying that Ronald Reagan's trip to Central America in 1982 was the last one by an American President before Bill Clinton's visit this week. Mr. Clinton went to Costa Rica in 1997.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
2 Big FrenchBanks Rebuff $37 Billion Takeover Offer

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE

DATELINE: ROME, March 10

 BODY:
Michel Pebereau thought he would crash the wedding, but the happy couple told him three was a crowd.
In a joint statement, two of France's biggest banks, Paribas S.A. and Societe Generale S.A., said that an offer on Tuesday by their big French rival, Mr. Pebereau's Banque Nationale de Paris, was a "hazardous venture" and that the offer "cannot therefore be considered as a friendly takeover bid." 
 The takeover effort was announced on Tuesday night as Mr. Pebereau, Banque Nationale's chairman, offered $37 billion for the two rivals, which had agreed to merge last month.
At a news conference in Paris this morning, Mr. Pebereau argued that the new European single currency had accelerated consolidation of banking and that the proposed alliance "will allow us to confront the competition on a European level."
Indeed, the alliance would yield a bank whose assets, totaling $1 trillion, would push it past UBS of Switzerland as the world's largest.
"Our country is capable of dominating this sector on a global scale," said Mr. Pebereau, 57, playing the nationalist card. He called banking "a sector in which France has historically excelled."
Stung by the hostile bid, Paribas and Societe Generale promised to study the proposal and then convene their boards. Paribas hired the investment bank Rothschild & Company to study ways to repel the bid, and Societe Generale said it, too, would hire advisers. Trading in the shares of all three banks was suspended in Paris but was expected to resume on Thursday.
For the two target banks, the bid threatens the well-laid plans for Societe Generale to acquire Paribas for $18 billion in stock. Investors have been skeptical of the plan, arguing that there was little overlap at the two banks and that there was scant room for cost-cutting.
For Banque Nationale de Paris, the bid holds great potential. It has been cut out of most French banking deals, and Mr. Pebereau is desperate for a partner. Societe Generale is a well-run bank with a good profit record, and Paribas is a respected name with a strong consumer banking unit, Cetelem.
Yet the move poses great risks. The bid effectively puts all three banks into play, and if Banque Nationale fails, it could fall prey to a takeover. Moreover, it could face resistance from labor unions and the French Government. The bank employees union denounced the plan today as "adventurous and very serious for jobs." For the French Government -- which is preparing a sale of Credit Lyonnais, the state-owned bank that has returned to profit after losing billions -- the proposed combination would create a retail banking giant that would alter the terms of any privatization.
And the bid could face resistance from Jewish organizations. In New York, Elan Steinberg, executive director of the World Jewish Congress, said that if the banks applied for a merger in the United States, a "great deal of sentiment" existed in the leadership of Congress to oppose it until French banks showed a more conciliatory attitude in talks to settle issues related to the accounts of Holocaust victims or their survivors.
The banking alliance that Mr. Pebereau proposed involves keeping all three banks' brand names and includes no sweeping layoffs. Banque Nationale de Paris intends to retain the investment banking activities of Paribas while combining its own banking units with those of Societe Generale.
The merger would create a bank with 4,700 branches in France, giving it 18 percent of the retail market and making it the No. 2 retail bank behind Credit Agricole. The bank said it expected annual savings, before taxes, of $1.3 billion, or 8 percent of combined costs, by 2002.
Elie Cohen, an economist at the National Center for Scientific Research, said: "It's crazy, but Pebereau had no other choice. For him it was a matter of survival." If the bid fails, Mr. Cohen said, Banque Nationale de Paris could find itself the target of a bid from a Dutch or German bank. "If he succeeds, he will be No. 1," he said.
Banque Nationale's bid is the latest in a series of giant-scale transactions that are reshaping European banks as they struggle for position in a market gaining cohesion with the euro. And there is no sign of the pace slackening.
"It's a bold, aggressive step," said John D. Leonard, banking analyst at Salomon Smith Barney in London. He said Banque Nationale wanted to ally itself with Societe Generale, a goal it set last year but failed to achieve when Societe Generale refused an alliance.
Some experts said the real winner, if the deal succeeds, would be Claude Bebear, chairman of the AXA insurance group. AXA is the largest shareholder in both Paribas and Banque Nationale de Paris and would emerge as a controlling shareholder in a combined bank. And Mr. Bebear, 63, a king maker in French finance, is said to want the deal done.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

CORRECTION-DATE: March 15, 1999, Monday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Thursday about an offer by the Banque Nationale de Paris to purchase two other French banks referred incorrectly to a comment by Elan Steinberg, executive director of the World Jewish Congress, on opposition to the merger. Mr. Steinberg said that because of the banks' resistance to settling issues involving accounts of Holocaust victims or their survivors, a great deal of opposition to the merger existed in the leadership of the World Jewish Congress -- not in the United States Congress.

SECTION: Section E; Part 1; Page 22; Column 5; Movies, Performing Arts/Weekend Desk

LENGTH: 2214 words

HEADLINE: MOVIE GUIDE

 BODY:

Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 8.
 
Now Playing
 
* "AFFLICTION," starring Nick Nolte, James Coburn, Willem Dafoe, Sissy Spacek and Mary Beth Hurt. Directed by Paul Schrader (R, 114 minutes). Mr. Nolte is devastating in the performance of his career, as Wade Whitehouse, a New Hampshire loner fighting a losing battle with demons from his past. Foremost among them: Mr. Coburn, terrifyingly authentic as the drunken, abusive father who long ago cowed his sons into submission. As directed by Mr. Schrader, this pure, unfettered adaptation of Russell Banks's novel starts on a deceptively ordinary note, then escalates into inexorable fury. Every little detail matters. Ms. Spacek and Ms. Hurt expertly play the women who trigger Wade's crisis (Janet Maslin). 

* "ANALYZE THIS," starring Robert De Niro and Billy Crystal. Directed by Harold Ramis (R, 110 minutes). The title, concept and teaming of these co-stars are all funny before the lights go down, so think of this comedy as an offer you can't refuse. Cast as a mobster whose confidence is shaken, Mr. De Niro is hilarious simply by playing his role halfway straight, in classic goodfella style. His mobster finds just the right comic foil in Billy Crystal, as the psychiatrist who utters the immortal: "When I got into family therapy, this wasn't the family I had in mind." There's a lot more where that came from in this breezy comic treat (Maslin).
 
"BLAST FROM THE PAST," starring Brendan Fraser, Christopher Walken, Alicia Silverstone and Sissy Spacek. Directed by Hugh Wilson (PG-13, 105 minutes). More amusingly than might be expected, this comedy tells the story of one very nuclear family that has been hiding in a fallout shelter since 1962 and emerges into a 90's world of grunge and attitude. In fact, it's funnier underground, with Mr. Fraser as the strapping son of a cheerfully mad scientist (Mr. Walken) and sherry-sipping housewife (Ms. Spacek), 1962 style. Once he comes above ground and meets a hard-boiled Ms. Silverstone, it's clear that Mr. Fraser is once again a film's true ingenu, doing the wide-eyed hunk thing that has become his specialty. He does it a lot better in "Gods and Monsters," but this comedy is still lighthearted fun (Maslin).
 
* "CENTRAL STATION," starring Fernanda Montenegro, Vinicius de Oliveira and Marilia Pera. Directed by Walter Salles (R, 115 minutes). In this quiet, luminous Brazilian gem, a joyless older woman crosses paths with an orphaned boy. There's plenty of room for sentimentality here, but the wonder of Mr. Salles's film is all in the telling. As these characters develop a fractious bond, then embark on a road trip that takes them vividly to Brazil's hinterlands in search of the boy's father, Mr. Salles brings great tenderness and surprise to the events that punctuate their journey. Ms. Montenegro's tough bravura performance was one of last year's very best (Maslin).
 
"EIGHT MILLIMETER," starring Nicolas Cage, Joaquin Phoenix, James Gandolfini, Myra Carter and Catherine Keener. Directed by Joel Schumacher (R, 120 minutes). This thriller delves into the perverse underworld of the pornography business, shocking audiences with the realization that sex and violence can be so dull. Mr. Cage, seriously miscast, plays a private detective and devoted family man who is suddenly, to his horror, drawn into the realm of porn. Naturally, this is where the film wanted to be even when its opening scenes were stuck in suburban Pennsylvania. But the story's parade of New York and Hollywood sleazeballs fails to deliver either engaging drama or heartfelt kinks. Mr. Phoenix is scene-stealingly good in a sidekick's role (Maslin).
 
* "LOCK, STOCK AND TWO SMOKING BARRELS," starring Jason Flemyng, Dexter Fletcher, Sting, Jason Statham, Vinnie Jones and Nick Moran. Directed by Guy Ritchie (R, 106 minutes). Not since "The Usual Suspects" has there been such an oversupply of cool macho schemers in a single film. And they're served up with a quick, tart economy that bespeaks the filmmaker's background making videos and commercials -- actually an advantage, for a change. There's not much beneath the surface here; what's most entertaining is Mr. Ritchie's droll, hard-boiled storytelling and the rogue's gallery of a cast that he has assembled. All the film need do is juggle assorted miscreants and four separate gangs who, figuratively speaking, can't shoot straight (Maslin).
 
"MESSAGE IN A BOTTLE," starring Kevin Costner, Robin Wright Penn and Paul Newman. Directed by Luis Mandoki (PG-13, 110 minutes). Nicholas Sparks's best-selling novel, about a lonely, sensitive man who sends a message out to sea and the lonely, beautiful woman who finds it, is now a long and soggy film. Kevin Costner crosses the line from teasingly laconic to stodgy and seems as likely to have written "Bleak House" as the love letter in question. Robin Wright Penn makes an appealing heroine, but there's not much room for real emotion in a film with the tenor of a commercial for hazelnut-flavored coffee. As the hero's crusty old father, Mr. Newman steals what's left of the show (Maslin).
 
"MY FAVORITE MARTIAN," starring Christopher Lloyd, Jeff Daniels and Ray Walston. Directed by Donald Petrie (PG, 88 minutes). Pixilated pixels and other up-to-the-minute moviemaking magic manage the neat feat of turning the big-screen, resurrected "My Favorite Martian" into an amiable family entertainment. In this updated version of the 1960's CBS sitcom, Jeff Daniels as Tim O'Hara (now a television newsman rather than a newspaper reporter) and Christopher Lloyd as the visitor from another planet take over the roles played by Bill Bixby and Ray Walston. In one of the happy and logical little jokes that lend a disarming charm to the comedy, Mr. Walston turns up once again in a welcome guise as Government bloodhounds set out to capture the Martian. But a good deal of the fun in this tale is provided by Zoot, his high-spirited polymorphic space suit (Lawrence Van Gelder).
 
"OCTOBER SKY," starring Jake Gyllenhaal, Chris Cooper, Chris Owen and Natalie Canaday. Directed by Joe Johnston (PG, 100 minutes). By far the most moving scenes here are home movie snippets, circa 1957, that show the real people on whom the film's characters are based. Otherwise, despite being closely based on a best-selling memoir ("Rocket Boys") by the NASA engineer Homer H. Hickam Jr., this earnest, nostalgic film has a way of seeming too good to be true. The film's simplicity is appealing, as is Mr. Gyllenhaal in the central role of a boy in a West Virginia coal mining town who becomes obsessed with rocketry. But the story, filled with father-son conflict and down-in-the-ground versus up-in-the-sky contrasts, often follows a familiar trajectory (Maslin).
 
"PAYBACK," starring Mel Gibson and Gregg Henry. Directed by Brian Helgeland (R, 110 minutes). In this inept, excessively sadistic film-noir spoof adapted from the same Richard Stark novel ("The Hunter") that inspired the 1967 genre classic "Point Blank," Mr. Gibson is a thief named Porter who retaliates with a vengeance after an attempt on his life. Determined to recover $70,000 that was stolen from him by a double-crossing partner in crime, he works his way up the pecking order of a crime syndicate, brutally dispatching all who stand in his way. The hard-boiled dialogue is ludicrous, the storytelling clunky, the acting fair to awful, the gore ankle deep. Credit the star with being able to keep a straight face through this loathsome mess (Stephen Holden).
 
* "SHAKESPEARE IN LOVE," starring Joseph Fiennes, Gwyneth Paltrow, Geoffrey Rush, Ben Affleck and Judi Dench. Directed by John Madden (R, 113 minutes). A witty, sexy and merrily literate delight, with an exhilaratingly clever premise that only gets better as the film unfolds. The screenplay, originating as Marc Norman's brainstorm and turned by Tom Stoppard into razor-sharp dialogue reminiscent of his "Rosencrantz and Guildenstern Are Dead," dares to imagine whatever it likes about the link between Shakespeare's artistic passions and his mad yearning for a certain aristocratic beauty. Meanwhile this tirelessly inventive comedy envisions an Elizabethan theater fraught with the same backbiting and conniving we enjoy today and has great fun presenting the creation of "Romeo and Juliet," glitches and all. Mr. Fiennes and Ms. Paltrow make a fine, tempestuous duo, and she gives the first great, fully realized starring performance of her career (Maslin).
 
* "TANGO," starring Miguel Angel Sola. Written and directed by Carlos Saura. Cinematography by Vittorio Storaro (PG-13, 100 minutes). A thrilling display of tango heat and virtuosity. And it's no slight to the actors who play lovers to say that the dancing here is steamier than any kiss. In his most electrifying dance film Mr. Saura offers transfixingly beautiful glimpses of the dance and the great range of emotions it can conjure. Mr. Storaro's dazzlingly fluid cinematography captures all the nuances this material demands. Everyone in the film is utterly consumed by tango fever; audiences will be, too (Maslin).
 
"THE THIN RED LINE," starring Jim Caviezel, Ben Chaplin, Nick Nolte, Sean Penn and Woody Harrelson. Directed by Terrence Malick (R, 166 minutes). From the first frame of this huge, drifting war epic loosely derived from James Jones's Guadalcanal novel, it's viscerally clear that Mr. Malick is back. The exquisite, oddly detached visual style that made "Badlands" and "Days of Heaven" the most beautiful films of the 1970's is instantly apparent here, even if the narrative vagueness and brooding voice-overs are also familiar. The film sprawls, gets lost and occasionally delivers visual poetry, the kind that could have been greatly helped by tighter editing. Bottom line: No one who admired Mr. Malick's early work should miss this. But those expecting anything simple will not find it here (Maslin).
 
"20 DATES," starring Myles Berkowitz. Directed by Mr. Berkowitz (R, 88 minutes). The filmmaker's gimmick is to make a film about dating. His goal: To go out with 20 different women, get them on camera by any means necessary and promise to fall in love with one before the experiment is over. Mr. Berkowitz, pesty and proud of it, has absorbed enough of Jerry Seinfeld and Garry Shandling to create a diffident, nit-picking, sitcom-ready persona. But whenever his film establishes a playful mood, it's liable to do something to make you squirm. Crassness and mock candor aren't all that funny (unless they're coming from Albert Brooks, whose "Real Life" paved the way for this). And discovering that cheese makes Mr. Berkowitz constipated, or that one of his dates disappoints him by not looking enough like Jessica Rabbit, is more than you need to know (Maslin).
 
"200 CIGARETTES," starring Paul Rudd, Kate Hudson, Ben Affleck, Janeane Garofalo and Courtney Love. Directed by Risa Bramon Garcia (R, 102 minutes). This contrived but cheery party movie marks the feature directing debut of a well-known casting director. And in making her film, Ms. Garcia does what she does best: cast. A group of bright young players is brought together for a largely plotless New Year's Eve, rambling around a colorfully evoked East Village, circa 1981. Essentially just a set of interwoven skits, this comedy still makes good use of the actors noted above, along with Casey Affleck as a nice-guy punk, Dave Chappelle as a cabbie full of advice and Martha Plimpton as a hopeless hostess. Ms. Hudson, who is Goldie Hawn's daughter and has her mother's grin and giggle, makes an adorable debut despite spending part of the movie with dog excrement on her coat (Maslin).
 
Film Series
 
RICHARD LESTER RETROSPECTIVE. Hip, free-wheeling and blessed with an irreverent comic spirit, Richard Lester burst on the filmmaking scene in 1959 with "The Running, Jumping, Standing Still Film," an 11-minute short with Peter Sellers and Spike Milligan. In the 1960's, Mr. Lester made "A Hard Day's Night" and "Help!" both starring the Beatles, as well as "The Knack. . . and How to Get It" and "How I Won the War," with John Lennon. Now Mr. Lester is the subject of a retrospective at the American Museum of the Moving Image that concludes this weekend with four of his films. The attractions tomorrow are "The Bed Sitting Room" (1969), with Rita Tushingham, Milligan, Peter Cook and Dudley Moore, at 2 P.M; and the autumnal romance "Robin and Marian" (1976) with Sean Connery and Audrey Hepburn at 4:30. Sunday brings not only "Petulia" (1968) at 2 P.M. and "A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum" (1966) at 4 but also discussions after each by Tony Walton, who designed the films for the director. Admission to the series at the museum, 34-12 36th Street, at 35th Avenue, Astoria, Queens, is $8.50 for adults, $5.50 for people over 65 and students with I.D., $4.50 for children from 5 to 18 and free to children under 4. Information: (718) 784-0077 (Van Gelder).

HEADLINE: HOME VIDEO;
The D.J. Apostles Of Rock 'n' Roll

BYLINE: By Peter M. Nichols 

 BODY:
Documentaries often make the better shows on video. On March 23, for example, Winstar is to release "Rock 'n' Roll Invaders," a Canadian film that goes past the performers to get at the AM radio disk jockeys who brought the music to the people in the 50's. 
 Produced by Dramarama, a Toronto company, the documentary took its director, Paul Eichgrun, around the United States on a three-year search for material about a little band of visionaries who sensed an impending revolution and spun every record they could get their hands on.
Postwar America was nervous about race and its increasingly restless teen-agers. "Kids were becoming an economic power, buying their own cars and clothes and records," Mr. Eichgrun said. "It was a shock."
But race was the sore point. The documentary is especially good at showing how disk jockeys helped move the music that became rock 'n' roll from black to white in the middle and latter part of the decade.
Several years earlier radio itself had been revitalized by black rhythm-and-blues, spread far and wide by the likes of Rufus Thomas and Martha Jean (The Queen) Steinberg, black disk jockeys on WDAI in Memphis (later she went to Detroit). Soon rhythm-and-blues met white rockabilly, introducing white disk jockeys like Dewey Phillips, the man with Beale Street connections, John R. (John Richbourg) and Bill (Hoss) Allen of WLAC in Nashville.
The music worked its way north, and in places like the Record Rendezvous in Cleveland, white teen-agers combed "sepia bins" for the hot, sweaty, boozy workingman's rhythm-and-blues. At Alan Freed's Moondog Ball, the first rock concert, a crowd of 26,000 tried to occupy 6,000 seats and there was a riot.
The rambunctious Freed ruled the scene, and the white mainstream was getting anxious. Rhythm-and-blues was about to become a white creation. "They bleached it and changed the name," Mr. Eichgrun said. Now it was rock 'n' roll and headed for the coasts.
There was trouble. Freed was on WINS in New York and promoting concerts around the East. "Kids, it looks like the Boston police don't want you to have fun," he told a packed crowd in Boston Arena. That got him indicted for inciting a riot and cost him his job at WINS. ABC television hired him, but he lost that job, too, when the black singer Frankie Lyman danced with a white girl. The show was instantly canceled.
Middle America wasn't amused when Jerry Lee Lewis married his 13-year-old second cousin. The payola scandals, with many leading disk jockeys caught taking money to play records, were no help either. "Booze, Broads, Bribes," shouted a headline about a riotous disk jockey convention in Miami. Station management introduced the Top 40, which were played over and over.
Disk jockeys responded by becoming performers in their own right. At the Apollo Theater in New York, Jocko Henderson gave songs rhymed introductions that were the forerunners of rap. In Mexico, Wolfman Jack ruled border radio, the one-million-watt stations heard all over the country and beyond. "The Russians had to spend time blocking out the Wolfman," Mr. Eichgrun said.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Technology;
Variable Transmission Wins New Disciples

BYLINE: By MICHELLE KREBS 

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
WHILE driving the Honda Civic HX coupe, one immediately senses that something is missing. Step hard on the accelerator when a stoplight turns green, or press the pedal to the floor to pass on a freeway, and there is no jerk as the transmission shifts gears. Nor does the sound of the engine rise just before a shift, along with its speed, and then fall off. The tachometer's needle holds steady.
Indeed, the car feels as though its transmission is not shifting at all. 
 That is because the Civic HX has a continuously variable transmission, or CVT, the only one currently available on a production model in the United States. It will certainly not be the last.
Last fall, the Ford Motor Company and ZF Friedrichshafen A.G., the German company that is Europe's largest supplier of transmissions, announced a joint venture that is expected to eventually produce a million CVT's a year at a Ford transmission plant in Batavia, Ohio. The transmissions will show up in cars from Ford and from other manufacturers.
The appeal of CVT's is simple. Aside from their smoothness, they allow an engine to operate at optimal efficiency nearly all the time, improving economy and saving wear and tear. They offer the convenience of an automatic transmission with the better mileage of a manual shift. Indeed, the Civic HX has been the only car without a stick shift to earn a place on the Environmental Protection Agency's list of the 10 mileage leaders, achieving a rating of 34 miles a gallon in the city and 38 on the highway.
"The customer gets improved fuel economy because the vehicle spends more time in areas of good efficiency," said Gordon Willis, Ford's chief engineer for automatic transmissions. Although gasoline prices are now around their all-time lows, Mr. Willis concedes that fuel economy will matter again someday. And global giants like Ford are already building plenty of cars for countries where fuel economy is indeed important because gasoline is very expensive.
Ford and ZF expect their new CVT to raise fuel economy by 10 to 15 percent. In addition to better mileage, the customer has the benefit of feeling and hearing no gear changes. "Every transmission causes you to feel the gear change to some degree, and customers say they would rather not feel those events," Mr. Willis said. "They worry about those events if they feel they are not always shifting exactly the same -- if it shifts different today than it did yesterday."
In fact, while a driver perceives that a CVT-equipped car is not shifting at all, it is actually shifting much of the time, though not in the specific increments of a traditional transmission. Shifts on a car with an automatic transmission are based on specific ratios between the speed of the engine and the speed of the vehicle. First gear is one ratio, and second, third and fourth gears are others; there are no possible settings between the gears. As a result, the engine is sometimes operating extremely efficiently, and sometimes quite inefficiently.
But a CVT shifts continuously as the engine speed and vehicle speed change, allowing an infinite number of possible gear ratios. ZF executives say this should result in less strain on the engine and longer life for other vehicle components.
Honda's CVT works like the gearing on the two sprocket rings of a 10-speed bicycle. Computerized sensors constantly adjust the diameters of pulleys -- the drive pulley from the engine and the driven pulley that sends power to the wheels -- at each end of a steel drive belt, pushing the belt closer or farther away from the center of each pulley. Every possible position of the belt on the two pulleys represents a gear ratio. On acceleration, for instance, the drive pulley will have a narrow diameter for more torque, like a low gear. At cruising speed, the drive pulley widens and acts like a high gear.
CVT's are not new. The earliest automobiles operated on a similar principle, and a Dutch car, the DAF, had a CVT in the years after World War II, using sturdy drive belts developed for such a purpose by a Dutch company, Van Doorne's Transmissie B.V. In the United States, Subaru offered a CVT on its Justy subcompact in the early 1990's. And CVT's are used in foreign markets on several Nissan Motor models, including the diesel Micra sold in Europe; on the Microcar of France, and on other vehicles. Snowmobiles have always used CVT's.
But while CVT's have been mainly used in small cars with small engines, that seems likely to change. University of Michigan studies of automotive trends predict rapid growth for CVT's in the next decade because of increased pressure on auto makers to raise fuel economy, in part because their brisk sales of low-mileage vehicles reduces their corporate fuel-economy averages.
The Ford and ZF joint venture is a big step toward the proliferation of CVT's. The first transmission from that venture will make its debut on a 2002 model; company officials said that would not be a Ford product, though Ford will not be far behind.
Technical issues are the focus of much attention. Improved materials, larger belts and better control systems should help make CVT's practical with larger engines. ZF has introduced a CVT aimed at engines of up to 3 liters. And Nissan is working on what it calls a toroidal CVT, which does not use belts. That CVT has been tested with a potent 300-horsepower engine.
Low volume and limited availability of parts have made CVT's expensive to produce, though Mr. Willis of Ford predicts that they could prove cheaper than traditional automatics as production increases, because they contain fewer parts.
"I'm convinced the technical benefits of the CVT will make it the dominant form of transmission," Mr. Willis said. "The speculation now is how long will it take?" 
http://www.nytimes.com

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: ON STAGE AND OFF;
Numbers Beat the 'Band'

BYLINE: By Jesse McKinley 

 BODY:
It may not be the worst decision of the season. (Remember "More to Love"?) But the booking of "Band in Berlin" in the Helen Hayes Theater on Broadway over the acclaimed drama "Wit" is looking more and more suspect.
For those just tuning in, last fall the owner of the Helen Hayes, Martin Markinson, opted to book "Band in Berlin," a musical based on a Nazi-era singing group, over "Wit," which was earning stellar reviews in a small theater Off Off Broadway. His reasoning, he said, was that the subject matter of "Wit," a literature professor's battle with ovarian cancer, was not appetizing to audiences. 
 Spurned, "Wit" subsequently reopened on Jan. 7 in the Union Square Theater, an Off Broadway house that, with 499 seats, is the same size as the Helen Hayes but that is not Tony eligible. The move has been a rousing success. This week the producers of "Wit" announced they had earned back the $500,000 it cost to mount the show and were making approximately $58,000 a week in profit. Average weekly grosses have been running about $142,000, out of a potential $168,000, said Roy Gabay, the show's general manager.
Meanwhile, at the Helen Hayes the producers of "Band in Berlin," which opened on Sunday to dismissive reviews, reported sales of a meager $66,283 last week. But Robert V. Straus, the lead producer, said the figure was low in part because on opening night most seats are given free to the press, investors, friends and others.
Mr. Straus said he was giving the show two to five weeks to build an audience. "If we're at $60,000 in three weeks," he said, "you know what we're going to have to do."
Mr. Markinson said: "I'm very happy for 'Wit,' but I come from a place where I never look back. To me that's negative energy. Would I have made the same choice? Probably. But I simply don't allow myself to take a whip out and beat myself."
 
Putting It Together
Cameron Mackintosh was in New York this week laying the groundwork for what promises to be a coming onslaught on Broadway.
Mr. Mackintosh, the producer of commercial behemoths like "Les Miserables" and "Miss Saigon," spent most days casting for "Martin Guerre," his oft-reworked musical, which will open in Minneapolis in September and then tour. It is aiming for Broadway in spring 2000.
But in his spare time -- and there wasn't much -- he turned his attention to several other shows. The first is "Putting It Together," a Stephen Sondheim revue, which now looks likely for the Barrymore Theater in September or October. Mr. Mackintosh dined with Mr. Sondheim on Tuesday night.
Mr. Mackintosh also was discussing his forthcoming revival of "Oliver," which will probably try out in Toronto, Chicago and possibly Boston before landing in New York in early spring. Audra McDonald and Geoffrey Rush have been mentioned for roles; a spokesman for Mr. Mackintosh, Marc Thibodeau, said he could not confirm any negotiations.
 
Straight Up
If any more proof were needed of this season's strange economic logic, consider this: The only real moneymakers have been straight plays.
Heading the pack last fall was "The Blue Room," which sold out a three-month run and returned a tidy $2 million profit, and "Electra," which will conclude a four-month run on March 21 about $400,000 in the black. The spring's first major opening, "Death of a Salesman," has also put up good numbers, regularly selling out and building a $3.5 million advance.
And more winners may be on the way. Emmanuel Azenberg, the producer of "The Iceman Cometh," opening in April, said this week that advance sales of his show would very likely top $4.4 million this week. Producers of "Amy's View," another April entry, declined to say what their advance was, but a member of the production who had seen sales figures said they were "Blue Room-like."
By contrast, of the season's musical offerings, only "Annie Get Your Gun" and "Fosse" are showing any real box-office vigor. "Footloose," which has had good weeks and bad, has slipped of late.
 
Filling 'Follies'
The cast of the Encores concert series's next show, "The Ziegfeld Follies of 1936," opening on March 25, will include two alumni of the musical "Chicago": Karen Ziemba, who is in the current New York production, and Ruthie Henshall, who was nominated for an Olivier Award for "Chicago" in London. "Ziegfeld"s cast also includes Christine Ebersole, Peter Scolari and Mary Testa. Ms. Henshall looks likely to join the New York "Chicago" in May, playing the role of Velma opposite Sandy Duncan.
 
'Dreaming Out Loud'
When Deidre Murray, composer of the music for "Running Man," first proposed a performance piece about her brother's heroin addiction to her collaborator, Cornelius Eady, he thought the concept was slightly unwieldy.
"It would have had to be an opera," said Mr. Eady, recalling Ms. Murray's original 20-page outline. "With a cast of thousands."
Ms. Murray said, "I wanted to do a homage to people who never make it." Her brother, Wellington, died in 1991. "He fell and kept falling," she said.
But over the course of two years the piece was whittled down into a 75-minute, jazz-infused piece, playing now through Sunday at the Here performance space in SoHo.
"Running Man," which has received some critical praise and subsequent attention from commercial producers, was commissioned by the Music-Theater Group. Lyn Austin, the producing director of the group, said negotiations were under way to reopen in a larger theater this spring.
Neither Mr. Eady nor Ms. Murray is accustomed to working in the theater. Ms. Murray is an accomplished jazz cellist; Mr. Eady is a poet.
But both seem to be enjoying their excursion. "Theater is kind of like dreaming out loud, " Mr. Eady said. "I think I'm hooked."
