HEADLINE: ART REVIEW;
The Modern Looks at Artists Looking at Museums

BYLINE: By ROBERTA SMITH 

 BODY:
Of all the love-hate relationships that roil the art world, none is more fraught or more stimulating than that between artists and museums. This makes perfect sense, since the two occupy opposite ends of the art world food chain.
Artists make art; museums select some of that art for their collections, where it is preserved, elevated and, most of all, displayed. Once on view, it offers other artists inspiration, helping them unlock their own talents, which brings the food chain full circle. 
 The artist-museum relationship could be called capitalist, a case of supply and demand, with the consumer (the museum) causing pain and competition among the producers (the artists). It could be called Oedipal, with the museum as a parental authority whose ordering, judgmental nature is anathema to the rebellious sensibilities of artists, even though they crave its approval. Or it could be seen as micro versus macro: artists are individuals and museums are institutions, but they are driven by a similar passion for the accumulation, enjoyment and perpetuation of art. The similarities and differences create a perfectly balanced mutual fascination.
Whatever it's called, this connection powers "Museum as Muse: Artists Reflect," a remarkable exhibition that opens on Sunday at the Museum of Modern Art. Organized by Kynaston McShine, the longtime senior curator in the department of painting and sculpture, it examines the many ways that artists, mostly in the 20th century, have seen the museum as the subject, rather than simply the destination, of their art.
This tendency has been on the rise since the advent of Conceptual Art, when artists became more aware and critical of the complex context -- ethical, social, economic -- surrounding art. But the show also includes a handful of works from previous centuries, suggesting that the fascination predates modernism. Its 62 artists range from Roger Fenton (the 19th-century photographer) to Marcel Duchamp and Joseph Cornell, to Hans Haacke, Ed Ruscha, Sherrie Levine and Fred Wilson. Janet Cardiff, a young Canadian artist, has created the show's amusingly disorienting audio guide, which takes the viewer into the Modern's permanent collection and beyond.
Although it is stronger in big ideas than in profound visual experiences, "Museum as Muse" is an unusually coherent, well-orchestrated theme show that transcends typical theme-show fare (as in the cow, nude or machine in art). Part of its power lies in the simple fact that, to paraphrase Frank Stella, what you see is where you see it. Its contents and its context are one.
Including painting, video, printed brochure and installation art, the show's 182 works mix media with a freedom that's unusual for the Modern, while veering pleasantly between the arcane and the accessible, the beautiful and the thought-provoking, the celebratory and the critical. The totality examines the museum from every angle, as a public place, as an accumulator and classifier of knowledge (natural history museums are also touched on), as a colonizer of cultures (so are ethnographic ones), as an exclusive social club and as a big business with products of its own.
Almost in passing, interrelated smaller themes are encompassed. The show offers an unusually comprehensible outline of the development of Conceptual Art, with its emphasis on language and photography and its influences on subsequent generations. It reflects how photography especially has metastasized throughout the art of the last 30 years. And, of course, by definition it also considers one of 20th-century art's biggest ideas: the site-specific work of art. This is, after all, an exhibition of art about art museums in the world's pre-eminent museum of modern art. For contemporary artists, a site can't be much richer with possibility.
This is nowhere clearer than in the works, like Ms. Cardiff's audio guide, that Mr. McShine commissioned specially for the show. The results are impressive, not least because they show the Modern being very flexible, uncharacteristically so, some would say. The museum clearly bent the furthest for a piece by the California Conceptualist Michael Asher: a brochure listing, as accurately as records permit, every work of painting and sculpture that the Modern has ever deaccessioned. Attached to one of the benches toward the end of the exhibition, it makes fascinating reading and is also available in the Modern's bookstore without charge (but with a museum ticket stub).
The French artist Daniel Buren, famous for reducing art to bright stripes that he applies to all kinds of surfaces, has been allowed to put his stripes not in the show proper but upstairs in the permanent collection galleries. To be precise, they appear on two walls that usually hold four paintings by Giorgio de Chirico. Meanwhile, the de Chirico paintings are on view in Mr. McShine's exhibition, where they provide an encounter as pleasantly surprising as Mr. Buren's walls of stripes upstairs.
And Mr. Wilson was given free rein in the Modern's photo archive, emerging with "Art in Our Time," a wall of images that evoke the museum as a bastion of the rich and white. The central image shows the museum "opened up," after a fire in 1958, with the windows of its famous stairwell knocked out by firefighters. It is typical of the exhibition that Mr. Wilson's work faces a more traditional arrangement, photographs of museum openings by Garry Winogrand and Larry Fink, which also don't always flatter the powers that be.
Mr. McShine rather slyly includes an earlier instance of flexibility at the Modern, in a work that was created for "Information," his 1970 survey of Conceptual Art. Titled "Service Piece," it is by Vito Acconci and documents the artist using his allotted space in the earlier show as a mail pickup. (Other "Information" alumni include Mr. Buren, Jan Dibbets, Mr. Haacke, Robert Smithson, Dennis Oppenheim and, surprisingly, Jeff Wall.)
Installed with the density of an 18th-century kunstkammer -- the collections of art, artifacts and natural wonders assembled by monarchs and aristocrats that is the point of origin of museums -- the show nonetheless moves easily from one idea to the next, while individual works play off each other well. Organizationally, it lures viewers in, saves its more difficult works for the middle and then sets them down gently.
The show's long narrow antechamber, as the first gallery might be called, concentrates on the museum as a public space that foments private experience, a stage whose social and visual dynamics have always attracted artists. Most of the works are photographs, and most of them show people looking at art. In Thomas Struth's enormous images -- almost big enough to walk into -- people gaze at the Modern's big Pollock, "One: No. 31, 1950," or at Gericault's looming "Raft of the Medusa" at the Louvre.
Across the way, Cartier-Bresson's "Musee du Louvre," with its clutch of people studying David's looming painting of the coronation of the Emperess Josephine, is surely an ancestor to the Struths. David Seymour shows Bernard Berenson contemplating a marble odalisque with self-satisfied calm, while Cartier-Bresson photographs two small boys avidly homing in on a sculpture in a museum in Tashkent. Elliott Erwitt and Eve Arnold capture the sexual puns in chance juxtapositions of viewers and objects, and Candida Hofer's photographs of modern museum lobbies reveal antiseptic spaces devoid of art or people. A short wall of 19th-century photographs by Fenton, Gustave LeGray and Charles Thurston Thompson underscores the point that photographers sought out museums and their contents as soon as the camera was invented.
Next, Charles Willson Peale, the 18th-century portrait painter who was also an inventor, zoologist and engraver, literally raises the curtain on the show. In a large 1822 self-portrait he unveils America's first museum, which he founded, a place where stuffed birds and painted portraits are overwhelmingly abundant. Gathering, selecting and classifying -- the museum's chief functions -- are the themes here, adapted by artists to their own purposes. Sometimes the result is highly personal, a museum of the self, the soul or the artist's work. Examples include Cornell's "Untitled (Bebe Marie)," a suitcase full of cards, photographs and illustrations forming a tender, obsessive dossier, and the various boxes that Duchamp filled with miniature replicas of his art, creating portable retrospectives. Herbert Distel's "Museum of Drawers," created in the 1970's, contains miniatures of and by other artists, 500 of them. Barbara Bloom's "Reign of Narcissism" is a portrait of the artist as demure museum display, while Christian Boltanski's "Vitrine of Reference (II)" from 1970 recalls his childhood in a series of pathetic little artifacts.
And not only art is gathered. Mark Dion amasses animal, vegetable and mineral specimens in "Chain of Being," a bookshelf-as-cornucopia and one of the show's commissions. Hiroshi Sugimoto's eerie photographs of natural history dioramas suggest how this material is put to use. And Susan Hiller's "From the Freud Museum" preserves valueless, meaningless little objects and texts, assembled into 50 separate boxes in juxtapositions that set off all sorts of bells concerning history, myth and memory. The only thing missing here is Claes Oldenburg's fabulous "Mouse Museum," a walk-in room in the shape of Mickey's head that is in fact a portrait of the Pop artist's fertile imagination and his omnivorous interest in popular culture. Too big for the exhibition, it is in the museum's lobby, along with works by Allan McCollum and the Canadian artist-team General Idea.
In the show's middle section, the museum is not so much imitated as scrutinized, with particular attention to the artwork as commodity and stolen property. Duchamp is back with his defaced reproduction of the Mona Lisa. Mr. Haacke traces the provenance of the small version of Seurat's "Poseuses" from the artist's studio in 1888 to the vaults of an investment group nearly 90 years later. Sophie Calle's "Last Seen . . ." series dwells upon another sort of transaction, the theft of three paintings from Boston's Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum. Lothar Baumgarten's slide projection piece "Unsettled Objects" considers a more extensive form of theft, with images of the non-Western art and artifacts warehoused in the Pitt Rivers Museum, an ethnographic museum in Oxford, England. These dense-packed displays, untouched for most of this century, are as disturbing as they are riveting.
Such cultural presumption echoes in Andrea Fraser's "Welcome to the Wadsworth Atheneum: A Museum Tour," a 1991 videotape that never gets to the art, instead reviewing the historical matrix of prominent individuals and families who created the city and provided the museum with art, patrons, wings, architects and even the occasional director or curator.
In the exhibition's final gallery, the end of the museum is broached with a lightness that suggests that reports of its death are greatly exaggerated. A 1966 painting by Mr. Ruscha shows the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, built over the La Brea Tar Pits, on fire. A maquette by Christo shows the Modern under wraps, and Komar and Melamid's paintings depict it and the Guggenheim in ruins. Quietly optimistic, Mr. Wall's illuminated Cibachrome image "Restoration" shows a panoramic history painting of the Franco-Prussian War being tended to by a team of conservators.
The last work in this rewarding exhibition is also the oldest, Hubert Robert's late-18th-century oil study for an imaginary scene of the Louvre's Grand Galerie in ruins. Like the large version, this work is in the Louvre's collection, making it an early instance of site-specific art. As such, it marks the beginning of a very fruitful relationship.
"Museum as Muse: Artists Reflect" opens on Sunday at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street, Manhattan, and remains there through June 1.

HEADLINE: U.S. Deficit for 1998 Shatters the Old Record

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 11

 BODY:
The deficit in the broadest measure of United States trade soared to a record in 1998 as exports sagged in the midst of a sharp slowdown in the global economy, the Government said today.
The current-account deficit swelled last year by $78.23 billion, to a record $233.45 billion, the Commerce Department reported. The previous record was $168 billion, set in 1987. 
 But the gap narrowed in the final three months last year, with its first quarterly drop in a year and a half.
It totaled $63.77 billion in the fourth quarter, down from $65.69 billion in the third quarter.
Still, the fourth-quarter deficit was larger than the $59.7 billion gap many economists had expected.
The current account measures trade in merchandise and services as well as investment flows between countries.
Exports last year suffered as crises in Asia and many emerging economies depressed demand for goods and services from the United States. But as the domestic economy proved surprisingly robust despite turmoil elsewhere, consumers snapped up cheaper goods from abroad, causing imports to soar.
Some of the current-account improvement at the end of last year resulted from a huge inflow of capital into United States stock and bond markets as nervous global investors fled turbulence elsewhere and sought a haven in the United States.
Total capital inflows increased nearly twofold, to $183.1 billion, in the fourth quarter from $98.7 billion in the third quarter. Net foreign purchases of United States bonds totaled $24.3 billion, compared with $1.4 billion in the third quarter. Net purchases of stocks grew to $8.3 billion from $5.5 billion.

HEADLINE: Retail Sales in U.S. Climbed For Seventh Consecutive Month

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 11

 BODY:
Consumers went on a spending spree in February, snapping up new cars, clothing and furniture, the Government said today in a report showing a still-vigorous expansion despite a weak global economy.
The Commerce Department said total retail sales jumped nine-tenths of a percent, to a seasonally adjusted $236.47 billion, after a 1 percent rise in January. The January figure was revised upward steeply from the previously reported two-tenths of a percent gain. 
 February marked the seventh consecutive month in which retail sales grew, adding powerful momentum to a nearly eight-year-old expansion since the last recession ended in March 1991.
The release of the data helped fuel a powerful rally on Wall Street into record territory as dealers saw the retail figures reinforcing other recent upbeat news on the economy.
Some analysts said robust spending might make Federal Reserve officials uneasy about potential price rises, but only moderately so, since other gauges of activity show only muted inflation.
"The real issue here is whether we may be seeing the last bunch of really strong numbers on the economy, as I think we might," said Robert Dederick, economic consultant to the Northern Trust Company in Chicago.
In a separate report, the Labor Department also reported on jobless benefit claims, which rose only a scant 1,000, to 289,000 in the week ended Saturday. The weekly figures have been under 300,000 for six consecutive weeks, indicating plenty of jobs in the world's largest economy.
Every major category of goods posted sales increases last month. Auto-dealer sales, which account for one-quarter of retail business, climbed 1.8 percent, to $59.38 billion, after a seven-tenths of a percent rise in January. Even excluding automobiles, February retail sales increased six-tenths of a percent after a 1.1 percent surge in January.
Sales of building materials climbed 1.2 percent, to $15 billion, following a 1.6 percent increase in January and general merchandise stores posted a half a percent gain in business, to $31.23 billion, after a 2.6 percent jump in January.
Clothing-store sales grew by 1 percent last month, to $10.92 billion, after a huge 3.7 percent increase in January. Even gasoline sales increased, despite generally lower prices, with February sales growing by eight-tenths of a percent, to $12.51 billion, reversing a three-tenths of a percent decline in January.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES;
Resignationof German Official Pushes Euro Up Against the Dollar

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The euro rose against the dollar yesterday as traders said that the resignation of the German Finance Minister, Oskar Lafontaine, would ease the economic change that Europe needs to revive growth.
"This is just what the euro needed," said Maureen MacFarland, who helps manage $1 billion at the MacKay Shields Financial Corporation and who recently bought euros. "It's good news because it means a shift from center-left policies to a more responsible stance as far as capital markets are concerned." 
 In New York, the euro rose to $1.1023, from $1.0940 on Wednesday. Still, the single currency is down almost 6 percent since its introduction on Jan. 1, with some citing their expectation of slowing growth in the 11-nation euro zone.
The dollar's decline against the euro drove it down against the Japanese yen, taking it to 119.33 yen, from 119.88 on Wednesday. Earlier, the dollar rose as high as 121.08 yen amid speculation that Japan opposes the yen's 2.5 percent gain over the last week because it hurts efforts to revive its economy.
A German Government statement gave no reason for the departure by Mr. Lafontaine, who also quit as chairman of the governing Social Democratic Party. His decision followed a report in the newspaper Die Welt that Chancellor Gerhard Schroder threatened to resign at a Cabinet meeting. A Government spokesman denied the report.
Central bankers had complained that Mr. Lafontaine's repeated lobbying for a cut in the European Central Bank's benchmark interest rate, now at 3 percent, undermined the bank's independence, possibly leading the bankers to dig in their heels.
"You get rid of somebody that isn't considered a free-market thinker and that's good for the euro," said Bob Lynch, a currency strategist at Paribas. "Traders didn't like the Socialist side of his policies, which emphasized government involvement in markets."

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
Condominium Developers Expand Boundaries of West Village

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
An 11-story, 9-unit condominium loft building is rising on what was once a weed-choked lot at 495 West Street at the western edge of Greenwich Village. Not far away, at 359 West 11th Street, a 10-story, 25-unit condominium will soon take shape where an old garage once stood.
The projects are the latest of six condominium structures, including the renovation of a 19th-century industrial building, that were recently completed or started, ending a 10-year dry spell of construction in the West Village. All told, they will produce 209 lofts and apartments, and at least 3 more projects, with 10 to 25 units each, are planned. 
Most of the activity began 18 months ago in an area west of Washington Street to West Street, running from Horatio Street south to Leroy Street, just a few blocks south of the Gansevoort meatpacking district, considered the last bastion for development in the West Village.
Arthur Strickler, district manager for Community Board 2, which guides growth in the area, said improvements to the West Side Highway and the planned Hudson River Park had helped attract developers to the neighborhood's western fringe. Because the area is outside the Greenwich Village Historic District, east of Washington Street, it does not face restrictions on development, like height limits, that accompany historic-district designation.
"The boundaries of the West Village," said Pamela Liebman, managing partner at the Corcoran Group, a Manhattan brokerage, "are expanding due to the demand for housing, especially condominiums, which are limited, and buyers' willingness to go beyond a neighborhood's traditional borders to find it."
The push to condominiums is also being stoked by a strong economy and favorable mortgage rates, as well as the lack of rentals and the high rents for those units available, which are encouraging people to buy, said Helene Luchnick, senior vice president at Douglas Elliman, another Manhattan brokerage.
Though the projects are smaller than their earlier counterparts -- mainly because of the size of development sites -- they offer apartments that are larger or seem bigger because they have high ceilings and many windows, she said.
The condominium apartments that are now or are soon to be under construction in the area range from 637 to 2,536 square feet. The lofts have 1,550 to 5,000 square feet.
The demand is being generated by professional couples and families from the Upper East and Upper West Sides, who are migrating downtown for more space, said Roberta Benzilio, executive vice president at the William B. May Company brokerage and manager of its West Village office. It is also coming from local residents seeking to trade up or switch from renting to owning, she said.
The demand is pushing up prices. The May brokerage puts the average sale price of condominiums in the West Village at $500 a square foot, up from $460 a foot last year, with luxury units selling at up to $700 a square foot.
Developers of projects that are nearing completion of their sales campaigns said they had increased prices three to four times in response to the market. For instance, since sales began last May at a building at 99 Jane Street, which with 84 apartments is the largest of the new projects, prices were increased 4 times, for an overall average rise of 10 percent, according to the developer, the Rockrose Development Corporation.
Prices for the units, with 1,193 to 2,321 square feet, are $500,000 to $1.5 million, or an average of $575 a square foot. Two apartments remain unsold, said Kevin P. Singleton, a vice president at Rockrose.
Brokers said that the demand for condominiums would continue and that the market would absorb the units. But Mr. Strickler of Community Board 2, noting that most of the projects were not in the landmark district, said concerns persisted among some local residents that the western-edge neighborhood would become crowded with tall buildings. His board and local business and civic groups are continuing to push for the creation of a waterfront historic district to help preserve the neighborhood's character.
Meanwhile, construction continues. The building at 495 West Street, across the West Side Highway from the river, will contain full-floor lofts, each with 3,300 square feet, on its first seven stories, which will be clad with blond and chocolate brick.
The top four floors, which are set back and faced with blond brick, will house two duplex penthouses, each with 5,000 square feet and a private terrace or rooftop deck.
The project, to be completed in June, is being developed by Tamarkin Architecture and Development of Manhattan.
All of the lofts will have 10 1/2-foot-high ceilings and will be offered as unfinished space, allowing buyers to design their own units.
The lofts will be priced at $950,000 to $3.8 million, with common charges, including taxes, of $1,000 to $4,600 a month. Sales are expected to start in 30 to 60 days.
The building at 359 West 11th will be constructed over the next 11 months by the Rockland Companies of Manhattan. The 25 one- to four-bedroom apartments, including two duplex penthouses, will have 673 to 2,536 square feet and some will be able to be combined. Prices are expected to range from $275,000 to $1.9 million.

HEADLINE: Help for the Uninsured May Rest in Tax Code

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 11

 BODY:
Not since the demise of the Clinton Administration plan to overhaul the nation's health care system have Americans without health insurance, now more than 43 million people, received so much attention.
With the post-impeachment Congress determined to demonstrate interest in domestic policy, and with lobbyists of all stripes trying to influence the health insurance debate, the long-overlooked uninsured are suddenly "hot." 
 The road to any enactment of legislation providing them coverage will be complicated, with many Republicans focused on marketplace solutions, and some Democrats on marketplace shortcomings. But across much of the political spectrum, a bit of consensus on an approach is developing.
Rather than start a whole new Government insurance program or expand the old ones -- Medicaid and the already overburdened Medicare -- Republican leaders, a number of Democrats and an array of powerful interest groups are looking for solutions in the tax system. Proposals receiving serious consideration on Capitol Hill would give millions of working families, which account for the bulk of the uninsured, tax breaks to buy health insurance.
Already this year, Republicans and Democrats alike have introduced at least six bills that would let the nation's three million self-employed workers immediately deduct the full cost of insurance. The bills would speed a phase-in that allows the self-employed to deduct 45 percent of premiums this year, a break that under current tax law escalates very gradually and does not reach 100 percent deduction until 2007.
In addition to those measures, others now pending would offer tax credits (distinct from a deduction in that they are subtracted from the tax bill itself, rather than just from the income on which the tax is based). For instance, Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the House majority leader, plans to introduce legislation this spring to give uninsured workers and their families an annual tax credit tentatively set at $800 per adult and $400 per child, to a maximum of $2,400, to buy insurance.
Under the Armey bill, the credits would even be "refundable" to the poorest workers, who earn too little to pay much or, often, any income tax. With a refundable credit, an individual worker whose tax would ordinarily be $500, for instance, would keep that amount and be sent $300 more by the Government, giving him $800 to pay for all or a part of his annual premium.
Even some Democrats who agree with Mr. Armey on little else are prepared to go along with credits, hopeful that by extending coverage to more people, they can move the nation a step closer to the goal of universal coverage that eluded President Clinton in 1994.
But others, like Representative Pete Stark of California, the ranking Democrat on the House Ways and Means Subcommittee on Health, are skeptical that the proposals now under consideration offer meaningful help. Mr. Armey's maximum credit of $2,400, for instance, would pay less than half the annual premium that insurers require of many families.
Whatever the merits of the proposals, there is little disagreement that the issue's time has come. "It's a very hot topic right now," said Eugene Steurele, a tax policy expert at the Urban Institute.
Some of the impetus to deal now with the problem stems from projections of more than a decade of Federal budget surpluses ahead. "Why not return some of it in a way that also helps alleviate the crisis of the uninsured?" Mr. Armey wrote to colleagues in January.
Weighing in with tax-break ideas of their own are a score of prominent lobbying groups and policy research organizations, running the gamut from the Heritage Foundation, the Cato Institute and the National Center for Policy Analysis on the right to the Progressive Policy Institute, a group of moderate Democrats. Similarly the American Medical Association (an emphatic proponent of strictly regulating health maintenance organizations) and the United States Chamber of Commerce (an emphatic opponent) joined last month to promote the idea of tax credits.
The concepts under discussion would be in keeping with a longtime Federal practice of using the tax code as an instrument of social policy. A provision in President Clinton's current budget proposal, for instance, offers $1,000 tax credits to help pay for long-term care.
But skeptics like Congressman Stark insist that the uninsured poor would find the health care credits too small to be of much appeal -- to say nothing of deductions, which favor people in high tax brackets and are all but meaningless to those who earn so little that they pay virtually no income tax.
"We're open to it," Chris Jennings, a White House health policy official, said of the tax credit notion, but "we have not found the model" that could be simply and fairly administered and be generous enough to reach large numbers of people.
Congressional critics of the Armey approach are perhaps most heatedly opposed to a Republican idea that would ultimately offer tax credits to all, so that they could do their own health insurance shopping. Mr. Stark says employers would use the availability of those credits as a rationale to stop providing benefits, which in many cases would be more generous than those that could be bought with the credits. "Tell me," he said, "why every employer wouldn't drop health insurance in a New York minute."
Indeed, Democrats who have little argument with "targeted" credits, aimed specifically at the poor, see broader credits that might undercut the employer-based insurance system as a danger that would leave workers vulnerable to the vagaries of the marketplace free-for-all.
More generally, Henry J. Aaron, senior fellow and budget economist at the Brookings Institution, finds little promise in using the tax system to steer consumers into the marketplace for coverage.
"It's part of the Zeitgeist," Mr. Aaron said of the emerging consensus. "We are into market solutions -- vouchers in education, privatizing Social Security. Not to be talking about tax credits for health care" would seem like "a gross omission."
"But I don't think it's got any future," he said, adding that unless Congress created a big regulatory apparatus like the one envisioned in the long-dead Clinton plan, insurers and H.M.O.'s would pick and choose among consumers, setting premiums low to attract the young and healthy and prohibitively high for older and sicker workers.
Ranit Schmelzer, a spokeswoman for the Senate Democratic leader, Tom Daschle of South Dakota, agreed that "a lot of things have to be fixed in the individual market" before a tax-break approach could be enacted. She said she did not see tax credits or vouchers "as something that has a lot of traction this year."
Still, the bills keep coming, and their details vary widely. Representative Jim McDermott of Washington, a doctor who is a Democratic member of the Federal commission on the future of Medicare, would give tax credits to cover 30 percent of the insurance premiums of individuals with incomes up to $25,000 and families with incomes up to $40,000.
Senator Barbara Boxer, Democrat of California, has drafted a bill that would allow a deduction of up to $2,000 to each working taxpayer who buys health insurance privately.
At the extreme is the legislation planned by Representative Bill Thomas of California, chairman of the House Ways and Means Subcommittee on Health. He says he will offer a bill this year to jettison the entire employer-based insurance system, which covers close to two-thirds of all workers. Mr Thomas's goal is shared by Mr. Armey, who acknowledges that as a political matter, it is unattainable any time soon.
Under the current system, Mr. Thomas complains, Congress gives tax breaks to businesses that provide insurance benefits to their workers, and the Government allows the businesses to pass the breaks on to their employees. (That is, the employees are not taxed on the benefits.)
In some cases, companies pay a worker's entire premium; more often they pay 60 to 80 percent. But more than 18 percent of all workers, 24.6 million of them, went without health insurance in 1997, according to the nonpartisan Employee Benefit Research Institute. And about half of those 24.6 million earned less than $30,000, leaving few with enough to buy insurance on their own.
"How can we provide 100 percent coverage for some workers," Mr. Thomas said, "when others have zero? That's crazy."
So he would take away the business tax break and build a new system based on tax breaks to individuals, who would buy their own insurance. "I want to change the whole system," he said. "You have to go back to square one and rethink it."

HEADLINE: Nike Critic Praises Gains in Air Quality at Vietnam Factory

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
A prominent critic who badly hurt Nike's image when he exposed unsafe conditions at one of its factories in Vietnam in 1997 issued a report yesterday that gave the footwear giant high marks for improving air quality at the plant, although he said some significant problems remained.
After disclosing 18 months ago that the air in parts of the plant had levels of cancer-causing substances that exceeded local standards by 177 times, the critic, Dara O'Rourke, applauded the factory for improving ventilation, reducing the use of hazardous chemicals and training managers on safety issues. 
 Mr. O'Rourke, an environmental researcher at the University of California at Berkeley, praised Nike for a turnaround, noting that it was substituting less harmful chemicals for dangerous ones and had taken the unusual step of allowing a critic like him to inspect the factory, which is outside Ho Chi Minh City. Nike, the world's largest athletic shoe company, let Mr. O'Rourke visit the factory in December while he was in Vietnam working as a consultant for the United Nations Industrial Development Organization.
"There have been important improvements, but I don't want to say Nike has solved all its problems," Mr. O'Rourke said in an interview.
Mr. O'Rourke criticized the factory, which is owned and operated by a Korean contractor, for making insufficient use of protective equipment like masks and gloves and for having excessive heat and noise in parts of the plant, which has 9,200 workers.
Dusty Kidd, Nike's director of labor relations, said in an interview that the Tae Kwang Vina factory was an average factory, not a model one, and that the improvements there were similar to those at Nike factories throughout Asia. To prove that conditions have improved at other Nike factories, Mr. Kidd said Nike would allow Mr. O'Rourke to visit any of its 37 footwear factories in Asia.
Global Exchange, a human rights group that has been Nike's harshest and most persistent critic, issued a statement yesterday praising the company for improving conditions and for letting an outside monitor inspect the factory.
Medea Benjamin, the group's co-director, said, "This is certainly an astounding transformation for a company that once treated independent monitoring as a public relations exercise, limiting factory access to people they thought would write favorable reports."
In November 1997, Mr. O'Rourke made public a damning inspection report about the Vietnam factory, leaked to him by a disgruntled employee, that the accounting firm Ernst & Young had prepared for Nike's internal use. That report said that 77 percent of the factory's workers reported respiratory problems in 1996 and that employees worked 65 hours a week, far more than Vietnamese law allowed. Hours have since been reduced to about 45 a week.
Much of Nike's effort to improve air quality has involved reducing the use of petroleum-based chemicals -- known as volatile organic compounds -- used in adhesives, solvents and primers. These chemicals include toluene, which causes damage to the liver, kidneys and central nervous system, and acetone, which causes respiratory problems. Nike is relying instead on water-based chemicals because they are considerably less dangerous when they evaporate, although Mr. O'Rourke called for studying the health effects of these chemicals.
Yesterday's report, which was written Mr. O'Rourke and Garrett Brown, an occupational safety expert, said the factory "has implemented important changes over the past 18 months which appear to have significantly reduced worker exposures to toxic solvents, adhesives and other chemicals."
Mr. Kidd said Nike had cut its use of volatile organic compounds to 70 grams for every pair of shoes from 340 grams three years ago. He said that converting to water-based chemicals had cost millions of dollars but but that because 30 percent less of these chemicals are needed than the petroleum-based ones, Nike's operating costs had been cut by more than $10 million a year.
Mr. O'Rourke's report noted that 18 percent of workers at the Vietnam factory reported nose and throat illnesses last year, down from 86 percent in 1997 and 77 percent in 1996. But his report said it was puzzling that the number of workers going to the factory's clinic for what they said were respiratory problems was about the same last year as in 1997. Mr. O'Rourke called on Nike to more closely monitor how many workers have respiratory problems.
His report noted that several rooms with heavy equipment had dangerously high noise levels and that the temperature in the plant often exceeded 98 degrees. He complained that many workers did not use ear plugs and that the cotton masks and gloves many workers used were inadequate to protect them from the chemicals with which they work.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Oil Ministers Study Export Cuts to Aid Prices

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
Oil ministers from five major oil producing nations met in the Netherlands yesterday in an effort to cut crude oil exports of up to two million barrels a day aimed at further bolstering the recent modest recovery in crude oil prices.
The discussions were taking place outside The Hague and included oil ministers from Saudi Arabia, Iran, Venezuela and Algeria, which are members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, as well as with Mexico. 
 The ministers broke up yesterday without issuing a statement and will meet again today.
Mexico joined Saudi Arabia and Venezuela last spring in an alliance to push through production cuts of 2.6 million barrels a day in the face of a 40 percent wholesale price decline last year. The glut of crude oil helped keep down gasoline prices, which normally rise in the spring as demand increases. Without the efforts of the producers, some analysts said, crude oil prices would have plunged even further.
Ali bin Ibrahim al-Naimi, the oil minister of Saudi Arabia, has said that the ministers would seek to hammer out a new accord between OPEC and non-OPEC producers that would result in substantial new cuts.
Prices of crude oil, which have rebounded by about $3.30 a barrel since mid-February, fell yesterday after surging on Wednesday.
Brent crude oil for April delivery fell by 9 cents, closing at $12.37 a barrel on the International Petroleum Exchange.
The price of crude oil for April delivery fell 38 cents, or 2.6 percent, to close at $14.31 on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
World demand has been rising slightly and production in such countries in the United States has dropped as wells have been shut because of low prices. The high level of inventories has also begun to drop.
But Ann-Louise Hittle, the director of international petroleum at Cambridge Energy Associates, an energy consulting group in Cambridge, Mass., cautioned that if further cuts were not made, inventories would again begin to build in the second quarter.
"There's going to be some downward pressure on prices," she added.
One problem had been that OPEC and the countries cooperating with it had failed to reach last year's goal of cutting 2.6 million barrels a day. In February they had achieved only about 79 percent of the pledged cut, according to a survey made by Bloomberg.
The current effort to cut production further is being led by Saudi Arabia, which is the world's largest oil exporter. Like many other major oil producers, its economy has been hit hard by the falling prices.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Banks Pledgeto Help Brazil

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Banks including Chase Manhattan, Citigroup Inc. and J. P. Morgan & Company pledged yesterday to stop cutting credit lines to Brazil, offering hope the country can stem an outflow of money that has caused its currency to plunge 37 percent since January.
Brazil has lost $19 billion in short-term finance since August, first because of a default by Russia and later because of its devaluation of its currency, the real. That has left the Government and companies in Brazil starved for cash as they struggle to repay debt and climb out of recession. 
 The pledge was made during a meeting in New York with Arminio Fraga, the recently appointed central bank chief. The banks agreed to maintain their interbank loans and trade lines at Feb. 28 levels through Aug. 31.
"I think as this program is successfully implemented the banks will voluntarily increase their lines" of credit, said William Rhodes, the vice chairman of Citibank. He was asked by the Brazilian Government to coordinate efforts to get other creditor banks to also keep their credit lines to February levels.
Mr. Fraga said the economic plan he presented to bankers was the same that Brazil agreed to with the International Monetary Fund last week.

HEADLINE: Will East Meet West in Europe? Cost of Union Is a Big Barrier

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: PARIS, March 11

 BODY:
Now that Poland, the Czech Republic and Hungary are joining the NATO alliance, perhaps the European Union might be less afraid about letting them in too, President Vaclav Havel of the Czech Republic observed during a recent swing through Western Europe.
"The curtain that came down 50 years ago was ripped away 10 years ago, but in certain respects, it still exists as a kind of psychological barrier," he said recently. "Admission into NATO is a significant step, because we see that the West is not afraid of us." 
 Ten years after the collapse of the Iron Curtain, the most important barrier still separating the east of Europe from the more fortunate west is money.
While the Atlantic alliance, led by the United States, is willing to see the first three formerly Communist countries as full partners, the European Union is still years away from admitting any of them.
Among the most important reasons are the costs.
According to the accession agreements they have worked out with the alliance, Poland, the Czech Republic and Hungary together will be assessed only about $65 million a year for NATO programs, according to allied officials in Brussels.
But offsetting this, the alliance plans to put $150 million a year for the next 10 years into helping the three countries improve military airfields, communications networks and air defenses they had built as members of the Warsaw Pact.
Poland plans to raise its military budget to $3.3 billion this year, half a billion more than in 1997, while the Czech Republic and Hungary plan to spend $1.2 billion and $745 million in 1999, respectively.
All three new members might well have been tempted to spend more on their militaries if they were not entering the collective security of NATO, supporters of expansion say. Skeptics say that NATO's cost estimates are much too low.
But joining NATO looks almost easy compared with the costs and the complexities of joining the European Union.
Letting poorer countries from Eastern Europe join the European Union will cost both new and old members of that organization money, though hardly as much as the United States spent after World War II in the Marshall Plan.
"The West spent a lot on armament," Gyorgy Konrad, a Hungarian writer, lamented at a recent gathering of central European and western policy makers and intellectuals in Berlin. "It appears not to want to spend a lot on solidarity."
Instead, starting with Germany, the cry from the rich but unemployment-plagued European countries is to spend less, not more, on items like farm programs, which cost Europe nearly $44 billion last year, 45 percent of the total European Union budget.
After wrangling all winter between Germany and France, European agriculture ministers finally agreed today, after negotiating all night, to cut price supports for grain, beef and dairy products by 15 to 20 percent over the next few years. But experts believe more changes are necessary before countries like Poland, with tens of thousands of small farmers, join the system.
The agricultural policy was set up at the end of the 1950's, when German leaders still felt guilty about what the Nazis had done to France. The goal was to keep French farmers, then far more numerous than they are now, prosperous while German industry got free access to French and other European markets.
But Chancellor Gerhard Schroder was not even alive during World War II, and questions why Germany pays more in farm support programs than it receives. Now, like many of his generation, he does not see why Germany should be asked to foot more than its share of the European bill.
Spain, Portugal, and Italy are fighting proposed cuts in European regional infrastructure investment programs. And almost all countries are fighting changes in cumbersome decision-making procedures that, with 15 member states, often make European Union meetings last all night.
Without change, European leaders keep saying, new members could bring only total gridlock or bankruptcy. But change will surely take a few more all-night meetings like a special European summit conference planned later this month in Berlin, the third such meeting since last fall.
Hans van den Broek, the European commissioner for foreign affairs, said that the European Union was spending $1.6 billion a year helping prospective new members get ready. "The candidates have to be able to adopt and, more importantly, implement some 80,000 pages of laws," he said.
All this will take time, he says, time the formerly Communist countries also need to make sure their economies are not overwhelmed and crushed by more powerful Western ones when they join the European Union and trade barriers come down.
At this rate, even Mr. Havel's target of 2002 for membership for the Czech Republic looks optimistic.
"European leaders spent more time at their summit in Vienna in December talking about ways to postpone abolishing duty-free shops next year than they did about the prospect of admitting countries from Eastern Europe," said the French philosopher Andre Glucksmann. "I think we have wasted 10 years."

HEADLINE: Investment Banks Must Soothe Asian Sensibilities

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, March 11

 BODY:
Investment banks have always struggled to reconcile their roles as tough-minded analysts and smooth-talking salespeople. Nowhere is this truer than in Asia, where the lines between government and business can be blurry and the opportunities to offend both are legion.
The regional division of Goldman, Sachs & Company has become the latest to stumble in this minefield. The investment firm recently felt obliged to apologize to Thailand after one of its reports drove down the shares of the nation's largest bank and angered the Finance Minister. 
 "All of us at Goldman Sachs deeply regret the controversial media attention that our 'Market Flash' dated February 8th subsequently generated in the Thai press," said the president of Goldman Sachs Asia, Philip Murphy, in a letter last month to the Finance Minister, Tarrin Nimmanahaeminda.
In that report to clients, Goldman's chief Asian banking analyst, Roy Ramos, said that Mr. Tarrin viewed Bangkok Bank as the "biggest risk factor in Thailand's banking system." After Mr. Tarrin denied saying that, Mr. Ramos conceded that the characterization was his own.
Like most of its competitors, Goldman has hastened to make amends, rather than risk losing business from either the Government or private companies, which are loath to use a bank that is in disfavor.
Eugene K. Galbraith, former head of research at ABN Amro in Hong Kong, remarked, "Since the nexus of government and business is so much closer in Asia than in Europe or the U.S., the consequences of offending the Government are much greater."
While officials can be thin-skinned in any Asian country, bankers feel this most acutely in dealings with China. Almost every major firm here can tell of a chill wind from Beijing after they published reports critical of the economy or of politically connected companies.
In one of the most prominent examples, Morgan Stanley ran afoul of Beijing when the firm's chief strategist, Barton M. Biggs, advised clients in October 1997 to steer clear of the Hong Kong stock market. (He had unkind words for some other Asian markets, too.)
The report outraged Wang Qishan, who was then chairman of a leading Chinese bank that played a role in the sale of shares in China Telecom. Mr. Wang is now the executive vice governor of Guangdong province.
Last May, Shandong International Power Development, a Government-controlled company, dismissed Morgan Stanley as its investment banker. A spokesman for the investment bank said he doubted that there was a direct link between the Biggs report and the bank's action, though he confirmed China's hard feelings.
More recently, the head of China research at HSBC Holdings resigned after clashing with his superiors over his forecast for economic growth in China in 1999. The researcher, Joe Zhang, had projected that China's gross domestic product would grow only 3 percent this year. Recent Chinese growth has approached 10 percent in some years, and this year's official projection is for 7 percent growth.
The subdued forecast angered officials in Beijing, who expressed their objections to HSBC's group chairman, John Bond, according to two executives at the banking group. When Mr. Zhang refused to endorse a more optimistic outlook, these people said, he was forced out. At the time, HSBC's investment banking unit was helping to underwrite a $1 billion bond issue by the Chinese Government.
HSBC has declined to discuss Mr. Zhang's departure. But in an interview late last month, the group chief executive, Keith R. Whitson, said: "We are in 79 countries around the world. By definition, that means we are a guest in 78. And we believe in behaving as guests should behave."
Such a gentlemanly approach comes more easily to commercial banks like HSBC than to investment banking firms like Goldman. As lenders of capital rather than wooers and deal financiers, they rely less on their research to market themselves. Goldman, by contrast, uses star analysts like Mr. Ramos to lure clients.
Mr. Ramos, who joined Goldman in 1984, was ranked as the No. 1 banking analyst in Asia by Asia Money magazine in 1998. A soft-spoken former executive at Mellon Bank, he enjoys easy access to finance ministers.
That access may have landed him in trouble. It was after a meeting with Mr. Tarrin on Feb. 5 that Mr. Ramos issued a downbeat report on Bangkok Bank. The remarks attributed to Mr. Tarrin scared investors, and the bank's shares plunged 8.1 percent after the report became public.
Executives at Goldman said Mr. Ramos's report had been scrutinized by lawyers, compliance officers and the head of research before it was released. But they said the reviewers would not generally question a senior analyst on the substance of talks with a Government official.
In Goldman's letter of apology, Mr. Murphy said Mr. Ramos admitted that he had, in effect, put his words in Mr. Tarrin's mouth.
Mr. Ramos was traveling in the United States and did not return a telephone call. Mr. Murphy also did not respond to requests for comment.
Peter Rose, a Goldman spokesman in Hong Kong, said, "We deeply regret the mischaracterization." But he added, "We were never asked to, nor did we, alter our conclusions on the Thai banking sector."
Another reason Goldman is so eager to resolve this dispute is that it may have inadvertently fed ammunition to Mr. Tarrin's critics. Opposition leaders have seized on the report as grist for their accusations that the Government wants to sell Thailand's troubled banks to foreigners.
Thai Parliament members are now considering whether to ask the Government to sever its relationship with Goldman. E. Gerald Corrigan, a Goldman partner and former president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, advises Mr. Tarrin. The firm also handled an $850 million stock offering for the Thai Farmers Bank.
If Goldman hopes to win more such assignments, it needs to persuade Thailand's business elite that it has not lost its friends in high places.

HEADLINE: 3 Fragments of Soviet Realm Joining NATO's Ranks Today

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WARSAW, March 11

 BODY:
When Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic formally join NATO on Friday, it will symbolize the return of three nations, and not merely their militaries, to the center of European civilization.
The Polish Foreign Minister, Bronislaw Geremek, a soulful historian of the medieval world, compares the importance of NATO accession to nothing less than Poland's conversion to Christianity nearly 1,000 years ago. 
President Aleksander Kwasniewski of Poland said enlarging the alliance brings an end to a divided Europe. "This is the most important moment in our history," he said.
For Vaclav Havel, the Czech President, who was jailed by the Communist regime, membership means that "we will have a solid security anchoring for the first time in our history, and an anchoring in the democratic world, in the world of protection of democratic values."
By their history and geography, these new members will help to protect and even promote those values. But NATO tenure requires high military spending and difficult choices at home just as the regional economy is cooling off. The Czechs are in recession, Hungary has a yawning budget deficit, and Poland's growth is expected to drop this year to 3.5 percent of economic output.
As the reality of membership looms -- together with the prospect of NATO's bombing Yugoslavia -- popular enthusiasm for the alliance has dropped in all three countries. Recent polls say some 60 percent of Poles and Hungarians favor membership now, down from over 80 percent a year ago, and just over 50 percent of Czechs, down from some 55 percent.
But all three governments remain enthusiastic about the alliance and committed to increased military spending. They are already contributing with peacekeepers, logistics and intelligence to the West's complicated efforts in the Balkans.
At first, these three countries will add little to NATO's military capabilities. In fact, they have just managed to meet the alliance's minimum military requirements for integrated air defense, security procedures and language training.
But few doubt that they will bring real military benefits to the alliance over the next 5 to 10 years as they make the slow shift from heavily armored forces top-heavy with officers to more mobile, flexible and smaller armies.
They are also eager to consolidate Western values at home, both to increase their own confidence and that of foreign investors. Their leaders welcome the moral standard NATO provides for their still turbulent post-Communist societies.
Six weeks before the alliance's 50th anniversary summit meeting in Washington, where the champagne and the rhetoric will overflow, members continue to argue about the organization's future.
But these three countries also bring a fresh dose of support to Washington's aims for redefining NATO's mission, officials of all three countries suggest. It was the United States, after all, that pushed their membership the hardest, a Polish official said.
"We want to be good Europeans," he said. "But more than anyone except perhaps the British, we understand how important it is to keep the Americans involved in Europe."
 
In the Service of NATO, An End to Servility
For the militaries of all three nations, NATO membership is also a chance to pacify, if not bury, some ghosts. While some officers feel they are simply exchanging the language of one empire for another, most recognize that it is a voluntary alliance that works by consensus.
Col. Petr Vlcnovsky, who commands a Czech air defense brigade, said that membership in the Warsaw Pact meant a depressing servility to Moscow's orders. A military career, he said, commanded little social respect. "We had no opportunity to make decisions as a sovereign state," he said. "Now we can decide for ourselves, as a full partner in NATO committees."
In Poland, the military, like the Roman Catholic Church, is at the center of its national identity, and the Hungarians, too, have an important military tradition. While there is some truth to "The Good Soldier Schweik" notion of the Czech military man -- survival despite apparent bungling in 300 years of occupation -- Czech soldiers have served with distinction alongside the British in Bosnia and the Americans in the Persian Gulf.
Such successes -- like Poland's peacekeeping efforts around the world and Hungary's engineering battalion, which has rebuilt 84 bridges in four years in Bosnia -- will go a long way to raise the stature of the military within society, says Tamas Wachsler, the young State Secretary of the Hungarian Defense Ministry.
"The key to rebuilding the overall character and prestige of the military is to give it teeth," he said. "NATO helps, not just by providing world standards but by opening up international careers to officers."
By insisting on civilian control over the military, the alliance makes it easier to reform these armies and subordinate them to popular will, a senior Polish official said.
"Poland has never before had a modern democracy, and the military, like the church, has never been a democratic institution in Poland," he said. "The real test for NATO -- and for Poland -- is how to deal with undemocratic institutions and make them compatible with democracy."
That process has started. Of Poland's 130 generals, fewer than 10 had the rank before 1989. "But it will also take time," the senior official said.
 
Military Demand Met, But Much Is Still to Do
Deep in a bunker under the Czech town of Stara Boleslav, there is a sophisticated Warsaw Pact air defense command headquarters that has been transformed with American aid into an alliance installation that keeps watch over Czech airspace.
There are similar centers in Poland and Hungary, and the American ambassadors to all three countries talk enthusiastically about their "Dr. Strangelove" quality, with their huge overhead screens and sophisticated computers. The installations will also help make commercial air travel safer for civilians.
All three centers opened only last month, but they were the most crucial military requirement for joining NATO. The new members could hardly be defended without an integrated air defense system, coupled with 24-hour patrols and jet fighters with a rapid reaction capability.
"That said," noted a senior military attache for a Western country, "all the air crews need better tactics, training and doctrine." Officials in all three countries expressed concern that while military spending was increasing, the money going to operations and training, especially for combat pilots, was insufficient or dropping. Except for the immediate front-line pilots, training hours are well below NATO standards.
Hungary, for instance, gives 27 pilots it must have for air defense NATO's standard of 100 hours of training, while other pilots currently get only one hour; last November, some 40 Polish pilots quit over insufficient training.
While all three countries have met the minimum military requirements, the training issue is a good example of the significant work that remains to be done to make membership less hollow. But this was the alliance's choice, argues a senior Hungarian official.
"NATO rightly decided to invite key countries to join, provide them minimum requirements to reach in a short term, and work with them to bring them up to speed," he said. "The chances of a significant NATO military operation are very small so it's O.K. to have some countries below NATO standards now, under the assumption they will reach them in five years."
Other minimum requirements the three countries worked to meet include sometimes humdrum compatibility issues like communications equipment, adapter nozzles for fuel lines and security procedures, so Western intelligence can be shared.
Outside Poland's sprawling old Defense Ministry headquarters, for instance, there are new gates and electronically controlled turnstiles, while new locks, safes and procedures have been installed in all three countries for handling NATO secrets.
Even here, the past intercedes, but in an ironic way. The Czechs were slow to vet enough officers to take up positions in the alliance's headquarters in Brussels or to handle NATO papers. The reason was a recent Czech security law requiring psychological exams and other queries that go beyond the alliance's standards.
 
The Swords of the British Needed Special Approval
The Czechs were so scarred by the misuse of security and the extent of collaboration with the secret police under the Communist regime that they set very high standards. "In the long run, that will benefit us," said Petr Necas, chairman of Parliament's Defense and Security Committee, reflecting lingering concerns within NATO about intelligence-sharing with former Communist militaries.
In Hungary, similarly, two-thirds of those elected to Parliament must vote to allow Hungarian troops to operate outside the country. Even for Friday's celebration for joining the alliance, Parliament had to vote to allow British Grenadiers to bring their ceremonial swords into the country.
These laws make it more complicated, but hardly impossible, to take part in NATO exercises, said Mr. Wachsler, the Defense Ministry State Secretary.
Another important requirement is training in English, the language commonly used by NATO, which has gone slowly in all three countries.
Colonel Vlcnovsky, the Czech commander, was interviewed in his advanced English class in an exquisite 14th-century castle in Komorni Hradek, near Brno. The castle was seized from a Nazi collaborator in 1945, and later served as a school for political commissars.
The classrooms are now used for some 90 students taking basic and advanced English. In one classroom, the words "body odor" were on the blackboard, an indication, the teacher said, that preparation for service abroad covered "many aspects of life."
For Colonel Vlcnovsky and his classmates, better English is a career-builder. "The chances of us fighting a war on our own territory now are very small compared to the possibility of serving abroad, in Bosnia or elsewhere," he said. "English is simply necessary for our future careers."
 
A Change in Mentality Is High on the Agenda
Despite the problems of transition, all three countries have worked with the alliance to insure that they are providing immediate resources and capabilities to the alliance.
The Hungarians have long provided Western access to the big Warsaw Pact air base at Taszar where several hundred American and other foreign troops handled Western deployments into Bosnia. They also permit NATO troops to be stationed there and to fly over Hungarian territory for surveillance of Serbia, Kosovo and the Albanian border. Hungary will also provide two brigades for NATO's rapid reaction force and a medical team with a hospital.
The Czechs specialize in defense against chemical and biological weapons and are providing a chemical defense company of about 140 people for immediate NATO service.
For their part, the Poles are providing an excellent antiterrorist unit, some of whose members already protect William Walker, the American diplomat who runs the international observers in Kosovo. They are providing an air assault brigade of paratroopers and some armored units, as well as 10,000 troops as part of a German-Danish-Polish mechanized corps.
But the biggest tasks are yet to come. All three countries need to modernize a Warsaw Pact structure that contained too many officers without enough initiative. They need to train a corps of noncommissioned officers, reduce the number of colonels by half and teach soldiers to make decisions.
Everyone agrees that changing mentality will be as difficult as finding the economic resources over the next 5 and 10 years to keep modernization on track. "The real question is staying power over time," a senior NATO official said.
Maj. Gen. Jaroslav Hudec, who directs Czech military modernization, said: "We've done our minimum requirements. Some will complain on March 12, but hourly it will be hard work for us, not just before joining NATO but afterward. We must all -- military officers and politicians -- continue to persuade everyone what must be done. We must move from a Warsaw Pact force to another kind, and it must be done for ourselves, for our nation, not just because of NATO."

HEADLINE: Clinton and Latin Leaders Turn to Immigration

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: ANTIGUA, Guatemala, March 11

 BODY:
President Clinton and a group of Central American leaders declared today that they would work among themselves and with the United States to reach "humane and permanent solutions" to the problems of illegal immigration.
The declaration was issued at a one-day meeting here that focused on reconstruction after a devastating autumn hurricane, development, trade and immigration. 
 The leaders also promised to accelerate efforts to assist one another in the economic and political transformation of the region after decades of strife and catastrophic natural disasters.
The meeting, at the end of a four-day visit by Mr. Clinton to the subcontinent, brought together Presidents Arnoldo Aleman of Nicaragua, Alvaro Arzu of Guatemala, Armando Calderon Sol of El Salvador, Leonel Fernandez Reyna of the Dominican Republic, Carlos Roberto Flores of Honduras and Miguel Angel Rodriguez Echeverria of Costa Rica, as well as Prime Minister Said Wilbert Musa of Belize.
They met at the Casa Santo Domingo, a hotel built around the ruins of a church and monastery built by Dominicans in the 16th century and largely destroyed by earthquakes in 1717 and 1773. This picturesque colonial town, in a valley formed by three volcanoes, was the capital of all of Central America until the 18th century.
At the opening of the session, Mr. Clinton noted that he was the first American President to visit Guatemala since Lyndon B. Johnson stopped briefly at the Guatemala City airport in the 60's. "This visit is long overdue," Mr. Clinton said. "More importantly, this moment in history is long overdue."
The Administration announced four small initiatives to foster growth and reconciliation. The Administration will provide $25 million to bolster the Guatemalan peace accord of 1996, including money for schools, small-business development, courts and local governments.
The Administration also plans to grant $25 million for environmental protection throughout the region, $11 million for disaster response and $8.2 million to eliminate child labor.
The meeting was marred by Mr. Clinton's inability to deliver a much larger package of hurricane relief, totaling $956 million, that has been held up by a dispute with Congress.
Central American leaders and a few protesters in El Salvador and Guatemala complained that United States immigration policy discriminated against some political refugees from the region.
Mr. Calderon Sol told Mr. Clinton on Wednesday that he did not feel that United States policy was justified, because refugees from El Salvador and Guatemala did not have the same rights to settle in the United States as those from Cuba and Nicaragua.
The United States is preparing to deport 1,000 Salvadorans who fled the devastation of Hurricane Mitch, while Washington seeks a way to let El Salvadoran political refugees remain in the United States.

Hurricane Aid Gains in House

HEADLINE: Lawmakers Want I.R.S. Help on Cruise Ships and Tax Laws

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS FRANTZ 

 BODY:
Saying the United States could be losing billions of dollars each year, two Democratic Congressmen asked the Internal Revenue Service yesterday to estimate how much foreign-owned cruise companies are saving because of tax code provisions that exempt them from income tax and other taxes.
The Congressmen, Peter A. DeFazio of Oregon and Gene Taylor of Mississippi, said in a letter to the I.R.S. Commissioner, Charles O. Rossotti, that they wanted the assessment because Congress might take up legislation later this year to expand access to United States ports by foreign-owned passenger ships. 
 Preliminary estimates from the Clinton Administration are that the tax provisions allow the industry to avoid billions of dollars a year in Federal taxes, Mr. DeFazio said.
"It appears that a large, growing and very profitable U.S.-based industry is escaping all of its Federal tax burden," Mr. DeFazio said in a telephone interview. "This is a basic issue of fairness."
Representatives of the cruise industry, which has annual revenues of about $10 billion, say that the unique tax exemption is part of international transportation law and that the industry pays millions of dollars a year in port fees and other charges. A new study for the industry found that it bought $6.6 billion worth of American goods and generated 176,433 jobs in 1997.
"We are very proud of the contribution which the cruise industry makes to the U.S. economy," said Cynthia A. Colenda, president of the International Council of Cruise Lines, the industry trade group in Washington.
Though the 17 major cruise lines are based in the United States and rely on American passengers, they are exempt from United States income tax and some other taxes because the companies are registered in foreign countries and their ships fly foreign flags. The countries in which those companies are registered do not have income tax.
An article last month in The New York Times described the tax benefits and said the Carnival Corporation, the world's largest cruise company, earned $2 billion in the last three years yet paid less than 1 percent in income taxes. The taxes were on revenue from hotels and tours in the United States. Carnival is based in Miami but registered in Panama.
Under longstanding tax law, to qualify for the income tax exemption, foreign cruise lines operating from an American port must visit a foreign destination before returning to the United States. But last year Congress debated permitting foreign ships to travel between United States ports without a foreign stop.
Some American port and tourism officials pushed for the change to increase tourism. The domestic cruise industry opposed it, arguing that American ships would have difficulty competing with foreign vessels that pay no taxes.
Mr. DeFazio, the ranking Democrat on the House Transportation and Infrastructure Committee's Coast Guard and Maritime Transportation subcommittee, said he expected the issue of expanding access to American ports to arise again.
Prospects for taxing foreign cruise companies appear slim despite some support. In January, Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader, called on the Administration to work with Congress to re-examine tax policies that might stifle the domestic cruise business.
Mr. DeFazio acknowledged that he faced a tough battle against the foreign cruise companies, which lobby effectively. "I've been told I'm walking into a buzz saw," he said.

HEADLINE: German Finance Aide Quits; European Markets Jubilant

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, March 11

 BODY:
After losing a power struggle over economic policy that had sent tremors across Europe for months, Germany's left-wing Finance Minister abruptly resigned today, and also quit as chairman of the ruling party.
The resignation by Oskar Lafontaine marked a stunning turn for Germany's new Chancellor, Gerhard Schroder, who defeated Helmut Kohl in elections last September but whose Government has seemed confused and adrift ever since. 
 The resignation has implications well beyond Germany. As one of Europe's most combative and ideological leaders, Mr. Lafontaine had almost single-handedly talked down the value of Europe's new single currency, the euro, with his unrelenting demands on the European Central Bank to lower interest rates.
He had also moved Germany, which accounts for more than one-quarter of Europe's economic output, toward a sharply left-wing direction that frequently clashed with Mr. Schroder's more pragmatic and pro-business instincts.
But Mr. Lafontaine has been unable to stimulate German economic growth, which has slowed to a crawl while unemployment has remained at more than 10 percent.
Financial markets in Europe reacted with thunderous approval within minutes of the resignation. The euro scored its biggest one-day jump in value since it was introduced in January. It climbed from just below $1.08 to $1.10, as investors bet that German growth could get a lift and that the European Central Bank would have more freedom to steer its own course. It is widely expected that German stocks would surge on Friday.
Mr. Lafontaine gave no reason for his departure, and Mr. Schroder appeared as surprised as everyone else tonight at the resignation. It was unclear whether the Chancellor would end up a loser or a winner after the dust clears.
On the one hand, the resignation clearly reflected the disarray in economic policy and Mr. Schroder's loss of credibility. German business leaders have expressed outrage over Mr. Lafontaine's plans to increase taxes, with some big companies even threatening to move operations out of the country. He had also raised hackles with American leaders, like Robert E. Rubin, the Treasury Secretary, by campaigning for controls over exchange rates.
At the same time, Mr. Schroder appeared to have eliminated a powerful rival. Mr. Lafontaine, a burly and garrulous politician who badly wanted to run for chancellor himself, wielded enormous power as the head of Germany's ruling Social Democratic Party. Although he could never match Mr. Schroder's charisma and flair for television, he commanded a loyalty among party traditionalists and among Germany's powerful labor unions, which were crucial to Mr. Schroder's victory.
Mr. Lafontaine deferred to Mr. Schroder last year, recognizing that he could never match Mr. Schroder's popularity with voters. But as finance minister, he quickly dominated German economic policy and muscled aside more pro-business moderates.
But tensions between the two had been rising. Last week, Mr. Schroder bypassed his finance minister by pledging to German insurance companies that he would limit their tax increase to about $5 billion a year.
He also began seeking out direct contacts with business leaders, soothing ruffled feathers in order to keep them from walking out of talks with the Government and unions to create jobs.
The hostility apparently erupted at a Cabinet meeting on Wednesday. According to a report today by the newspaper Die Welt, Mr. Schroder obliquely hinted about resigning himself if the Government did not stop antagonizing industry.
According to Die Welt, Mr. Schroder railed at "anti-business policies" that were "against the majority of the people" and said he might reach the point where he would "no longer assume responsbility for such a policy."
But people who were in the chancellory today said Mr. Schroder and his top lieutenants were genuinely shocked by Mr. Lafontaine's decision, which he conveyed in an icy letter one sentence long.
In a one-minute news conference tonight in which he refused to take any questions, Mr. Schroder said he was "taken aback" by the decision, while insisting that "the stability of the work of Government is not in question."
Both supporters and opponents speculated that Mr. Schroder might seek out a new coalition, perhaps with Germany's small liberal party, the Free Democrats.
"I am shocked," said Peter Siegel, chairman of the Social Democratic Party local branch in Limbach-Oberfrohna, near Berlin. "It was evident that differences between Lafontaine and Schroder would eventually surface. But everybody in the party had hoped that one could handle them in a professional way."
Hans-Olaf Henkel, president of the German Federation of Industry and one of Mr. Schroder's toughest critics, was elated. "This will give Schroder the maneuvering room to come up with policies that are more friendly to business and growth," he said.
That view was echoed by Theo Sommer, co-publisher of the liberal weekly Die Zeit, whose other co-publisher is Helmut Schmidt, Germany's Social Democratic Chancellor in the early 1980's.
"I am happy to see this, because they had lost five months by trying to do things without knowing how to go about it," said Mr. Sommer. Much of the blame, Mr. Sommer said, went straight to Mr. Lafontaine.
"He was steering the wrong course -- far too ideological, far too left-wing and too removed from the economic realities of the country," he said.
Some experts said Mr. Lafontaine brought Mr. Schroder invaluable political skills that he may soon miss badly. "It was Lafontaine who held the party together," said Oskar Niedermeyer, a political scientist at the Free University of Berlin.
