INTERNATIONAL A3-6
 
Czech Republic, Poland And Hungary Join NATO
The three nations made their formal entrance into the Western military alliance in a ceremony at the Truman Presidential Library in Missouri. For decades they lived under the Soviet domination that began after World War II. A1 

Poland celebrated with a flag-raising ceremony and fireworks, bringing an emotional end to decades of ideological division and a new hope for national security. A5
 
Maps at Issue in Cable Case
More than a year after a Marine Corps jet hit an alpine gondola cable that was not on the crew's map, the Pentagon has not updated its maps. Although the Defense Department says it can operate safely with the old maps, a lawyer for victims' families said changes in the maps would complicate the Government's legal defenses. A3
 
Italy's Prime Minister warned that if no one is found responsible for last year's ski lift disaster, Italy might have to reconsider aspects of a 1951 NATO agreement with regard to how jurisdiction is awarded. A3
 
German Stock Market Soars
The German stock market surged, as investors hoped that the resignation of Finance Minister Oskar Lafontaine would call into question Chancellor Gerhard Schroder's tax plans. Mr. Schroder named Hans Eichel, outgoing premier of Hesse, as new Finance Minister and he himself took over as head of the Social Democratic Party, taking charge of both the Government and the powerful machinery of his party. HEADLINE: Oil Is Rising, but Inflation Seems to Be in Check

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
The oil price surge this year, which got another boost yesterday with a new agreement on cutting production, is beginning to sting consumers.
Gasoline pump prices began to creep up this month. Colder weather in the Northeast could add to the heating oil pinch. Higher prices for airplane fuel may make tickets more expensive quickly. The indirect ripple effects, in products, like plastics, that use oil, will take longer to bite, but will come. 
 But despite the oil price increase, economists are not predicting a new surge in inflation across the board. Rather, they are merely saying that the decline in inflation, which limited last year's increase in the Consumer Price Index to 1.6 percent, will be over if the oil price rises stick.
This means, economists said yesterday, that the rate of inflation over all, which includes energy and food prices, is likely to move up toward the rate for what economists call core inflation. That rate, which excludes energy and food, is considered by some to be a better measure of the long-term rate of price increases. Last year, the C.P.I.'s core rate rose 2.3 percent. But, the economists agree, there is no upward spiral on the horizon.
"I think we should notice but not worry," said Gail D. Fosler, the chief economist at the Conference Board. "There is really nothing in the global environment or the United States environment that suggests that this is going to spread."
Still, it remains to be seen whether consumers will get unnerved when they see reports that prices are moving up rather than holding steady or declining. Investors might also get disturbed and push the price of bonds down and interest rates higher. But there was no sign of this kind of concern in the bond market yesterday, as interest rates on Treasury securities fell and the Government's inflation-indexed bonds were virtually unchanged.
The changing outlook for inflation was reflected pointedly in two separate news events yesterday. First, the Labor Department reported that prices paid to producers fell four-tenths of 1 percent in February. Without energy and food, producer prices were unchanged. Throughout the report there were signs that the prices of many goods were still falling.
Oil ministers meeting at The Hague also announced that they had the outline of an agreement to cut oil production by two million barrels a day. That report pushed up the price of oil for delivery in April to $14.49 a barrel, its highest since October. The anticipation of some kind of new cut in output has been pushing up the price of oil steadily since mid-February, when it was $11.37 a barrel, just above a 13-year low.
There are several reasons that economists are not predicting another general price spiral. One is that the global economic growth is still sluggish at best. Even if Asia, which touched off a worldwide financial crisis in 1997 with a series of currency devaluations, is recovering, Latin America is in decline and Europe seems to be standing still or slipping.
Chase Manhattan Bank forecasts about 1.5 percent growth globally this year. Even if stronger-than-expected United States growth pulls that up to 2 percent, that will be significantly below recent years' pace, said James E. Glassman, Chase's senior United States economist.
"The main driver for all this good inflation news is that we are not growing at our potential globally," he said. The way to change his mind about the outlook for inflation, he said, is to have oil prices rising because global demand was picking up.
Another factor is that other commodity prices, from cotton to copper, are at or near their recent lows. The Commodity Research Bureau/ Bridge index of 17 commodities, which fell yesterday, is just 5 points above its 24-year low hit at the end of February.
"Until there is significant upward pressure on all commodities, we are not going to have any worrisome price impact," said Ms. Fosler of the Conference Board.
In addition, while oil prices have shot up 20 percent this year, they have risen from very low levels and are just back to where they were last summer or fall, when they were already low. The same is true for gasoline prices, which were at their lowest level, after adjustment for inflation, since at least the 1950's.
And there is the question of whether the production cuts will hold or have a significant impact. Oil producers are notorious for cheating, even after agreeing to pump less oil. After the last major effort to cut production began in March 1998, the price of oil dropped 36 percent to its low of $10.72 a barrel in December.
But while there is not a new inflation spiral in sight, the overall inflation rate will rise if the oil price increase holds.
Michael Rothman, senior energy analyst at Merrill Lynch, estimates that the price of oil could move up to $17 a barrel soon. And he said it could possibly move near $20 a barrel by the end of the year if there was a sustained reduction in production that made a meaningful dent in the current overload of oil inventories.
Cynthia Latta, principal United States economist at Standard & Poor's DRI in Lexington, Mass., ran an end-of-the-year oil price of $18 a barrel through her computer model and found the following: The DRI forecast of a 1.8 percent rise in the C.P.I., year-over-year, in 1999 inches up to 2.1 percent. And if the oil price held there, the C.P.I. would increase 2.8 percent in 2000 and 2.6 percent in 2001, before slipping back to 2.4 percent in 2002.
This is above the 1.6 percent increase for 1998. But the number is less startling when compared with the 2.3 percent increase in the C.P.I. in 1997 and the 3 percent rise in 1996. In addition, the forecasts are close to the increase in the core C.P.I., without the volatile elements of food and energy, which rose 2.3 percent in 1998, 2.4 percent in 1997 and 2.7 percent in 1996.
All this leads Ms. Latta to agree with the other economists on the recent rise in oil prices: "It is not going to have much of an impact on inflation."

January Inventories Up
 WASHINGTON, March 12 (Reuters) -- United States businesses added to their stocks of goods on hand in January, with retailers in particular building inventories in anticipation of strong shopping, the Government said today.
Total business inventories increased one-tenth of a percent to a seasonally adjusted $1.088 trillion in January, reversing a one-tenth of a percent decrease in December. But overall sales were down for the first time in five months.
The report reflected booming consumer demand as retailers recorded strong sales and inventory building. The reverse was true for both wholesalers and manufacturers, whose January sales and inventories were lower than in December.
Retailers, enjoying robust sales, increased their goods on hand in January by eight-tenths of a percent, to $336.3 billion, after a seven-tenths of a percent rise in December. Retail sales increased 1 percent, to $234.35 billion, after a 1.1 percent surge in December.
Total sales by all levels of businesses -- retail, wholesale and manufacturing -- were down in January by three-tenths of 1 percent, to $791.09 billion, after a 1 percent jump in December.
It was the first decline in total monthly business sales since a two-tenths of 1 percent fall in August last year and was the biggest monthly drop since a half a percent dip in August 1997.
Manufacturers' inventories fell in January by three-tenths of 1 percent, to $465.57 billion, after a nine-tenths of 1 percent December fall. Sales by manufacturing companies declined eight-tenths of 1 percent, to $341.46 billion, after an eight-tenths of 1 percent gain in December.

HEADLINE: Caterpillar Says Its Profits Will Be Below Expectations

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

DATELINE: PEORIA, Ill., March 12

 BODY:
Citing a sales slowdown in Latin America and stiff competition in North America, Caterpillar Inc., the world's largest maker of construction and earthmoving equipment, warned today that its first-quarter profits would be far below expectations. The news caused the company's stock to tumble 12.2 percent, pulling down the Dow Jones industrial average.
The warning was just the latest in a series of blows to Caterpillar, which has been suffering through a gradual decline in sales and profits over the last year, largely because of the global economic crisis that began in Asia in late 1997. 
 Caterpillar shares fell $6.1875, or 12.2 percent, on the New York Stock Exchange today, to $44.6875. The stock had the biggest decline among the 30 stocks in the industrial average, which finished the day off 21.09 points, or two-tenths of 1 percent.
In a press release issued this morning, the company said it expected earnings per share to decline by as much as 50 percent from the corresponding quarter a year ago, well below the estimates of Wall Street analysts. Business is expected to strengthen in the second half of the year, the company said.
Still, analysts are projecting an earnings-per-share decline of 10 to 15 percent in 1999, and Caterpillar officials say they are comfortable with those estimates.
Caterpillar said it would temporarily idle plants here and abroad in the coming months and cut back on administrative costs and on research and development. Reductions in the work force are also being considered.
While the company's North American business is suffering from stiff competition and pricing pressure, most of its problems are related to recessionary forces in Asia and Latin America. And that has many analysts worried that the same forces could spread to the United States.
"We knew that Asia was quite depressed, and now Latin America is sinking like a stone and Europe is flattish," Robert McCarthy, an analyst at ABN Amro in Chicago, said. "This means they are very vulnerable to any slowdown in North America."
While sales of construction and earthmoving equipment remain strong in the United States, sales of agricultural and mining equipment are slumping because of weakness in those sectors. Sales of engines and solar turbines are also depressed, Caterpillar said, which could force temporary plant shutdowns in Europe and Latin America.
In 1998, Latin America accounted for about 9 percent of Caterpillar's sales. The company said its sales in Brazil were particularly bad.
"We said before that Brazil and Latin America were going to be in recession, and that's definitely the case," said Marsha Hausser, a spokeswoman for Caterpillar. "But we're anticipating that the second half is going to be better than the first."
Part of the problem, analysts say, is that Caterpillar and other companies have introduced a broad mix of new agricultural tractors, but the agricultural sector -- even in the United States -- is in a slump because of plummeting commodity prices. Those tractors are being aggressively priced, and as a result profit margins are shrinking throughout the industry, particularly at companies like the Case Corporation, which is based in Racine, Wis.
For Caterpillar, one of the companies that make up the Dow Jones industrial average, the economy in the United States has been strong enough to offset some losses in other markets. But the construction industry here has not been strong enough to bring healthy profits to a global company.
Wall Street analysts said today's announcement was not very surprising, but it did force some of them to trim back their expectations for 1999.
"This pretty well cements the fact that this will be the second down year for Caterpillar, even though North America remains strong," Mr. McCarthy of ABN Amro said.

HEADLINE: EXPANDING ALLIANCE: THE OVERVIEW;
Poland, Hungary and the Czechs Join NATO

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ

DATELINE: INDEPENDENCE, Mo., March 12

 BODY:
The North Atlantic Treaty Organization today embraced three former rivals -- the Czech Republic, Hungary and Poland -- formally ending the Soviet domination that began after World War II and opening a new path for the military alliance.
In a ceremony at the Truman Presidential Library tinged with the personal and the emotional, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright watched the three foreign ministers sign the documents of accession, signed them herself, then held them aloft like victory trophies. 
 Ms. Albright, who was born in Prague and fled just after the Communist takeover in 1948, made no secret today of her joy as her homeland and the two other nations joined the alliance, after six years of trans-Atlantic diplomacy led by the Clinton Administration.
"To quote an old Central European expression, 'Hallelujah!' ' she said.
In Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic, the moment was marked by small public celebrations.
In Warsaw, as fireworks lit the sky, the Polish flag and the flag of NATO were raised side by side near the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier in Pilsudski Square. In Hungary, members' flags were raised outside the Defense Ministry. And in Prague, President Vaclav Havel said in a statement, "Never have we been part of such a broad, solid and binding security alliance, which at the same time respects in its essence the sovereignty and will of our nation."
The enlargement of NATO to 19 members, from 16, has been one of the Administration's foremost goals, one that grew out of a desire to cement the democratic gains made in the former Warsaw Pact countries after the collapse of Communism 10 years ago.
But the policy also faced critics, who argued that welcoming these countries would draw a new line across Europe and antagonize the Russians.
In a speech in the small auditorium to dignitaries from the three countries, and with the three foreign ministers flanking her, Ms. Albright countered that the alliance would do "for Europe's east what NATO has already helped to do for Europe's west: steadily and systematically, we will continue erasing -- without replacing -- the line drawn in Europe by Stalin's bloody boot."
Ms. Albright also offered a forward-looking vision for NATO, which celebrates its 50th anniversary in Washington next month, and defended possible NATO involvement in Kosovo.
In the aftermath of the cold war, she said, members must be ready to face "an aggressive regime, a rampaging faction or a terrorist group."
"And we know that if past is prologue," she continued, "we face a future in which weapons will be more destructive at longer distances than ever before." The summit meeting for the 50th anniversary, she said, will produce a program that "responds to the grave threat posed by weapons of mass destruction and their means of delivery."
Regarding Kosovo, where President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia has rejected the deployment of NATO troops, Ms. Albright insisted the organization is the best tool to enforce a peace settlement.
"We must be clear in explaining that a settlement without NATO-led enforcement is not acceptable," she said, "because only NATO has the credibility and capability to make it work. And we must be resolute in spelling out the consequences of intransigence," referring to the threat of air strikes against Mr. Milosevic if he does not agree to the deployment.
But in many ways, today belonged to the Czech Republic, Hungary and Poland, who have had to cut the size of their Soviet-style armies, organize civilian control of the military and agree to buy NATO-compatible equipment in the coming years.
It was the spiritual homecoming to the West that all three foreign ministers stressed today.
"Poland forever returns where she has always belonged: the free world," said Bronislaw Geremek, the Polish Foreign Minister, who was a dissident during the Communist era.
Mr. Geremek said he had brought some appropriate mementoes to the Truman library, including a campaign poster from 1989, when the Solidarity labor movement won against the Communists. The poster showed a picture of Gary Cooper from the film "High Noon."
"It helped us to win," Mr. Geremek said. "For the people of Poland, high noon comes today."
The Czech Foreign Minister, Jan Kavan, who lived in London from 1968, when Soviet troops invaded Czechoslovakia, until 1989, said he had remained buoyant during his work as an emigre by believing that Communism would eventually fall. But he never dreamed, he said, that his country would join NATO.
"Accession to NATO is a guarantee that we will never again become powerless victims of any foreign aggression," he said.
The Hungarian Foreign Minister, Janos Martonyi, who saw the 1956 uprising as a 13-year-old, said Hungary is returning "to her natural habitat."
"It has been our manifest destiny to rejoin those with whom we share the same values, interests and goals," he said.
But Mr. Martonyi also went out of his way to emphasize that Hungary understands that membership carries obligations as well as privileges. "We shall prove that new members can indeed add to the weight of the alliance," he said.
The location for today's ceremony in America's heartland was chosen by Ms. Albright.
She made the unusual decision on a site outside Washington because she wanted the ceremony to resonate with the memories of President Truman, under whom NATO was founded. On April 4, 1949, Secretary of State Dean Acheson signed the Washington Treaty, which established the alliance. Acheson is Ms. Albright's favorite predecessor, her aides said.
Formed to face the threat of the Soviet Union under Stalin, NATO calls for the collective defense of its members. At first there were 12; Greece and Turkey joined in 1952, West Germany in 1955 and Spain in 1982. But never before has the group reached out to former enemies.
The Administration embarked on the expansion in 1993 after Mr. Clinton met in Washington with President Havel and Lech Walesa, then President of Poland. Those conversations are remembered by Mr. Clinton's foreign policy advisers because they took place after the opening of the Holocaust Museum and because they involved two very different leaders who brought the same message: that NATO should be the mechanism to secure the democratic progress in their countries, and at the same time deter Russia from any more imperial designs.
The American Ambassador to Poland, Daniel Fried, who was then on the National Security Council, said today that he remembered being asked to help "turn this pious wish into a policy."
In July 1997, at a summit meeting in Madrid, the alliance announced it would accept Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic. Romania and Slovenia, which had tried hard to meet the standards, were turned away for the time being.
One problem was how to deal with the Russians, who inched from outright hostility to acceptance of the inevitable. In early 1997, President Boris N. Yeltsin told President Clinton he could live with NATO expansion. But in order to accommodate the Russians, the group set up a consultative body that formalized relations between Moscow and the alliance.
Poland has been sensitive to Russia's reactions, and Mr. Geremek has gone out of his way to reassure Moscow. "We want our membership of NATO to serve as a catalyst for Polish-Russian cooperation," he said last year.
Even so, on the plane bringing the foreign ministers here today, when they were asked whether they could ever foresee Russia as a member of NATO, there was a long pause. Then Mr. Martonyi replied, "Silence is your answer."

CORRECTION-DATE: March 20, 1999, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
A front-page picture caption last Saturday with articles about the entry of Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic into NATO misspelled the given name of Poland's Foreign Minister. He is Bronislaw Geremek, not Bronislav.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Madeleine Albright congratulated Foreign Minister Bronislav Geremek of Poland yesterday with a kiss after they and Jan Kavan of the Czech Republic, left, and Janos Martonyi of Hungary signed the NATO accord. (Associated Press)(pg. A1)
 
Chart: "SHIFTING HISTORY"
1945 -- Soviet troops occupy much of Eastern Europe as World War II ends.
 
1946 -- Churchill gives Iron Curtain speech in Fulton, Mo.
 
1948 -- Soviet blockade of Berlin and Communist takeover in Czechoslovakia.
 
January 1949 -- Soviet Union establishes Comecon, an economic block.
 
April 1949 -- Twelve countries sign the North Atlantic Treaty in Washington.
 
1955 -- Soviet Union and its allies form the Warsaw Treaty Organization, creating what is known as the Warsaw Pact.
 
1956 -- Soviets repress workers' demonstrations in Poland and revolt in Hungary.
 
1961 -- Berlin Wall goes up.
 
1968 -- Soviets lead Warsaw Pact invasion of Czechoslovakia to crush Prague Spring reforms.
 
1970 -- Soviets and Americans open first strategic arms talks in Vienna, leading to the SALT treaties.
 
1975 -- The West, the Soviet bloc and neutral nations sign the Helsinki Final Act, setting up new human rights guarantees.
 
1981 -- Martial law imposed in Poland to avert invasion threatened by the Soviet Union and to crush the Solidarity labor movement.
 
1989 -- Berlin Wall falls. Communist regimes crumble across eastern Europe.
 
March 1991 -- Warsaw Pact dissolved.
 
December 1991 -- Soviet Union disbands.
 
1997 -- NATO invites Poland, the Czech Republic and Hungary to join.
 
1999 -- They become members. (pg. A5)

SECTION: Section 7; Page 4; Column 4; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 225 words

HEADLINE: Spend, Spend, Spend

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In reviewing Peter G. Peterson's "Gray Dawn" (Feb. 14), David Kusnet is much too kind, largely because economists of virtually all persuasions share some basic fallacies. Principal among these is that Government deficit spending damages the economy and must be eliminated, no matter what public needs have to be thrown aside. Presumably, the Social Security system cannot deal with demographic trends without dangerous deficit spending. 
 The historical record is largely ignored. Multiyear budget surpluses have always led to major depressions, a 6-for-6 batting average since 1819. The national debt was cut 36 percent in the 1920's, for example, and the Great Depression followed. Only the deficits of World War II ended the misery, and the 1946 national debt was 127 percent of gross domestic product. Today's debt is less than half that size, relative to the economy, and is probably too small. A country that could afford that war and that debt can afford Social Security. Deficit spending always helps the economy; it never hurts it.
The past half-century is the first relatively stable economic period in our history, and also a period of almost constant deficits. Deficit cuts and a balanced budget are slowing our economy and damaging the global economy, as they always have.
 
Frederick Thayer
Baton Rouge, La. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: FRUGAL TRAVELER;
An Orlando Weekend Of Blooms, Birds and Tiffany

BYLINE: By SARAH FERRELL; SARAH FERRELL is the associate editor of The Sophisticated Traveler of The New York Times Magazine.

 BODY:
THE snow and sleet and ice that we were hoping to escape delayed our departure from New York for several hours, but Tom and I couldn't complain. Unlike many other flights, ours made it to Florida that Thursday.
Orlando had much to recommend it as a quick winter getaway: warm weather, low air fare, cheap rental cars. I had telephoned Budget and discovered, to my delight, that the cheapest available rental vehicle, at a promotional rate of $19.99 a day, was a Ford Ranger pickup -- spanking new, painted metallic cinnabar, with a locking cover for the truck bed. In the cab, two comfortable bucket seats provided an overview of the heavy rush-hour traffic. 
 Since we intended to avoid downtown Orlando and all things Disney, I had negotiated a $71.10 room at a Fairfield Inn, a Marriott economy chain, in the suburb of Winter Park. Our room, No. 137, was nicely, if generically, furnished; the dressing area and sink were at the back of the bedroom, while the tub-shower combination and toilet had a little room of their own. A fair-sized, lighted swimming pool lay just outside the door.
By the time we checked in, it was dark and we were hungry. The path of least resistance led directly across the highway to a Denny's, where we checked the menu for regional specialties and came up with the chicken-fried steak dinner. Two big pieces of meat apiece, carrots and real mashed potatoes with peppery country gravy were $5.09; endlessly refillable iced tea, $1.28. We went back to our room to count our cholesterol.
We awoke to bright sunlight and the song of a cardinal. Breakfast, which came with the room, offered a choice of teas, coffee, cereals, toast, fresh fruit and individually wrapped breakfast breads -- very odd, when the bread in question is a bagel. And orange juice, which, like tea and coffee, was always available in the lobby. As we ate, we watched televised scenes of frozen crowds waving to the cameras in Rockefeller Center and tried not to giggle.
The town of Winter Park is, well, pretty cute. A street of mostly two-story stucco buildings containing boutiques and galleries and cafes parallels the park that gives the street its name, Park Avenue. The park itself is called Central Park, and is charmingly green, with old live oaks and tiny squirrels, a decorative fountain and an Amtrak station -- the railroad came through in 1882, shortly before the city was founded. The town is surrounded by lakes, and is anchored by Rollins College, a small, private liberal-arts college founded in 1885.
Admission to the Charles Hosmer Morse Museum of American Art, at the northern end of the brief commercial district, is usually $3, but it was temporarily free because the galleries were being reconstructed to house the chapel that Louis Comfort Tiffany designed for the 1893 Chicago world's fair. If only a part of the collection of Tiffany glass and art pottery and jewelry were on display, we didn't mind. The collection was assembled by Jeannette McKean and her husband, Hugh F. McKean, a former fellow at the Tiffany Foundation who was also a president of Rollins. (Mr. Morse, an early settler, was her grandfather.) The glowing favrile glass vases and dragonfly and spider-web lamps are, of course, glorious, but the windows are a wonder, especially the three-panel "Magnolia" window that was made for the Tiffany mansion on East 72d Street in New York. (You can touch an exhibit of the types of glass that Tiffany developed for his work, including the semi-opaque "draped" glass used to create the magnolias.) After several passes through the galleries, we were giddy with color.
We had lunch at a modest vegetarian establishment, the Powerhouse Cafe, just off the avenue. I had vegetarian grape leaves, Tom a sandwich of many kinds of veggies in pita bread. We drank smoothies: Mine was the fairly straightfoward berry-cherry (174 calories); Tom's was 255 calories worth of cosmic crunch -- papaya juice, strawberries, bananas, dates, granola and honey. The drinks came in pretty tropical pastel shades of coral and lilac. The bill was less than $15.
We had decided to take the Scenic Boat Tour through three of Winter Park's lakes, but later in the afternoon, which left us with some time to kill. None of our guidebooks mentioned Mead Botanical Garden, but it was on one of our maps, and nearby. It turned out to be less of an actual garden than a piece of untouched semiswamp, through which a boardwalk snaked its way. We wandered past sawgrass and wax myrtle, listening to the palmettos clatter in the wind and enjoying the boggy smell. In the hour or so we spent there, we saw only one other person, a young man seated in silent contemplation at the edge of a stream. But there was a pileated wookpecker, and monarchs cavorting in the designated butterfly garden. We felt as if we had discovered a secret.
The Scenic Boat Tours leave from the foot of Morse Avenue on Lake Osceola. The tour, which costs $7, takes a little over an hour, traversing Lakes Osceola, Virginia and Maitland, which are connected by narrow, shady canals. The boat, which looks like a big sardine tin on three pontoons, seats 18 on open benches.
We passed the backs of grand houses and boathouses in every conceivable style, and admired a landscape of cypress knees, live oaks, philodendrons and Spanish moss. The guide-narrator gave us bad jokes and good information, particularly about the fauna. We did not see the alligators or barred owls that occasionally appear, but we did see cormorants, and herons blue and white and great and small, and egrets and a whole tree full of anhingas, those strange denizens of the Everglades also know as snake birds because they hunt with only their heads and long, serpentish necks sticking out of the water.
Back on Park, we window-shopped art glass and jewelry and European toys for a bit, then settled into the Park Avenue Grill for dinner. At the bar, Tom, the designated driver, had a virgin mary, and I had a gimlet. In a fit of false economy, since it was still happy hour, with $1 off every drink, I had two. The bill, for drinks and dinner in the skylighted dining room, came to less than $ 40: Tom had a huge chunk of prime rib and I had a full dozen giant coconut-fried prawns -- more than I could eat.
We spent the next day, a Saturday, at the Kennedy Space Center, a little more than an hour's drive from Orlando. Fast-food urban sprawl gave way to vicious-looking palmetto scrub and then, as we approached the center itself, to a truly surreal skyline. There, gleaming against a huge blue sky, were the seven great boosters that stand like monoliths in the outdoor Rocket Garden display. For the first of several times, our jaws dropped.
Entrance to the Space Center is free, but you have to take a bus through restricted areas to get to the really good stuff. We decided that the best value for us was the Crew Pass ($19), which would get us on the bus and allow us to see one of three IMAX movies. Since I had a book of coupons (widely available) that gave us $2 off each pass, we paid $17 each.
The bus makes three stops: at the LC 39 observation gantry, at the International Space Station Center and at the Apollo-Saturn V Center. Since we had only a day, we chose to devote ourselves to the last. But the center is also a nature preserve, filled with the usual (by now) egrets and herons. From the bus, we also spotted a couple of alligators snoozing beside a drainage ditch. Then suddenly, the driver pointed out a bald eagle seated on a cement stanchion. Major jaw-drop. A few yards farther on, an enormous conical eagles' nest hung in a tree. Golly.
You enter the Apollo-Saturn V Center through a gigantic Flash Gordonish time lock. After some orientation movies, you pass through a big metal door and into the firing room, where blinking lights and audio clips recreate the Apollo 8 launching. Anyone old enough to remember the moon landing is apt to be awe-struck; we were. In the next room, hanging horizontally, is a Saturn V booster; we'd always known they were big, but its length still came as a surprise. The same gallery has a lot of interactive exhibits and toys and (what had become of great interest to us) a cafeteria. We took our hot dogs, fries and lemonades ($10.90 total) out onto a broad terrace, and watched turkey buzzards circle over yet another lake.
Back at the Visitor Complex, we chose the IMAX movie "The Dream Is Alive," with some truly stomach-churning footage of a landing taken from the nose of a shuttle. We poked around the gift shop and the Rocket Garden and had a few snacks until it was suddenly time to leave.
Our route to Winter Park took us along the Beeline Expressway, the last few miles of which was lined with huge billboards, many in 3-D, for the big-budget attractions that we were ignoring. Traffic was heavy, and we moved slowly. This stretch, as Tom observed, must be hell if you have children in the car.
On an earlier stroll along Park Avenue, we had caught a glimpse of what appeared to be Tiffany glass in La Venezia Cafe. And so it was, three big panels on loan from the Morse Museum. Since the cocktail hour had arrived, we settled down at the bar to admire the shining window that, appropriately, showed grapes on a trellis, and ordered a couple of what turned out to be expensive drinks. My gimlet was $6.50, and the designated driver's virgin mary was a shocking $5.95, more than a whole chicken-fried steak dinner. But it was probably worth it, since it came with a slab of carrot, a celery stalk, a large stuffed olive, an onion, lemon and lime slices and a giant shrimp. "When we garnish, we garnish," the young woman behind the bar said.
Dinner, served on a patio with louvers opening onto the street, was of necessity something of an anticlimax, although my lamb with couscous was fine. (Tom's paella, made with orzo instead of rice, was less successful.) Still, at $32 for two, not counting drinks, it wasn't a bad buy. We wished we had left room for dessert, since the pastry selection looked superb; or perhaps we should have just stopped in for coffee and cake, as others seemed to be doing.
We had most of a day on Sunday, since we did not have to return the Ranger until 5 P.M. If I had been disappointed in anything, it was that we had not seen many flowers, a situation that we decided to remedy by a visit to the Harry P. Leu Gardens, overlooking Lake Rowena (Lake Ivanhoe is just up the road) in Orlando proper. Admission to the gardens is $4, but that day it was free, since it was the annual Camellia Weekend. Events included a camellia ikebana workshop and a juried exhibit of camellia blossoms -- several hundred, singly or in groups, in every possible color and shape.
By official count, the nearly 50 acres of gardens, donated to the City of Orlando by Harry P. Leu, a local businessman, and his wife, Mary Jane, contains some 2,200 camellias, planted between 1936 and the early 1960's. Their peak blooming period is from mid-January to mid-March, and most of them have grown into substantial trees. Many of them, in full bloom, were veiled in Spanish moss, as mysterious and magical as anything in the Brothers Grimm. But camellias are only part, although a large one, of the gardens. There are, among other things, an orchid house, a rose garden, a butterfly garden and an enchanting, cool forest of bamboo, palms and cycads, as well as an overlook on the lake, where one can spy on herons.
We found lunch at the Red Rose Cafe, which had been set up exclusively for the camellia festival to serve sort of church-bazaar food at church-bazaar prices. A generous ham-and-brie sandwich was $3, lemonade $1, a homemade lemon-coconut square $1. We ate on a terrace under a giant live oak, and watched cloud reflections on the lake. Refreshed and rejoicing in our good luck, we took another leisurely tour of the gardens, then headed for the airport. A few drops of rain were falling.
Back in New York, braving the icy winds, we still felt warm.
 
Bottom line: variations from a theme park
Our three-night escape to Florida cost us about $950, including farewell drinks at the Orlando airport, where the designated driver allowed himself a martini.
Our New York-Orlando fares on Delta were $208 each. The pickup rental came to just under $100, with tax and gasoline; tolls were $3.50.
Three nights at the Fairfield Inn, 951 Wymore Road, Winter Park, telephone and fax (407) 539-1955, were $236.76, with tax and breakfast. Other meals, including snacks and drinks, were about $150.
By fluke, we avoided $14 in admission fees; the Winter Park boat tour and Crew Pass at the Kennedy Space Center cost a total of $48.
 
Where to Eat
The Powerhouse Cafe, 111 East Lyman Avenue, Winter Park, (407) 645-3616, is open from 10 A.M. to 7 P.M., Monday through Friday; from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. on Saturday, and closed Sunday. Healthy soups ($2 to $2.75), salads ($3.50 to $5) and sandwiches ($2.50 to $4.50), as well as vegetarian Middle Eastern specialties and smoothies ($2.75).
Both Park Avenue Grill, 358 Park Avenue North, Winter Park, (407) 647-4556, and La Venezia Cafe, 142 Park Avenue South, Winter Park, (407) 647-7557, are open daily for lunch and dinner. At either, a meal for two with drinks should be about $40 to $50.
Fast food and snacks are available at the Kennedy Space Center. Specialties include Apollo beer and Space Dots, "the ice cream of the future" ($2.75 for more than you'll probably want to eat). We had our modest lunch ($10.90) on the terrace of the Moon Rock Cafe in the Apollo-Saturn V Center.
 
Sightseeing
The Charles Hosmer Morse Museum of American Art, 445 Park Avenue North, Winter Park, (407) 645-5311. Open 9:30 A.M. to 4 P.M. Tuesday to Saturday, 1 to 4 P.M. Sunday. Admission is $3. The opening of the expansion that contains the Tiffany chapel is scheduled for April 17.
To get to Mead Botanical Garden, (407) 599-3334, go south on Park Avenue and turn right onto Fairbanks Avenue. Then turn left onto Denning Avenue and left again on Garden. It is open from dawn to dusk. Free.
The Scenic Boat Tour departs from the end of East Morse Boulevard, on Lake Osceola, Winter Park (407) 644-4056. Tours leave on the hour, from 10 to 4, daily except Christmas. The fare is $7.
Kennedy Space Center, (407) 452-2121, is about an hour's drive from Orlando. Open daily (except Christmas and during some launchings) 9 A.M. to dusk. Tours leave the visitor center at short intervals between 9:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.; you can get off at any of the three destinations and spend as much time as you like. Several packages are available, including the $19 Crew Pass, which includes the Space Center Tour and an IMAX movie, as well as a tour of old Cape Canaveral, which departs at 3:30 P.M. (the time can vary).
Harry P. Leu Gardens, 1920 North Forest Avenue, Orlando; (407) 246-2620. Open daily, except Christmas, 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. (later in summer). Admission ($4, schoolchildren $1) includes a brief tour of the Leu House; the last tour is at 3:30 P.M. SARAH FERRELL

SECTION: Section 5; Page 4; Column 5; Travel Desk 

LENGTH: 1187 words

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
How Safe Is the Hotel Safe?

BYLINE: By BETSY WADE 

 BODY:
LAST Sept. 1, Dr. Odi Matityahu and his wife, Liat, arrived in St. Thomas, the Virgin Islands, to celebrate her birthday. They checked into the Renaissance Grand Beach Resort about 3 P.M. Dr. Matityahu said that the hotel staff asked if they needed a safe for their valuables, and they were given the key to a wall safe in their room. They stored their valuables, including passports and jewelry, and went swimming. When they returned at 5:20, the room safe had been removed with a beer-can opener, which was left behind. The room door had not been forced, they said.
This situation, and a different problem that befell two other hotel guests in Miami, illuminate aspects of hotel liability that may come as unwelcome news to travelers. 
 Dr. Matityahu said that he and his wife got a hotel and a police report about the theft and that the resort manager said there was nothing to worry about because the insurance company would take care of them. After the couple returned home to Plano, Tex., Dr. Matityahu said, an insurance adjuster called to say the couple would be compensated for their losses -- up to a total of $200. Since Dr. Matityahu's list includes more than $33,000 in jewelry, he refused to accept.
The $200 offer was not a random one. It is the limit of "innkeeper liability" in the Virgin Islands' legal code when guests entrust their valuables to the hotel for safekeeping and the valuables are lost through "theft, damage, destruction or otherwise." It is not that a hotel cannot pay more, but $200 is the most it is obliged to pay.
If valuables are not entrusted to the hotel, the guest is entitled to no compensation in the event of a loss.
Since the event, Dr. Matityahu said, he has received unsatisfactory and "rude" responses from the hotel and some of its officers. He turned the matter over to a lawyer at home and a suit was filed for damages of $47,565, including losses caused by Dr. Matityahu's absence from his chiropractic practice, airline tickets, new passports and a replacement for his green card (he is an Israeli national).
 
Who Owns What?
 The issue of whom to sue, in the age of real estate investment trusts, franchising and hotel management companies, is difficult. George B. Flint, the Matityahus' lawyer, filed the suit in Texas against Marriott, which owns the Renaissance Group.
The Dallas lawyer representing Marriott in this case, Ellen Presby of Mills, Presby & Associates, said "they sued the wrong company" and that despite the name, the real owner of the hotel is Hotel Property Investment Inc., whose address she did not know. Mr. Flint has asked for this.
The jewelry is carried on the family insurance policy, and Dr. Matit yahu is filing a claim. But he says his premiums will rise sharply.
Mr. Flint says that the case will hinge on negligence. "That was not a safe as 'safe' is understood in Texas law," he said in an interview. "I think if you asked 12 members of a jury if something you could remove with a can opener is a safe, the vote would be 12-0 against it."
The matter of limiting innkeepers' liability goes far back in law. A cap on what an innkeeper must pay if travelers lose their belongings came about to protect those who provided shelter to people on the road -- a desirable situation in the view of public policy -- from being put out of business by visitors who sued after being robbed on the premises.
In the United States, every state and territory has a law limiting this liability, and each state requires that notices of this be posted in a particular way. No Federal law is involved.
Many of these limits were set in the last century, and inflation has made them out of date. In the last five years, some legislatures have been pushed by consumers into raising the limits.
John Hyland, a lawyer at Sherry & O'Neill in New York, which specializes in hotel law, gave some figures for the limits in states popular with tourists: New Jersey, $5,000; New York, $1,500; Florida, $1,000; California, $1,000; Nevada, $750, and Illinois, $500.
John Sherry Jr., emeritus professor of law at the Cornell School of Hotel Administration, whose father was an original partner of Sherry & O'Neill, is more pragmatist than litigator. "If you have heirloom jewelry," he said, "don't take it to a hotel, even for a wedding. The best hotels attract the best confidence artists, and they will get to you some way. You might as well wear good-quality paste."
 
A Miami Robbery
Another issue of hotel liability appears in the case of Jim and Judith Whalen of Seal Beach, Calif., who describe themselves as a senior couple. On Nov. 19, on a business trip to Miami, they returned to the hotel, the Doubletree at Coconut Grove, at 8 P.M. When they were 50 feet from the hotel entrance, they said, they and a couple leaving the hotel with two young children were set upon by four youths, knocked down and robbed.
"Despite the proximity to the hotel entrance," Mrs. Whalen wrote, "hotel security did not respond to our collective screams."
She said that research by friends who were members of the Florida bar showed that Florida law provided no shield to forbid lawsuits against good Samaritans who made mistakes in pursuit of their good intentions. This resulted in security officers' normally refusing to go outside a hotel's entrance and driveway to help guests in difficulty.
It has a wrong-way sound to it, but a spokesman for the hotel industry in Florida says hotels do not want their employees going into the street to help people because of this liability issue. The spokesman, Thomas A. Waits, president of the Florida Hotel and Motel Association, said: "Hotels have gone the extra mile, and they can be held liable for these actions. Business does not win in court."
He added that with tort reform, good Samaritans would be supported by law.
Tort reform, a sticky political issue everywhere, is opposed by law groups because it makes it tougher for consumers to sue businesses. The Florida Legislature approved tort reform last year, but it was vetoed by Gov. Lawton Chiles, a Democrat. The new Governor, Jeb Bush, a Republican, has pledged himself to tort reform.
Mrs. Whalen said that when she talked to clerks in the hotel afterward, she was told the area was unsafe at night. Although she had earlier received directions from the hotel desk, that does not create liability. Repeated calls to Doubletree management yielded no response.
Prof. Robert M. Jarvis, an author of "Travel Law, Cases and Materials" (Carolina Academic Press), said that hotels had won cases in situations where concierges gave directions to places that proved unsafe. "Even though the hotel sets the trip in motion," said Professor Jarvis, who teaches at Nova Southeastern University in Fort Lauderdale, "if it happens outside the perimeter, the hotel is not liable."
Both stories remind travelers that although one's home may be one's castle, one's hotel is not one's home. Costly jewelry should be insured and not taken to hotels, and guests who suspect that an area may be of doubtful safety should call for a cab.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 13; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 1484 words

HEADLINE: FILM;
Nihilsm Gets a Butcher's Face, France a Jolt of Realism

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING 

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
AFTER seeing "I Stand Alone," after meeting its 35-year-old director, Gaspar Noe, one couldn't help but ask: How could a pleasant young man with a positive view of life make a film as dark and desperate as this one?
Well, Mr. Noe might of course have confessed that he was a secret nihilist, that "I Stand Alone" ("Seul Contre Tous") was a public form of psychotherapy. Reassuringly, his answer was more straightforward. 
 "I can make a film like this because I feel at ease with myself," he said. "I was raised in a comfortable household with adoring parents who gave me nothing but love, and this allows me to make a film about depression that in the end is very combative."
An Argentine-born Frenchman, Mr. Noe was talking in a cafe beside one of the two Paris theaters where his movie is playing. On Wednesday it opens in New York for a two-week run at the Film Forum. "I Stand Alone" is his first feature film, but in fact it picks up where his award-winning 1991 short, "Carne," left off in its portrayal of an ill-starred Paris butcher of horse meat, again played by the burly Philippe Nahon. The new film stands on its own, but to explain why its central character is about to move still closer to the edge, Mr. Noe opens with a series of stills, accompanied by the butcher's raspy voiceover, recapitulating the story so far:
The butcher has achieved his dream of opening his own shop when he meets a factory worker who becomes pregnant and then abandons him, leaving their mute daughter for him to raise. When the girl reaches puberty, she is frightened by her first menstruation and rushes to her father's shop. Seeing blood on her dress and imagining she has been raped, he stabs an innocent passer-by. After serving time in jail, with his daughter now institutionalized, he finds work as a barman and promptly seduces the owner's wife. Then, when she becomes pregnant, they decide to start a new life in Lille.
"I Stand Alone" finds the butcher living in the crammed apartment of his mistress's mother, growing ever more depressed as he struggles to find work. "You have to smile to be a butcher," he is told when he applies for a job in the meat section of a Lille supermarket. He cannot and is ordered to leave. At home, the walls close in on him as his mistress baits him for watching television. One night he explodes in anger, attacking her and pummeling her swollen stomach.He grabs his pistol and hitchhikes to Paris, never looking back.
He still imagines that hope is somewhere to be found. He checks into the very hotel room where his daughter was conceived and again looks for work without success. He tries to borrow money from old friends, but they, too, are down at heel or simply tightfisted. As his anger mounts, he is freshly humiliated: he gets into an argument in a bar and is forced to leave by a shotgun-waving owner. When a gay meat supplier turns him down for yet another job because of his jail record, he swears revenge. He has three bullets in his pistol and he plans to use them.
Recounted in this way (without revealing its ending), the story seems to be that of a middle-aged man driven to despair by unemployment, rejection and lack of love. What gives the film its extraordinary intensity, though, is the stream-of-consciousness voice-over that records the butcher's descent into hate for the world and disgust with himself.
"You are always alone, alone when you're born, alone when you die, alone, always alone," the butcher's mind tells him at one point. "The older you get, the lonelier you are, alone with a few memories that life steadily destroys. Life is like a tunnel. Everyone has his little tunnel. But at the end of the tunnel, there is no light. There is nothing."
Describing the movie as "devastating" after it was shown at last fall's New York Film Festival, Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times that " 'I Stand Alone' probes as relentlessly into the psychology of nihilism as any movie has ever attempted."
Mr. Noe reinforces this message in the way he has shot and cut the film (he was the film's cameraman as well as its screenwriter, director, producer and co-editor), using close-up images of violence and hard-core pornography followed by sudden camera movements accompanied by amplified gunshots that heighten the tension. Interspersed, he has one-word tabloid headlines, like "Morality" and "Justice," as well as a "Warning" -- giving audiences time to leave the theater -- before the film's denouement.
Mr. Nahon's performance has deservedly won praise, not least because Mr. Noe's endless difficulties in raising money for the movie meant that the 30 days of filming were spread over almost three years. For "Carne," the actor learned how to handle and cut meat; for "I Stand Alone," it was more a question of entering into a state of mind. But he said he was unfazed by the interruptions.
"Gaspar would call up and say, 'We're shooting tomorrow because I have found money for some film stock,' " said Mr. Nahon, who is 60. "We'd meet and work out if we were shooting before or after the last scene we did. He'd say, 'Action!' and I was inside the character. It wasn't difficult. You see people like that every day everywhere. Homeless people. At 50, no one can find a job. If you've spent a few days in jail, it's worse. You're finished."
Although "I Stand Alone" is essentially a psychological study, not political commentary, some French critics have seen it as an indictment of contemporary France and, indirectly, of a French movie industry that until recently has been dominated by comedies, historical costume dramas and intimate love stories.
"The important thing is not that France at the end of the 20th century can be as sordid, ugly and pitiless as that," Le Monde's film critic, Jean-Michel Frodon, wrote of Mr. Noe's movie. "It can be. But since movies tend all too often to forget this, one that points this out is to be welcomed."
That this film was ever made is itself surprising. Neo-realism may be making a comeback here, as witnessed by Mathieu Kassovitz's "Hate," Bruno Dumont's "Life of Jesus," Erick Zonca's "Dreamlife of Angels" and Bertrand Tavernier's still-unreleased "Life Begins Today," but Mr. Noe's screenplay proved too realistic to win the backing of any French television company. And since this is the first step toward making a film here, he was on his own.
It did not help that Mr. Noe was not part of the Paris movie world. He attended a Paris film school, L'Ecole Lumiere, but he said that until he made "Carne" he was more interested in amusing himself than in working. And it was thanks to "Carne" that he eventually won support to make another 40-minute movie from the short-films division of the pay-TV channel, Canal Plus. Even then, it was almost two years before the French designer, Agnes B., provided him with the funds to make a feature-length film.
"The television people said to me, 'Why don't you come with a real project, a real police thriller, with real producers, real actors?' " Mr. Noe recalled. "The people who read screenplays are employees worried about losing their jobs if they approve something too explosive. They prefer to give money to an established director even if he makes a flop. Anyway, I worked once or twice as an assistant director on big productions and they're not for me. They resemble the Normandy landings more than a work of art. I like to work with a small team, without makeup, with little decor, where you can improvise, you can invent scenes on location."
Perhaps inevitably, "I Stand Alone" has been compared with Martin Scorsese's "Taxi Driver," but Mr. Noe also speaks admiringly of numerous other directors, among them Luis Bunuel, Elia Kazan, Sam Peckinpah, Roberto Rosselini, Vittorio de Sica and Pier Paolo Pasolini. And for his next film, he said, he would like to follow in the footsteps of Nagisa Oshima's erotic 1976 classic, "In the Realm of the Senses."
"I would like to make a film that shows people making love without it being pornographic, like 'In the Realm of the Senses,' but perhaps less morbid," he said. "I'd like to show a love story where people make love from time to time, but where the camera does not then turn to the fireplace. You can show a lot about people's psychology in the way they make love."
So, the young director was asked, does he like to shock?
"My film does not set out to shock," he said. "I think that in English the word 'shock' is more negative than in French. In French, it means more 'to disturb.' I don't think you should remove things that stir the emotions. If something disturbing leads somewhere else, why not? You know, perhaps strangely, no one has said that the violence in 'I Stand Alone' is gratuitous violence. All I have done is filter out the positive side of life. I have left the butcher with nothing more than the negative power of his existence."

HEADLINE: Q & A/Dr. Richard L. Schwab;
What It Takes to Produce Good Teachers

BYLINE: By NANCY POLK 

 BODY:
THE dean of the School of Education at the University of Connecticut, Dr. Richard L. Schwab, is a happy man. Recently a philanthropist and alumnus, Raymond Neag, donated $21 million to the school. Dr. Schwab has lots of plans for that money: scholarships and graduate assistantships, endowed chairs, outreach activities and professional development activities were among the areas he mentioned.
Dr. Schwab said his goal is to make the Neag School of Education, as it will be known, "one of the top 10 schools of education in five years." 
 Recently Dr. Schwab met to discuss his observations on education. Following are some excerpts from that conversation.
Q. Why do you require your students to work in cities and rural areas, and with special education students, if they want to teach in the suburbs?
A. We require the urban experience because urban areas reflect now what population trends will be. We're increasingly becoming more diverse. Our students need to know what all students are like, not just suburban students.
If students are going to be secondary school teachers we make them go into an elementary classroom, just so they understand -- before they get too set in their ways -- what it is that they're receiving. We might put elementary education students in a high school so they know what happens to their students after they leave.
Every one of our students has an experience with special education students, not just those preparing for special education, because they need to understand the learning needs of all children. In their junior year they have field experience, fall and spring. In their senior year they have field experience in the fall, followed by student teaching.
Q. Have you been able to diversify your student body and faculty?
A. My goal is to have all our programs, whether it is in exercise science, educational leadership or teaching, reflect the realities of today's society. We have to be prepared to work with all children, all adults, no matter what their socio-economic, ethnic or racial background.
We need to prepare more teachers from underrepresented populations so kids can see role models like themselves. Last year we went from 10 percent to 17 percent minority enrollment in our teacher education program without sacrificing one bit in the G.P.A. or requirements phase.
If you're going to build a good team you have to be like Coaches Calhoun and Geno Auriemma. You have to go out and actively recruit. It's not "build it and wait for them to come." It's "build it and make sure people know about it."
I'm working very hard to diversify our faculty in all departments. For example, I'm doing a joint search with the Puerto Rican and Latino Studies Institute.
Q. Schools of Education have come under fire as part of the general dissatisfaction with American education. How do you perceive education schools in general?
A. Just like schools of business and schools of law, there are some very good ones and some very weak ones. We have not done a good job of policing the weaker programs. A broad stroke is painted with all schools of education based on peoples' experience with many of the weak ones.
Q. How difficult is it to get into the School of Education?
A. We are highly selective. The average S.A.T. score of teacher education applicants is 1150. We don't admit them until their junior year. The G.P.A. in a subject area major is about a 3.3. Our elementary education candidates have to have a content major in English, science, history or math.
The first criteria of a good program is to get very bright talented students into it. Second, make sure they have a strong content preparation, that they know something before we expect them to teach. Third, be very selective not only in content preparation but in interpersonal skills. You need both. It's not good enough to like kids to be a good teacher. You have to love to learn. The key to being a good teacher is, do you have a love of learning?
We interview our students, we look at their grades, what experiences they've had with kids. At the end of their sophomore year they apply. In some of our programs we have three applicants and one gets in. We're almost as selective as some law schools.
Q. How many students do you have?
A. We admit 130 students each year for a total of 400 in our five-year teacher education program. It's undergraduate and graduate. It's an integrated bachelor's/master's program.
Q. Do your students work in local schools?
A. All of our methods courses are anchored in schools. We've developed relationships with local partner schools, known as professional development schools. We engage in a process called simultaneous renewal. They work with us to prepare our future teachers. And we work with them to improve practice. Our partner schools are Hartford, East Hartford, Mansfield, Ashford, Windham, Tolland, Glastonbury and E.O. Smith.
Also important in the integrated bachelor's/master's program is that our students are there in their junior and senior years and then they return to do a yearlong master's internship in one of the professional development schools. The internship is defined by the school. They work a 20-hour-a-week internship that might be setting up a technology lab or starting a tutorial program. They are not working as classroom teachers.
The district gets these very bright, talented students who tackle very significant projects for the schools. Our students write up the results of what they've done in their research. We're developing teachers who are reflective practitioners, who look at what they do, what they write, what they think, and what they test. They evaluate with their cooperating teachers and their professors.
Q. How are you changing the curriculum?
A. First we identified centers of excellence. We will be building upon those programs for gifted and talented students, teacher education, administrative preparation. We are developing an interdisciplinary early childhood program for children from birth to 5.
We're phasing out programs in sports psychology at the bachelor's, master's and Ph.D. level. We're getting rid of the Sports and Society bachelor's degree that we have. We're going to phase out our counseling psychology program and look to see if there might not be other places at the university that might be able to do it better than we can. The faculty decided that the amount of resources that it would take to make it excellent could be found somewhere else at UConn.
What we're doing instead is enhancing our program in sports management, which has much broader implications. We're also going to focus on health and wellness across the life span in that department.
Q. One problem that school teachers and administrators site as serious is the lack of parental involvement? Do you agree?
A. Parents and guardians play a key role. They should send their kids to school with breakfast, a good night's sleep. They should read to kids at home. They should shut off the TV for part of the evening and be sure that kids are doing their homework. They should take an active interest in their children's work.
Q. Do you see public schools adding hours to the day and days to the school year?
A. It's inevitable. The amount of information that we need kids to process is way beyond what they can process in 180 days from 8 to 2.
I think we have to make the best use of the school year we have now. We also have to think conceptually about restructuring the school year. It's based on the old agricultural model. The reality is in Connecticut there are very few kids who have to get in the crops. In some kids' cases, especially with children at risk, that gap of time over the summer will take a month to catch up.
It's not necessary to have everyone take vacation that one week in February. If the year was spread out more like the adult work year, we could take advantage of that. The gross reality is that some kids are left alone on the street. I contend that kids get into trouble when there is too little to do, not when there is too much to do.
Connecticut wants progress without change and inevitably if we want to improve the system we have to look at some changes.

SECTION: Section 11; Page 9; Column 1; Real Estate Desk

HEADLINE: Commercial Property /New Jersey;
A 45-Acre Renewal for a Rundown Section of Lodi

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
FROM an empty site at Main Street and Union Avenue here the view northward is of a tattered landscape. Rundown factories, many vacant, press hard against the west side of Main Street while a cluster of houses and small businesses line the east side. Salvage yards, an apartment complex and a mobile-home park dot the area's northwestern fringe.
The legacy of this Bergen County borough's industrial past is most evident in this neighborhood. The area, long thick with factories, was the site of the the 1994 explosion at the Napp Technologies pharmaceutical plant, which killed five workers and injured 41 others. 
 The neighborhood, as the sign at the planned renewal site says, will be the "New Main Street," where the $150 million Lodi Towne Center -- up to 600,000 square feet of stores, offices and entertainment uses, including a 14- to 20-screen movie theater -- will rise on 45 acres. Much of the property, which is bisected by the Saddle River, is polluted.
The borough, the redevelopment agent for the project, last year designated Crown Properties of Jersey City as the redeveloper. The project, designed as a throwback to the Main Streets of long ago, where people came to gather and shop, will rise parcel by parcel over the next five years.
"We saw through the mess to the underlying demographics that would support what we envision," said Warren Waters, a partner with Douglas Kanter at Crown Properties. Mr. Waters said a study done for the borough shows that 550,000 people with an average household income of $47,000 live within a five-mile radius of the site, where 34,000 cars pass each day.
The first five buildings, with a total of 118,000 square feet, will rise at the corner of Main Street and Union Avenue. In May, construction of two buildings will begin on an 8-acre site on the west side of Main Street -- the first structure for a 13,000-square-foot bank headquarters,to be followed in December by a 67,000-square-foot Edwards Super Food market. Across Main Street on a four-acre site, work will begin this fall on a 14,000-square-foot drugstore, a 4,000-square-foot fast food outlet and a 20,000-square-foot building for small users.
The plan, shaped over the last eight years and approved by residents in a referendum in 1994, reflects several characteristics of contemporary urban redevelopment. One is the recycling of industrial sites to new uses, which follows the aims of the state's Development and Redevelopment Plan. The plan encourages growth where highways and utilities are in place and discourages it in less developed areas.
Mayor Philip V. Toronto, who likens the area to "bombed-out Beirut" and has spearheaded its redevelopment, said Main Street was where the future of the 2.2-square-mile borough lies. The project, he said, will inject new economic life into the neighborhood, increase the tax base of the entire community and give it back its communal heart.
The borough's old downtown on the southern stretch of Main Street -- an area of small shops now called Memorial Drive -- was replaced under an urban renewal plan in the 70's with strip shopping centers.
THE new Main Street will have a different face, its backers say, helping the borough shed its perceived image as a gritty address. Planned are brick sidewalks, old-fashioned street lamps and a clock tower at the entrance to the project, around which there will be a benches for shoppers. There will be additional seating areas along the river, whose litter-strewn banks will be spruced up.
Mr. Waters said plans for the project, which will be financed mainly by private sources willing to lend on leases secured by creditworthy tenants, call for the county and state to make improvements. Among them will be the widening of Main Street and replacement of the Arnot Street bridge. In addition, the Army Corp of Engineers must dredge the Saddle River to control flooding in the area.
Existing buildings in the area will be razed, triggering the relocation of some 200 families and a nest of businesses. As such the project also speaks to the struggle fully developed towns like Lodi face -- how to diversify their economic bases and enhance the quality of life of residents even though the lives of some residents will be affected in the process.
"With the condition of the land and the hodgepodge of uses, the area, stagnant for 60 years, was generating only one-tenth of the tax revenue it could," Mayor Toronto said. Annual tax revenues from the completed project will rise from the current $400,000 in the area to more than $1.5 million, he said.
Bergen County Executive William Schuber said Lodi's plan, if successful, would have an economic ripple effect on the county and serve as a model that other semi-industrial towns in southern Bergen County could follow.
But with so extensive a project, many challenges exist. They range from getting the government agencies to move forward with the infrastructure improvements to acquiring the land. To date the developers have successfully negotiated with seven property owners for a total of 12 acres, but if the process becomes difficult the borough, which is the redevelopment agent, could use its condemnation powers to acquire the rest of the property.
The cleanup of some sites may also prove difficult, including the two-acre Napp property, which the state's Department of Environmental Protection lists as having PCBs in the soil and ground water.
The company, which is based in Saddle Brook, moved its chemical operations to Coventry, R.I., after the 1994 explosion but has yet to complete a cleanup of the Main Street site. Jon Holt, a company spokesman, said Napp "wants to be cooperative" and has submitted to the state a cleanup plan, which still awaits approval.
In addition, there is the practical hurdle of addressing neighborhood concerns.
"It is the best thing that could happen to the borough and the surrounding towns," said George R. Geswaldo, who operates two businesses in the area that would be affected. "If the area is left the way it is, the town will break down and other towns will suffer."
Mr. Geswaldo manages his family's 38,000-square-foot industrial building on Dell Glen Avenue, where he also operates his stained-glass design business. Five other tenants also occupy the building.
AS a business owner, he said, he considers the redevelopment project "an opportunity to relocate elsewhere in Lodi or in the redevelopment area, providing my business, now off the beaten track, with more exposure." But as a landlord, he added, "I'd like to see the process expedited, because it's hard to do business" in an area whose future will change.
Others, like Angelina Sidari, who has lived for 52 years in her Main Street home, remain resistant, vowing she will not move. "I knew it would eventually happen," Mrs. Sidari, a widow, said of the redevelopment. "Even though it's a rundown area, it's safe and this is my home."
Mayor Toronto said the relocations "had to be weighed against the greater public good." He said that property owners would be given a fair market prices for their properties and that every attempt would be made to move homeowners to comparable housing in the borough.
Mr. Waters added that retailers in the neighborhood would have the chance either to move elsewhere in Lodi or to the redevelopment site, where 20,000 square feet in the initial phase has been designed for smaller users. With the state economy and retail market strong and a trend among shoppers away from malls to traditional downtowns, the developer said, Crown is betting that national and regional retailers, as well as office users, would be attracted to the site.
Kurt Barnard, a retail analyst based in Upper Montclair who publishes Barnard's Retail Trend Report agreed, but with a caveat.
"It is not a full-blown trend," he said, "though there is a sense of revival in some downtowns and retailers are looking at them as having high populations that are underserved." To be successful, he added, there must be a magnet to draw shoppers.
Mr. Waters said the Lodi project's draw would be its supermarket, entertainment uses and the arrival of a national retailer not currently in Bergen County. Beyond the initial buildings, he said, discussions are under way with users for 330,000 more square feet of space.
Mayor Toronto said he was optimistic that once the first phase is started "people will see what can be," and that the rest of the project would fall into place. Not that he thinks it will be built tomorrow. "It takes time to undo 100 years of mistakes, but a solution will be found to every problem," he said, adding, "What is the alternative?"
