HEADLINE: The View From/Hampton;
A Writer's World and the Legacy at Trail Wood

BYLINE: By STACEY STOWE 

 BODY:
FORTY years ago, Edwin Way Teale and his wife, Nellie, stood in the doorway of their snug Cape Cod-style house and watched yellow lights in the field opposite them wink on and off in the soft air of a summer evening. That was how Firefly Meadow was christened.
All around Trail Wood, the 156-acre preserve in the town of Hampton that was home for 20 years to the Pulitzer Prize-winning nature writer Mr. Teale, are signs that bear a literary antecedent. 
 It was there, in a cabin overlooking the pond he and his wife commissioned, that Mr. Teale wrote "A Naturalist Buys an Old Farm," the book that chronicles his daily study of the comprehensive array of habitats at Trail Wood: pond and swamp, forest and meadow, and wildflower walk and hay field. The book, long out of print, was reissued last fall by the University of Connecticut's Biblioploa Press.
Before he died, Mr. Teale, an accomplished photographer and an inveterate saver of field notes, journals and book outlines, willed his papers and books to the Thomas J. Dodd Research Center at the University of Connecticut libraries.
For the second consecutive year, the university is sponsoring an Edwin Way Teale Lecture Series (the next is March 23 at the Dodd Center). Economists, poets, political scientists and philosophers from throughout the country address the issue of the environment from the perspective of their discipline. Past speakers, including the poet Gary Snyder, visit the property, now also known as the Edwin Way Teale Memorial Sanctuary, for inspiration before their lectures. Students in the school's Nature and Literature class also visit.
If the University of Connecticut is safeguarding the literary legacy of Trail Wood, then the Connecticut Audubon Society, to whom the Teales willed the property, is its physical guardian. The society has owned the property since Mr. Teale died in 1980 at the age of 81. Mrs. Teale, whose keen abilities as a naturalist were generously detailed in her husband's books, continued to live in the house at Trail Wood until her death, at age 93, in 1993. Last summer, the Connecticut Audubon Society acquired one acre through donation and bought an additional 13.63 acres to enlarge the eastern end of the property.
Between 50 and 100 people visit Trail Wood each month. Audubon staff said the Teale property strengthens the society's presence in the northeastern part of the state. The society also owns the 300-acre Pomfret Farms sanctuary and operates the Ragged Hill Woods 4-H program, based in Brooklyn. The two sanctuaries and center are among 17 Connecticut Audubon Society properties, for a total of 2,500 acres.
The society's plans for the Teale property include continuing guided nature walks, programs for children and adults and maintaining the land as a sanctuary, where the public can visit daily from dawn to dusk, said Sherman Kent, who has been president of the 100-year-old Connecticut Audubon Society for the past decade.
In the warmer months, the public can enter the house and see the study where Mr. Teale arranged notes for his books, chapter by chapter in a metal file cabinet. His Pulitzer Prize for "Wandering Through Winter," sits in a frame on the desk. There is also a small museum in a former barn behind the house that contains several of Mr. Teale's photographs and copies of articles he wrote for Popular Science magazine.
Almost everything remains the same as when the Teales lived at Trail Wood.
"We cut vines and remove branches to keep the trails clear," Mr. Kent said. "We occasionally mow the hay field to stop it from ultimately turning into woods."
On the edge of that former hay field sit an array of wire cages placed over wildflowers that are rapidly going to seed. The cages are part of a study of grasshoppers being conducted by a student at the Yale School of Forestry. "Edwin would have loved it," said Jeff Weiler, who with his wife, Annie Guion, is a caretaker of the property and program coordinator for Audubon. Indeed, it is just that kind of meticulous attention to nature's details that entranced Mr. Teale. Captivated by the bounty of fern varieties on the property, he once counted 2,972 ebony spleenwort ferns in a 200-square-foot area on the property's north woods. Each day before his long hours of writing, he would walk the grounds or lay in a hammock he had strung up in the woods. He routinely spent hours beside Hampton Brook, camouflaged beneath a pile of brush, to observe birds and mammals and insects.
The brush pile still stands, albeit sturdier than in Teale's days. An interior frame was fashioned by the Teale's close friend, Wendell Davis, who is generally acknowledged as the torchbearer of the Trail Wood legacy.
It was Mr. Davis and his wife, Alison, who found the farm in Hampton for the Teales in 1959. They were asked by James Slater, a colleague of Mr. Davis's at the University of Connecticut, if they knew of any houses with for sale with land. The Teales were living on Long Island, where suburbia was rapidly encroaching. The property off Kenyon Road, a former dairy and hay farm with a circa-1806 house surrounded by 79 acres (the Teales ultimately bought more surrounding land) better suited their needs.
Mr. Davis, a former First Selectman of Hampton and past professor of engineering at the University of Connecticut, lives not far away on his own farm. Mr. Davis and his wife, Alison, had long admired Mr. Teale's work and were honored to have the Teales in Hampton. They were kindred spirits; after Mr. Teale died, Mrs. Teale gave Mr. Davis his canoe and camera. Mr. Davis said he believed he was "a kind of marker for them," being roughly the same age as their son David would have been had he survived service in World War II.
Walking the trails with the 77-year-old Mr. Davis is a learning experience. Mr. Davis, whose quiet, erudite manner bespeak a New England gentleman farmer, points out geologic formations, remains of Colonial barns and varieties of trees. He routinely tosses fallen branches off the path and is disturbed to find a gutted deer on one of the trails. In late fall the bones of the trees were visible, along with a vista of Beaver Pond, a body of water the Teales saw transformed from swamp to pond by those industrious creatures.
"There's a lot to love about his place," Mr. Davis said, noting the emerald and pea-green mosses quilting the rocks and the peace of the seemingly boundless woods. After Mr. Teale's death, Mr. Davis formed a volunteer group, Friends of Trail Wood, to insure the preservation of the property.
Earlier in the fall, on a cool, sunny Saturday, a group of eight people had sat around a picnic table adjacent to the house at Trail Wood, to participate in a program sponsored by the Connecticut State Museum of Natural History in Storrs. Several people carried copies of "A Naturalist Buys an Old Farm," others had their own journals. A discussion about Mr. Teale, his life and his work, was led by John Gatta, a professor of the Nature and Literature course at the University of Connecticut and Kurt Heidinger, a graduate student. (Mr. Gatta was one of the professors who conceived the Teale Lecture Series.)
Two women recounted a story they were told about Mr. Teale fording local water in a canoe and tipping over. Others read favorite passages from Teale's work.
"It is a sensuous experience, coming here," said one woman in the group, Elizabeth Austin, a composer from Storrs.
Some who walk the paths at Trail Wood are unaware they are following in the footsteps of a well-known writer. For instance, John Moran and Nicole Krassas of Willimantic, regular hikers, said they were unfamiliar with Mr. Teale's work, but were drawn by the landscape.
"It has hills, meadows, ponds, there's every kind of habitat," Ms. Krassas said.
Mr. Teale shared that observation when he wrote: "It contained woods, open fields, swamps, two good-sized brooks and a waterfall. In my mind I ticked off the list of things we had hoped for in a country home. Miraculously, they all seemed here."

HEADLINE: A Baedeker for First-Time Homebuyers

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO 

 BODY:
AT times, the struggle to become a first-time homeowner seems like learning to ride a bicycle: You can't help but wonder how something that seems to have been so easy for others could be so difficult.
But perseverance apparently pays. A survey by the Chicago Title Corporation found that more than 46 percent of home purchases nationwide in 1998 were made by first-time buyers. In New York City, the survey found, 52 percent of home sales in 1998 were made to first-time buyers. 
 The combination in recent months of low interest rates and intense competition among mortgage lenders has been making home ownership possible for increasing numbers of first-time buyers, real estate brokers and lenders say. And offerings like a new mortgage program that allows buyers to put as little as 3 percent down for a "handyman's special" -- and include the cost of anticipated repairs in the mortgage -- are making home ownership possible for first-time buyers of more modest means.
Buying a first home, though, is a bit like buying a custom-made suit: it may not have to fit perfectly forever, but it sure should fit nicely now. What follows are some tips, strategies and cautions offered by brokers, mortgage specialists, lawyers and others with long experience in real estate for finding the best fit for the first-time home-buyer's dollar.
"The first piece of advice I give first-time buyers is to figure out how much house they can honestly afford," said Jack Hopkins, an associate broker at Harbor Gates Realty in Greenlawn, N.Y. "The second is to figure out what kind of house they want to live in."
While both suggestions may seem obvious, Mr. Hopkins said, it is not uncommon for those in search of a first home to spend a lot of time looking at houses they cannot afford. And all that does, the Long Island broker said, is make it more difficult to be satisfied with houses within their range.
Finding an affordable house, however, does not always mean finding a less expensive one. "I always explain to first-time buyers that you can work property taxes against the price of the house to end up with more house for your money," Mr. Hopkins said, explaining that a relatively small savings on annual property taxes can create a sizeable increase in the price of the house one can afford. "I show them that at today's interest rates, paying $1,000 a year less in property taxes will enable them to buy a house worth $12,000 more," he said; the increase in buying power comes from having more money available each month to pay the mortgage.
For example, Mr. Hopkins said, someone buying a $150,000 house with a $135,000 mortgage with a fixed rate of 7.5 percent interest for 30 years would have a monthly mortgage payment of $943.93. If the property taxes on the house are $5,000, he said, that would add $416.66 to the monthly payment, resulting in a total monthly payment of $1,360.59.
If, however, the annual taxes on the house are $4,000 instead of $5,000 -- a difference of $83.33 a month -- the purchaser could borrow an additional $12,000 and have the same monthly payment of $1,360.59.
Some buyers, Mr. Hopkins said, particularly young married couples, spend too much time looking at houses they might be able to afford but that one or the other doesn't like.
"I can't tell you how many times I'll sit down with couples who come into my office and find out that neither knows what the other wants," he said, adding that he encourages each to articulate "the house of their dreams" to the other, at times using drawings and cartoons of various kinds of houses to get the conversation flowing with specific examples. And even if they are far apart, he said, knowing what the other wants makes it easier to compromise.
A willingness to compromise is, of course, essential. "You have to keep an open mind," said Gina Guarnieri, a resident of Bronxville, N.Y., who, with her husband, Andrew Ripps, visited more than 50 properties before finding one they both liked in Cortlandt Manor in Westchester County.
LIKE many first-time home-buyers, Ms. Guarnieri and Mr. Ripps started their search with higher expectations than they eventually realized.
"We wanted to try and stay in lower Westchester," Ms. Guarnieri said, explaining that since both she and Mr. Ripps work in Manhattan, they wanted their commute to be as convenient as possible. But since home prices in Westchester generally increase as commuting times decrease, the couple found that they would have to head farther north in the county to get the most house for their money.
"You're not going to find exactly what you want," Ms. Guarnieri said. "There's always going to be something you're going to have to sacrifice."
In fact, she said, location is not the only thing to keep an open mind about.
"Initially, I would have preferred a Victorian or a colonial," Ms. Guarnieri said, adding that her husband preferred a more contemporary home. Both were surprised, then, when they walked into a 2,400 square-foot, three-bedroom contemporary-style home in Cortlandt Manor priced at $324,900 and she experienced the moment first-time home-buyers yearn for. "We called it 'The Feeling,' " Ms. Guarnieri said, that undefinable sense that the house is just the right fit.
And while the couple is negotiating with the owner and declined to say what they are willing to pay, they entered negotiations with a distinct advantage over less-savvy first-time buyers: They have already been approved for a mortgage. "One of the most important things a first-time buyer can do is get pre-approved for a mortgage," said Peter Bell, chief operating officer of Balch Buyers Realty in Mamaroneck, N.Y., the company that helped Ms. Guarnieri and Mr. Ripps.
"I'm not talking about prequalification, I'm talking about getting an actual commitment from a lender for a specific amount of money," Mr. Bell said, adding that obtaining pre-approval from a lender will not only give first-time buyers an indisputable idea of what they can afford -- it may also give them an edge over other buyers.
"We're still in a market where it's not unusual for sellers to get several full-price offers," he said. "And when they have to choose one buyer over another, they're probably going to pick the one who already has a mortgage lined up."
Mary Kay Gallagher, an independent real estate broker in the Prospect Park South neighborhood of Brooklyn, said that applying for a mortgage before starting to look for a house could result in a pleasant surprise for some buyers. "I'm finding that people can usually afford more than they think they can afford," Ms. Gallagher said. "I think it's because of the combination of low interest rates and banks being willing to lend more money with less money down."
In the not-too-distant-past, she said, sellers would get skittish about going into contract with a buyer with a low down payment, fearing that the buyer would ultimately not be able to get a mortgage. That fear is eliminated, however, if the buyer's mortgage has already been approved, no matter how low the down payment may be.
And how low is low?
"First-time buyers can get into a house with as little as 3 percent down," said John Minicozzi, a loan specialist with Norwest Mortgage in Wayne, N.J. "And in some cases, you can even borrow that."
Under a program sponsored by the Department of Housing and Urban Development, prospective buyers who want to save money by purchasing a handyman's special, hoping to improve the property while they own it, can now include the anticipated cost of the improvements in the mortgage.
"This is a great deal for first-time buyers," Mr. Minicozzi said, explaining that the program, known as Section 203(k), can be used to rehabilitate significantly deteriorated property or to make repairs or capital improvements in properties that just need upgrading. Section 203(k) mortgages have no income or geographical limitations, he said, and can be used for one- to four-family dwellings.
The down payment required under the program, Mr. Minicozzi said, is 3 percent. The total mortgage, which is based on the anticipated improved value of the property, cannot exceed F.H.A. loan limits for the area where the property is situated. In New York City and Westchester and Rockland Counties, Fairfield County in Connecticut and Bergen County in New Jersey, the maximum 203(k) loan is $208,800 for a one-family house and $401,375 for a four-family.
A similar mortgage product -- offered through lenders approved by Fannie Mae, a Congressionally chartered, shareholder-owned corporation that is the nation's largest source of residential mortgage funds -- allows buyers to obtain mortgages up to current Fannie Mae limits. Those limits range from $240,000 for a one-family house to $461,350 for a four-family. The borrowers may apply up to 50 percent of the financing to repairs and structural alterations and to nonessential items like sun rooms, swimming pools, saunas and even hot tubs.
Raschelle Burton, a spokeswoman for Fannie Mae, said that the minimum down payment for such loans is 5 percent. Another Fannie Mae program, Flexible 97, allows buyers to obtain mortgages with as little as 3 percent down -- and that 3 percent can be a gift from a family member.
But what can a first-time buyer do if there are no potential benefactors in the family? "You might be able to borrow some money from yourself," said Saul Simon, a certified financial planner in Edison, N.J.
Under current law, Mr. Simon said, a person who has a 401(k) retirement plan can borrow 50 percent of the plan balance, up to $50,000, and use it for a down payment on a house, no matter how the mortgage is obtained. "You're not paying any penalty because you're taking the money as a loan," he said. "Then you pay yourself back at 5 or 6 percent interest and amortize the repayment over five years. It's a great technique."
For those who don't want to borrow money, even from themselves, because it will increase their monthly expenses and so decrease the maximum mortgage they can qualify for, there is another option.
"A person with an Individual Retirement Account can withdraw up to $10,000 without paying a penalty, and then use the money as a down payment on a house," Mr. Simon said. "It's only available for first-time home buyers," he said, adding that the withdrawn money is taxable and must be reported as ordinary income.
EILEEN DALY, an associate broker with Prudential Rand Real Estate in Nanuet, N.Y., said that many first-time buyers believe that the best mortgage for them is an adjustable-rate loan. But, she said, such mortgages, which have a low introductory interest rate that can increase after as little as one year, are a risky proposition in today's market.
"Interest rates are so reasonable today that most people are much better off with a fixed-rate loan," Ms. Daly said. "At least you know your payments are going to remain the same no matter what happens to the interest rate."
Keith T. Gumbinger, vice president of HSH Associates, a mortgage publishing company in Butler, N.J., agreed. "The interest rate on one-year adjustables is about 5.8 percent today," Mr. Gumbinger said, about 1.3 percentage points lower than the current rate for 30-year fixed-rate loans. However, he said, under the terms of most adjustable-rate mortgage agreements, that 5.8 percent will likely jump to 7.5 percent next year, even if interest rates on fixed-rate loans remain the same.
"Adjustables are usually worthwhile only when the difference between the 30-year fixed rate and the one-year adjustable is 2.25 percent or more," he said. "That at least provides you with some fairly substantial savings in the first year and a bit of a cushion in the second."
Some new programs reduce the cost of Private Mortgage Insurance, which is generally required when the down payment is less than 20 percent. The Mortgage Guarantee Insurance Corporation in Milwaukee allows borrowers to reduce their monthly insurance payments by including part of the insurance cost in the mortgage. And Fannie Mae's "Lowest Cost M.I." program, available from lenders who use its Desktop Underwriter system, allows borrowers to make down payments of as little as 5 or 10 percent without having to buy P.M.I.
Of course, innovative mortgage programs won't help a first-time buyer with bad credit -- right?
"Not so," said Gerri Detweiler, education adviser for Debt Counselors of America, a nonprofit debt counseling agency based in Rockville, Md. Ms. Detweiler said that even those with negative marks on their credit -- late payments, repossessions, liens, judgments and even bankruptcy -- can get a mortgage if they have sufficient income.
"For many years, mortgage lenders only wrote A loans," Ms. Detweiler said, explaining that such loans -- typically available only to borrowers with excellent credit -- usually carry the best interest rates and require the lowest down payments.
In recent years, however, increasing numbers of lenders have been writing what are known as B, C and D loans for borrowers with credit histories ranging anywhere from marred to horrible. And while such loans generally require significant down payments and carry higher-than-average interest rates, she said, their availability makes it possible for even those with terrible credit to buy a house.
No matter what a prospective buyer thinks his or her credit history is, Ms. Detweiler said, it is always prudent to call one of the three nationwide credit reporting agencies -- Equifax, TransUnion or Experion -- and request a credit report. The typical fee is $8.
"Ideally, you should do this six to eight weeks before you plan to get pre-approved," Ms. Detweiler said, explaining that if incorrect information is contained in the report, the borrower should obtain reports from the other agencies to see if the mistake is repeated and then advise each agency of all errors. "There will be a form included with the report that can be used to dispute any incorrect information," she said. "Fill out the form and send it in as soon as possible because mistakes don't get fixed overnight."
For negative items that are not removed or credit blotches that are accurate, she said, it is typically worthwhile for the borrower to send the agency a statement giving the borrower's side of the story.
"You're allowed by law to have a 100-word statement added to your credit report," she said. "Just be sure to make it straightforward, honest and factual."
Once first-time buyers have decided what kind of house they're looking for and where they are going to look for it, and once the best available financing is in place, the only thing left is start looking.
"The biggest mistake first-time buyers make is buying as the result of an emotional decision," said Enid Hamelin, director of advertising and public relations for Lawrence Properties, a Manhattan brokerage company. "They walk into a house or apartment and the first thing they do is visualize where the nursery is going to be and what it will look like."
And while getting "the feeling" about a particular house or apartment is undoubtedly important, Ms. Hamelin said, it is just as important to keep in mind that buying property is an investment. "This is business," she said. "And one has to do one's homework."
For example, Ms. Hamelin said, a prospective purchaser looking at a co-op or condominium apartment should try to talk to as many people in the building as possible -- particularly the superintendent or other building employees -- to obtain as much first-hand information as possible.
Those buying houses, she said, should make a trip to the buildings department in the town where the property is situated and ask to see whatever documentation is on file for the house.
"You might find out that your dream house is built on a landfill," she said.
One of the most important things a buyer can do, she said -- particularly a first-time buyer who may not be familiar with how a house works -- is hire a competent engineer to inspect the property.
"You want somebody who is going to do a hands-on inspection," she said. "You want the house inspected inside and outside, from top to bottom. You want an inspector who will be able to tell you exactly what you're buying." House inspections can cost from several hundred dollars to $1,000, Ms. Hamelin said, depending on the type and location of the property.
Richard L. Heimer, president of Heimer Engineering in Huntington Station, N.Y., said that a similar price range applies to co-ops and condominiums. While such inspections cannot cover a building's structural details, he said, they are nevertheless important because they emphasize items unique to the apartment.
ANDREW BRODNICK, a White Plains real estate lawyer, said that it is also important for first-time buyers to accompany the engineer or inspector while the inspection is being performed. That, he said, will allow the buyer to ask specific questions about appliances and systems in the house. In addition, he said, it would be very helpful for a buyer to obtain a copy of the survey for the property and ask the engineer to walk the property lines with the survey in hand and the buyer in tow.
"It's easy to think you own a section of property that really belongs to your neighbor," Mr. Brodnick said, adding that a buyer should also determine, with the help of the lawyer who will handle the closing, whether there are existing easements or rights-of-way that give others use or access to the property. "I've seen easements where the next-door neighbor has a right to use a driveway but has no obligation to plow it," he said.
Jerome Billingsley, an owner of Frances Billingsley Realty in Katonah, N.Y., said that first-time buyers looking in an area they are not familiar with should drive around the neighborhood -- a lot -- at different times of day. "Drive into town one way and out another," Mr. Billingsley said. "Drive around at 8 o'clock on a Monday morning to find out where the traffic is and drive around on Friday night to find out where the teenagers hang out."
And once zeroed in on a particular house, he said, get out of the car and walk.
"Knock on the neighbors' doors, talk to them, find out what they like about the neighborhood and what they don't like about it," he said. "If you're moving into a development, talk to people who live there and ask if there are any problems with the houses. They'll probably be able to tell you something the broker doesn't even know."
If, after all that, Mr. Billingsley said, a house still seems right, be decisive. "In this market you've got to move quickly," he said. "I know many a person who has found a house they love, but then gone and seen a couple of dozen more only to come back and find the first house already in contract."
And finally, he said, every buyer should resist the urge to be "penny wise and pound foolish" when negotiating in a seller's market. "I've seen quarter-million-dollar sales fall apart over a $250 chandelier," Mr. Billingsley said. "If the seller wants to take the chandelier, let them have it. You can always buy another."

HEADLINE: Tax Reassessment Bid Lacking on Wish List

BYLINE: By DONNA GREENE 

 BODY:
WHEN Westchester tax rates were set last December there seemed to be little correlation between the budget the county had adopted and what some local governments were being billed, raising a cry from County Legislators for a state law that would let the county change its system of assessment.
But for the second year in a row, a request for state authorization to make changes in methods of assessment, upon which tax rates are set, is not on the county's wish list, reflecting a division among legislators and concern that any proposal that does not have the support of the business community might be vetoed by Gov. George E. Pataki, as he did with a reassessment plan in 1996. 
 Only in a letter accompanying its 1999 state legislative package approved earlier this month do County Executive Andrew J. Spano and the Board of Legislators even mention overhauling the tax-assessment system, saying, "Westchester shall continue to work to eliminate the inequities among existing property tax bills." Toward that end, the letter said, the Westchester Municipal Officials Association is working to "identify and develop along with the business community, acceptable options to deal with this problem."
In contrast, in its requests sent to Albany, the county most wants the state to grant it a higher reimbursement rate for federally mandated programs to teach handicapped preschoolers and continued authorization to impose an extra 1 percent sales tax. The preschool program will cost about $68 million this year. The sales tax raises about $80 million a year, part of which is shared by the county government with local governments and school districts.
In 1996, the State Legislature, at the urging of a bipartisan majority of county legislators, approved a bill that would have directed the county government to reassess all its property within five years, phase in any increases that some homeowners could face and allow the county to set up a so-called classification system, by which businesses could be taxed differently (presumably at a higher rate) from residences. That bill was vetoed by Governor Pataki, who said at the time it could have "unintended, devastating consequences for local economies." The veto came in the aftermath of an 11th-hour lobbying effort against the bill by some county-based corporations, including Pepsico and I.B.M.
Proponents of reassessment say many parcels in the county have not been reassessed for years and contend there are large disparities in taxes paid by property owners with nearly identical parcels. Opponents cite a shift of the tax burden to businesses, which the legislation might cause.
The confusion that the tax system creates was dramatized last December when the county enacted a 1999 budget that decreased by 0.65 percent the amount it collected in property taxes but still resulted in double-digit property tax increases in some communities while lowering them in others. The disparity is caused because each local government uses different assessing practices and assesses property at a different percent of full value.
Two key members of Westchester's delegation to the State Legislature say they are ready to carry the ball again on reassessment when -- and if -- the county asks them to.
State Senator Nicholas A. Spano, Republican of Yonkers and chairman of the Westchester Republican Committee, said: "The County Executive has indicated he has been working with municipal officials to craft an agreement that business can also sign on to. If that happens we're prepared to act."
He and Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky, Democrat of Greenburgh, said they support proposals to tax business property at a higher rate than residential property. Mr. Brodsky called it unfortunate that the county has not yet acted, saying, "The business community and real estate guys have lobbied very effectively, which they have every right to do."
The two lawmakers did not think it was likely that the county would get a higher reimbursement for programs for teaching handicapped preschoolers. One program serves children up to age 3 and the other up to 5. The county maintains that the state has reneged on a promise to reimburse counties for almost 70 percent of some of the programs' costs, paying instead 50 to 60 percent. Westchester argues that the state should pay 75 percent.
Mr. Brodsky said: "We're always looking to improve and control these programs and get as much money as possible, but it has never been an effective tactic to accuse someone you're trying to work with of having broken promises, especially when it's not true. It's one of many budget issues we have to fight, including a big battle on the Governor's attempt to cut back on special ed funding."
Mr. Spano said: "I have to be realistic. This is an issue with ramifications outside of Westchester," and so would be very costly to the state.
As for the sales tax, the two Legislators are divided. Mr. Brodsky opposes -- as he has unsuccessfully in the past -- the extension of the extra 1 percent sales tax; Mr. Spano supports it. The 1 percent sales tax, first enacted in 1991, is in addition to other sales taxes collected in Westchester by the county, the state, some cities and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. Total sales taxes within the county range from 6.75 percent to 8.25 percent.
In its package to the state legislators, the Westchester lawmakers wrote: "Without an extension of the Westchester County Property Tax Stabilization and Relief Act, the county will be forced to find alternative revenue sources and/or cut service to make up for the losses," adding, "Regardless of how the revenue is made up, it is certain that the end result will be significant erosion in the quality of life for all Westchester County residents."

HEADLINE: THE ENVIRONMENT;
Proposal for Huge Mall in Meadowlands Is Mired in Debate

BYLINE: By GEORGE JAMES 

DATELINE: CARLSTADT

 BODY:
The Meadowlands has been viewed as many things: a shelter for wildlife, a water filtration system and a dump. And it has also been seen, because of its location a half-dozen miles from Manhattan, as a prime location for development.
Now a proposal for a huge mall amid the acres of brown, brittle weeds called phragmites has been working its way through a review process involving Federal and state agencies that resembles a snake digesting a pig. 
 The approval process -- aimed at regulating development in some parts of the 32-square-mile marshland bordered by 14 communities while preserving the environment in others -- is a complex and lengthy one.
"Projects in the wetlands are extremely contentious and controversial," said Joseph J. Seebode, chief of the regulatory branch of the Army Corps of Engineers in the New York District. He could have been talking about a hearing last week at the Hackensack Meadowlands Development Commission, when opponents argued over the economic and environmental effect of the project.
The Meadowlands Commission is considering a variance that would eliminate a provision for construction of residential housing adjacent to the mall. Another variance would eliminate a buffer zone that would join two tracts for the construction. Further hearings are scheduled for Wednesday and March 29, and a vote on the variances is scheduled for April.
"The process may be lengthy," Mr. Seebode said, but we think it is an objective process to evaluate these projects."
David J. Charette, a consulting engineer from Warren who is working for Mills Corporation of Arlington, Va., the mall's developer, said the process allows the regulatory agencies, the public and other parties to to address all the issues and make informed decisions. ""It can be very time-consuming, said Mr. Charette,"which, obviously, from a developer's point of view means: time is money."
The process apparently is so complex that it took a full day for the Hackensack Meadowlands Commission to come up with a description of it. Officials also declined to discuss the Mills proposal while the project is under review.
The mall, at 2.1 million square feet, would be the largest in the state. Consisting of brand-name retail outlets, a score of specialty stores, a multiplex theater, a dozen restaurants, office towers and a 1,000-room hotel, it would cost $1 billion to build.
The plan, which would encompass about 590 acres, would make it the biggest project in the Meadowlands after the 750-acre sports complex, which was built in 1974.
The company is seeking a permit from the Army Corps of Engineers, which has Federal oversight of wetlands, to fill in 206 acres on which the actual complex would be built, a move opposed by enviromentalists, and the two variances from the Hackensack Meadowlands Development Commission, a state agency with planning and zoning jurisdicton.
Under the plan, Mills would also spend $25 million to restore 380 acres of what is now primarily a polluted expanse covered by the tall, thick, brown phragmites. On a recent visit visible amid the reeds was a disembowled washing machine, a rusted wheel well of a car and other urban litter.
This area to be restored encompasses two-thirds of the overall project site: a 550-acre site bounded in the east by the western spur of the New Jersey Turnpike, Paterson Plank Road in the south, Washington Avenue, which is lined by industry to the west, and the Hackensack River to the north and another 40 acres to the east of the turnpike.
Many environmentalists fear that allowing Mills to fill so large a space will result in even more development.
But many area officials and labor leaders support the project, saying it will bring an estimated 2,500 construction jobs and 9,000 permanent jobs.
A plan by Mills to fill in 206 acres of wetlands currently is being held up as the Corps develops an environmental impact statement. In the Corps review process, a developer submits a permit application to fill in wetland. The Corps requests more information, and receiving that, issues a public notice about the project.
The notice generates comment from the public and governmental agencies. A public hearing on the Mills project generated "a lot of public comment," Mr. Seebode said.
"As a result of that process. we determined that the project warranted a full environmental impact statement," Mr. Seebode said.
The next step will be to issue a draft environmental impact statement for public comment and a public hearing. Comments will be incorporated in the final environmental impact statement and be sent out for another 30 days for public review.
The Corps then will collect and evaluate the comments and issues a record of decision, which concludes with a decision.
Mr. Seebode said the draft environmental impact statement on the Mills project should be out by early summer. He described the date for a final decision to this point as having been "a moving target." But he added, a decision is expected before the end of 1999.
The Corps works closely with the Hackensack Meadowlands Commission, which must determine whether a project complies with the Coastal Zone Development act before the Corps can consider granting a permit.
In the meantime, a decision by Federal authorities is pending on a "special area management plan," proposed by the Meadowlands Commission, that would limit the number of wetlands that could be filled and developed.

HEADLINE: IN BRIEF;
Lower Interest Rates

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
The state's Mortgage Agency has dropped its interest rate, under a low-interest-rate program, to 5.5 percent. To expand the number of families eligible for its programs, effective March 1, the program, commonly known as Sonyma, also increased the household income limits for house buyers.
"We're making the American dream of home ownership more attainable for hard-working New York families," Gov. George E. Pataki said. 
 For Westchester residents, that means raising the limit for a family of three from $91,880 to $111,860, the second-highest limit in the state. In Rockland, the income limit for a family of three rose from $92,690 to $112,840 -- the highest income limit.
The Low Interest Rate Mortgage Program provides up to 97 percent financing on one- to four-family dwellings, including condominium units, and 90 percent financing for cooperative units and mobile homes.
Since 1970, the program has given more than 110,OO0 families a chance to buy houses through various programs. Sonyma's home ownership programs are primarily financed with tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds. Financing is made available through a network of 96 lenders. For more information, home buyers can contact the agency's toll-free number, (800) 382-4663.

HEADLINE: IN BRIEF;
Polluted Runoff

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
The most common source of water pollution is runoff -- from city streets, parking lots, marinas, construction sites, logging sites and roadways -- and it threatens the public health and the economy of coastal communities. That is the conclusion of a report released by 20 organizations, including Save the Sound, an environmental group in Glen Cove and Stamford.
In the state, 100 percent of the shellfish bed closings are attributable to polluted runoff, John Atkin, president of Save the Sound, said. In Connecticut, the number is similar, with 96 percent of the closings caused by polluted runoff. 
 "If Long Island Sound and the tributaries that feed it are to see marked improvement in the next decade and beyond," it will require a more focused effort by governments of both states and local governments to address the polluted runoff portion of the equation, particularly the impact of storm water," Mr. Atkin said.
Surrounded by one of the most densely populated areas in the United States, the Sound is particularly vulnerable to pollution, the report says, adding that as the area grows, the pressures on wetlands, forested areas and undeveloped lands also increases. ELSA BRENNER

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: LOWER MANHATTAN;
N.Y.U. Hospital Plans a High-Rise, to Neighbors' Dismay

BYLINE: By BERNARD STAMLER 

 BODY:
For years, the vacant lot in the block bordered by Beekman, Spruce, Nassau and Gold Streets has been used as a hospital parking lot. But last week, the president of New York University Downtown Hospital told a Community Board 1 committee meeting that financial pressures are forcing the hospital to put up a building, perhaps as tall as 45 stories, on the site. Many neighbors reacted warily to the plan.
The hospital was established in 1920 after a terrorist bombing at the Wall Street headquarters of J. P. Morgan pointed out the need for medical care nearby. Known for many years as Beekman Downtown Hospital, it became New York University Downtown after affiliating with New York University Medical Center. 
 Whatever its name, the hospital, just a few blocks south of Chinatown, has long suffered financially because of its large immigrant clientele.
"We serve four to five times as many Medicaid patients and three to four times as many uninsured patients than, say, New York Hospital," its president, Leonard A. Aubrey, told a meeting of Board 1's Seaport-Civic Center committee on Tuesday night, a session that was attended by more than 20 local residents. He noted that the state had classified the hospital as "financially distressed" in 1995. Its affiliation with New York University Medical Center provides the hospital with access to the larger institution's experts and its managed care contracts, but no additional subsidies, he said.
"The idea of the building is to help the hospital survive," Mr. Aubrey said. "We have a very serious problem facing us in the coming years."
He said that development of the parking lot, deeded to the hospital long ago as part of an urban renewal project, offers a unique opportunity to raise badly needed money. The hospital does not expect to complete plans for at least a year, he said, adding that he envisions a building with an outpatient clinic, assisted living quarters for the elderly and market-rate apartments. To make the project profitable, he said, variances would be sought from the city to allow a building of 800,000 to 1 million square feet, or 40 to 45 stories.
Neighborhood residents who attended the meeting questioned whether the building needed to be that tall. Phil Toy, the president of the co-op board of 140 Nassau Street, adjacent to the parking lot, said he feared that construction might damage his building, as did recent work on the parking lot.
Others wondered whether the restrictions of the urban renewal deed, which requires the site to be used for a "health facility," would be satisfied by the mixed-use structure that Mr. Aubrey proposed. Most in attendance fretted about the noise and dirt of construction, and the prospect of losing their light and views to the new building.
"It terrifies me," said Lori Lasch, who has lived for 10 years at 140 Nassau Street. "If they build it, I'll never be able to keep my windows open." BERNARD STAMLER

SECTION: Section 9; Page 1; Column 3; Style Desk 

LENGTH: 1436 words

HEADLINE: Trying To Stay True to The Street

BYLINE: By LESLIE KAUFMAN 

 BODY:
WHEN Daymond John, the co-founder and chief executive of Fubu hip-hop clothing, drives through his old neighborhood in Hollis, Queens, he leaves no doubt that he has moved on -- and up.
His Bentley, royal blue with a matching pinstripe on the cream-color upholstery and so new that plastic wrap still covers the wood paneling, makes heads spin in this working-class enclave. Mr. John shook his head when he saw two women walking by to inspect the car. "I haven't brought it around here before because it makes us look unattainable," he explained. 
 Appearing attainable is no small concern. Fubu stands for "For us, by us." The company, which was founded in 1992, has prospered by promoting itself as a black-owned label by and for young urban men. The founders, who also include Carl Brown, Keith Perrin and J. Alexander Martin, all from Hollis, insist that "For us, by us" is not a call to racial exclusiveness, but clearly race is part of their appeal. "Customers see our pictures and can relate, whereas they couldn't relate to some 45-year-old man living in Italy," Mr. John, 30, said. "We are just like them. We are the consumer."
In other words, Fubu's origins give it street credibility. And these days, street credibility translates into sales. The company says its revenues rocketed nearly tenfold, from $40 million in 1997 to a stunning $350 million last year, which catapults it beyond a niche market into a league with labels like Donna Karan ($670 million) and Tommy Hilfiger ($847 million.)
But because Fubu's success is so dependent on its homeboy appeal, this wow-wow growth carries risks. If the company is going to expand as much as Mr. John and his partners would like -- and in the last year they've added everything from backpacks to a men's suit line -- it will have to do even more business with middle-class, mainstream America. The problem is that nothing destroys the urban buzz of a label quite so fast as having Westchester teen-agers clamor for it. Tony Shellman, vice president of Enyce, a Fubu competitor, predicts, "Fubu is going to lose its street essence as little Johnny in suburbia starts picking up its stuff."
For now, the brand is having an it moment. Not only is the rapper LL Cool J, a company spokesman, seen wearing Fubu designs (he sports Fubu's signature oversize football and hockey shirts), but also stars like Janet Jackson, Will Smith and Whitney Houston. At night, Mr. John and his partners make the scene with style players like Sean (Puffy) Combs, the rap impresario. They recently received an award for black economic enterprise from Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. Mr. John, who wore a black, sueded rubber Fubu track suit to Gracie Maison to accept it, took the attention in stride. "Just business," he explained.
Coming up fast, however, are copycat competitors who say they have a better bead on the street's needs than Fubu. These days it seems that every other rap and inner-city entrepreneur is hawking his own line of baggy fashions.
At some of Manhattan's most fashion-conscious emporiums of urban gear, Fubu is already losing ground to challengers like Phat Farm, Mecca USA and Enyce (pronounced en-EE-chay). At Transit, today's must stop-and-shop, on Lower Broadway, Nikki Abreu, a manager, said: "We dont even carry Fubu anymore. It wasn't selling that much. Enyce is the hottest."
Because Fubu is privately owned, it does not have to publish its sales figures, and, in fact, next year it won't. Some analysts speculate that it is a sign of trouble. But Mr. John and his partners don't appear to be panicked by their rivals. Short, thick and supremely confident, Mr. John is the de facto company spokesman and persona. He brags that Fubu has a far closer relationship with customers than other clothing labels have.
"How many companies do you know that get 5,000 E-mail messages a day?" he asked. The E-mail often includes detailed design suggestions. Some of those, Mr. John said, like making a soft leather jacket covered with small embroidered patterns, have been followed up by Fubu.
Mr. John is too smooth to say so, but he clearly keeps close tabs on how his company is faring on the streets. He does not want his Bentley mentioned in this article, for example, because "people might get the wrong idea."
The founders also keep a high profile in the old neighborhood, doing good works like handing out Thanksgiving turkeys and filling the Christmas wish lists of needy local children.
In the end, the Fubu men rely on one another to stay grounded. All of their clothes, whether designed in the house by Mr. Martin or by outside licensees, have to be approved by three of the four partners. They make a wide range of products, from the core men's casual line, emphasizing oversize cuts and bright colors, to footwear and lounge wear (think red satin robes a la Hugh Hefner).
"If we all like it, it'll probably sell," Mr. John said confidently. Whatever the changing public perception, he believes that he and his partners are too rooted in their community to be cut off from it by a little flash and money.
Their life story, as he tells it, is a Horatio Alger tale updated for the VH-1 age. In 1992, Mr. John was waiting tables at a local Red Lobster and working any get-rich scheme he could think of. These included, as he told Vibe magazine this month, dealing crack cocaine. "It wasn't until I started the company that I didn't have something crooked going on," he was quoted as saying by Vibe.
Although being known as a former drug dealer may enhance a rap star's "street cred," it is no asset for a businessman whose clothes are manufactured and distributed by Samsung, the Korean electronics giant. Mr. John declined to comment on the Vibe article. A company spokeswoman, Leslie Short, said, "Those remarks were taken out of context, and frankly I am very angry."
Fubu began modestly enough. The fashion rage at the time was wool hats with their tops cut off and tied with string. When Mr. John saw the hats being sold for $20, he corraled a next-door neighbor, Carl Brown, to help sew up a bunch. The two sold their homemade headwear for $10 a pop in front of the New York Coliseum. They made $800 in a single day, and a clothing label was born.
There were years of struggle as Mr. John and Mr. Brown (whose job now is to handle licensees), joined by Mr. Martin and Mr. Perrin (who now manages celebrity relations), moved into Mr. John's mother's house and sewed logos on hockey jerseys and sweatshirts. Their first break came in 1993, when they convinced LL Cool J, a double-platinum rapper, who grew up a just few blocks from Mr. John's home, to pose in a Fubu T-shirt. It took months more of cajoling and sitting in on video shoots to persuade him to wear the line while performing. When he did, Fubu started taking off. The rapper, a paid spokesman for the company since 1996, managed to pull off a perfect bit of insider subversion by wearing a Fubu hat in an advertisement he did for the Gap a couple of years ago.
Mr. John says the company also found motivation in what the partners perceived as efforts by white-owned outdoor apparel brands like Timberland and North Face, popular with inner-city youths, to distance themselves from the customers who were making them street chic.
Fubu's marketing played off a sense of shared resentment at being ignored. Gritty pictures of Fubu's founders, posed with exposed tattoos, reversed baseball caps and a hint of gang-style menace, started popping up in magazine advertisements and even on the company's labels. The message was clear enough to the initiated.
"I knew what they were talking about, and it made me happy," said Tracii McGregor, executive editor of The Source, a magazine on hip-hop culture. "The way they are marketing is unmistakably black."
But gangsta style has it limitations, said Irma Zandl, president of a youth marketing consulting firm in New York. "There is something about their premise that is a little alienating for nonblacks," she continued. "I've had white kids say to me, 'They don't want me to wear this.' "
David Watkins, president and chief executive of Icon Lifestyle Marketing, a marketing company that focuses on urban areas, said that even if this were true, concessions of any type to the suburban market would be the wrong way to go. So far, Fubu has done well, he said, because "they have let people outside the market come to them, instead of the other way around."
He offered Fubu a bit of Shakespearean advice: "They just have to keep their marketing message the same -- and be true to themselves."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 8; Column 2; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 761 words

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
A Goodbye To the Weight Of Leveraging

BYLINE: By LAURA M. HOLSON 

 BODY:
WHEN RJR Nabisco Holdings' plan to split itself into two companies made headlines last week, a notorious chapter in the history of corporate restructuring came closer to an end. But no one waxed nostalgic for the good old 1980's.
Instead, a collective sigh could be heard as RJR, a symbol of that era's daring experiment in financial engineering, began its transformation back into two companies, as was the case 14 years ago. 
 The leveraged buyouts of that decade -- when financiers like Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company took over established companies using immense issues of high-yield debt, hoping to whittle them into lean operations and sell them for a profit -- did little for the target companies. According to KDP Investment Advisors, a Montpelier, Vt., research firm, of the 25 cases between 1985 and 1989 where companies were saddled with more than $1 billion in high-yield debt, almost half defaulted on their loans. Even more filed for bankruptcy or sold off substantial assets. Meanwhile, bond holders who got stuck with the junk watched its value drop.
"It was called 'the Debacle,' " said Kingman Penniman, president of KDP, referring to the number of companies that could not pay their debts. "A lot of these investors were not creators of new companies."
The debacle was due, in part, to a slowing domestic economy early in the 1990's. Companies burdened with billions in loans and faltering earnings stumbled under the strain -- perhaps most notably RJR Nabisco, which might have split up sooner, or grown its food business faster, were it not for its big interest payments, among other things. Many debt-laden companies emerged as more efficient operations, but not without great personal and social costs.
Still, companies and investors learned several lessons. And experts say it is questionable whether the United States market will again see the types of deals that were common a decade ago. The percentage of junk bonds borrowed by leveraged-buyout firms hovers at 15 percent of all high-yield offerings, said Dwight Sipprelle, co-head of global high-yield operations at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, down from 50 percent peak levels in the 1980's.
Companies today are less apt to borrow without good reason. "It's cheaper for companies to issue stock than debt," Mr. Penniman said -- though, of course, interest rates are lower on today's junk bonds. And corporate managers have greater personal incentives, in the form of stock option packages, to increase shareholder value.
 BOND issuers, too, have become more disciplined as the high-yield market has matured. "Some things are just too risky and won't get done," Mr. Sipprelle said. Still, high-yield debt is one of the few remaining investments that can deliver double-digit returns, so many investors will snap up bonds representing even the most aggressive financing.
Another change from the 1980's is that corporations are now more likely to use junk bonds to finance expansion as well as acquisitions, particularly in hot growth areas like telecommunications, cable and media. This harkens back to the period before the leveraged-buyout boom, when respected companies like MCI Communications and Time Warner used junk bonds to jump-start their growth in the late 1970's and early 1980's.
Viatel, a fledgling global long-distance provider that went public in 1996, borrowed $900 million through high-yield debt in 1998 and is raising more money that way to help expand its network.
Of course, consolidation, the major theme in this decade's merger wave, is still a driver of the leveraged market. Last week, Allied Waste Industries, along with two financial buyout firms, announced a friendly acquisition of the trash hauler Browning-Ferris Industries, financed in part by borrowing $9.5 billion.
Europe, too, is discovering American-style merger financing. Consider Olivetti's $60 billion hostile bid for Telecom Italia. Such a bold move would have been unthinkable a few years ago, in part because continental Europe essentially had no high-yield market.
So what is the biggest risk in this era's high-yield lending? The same one that caused the last debacle: a downturn in the economy or an industry.
"When the stock market is humming along, things are great," said Steven N. Kaplan, a professor of finance in the graduate school of business at the University of Chicago. "The risk is -- and this has not yet been tested in this market -- if there is a downturn and companies have to make interest payments. If you can't make it, you've got a problem."

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH: William V. Fries;
Thornburg Value Fund

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
THE idea, as always, is to buy low and sell high -- but that doesn't mean that William V. Fries looks only at stocks with tiny price-to-earnings ratios.
A low ratio can sway him, of course, but Mr. Fries, who runs the $297.4 million Thornburg Value fund, has a more elastic definition of "value" than many of his peers. And investors tend to take notice: Thornburg Value had an annual average return of 29.7 percent in the three years through March 5, compared with 28.5 percent for the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, placing it in the top 2 percent of mid-cap value funds, according to Morningstar Inc., the financial publisher in Chicago. The fund returned 14.2 percent in the 12 months through March 5, below the 22.6 percent of the S.& P. but still in the top 4 percent of its peer group. 
 Thornburg Value has achieved such performance in part by thinking small -- in portfolio size. The fund holds just 42 stocks, compared with 111 in the average value fund, according to Morningstar.
Mr. Fries, who is 60, favors three broad categories of stocks: the basic-value companies that are the bread and butter of his trade, but also what he calls "consistent growers" and "emerging franchises."
He chooses basic-value stocks -- which account for 56 percent of the fund's assets -- by using traditional yardsticks like low price-to-earnings and price-to-book ratios and high dividend yields. For these stocks, which tend to be clustered in the financial services, energy and telecommunications industries, he aims to pay no more than two-thirds of the market multiple -- the average price-to-earnings ratio of all S.& P. 500 stocks -- or about 22, lately.
The consistent growers, including pharmaceutical and consumer products companies, are 20 percent of the fund. "Typically these companies will be less cyclical or have more reliable top-line earnings growth," said Mr. Fries, who is willing to pay the market multiple for them.
He is willing to pay a premium, however, for his emerging franchises -- generally fast-growing companies that are not yet well-established in new or changing industries. "These stocks are a lot more risky and tend to grow much faster," he said in a phone interview from his office in Santa Fe, N.M. For these companies in the portfolio, he projects average earnings growth of at least 15 to 20 percent. (Emerging franchises account for 17 percent of the fund; most of the remainder is in cash.)
Mr. Fries sets a target selling price for each stock in his portfolio and veers from it only if the outlook for the company shifts significantly. For example, he has raised his target price for Charles Schwab & Company -- he won't specify how much -- because it has become a big force in Internet stock trading.
Most value-fund managers favor stocks with P/E ratios in the single or low double digits, but Mr. Fries can scour for bargains at much higher elevations. "We have a couple of positions in companies that haven't produced much in the way of earnings, like semiconductor manufacturers, and that drives up the P/E," he said.
Technology stocks account for more than 20 percent of the portfolio -- unusually high for a value fund. But he said prices were so cheap for some of these stocks last summer that he couldn't resist buying shares of Intel, Brooks Automation and Lam Research.
 ONE of his favorite basic-value stocks is El Paso Energy, a natural-gas company. Because of the company's extensive holdings overseas, the stock weakened last fall, when Mr. Fries began buying shares at $25 each. It closed on Friday at $35.75, or 17 times his 1999 earnings estimate of $2.10 a share. He predicted a three-year earnings growth rate of 10 percent.
Mr. Fries also sees big potential in American Home Products, a pharmaceutical company in which some other investors see mostly a dearth of blockbuster drugs. "It's been very good at making acquisitions, taking the costs out and boosting the revenues of acquired products," he said. He began buying the stock at $49 last June and projects a three-year earnings growth rate of 12 to 15 percent. It now trades at $65.375, about 33 times his 1999 earnings estimate of $2.
In the emerging-franchise category, Mr. Fries likes Advent Software, which produces software used by investment advisers to track, report and reconcile stock trades. In his view, Advent's software is the most popular and economical on the market. Given the aging of America and all those retirement nest eggs to be managed, he projects that Advent's earnings will climb 20 to 30 percent a year, on average, over three years.
He began buying Advent shares in November 1997 at $24 and recently added to his holdings. The stock now is at $48.875, or 31.5 times his 1999 earnings estimate of $1.55.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
As Tough As, Well, Netting a Butterfly

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

 BODY:
LIKE Muhammad Ali in his boxing prime, financial wagers on the Year 2000 problem can float like a butterfly, sting like a bee. Just ask futures traders at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.
They began betting last fall that the final days of 1999 would bring worldwide panic about potential Year 2000 computer glitches. They speculated that nervous people and businesses would hoard cash, putting a severe strain on banks and driving up borrowing costs for anyone needing credit. 
 By the end of the year, the traders had driven December 1999 futures prices to levels that, in effect, projected a devastating jump of about 13 percentage points in dollar interest rates at the end of this year. They did it with trades known as "butterflies" that usually look a bit like the insects when their components are charted. By December, the charts for the "millennium butterfly" -- the purchase of a September 1999 contract, the sale of two December 1999's and the purchase of a March 2000 -- had wings at the sharpest angles in memory.
The trading was greeted as an overdue guest by Year 2000 alarmists, who had been longing for evidence to support their predictions that Y2K, as the computer problem has been nicknamed, would make huge waves in the markets. It also grabbed much attention in banking circles. "We are all looking for road signs as to what will happen," a Year 2000 project manager at a major New York bank confided at the time.
The road sign has since been flattened, though, along with those who were certain it pointed somewhere. By last month, December futures prices had tumbled back into their traditional relationship with the September and March contracts. Participants were left wondering what to make of it all.
"I think it was a bubble rather than anything substantive," said Galen Burghardt, a senior vice president at Carr Futures, a brokerage firm based in Chicago. "If you really got a sense people couldn't bank at year-end, all hell would break loose."
The aborted flight of the futures butterfly has reinforced the prevailing sentiment that it does not pay -- so far, at least -- to bet that Year 2000 problems will produce any sharp moves in stocks, bonds and other mainstream markets. Some managers say it is a mistake to think that bets on Y2K will ever be rewarded.
"By definition, the stock market only moves on surprises, since today's prices reflect expectations," said Kenneth L. Fisher of Fisher Investments in Woodside, Calif., which manages $2.9 billion for institutions and private clients. "Y2K is no surprise."
 GIVE Mr. Fisher a gold medal in the Understatement Olympics. It would be a feat these days to find an investor who has never heard that the decades-old practice of using two digits in computer dates, like "99" for 1999, could trip up computers, programs and electronically controlled machines reading year 2000 dates. The "00" might be read as 1900 or not recognized as a valid date; some malfunctions lead to shutdowns and others to faulty calculations.
Still, many investment advisers and managers are not quite as confident as Mr. Fisher that the market has anticipated Y2K: Everyone may know that Y2K is coming, but there is great uncertainty over how extensive disruptions will be, where they will strike and when their impacts will be felt by individual companies and nations. Prices may plunge where disruptions hit or skyrocket where they do not.
Well before Jan. 1, some analysts say, the prospect of volatility could force trillions of dollars in investment portfolios to be rearranged as managers try to reduce their risks. If that happens, those who move before the crowd will, as always, pay less to achieve their goals. So even skeptics must be poised to jump.
"It's a puzzle to me," said Jonathan Muehl, a pension fund adviser at Buck Consultants in Pittsburgh, who sees no sign yet of Y2K hedging activity in options prices. (An option is the right to buy or sell a commodity, a stock or an entire basket of stocks for a specific price at a specific date in the future; a future is an obligation to complete such a deal.)
Mr. Muehl says options that would protect investors from sharp stock-portfolio declines in the trading days before 2000 currently sell at the Chicago Board Options Exchange and in over-the-counter trading at prices that imply almost no increase in the risk that stocks will gyrate later this year.
"It could be that the market isn't concerned, but part of me wonders whether the market has really focused on the issue yet," Mr. Muehl said.
The prevailing wisdom -- reflected in a report this month from a United States Senate special committee tracking Y2K as well as recent analyses by leading Wall Street brokerage firms -- is that overseas markets are especially vulnerable to Y2K problems. Most countries started dealing with Y2K later than the United States, and many developing nations are hard pressed for resources.
Just last month, the Global 2000 Coordinating Group, an international organization of more than 230 banks, insurance companies and other financial institutions, dropped plans to publicly rate the readiness of 35 key countries after regulators fretted privately that such a move could ignite a disruptive flight of capital. But lagging nations -- and the businesses within them -- may have received only a temporary reprieve.
"It is probably too early for Y2K factors to dominate an investment decision," said George A. Murnaghan, executive vice president and marketing manager at Rowe Price-Fleming International in Baltimore, which manages $30 billion for mutual funds and institutions with international portfolios. "As the year goes on, it will become more important."
To be sure, there has already been plenty of action involving the stocks of companies like Viasoft Inc. and Data Dimensions that have been beneficiaries of the billions being spent to repair Y2K defects.
Starting in 1996, such stocks soared -- and often later crashed -- as investors placed bets on how big the repair effort would be and which companies would profit most. Now all those players are treating Y2K as history as they race to convince Wall Street that they have viable strategies to prosper when the Year 2000 work dries up.
 BUT such investments were never bets on either the actual impact of Y2K or on how individuals and business will act in the final run up to it. Other than the butterfly, which involved contracts so large that only large institutional investors and professional traders at the Merc waded in, the only hot Year 2000 investment action to date has been in market niches like gold and silver coins, where small investors are chasing limited supplies.
The coins are being snapped up not only as investments but also because many alarmists see them as valuable assets for barter if the Year 2000 banking collapse they foresee comes to pass. Demand was so strong for 1998 Silver Eagles that the United States Mint ran out in early December; the 1999 version is already in short supply.
"The shortages are just driving demand higher," said David Harper, editor of Numismatic News, a weekly newspaper for coin collectors, based in Iola, Wis. He said many dealer quotes for the coins have been running at more than triple the once-common $1.25 premium to spot silver prices.
He recently wrote an editorial that warned of the potential for a crash in the coin markets if, as most experts predict, Y2K disruptions turn out to be minor in the United States. Prices may also dive if the Mint sharply increases its output this year, he said.
The coin markets are being stoked by feverish talk on the Internet of inevitable catastrophe come the millennium. More respected voices -- like Edward Yardeni, the chief economist at Deutsche Bank Securities, who gained a following on Wall Street for correctly forecasting the market boom of the 90's -- couch their warnings in terms of probabilities. Mr. Yardeni currently says there is a 70 percent chance that Y2K breakdowns will usher in a global recession and that the most likely impact on the stock market is a 30 percent to 40 percent decline.
Investors who bother to look up Mr. Yardeni's full analysis, however, might sit tight. He expects a major rebound in 2001 and sees the Dow Jones industrial average, currently at 9,876.35, reaching 15,000 by 2005. Of course, if he and other forecasters who are relatively gloomy about Y2K are correct, there are huge profits to be made by selling now and buying just after prices tumble.
"The market is currently priced for perfection, and that just won't happen," said Dennis G. Grabow, chief executive of the Millennium Investment Corporation, a Chicago-based investment adviser to pension funds with $20 billion in assets.
Mr. Grabow advocates dumping investments in emerging markets, urban real estate and the chemical industry, among others, in favor of Government bonds. He expects a "flight to quality" to drive up demand for such bonds, creating profits for those who hold them. Investors, he said, can easily move their money back into stocks once markets have absorbed a Y2K hit.
The market is not accurately anticipating Y2K, Mr. Grabow argued, because analysts are talking to their usual sources, like corporate financial officers, instead of those lower down the ranks who are managing repair work and testing.
But Mr. Grabow's view has been, at best, premature. He had predicted that anticipation of Y2K would send stocks down 25 percent last year; in fact, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 26.7 percent. Small investors who saw Tony Keyes on Oprah Winfrey's television program last year and snapped up his book, "The Year 2000 Computer Crisis: An Investor's Survival Guide" (Y2K Investor, 1997), may also have turned defensive too soon.
"I've left a lot of money on the table," conceded Mr. Keyes, a former computer systems analyst turned Washington talk-radio host.
He outlines many investment choices in his book but chose a defensive posture emphasizing Government bonds for himself. Though he largely missed the latest leg of the bull market in stocks, he added, the upside is that he has been sleeping well.
Such experiences underscore the exquisite timing skills that Y2K financial bets require -- exactly the kind of market timing that many Wall Street professionals and financial advisers tell investors to avoid. Not only are there varying theories of when disruptions might strike -- it could take months, for example, for overseas problems to hurt many American businesses -- but it is also difficult to predict when investors might start reacting.
Mr. Fisher, the California money manager, is fond of calling stock markets "The Great Humiliator."
He said he could easily envision a "relatively normal correction" this year in a market that has reached record prices. Such a correction, he said, could become exaggerated if "Y2K people come screaming out of the woodwork." Investors trying to time the market, he added, could be lured into foolish selling.
Others warn that even in the event of a New Year's debacle, the reactions in financial markets might not all be so obvious as a race into Government bonds. Y2K problems might not send markets tumbling in Asia, for example; so much money has already been pulled out of troubled stock markets there that major investors might simply delay reinvestment instead of selling more.
Or how about this twist: Big companies with no Year 2000 problems might face selling pressure if mutual funds see selling those stocks as the least costly way to build up cash to buy stocks they regard as unfairly beaten down. That picture seems plausible to the chief strategist of one of the country's biggest pension funds.
"We're long-term investors, but we're also opportunistic," he explained, speaking on the condition of anonymity.
 OF course, while institutions may have a variety of deft strategies for jumping on opportunities, history suggests that many will end up outwitting themselves if Year 2000 trouble develops. In every recent downturn, the big institutions have done the bulk of the misguided panic selling and small investors a large proportion of the timely buying.
One could easily imagine Y2K producing a similar result. Many of the most skittish small investors are already out of the market and into coins or other defensive investments. If trouble hits, they will not be around for the panic selling.
Instead, those left may well be mostly long-term investors perfectly willing to snap up any bargains the institutions create in their race to the exits.
 
From One Bug to Another
 UNCERTAINTY about the Year 2000 computer problem has popped up in the pits at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, where 90-day Eurodollar futures are traded by institutions trying to protect themselves from swings in interest rates.
Normally, the further away the period covered by a 90-day Eurodollar futures contract, the higher the projected interest rate, just as a loan due further in the future will usually carry a higher rate because of the added risk. In other words, today, a June futures contract -- which embodies the market's guess at what interest rates will be from mid-June to mid-September -- would be priced to reflect a lower rate than a September contract, which projects rates from mid-September through mid-December.
One common exception to the price patterns occurs because banks often need extra cash near year-end, especially over the New Year's holiday, when the Federal Reserve is closed. Speculating that the supply of money will be tight enough to force up interest rates temporarily, traders take a "butterfly" position across the September, December and March contracts.
When turned into a chart, this phenomenon usually shows what looks like gently angled "wings" from the September and March contracts to the December "body" between them. That implies a modest interest-rate increase the last day of the year. A typical trading pattern was seen last Nov. 13, shown in Chart 1.
However, late last year, Year 2000 fever drove implied interest rates way up for December 1999 futures, giving the butterfly sharply angled wings. At its peak on Dec. 28, the contract price indicated that traders expected a rate jump that was far larger than normal at the end of 1999, as shown in Chart 2.
By late February, the patterns were closer to normal. Since then, the trend has edged toward slightly more nervousness. But volume has dropped sharply, indicating that many traders have decided that the butterfly spread this year is too unpredictable to trade. Chart 3 shows the current picture.
How is the year-end butterfly turned into a calculation of projected interest rates? The difference between the projected December interest rate and the rate of the contracts on either side of it, September and March, is seen by banks as a starting point for estimating by how much market interest rates in the London currency market, where the Eurodollars are traded, will exceed the Federal Reserve overnight bank lending rate over the New Year's holiday.
Because the three-day New Year's weekend beginning Dec. 31, 1999, is one-thirtieth of the 90-day contract period, bankers simply multiply the difference by 30 to come up with a number that roughly approximates how much the market expects interest rates to jump at the end of the year.
As Chart 3 shows, traders still expect rates to climb, but not nearly to the extent that they did in December. BARNABY J. FEDER
