HEADLINE: Massacres of Low-Born Touch Off a Crisis in India

BYLINE: By CELIA W. DUGGER 

DATELINE: SHANKER BIGHA, India

 BODY:
This hamlet on the edge of a lush, palm-fringed field lay quiet on the moonlit night of Jan. 25. But as the villagers slept, more than 50 upper-caste men, members of an outlawed landowners' army, crept toward them through rustling spears of wheat.
The men fanned out in the dirt lanes, flinging open the doors of mud huts and shouting: "Kill them! Kill them!" Guns blazing, they massacred 22 people in just a few minutes, among them a 3-year-old boy and his baby sister, who were crying as they huddled in their grandmother's arms. 
 This massacre of farm workers and their families -- untouchables at the bottom of Hinduism's hierarchical social order -- was numbingly similar to dozens of others committed during nearly three decades in the eastern state of Bihar.
The state is blessed by mineral wealth and fertile soil but cursed by the nation's highest rates of illiteracy and poverty. Almost 9 out of 10 of the state's 100 million people live in the countryside, and more than half are very poor. The untouchables, who make up 14 percent of the population, are the poorest of the poor.
Bihar is now in the midst of an upheaval that has seen the middle castes depose the upper castes from the seats of political power. The untouchables -- now called Dalits, which means ground down in Hindi -- have not yet gained an independent political voice, but they have begun grass-roots organizing.
And as they have banded together under various leftist banners to agitate, sometimes violently, for higher wages, a share of land and an end to the sexual exploitation of Dalit women and other humiliations, both middle- and upper-caste landowners have struck back with terror tactics.
"In the American South after the Civil War, the lynchings of blacks were aimed at curbing their uppitiness," said Ashutosh Varshney, a political scientist at Columbia University. "India never had slavery, but the Dalits are as close to slavery as you can get. The massacres are aimed at checking their uppitiness."
Successive governments, dominated by the upper and middle castes, have failed since the 1970's to stop the carnage or to address the harsh social and economic inequalities between the landed and the landless that persist in Bihar and in most of north India.
But this time, the massacres got caught up in a power struggle between the upper and middle castes.
The bloodletting here in Shanker Bigha and another massacre of 12 untouchables on Feb. 11 in the village of Narayanpur set off a crisis that rocked the state's political establishment, humbled the national governing coalition and, for a time, riveted public attention on the violence that has raged like an intermittent fever.
The Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party, which draws most of its support in Bihar from the upper castes and which leads the national coalition Government, maintained that the massacres justified its dismissal of the middle-caste state government, widely seen as corrupt and inefficient.
But even after central rule was imposed in February, the violence continued. Retaliating for the massacres of untouchables, a squad of leftist militants gunned down seven people on Feb. 14, apparently for no reason except their upper-caste status, human rights workers said. Four more upper-caste men were slain on March 2. The police say they arrested 47 members of the landowners' militia, the Ranvir Sena, for involvement in the two massacres, as well as dozens of members of leftist groups. Human rights groups say the police, dominated by upper castes, have in the past cracked down much harder on the leftists than on the landowners' armies.
 On March 8 the central Government, unable to get its takeover of Bihar ratified in Parliament, took the humiliating step of reinstating the dismissed state officials.
While political intrigues have swirled in New Delhi and the state capital of Patna, the mourning has continued in Shanker Bigha, an isolated hamlet of 300 to 400 Dalits.
There is no road leading into Shanker Bigha, only a dirt pathway through a glorious, rippling field of wheat, the same one used by members of the Ranvir Sena. The village has no electricity, no phone, no school, no clock, no car, no scooter and no health clinic.
Itwaria Devi saw her son, who was about 20, gunned down as he reached the door of her hut to warn her of the danger. The husband of Pyari Thakur was fatally shot in a lane as he rushed to her from the men's sleeping quarters. Sona Dhari, a young mother whose eyes are pits of sorrow, had left her mud hut to go to the bathroom just before the armed men arrived. She told her husband, who was in the men's quarters, to come keep an eye on their 3-year-old son and 9-month-old daughter. By the time he got there, gunfire and screams echoed through the lanes.
"The children started weeping, so I gave them to my mother," said Raj Kumar Paswan, who hid himself while his mother and children cowered on their straw pallet.
When his wife made it back to the tiny, windowless hut, she fainted at the sight that confronted her: the bodies of her mother-in-law, toddler son and baby girl torn apart by bullets and sprawled akimbo on the blood-soaked pallet.
Once the killing was finished, the men shouted, "Long live Ranvir Sena!" Then, with three sharp whistles, they melted away into the field.
There seems to be no reason why Shanker Bigha was singled out for attack, other than its identity as a Dalit settlement. The police and the villagers say there was no dispute between the landowners and the farm workers who labor in the fields for 50 cents a day, less than the widely ignored state minimum wage of almost $1 a day.
"We find it difficult to fill our stomachs," said Mr. Paswan, a slender young man in a loincloth and tank top. "But we were always afraid we'd lose our jobs, so we never raised our voices."
The survivors of the massacre say they recognized some of the killers as familiar residents of Dhobi Bigha, an upper-caste village within plain sight of Shanker Bigha, just on the other side of the wheat field.
Dhobi Bigha is filled with sturdy brick houses inhabited by landowners from the Bhumihar caste, which makes up 3 percent of the state's population. Residents say the village solidly supports the Bharatiya Janata Party.
By Western standards Dhobi Bigha's residents are far from wealthy. Bhumihar landowners in central Bihar own from 2 to at most 50 acres of land. But by Bihar's standards they are the rural elite.
At dusk Shrikant Singh and Kameshwar Singh, Bhumihar landowners, stood talking next to a towering haystack. Both men have sons charged with taking part in the massacre in Shanker Bigha -- charges the fathers deny.
Dhobi Bigha itself was deserted. The men said the other residents had fled, fearing more arrests.
After India gained independence from Britain in 1947, land reform was supposed to bring justice to farmers who had been exploited for hundreds of years by the colonialists. Like states across India, Bihar in the 1950's abolished a system that operated through absentee landlords.
After the reforms, land was distributed to people from upper and middle castes who had been tenants. But the Dalits got virtually nothing. They were pariahs so politically powerless that they were unable to assert their right to a share, said Anand Chakravarti, a sociologist at Delhi University. The Dalits continued providing cheap, pliant labor for the landowning castes.
But in the 1970's, leftist radicals began organizing the Dalits to strike against certain landowners and enforced blockades on their land to prevent them from cultivating crops, often with threats of violence.
The landowners responded with violence. The massacres of Dalits date back to 1971, researchers say. And by 1979, various landowning castes were organizing private armies.
The Ranvir Sena is only the most recent of the armies. It was founded in 1994 in the Bhumihar village of Belaur in central Bihar and has since committed many massacres. The worst was in Laxmanpur-Bathe, where its members killed 61 Dalits on Dec. 1, 1997.
Shivanand Tiwary, a maverick Brahmin in the state legislature who represents a district that is a Ranvir Sena stronghold, said he sympathized with both the oppressed Dalits and the landowners. He understands that the Dalits want to be treated like human beings, he said.
"And I don't approve of the way the Ravir Sena takes revenge," he said. "This is a sick-mind approach. But what would anybody do? Those with small holdings are forced to leave their fields without crops for several years, and that is their only source of income. What will they do?"

HEADLINE: Southwest Flights at MacArthur Take Off to Mixed Reactions

BYLINE: By PAUL ZIELBAUER 

DATELINE: ISLIP, N.Y., March 14

 BODY:
Bumped off an overbooked flight home hours earlier, Jim Mihnovich stood at the end of a long line at Long Island MacArthur Airport this morning a grateful man. Grateful mostly for Southwest Airlines, which started operations at MacArthur today.
"This was awesome," he said, pocketing one of the carrier's distinctive blue plastic boarding passes for a 12:10 P.M. flight to Nashville. 
 But there are others in Islip who do not share Mr. Mihnovich's enthusiasm. While many frequent flyers said they hoped that the arrival of Southwest would force other large airlines to cut prices to the Long Island airport, residents who live near the airport complained about the prospect of more jet engines roaring overhead.
Initially, the airline will offer 12 nonstops a day from MacArthur to Baltimore, Chicago, Nashville and Tampa, Fla. If that modest beginning stimulates enough interest, the airline may add more flights later.
That concerns residents like Ronald Falcone, who said he is already weary of hearing planes flying over his four-bedroom home in Holbrook, a hamlet bordering the airport's property.
"Listen, I use the airport, nobody wants to see it closed," said Mr. Falcone, 43, a manager for an insurance company. "We want to see it prosper. But you could do it with a little bit of class and consideration for the residents. What's this house going to be worth in 10 years if this airport takes off?"
If today's large and enthusiastic crop of first-day passengers was any indication, Southwest may increase the airport's popularity in much less than a decade.
Consider Mr. Mihnovich's story. With no chance of getting on an overbooked American Airlines flight at La Guardia Airport this morning, he summoned his father from Brooklyn for a car ride out to Islip, about 40 miles away.
"I got in the car, got on my cell phone, called Southwest and bought a ticket for $130 -- and that was at the last minute," said Mr. Mihnovich, 35, an executive for a Nashville home health care company. Less than one hour later, he had his boarding pass. "That's pretty amazing," he said.
The airline is almost guaranteed to enhance the image of the no-frills airport, a decaying one-story structure with two linoleum-tiled concourses and 1970's Muzak piped over the public-address system.
Marian Wise, a 56-year-old lawyer who was also waiting for a Southwest flight to Nashville, said the airline's new service would put an end to eight-hour plane-to-train-to-automobile odysseys to visit friends in Islip. "It's inexpensive, it's efficient, they get you where you need to be when you need to be there," she said. "And I love the peanuts."
Islip officials said they expect Southwest to generate hundreds of thousands of dollars in revenue for the town each year. The town's Supervisor, Peter J. McGowan, said he hoped that the eight other airlines that serve the airport would cut fares to match those of Southwest.
"The traveling public will certainly gain from the spirit of competition that Southwest will create," Mr. McGowan said in a telephone interview. "It will certainly help the economy of Islip and all of Long Island. It brings Islip MacArthur Airport into the next millennium, and it helps to bring Long Island into the next millennium."
But some residents in two adjacent communities believe Southwest's arrival at MacArthur, which serves more than a million passengers a year, may be a harbinger of more noise and traffic congestion. Mr. Falcone and other residents have formed the Committee for the Enforcement of MacArthur Airport Control, which is seeking to force Islip to cap the number of daily flights to and from MacArthur and to prohibit late-night flights.
Mr. McGowan said the airport's jet traffic complies with Federal noise regulations and will remain within such boundaries.
Whether Southwest will be able to draw New York City-based passengers away from Kennedy International and La Guardia Airports remains to be seen. Though the airline is offering rock-bottom one-way prices -- $39 to Baltimore, $79 to Chicago or Nashville, and $89 to Tampa -- MacArthur Airport, on the South Shore of Long Island, is a good hour's drive from Manhattan even when there is no traffic.

HEADLINE: Editorial Observer;
A Wild Market Ride: From Fearful to Fearless

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
There has never been a bull market quite like the one that America is now enjoying. And while there is logically no more significance to approaching 10,000 on the Dow Jones industrial average than there was to approaching 9,500 or any other number, it is worth noting just how far -- and fast -- we have come.
This bull market has reflected and encouraged the renaissance of America's economic power and self-confidence. Its very existence is one reason the economy has been so strong, and the impact of an end to the bull market would be felt even by those who have never invested in a stock or mutual fund. 
 That group, to be sure, is dwindling. As the bull has grown, stocks have gone from a subject of scorn, seen by many as little more than gambling, to being widely regarded as the best long-term investment -- one that both Democrats and Republicans agree should be bought to help finance Social Security. America itself has gone from fearful to supremely self-confident.
The birth of this bull came on Dec. 6, 1974, although no one knew it at the time. That was when the Dow hit bottom at 577.60, having plunged 45 percent in less than two years amid the worst economic news America had seen since the Great Depression. The country was in a recession and inflation was rising. New York City, the financial capital of the country, was on the verge of going broke.
American industry appeared to be in an irreversible decline. There were predictions that first the oil-producing countries, and then the Japanese, would be able to buy America. Such fears played a role in the next two Presidential elections, in which incumbents were rejected.
At the bottom in 1974, the stocks in the Standard & Poor's 500 index were trading at seven times that year's profits. On average, those stocks paid dividends equal to 5.8 percent of their purchase price.
A quarter-century later, almost everything has changed. Books celebrate the American century and Americans lecture Japanese on economics, rather than the reverse. Commodity prices are low, and producers are suffering. Technology is pre-eminent. The value in many companies is seen as being in their brand names, not in their manufacturing plants, which are viewed as expendable.
The rise in stock prices can be traced only in part to the country's economic success. Corporate profits have risen in recent years, but not nearly as rapidly as stock prices. The S.& P. 500 is at 28-times estimated profits, and has a dividend yield of 1.3 percent.
If investors were willing to pay about the same price for profits and dividends as they were in 1974, the Dow today would be around 2,500, not on the verge of topping 10,000. If valuations were equal to those at the 1987 peak, before that year's crash, the Dow would be somewhere between 5,000 and 7,000. That people are willing to pay so much more is a tribute to optimism and to the fact that stocks are now viewed as a long-term sure thing.
In the past couple of years, the breadth of the great bull market has narrowed. Stocks in smaller companies -- Internet operations excluded -- have lagged notably, and the Russell 2,000, an index of stocks that rank just below the 1,000 largest companies, is now about where it was in mid-1997, while the Dow is up nearly 30 percent. For most of the decade, the biggest winners have been in technology and financial services -- the industries through which America has re-emerged as the world's strongest economy.
At the same time, the very existence of the bull market -- and the wealth it has created -- has made Americans far more willing to spend on houses, cars, cell phones and all the other accouterments of the good life. In recent years, that spending has consistently exceeded economists' expectations, producing surprisingly fast growth and reinforcing the bull market.
When -- or should I say "if"? -- the bull market ends, the impact on the American economy and psyche will be much greater than it would have been before so many Americans pinned their hopes for the future on Wall Street's advance. No doubt the pessimism of 1974 was excessive, but so too may be the optimism that seems embedded now as the Dow nears 10,000.

HEADLINE: Art on the Hudson: New Use for an Old Factory Lifts a City's Hopes

BYLINE: By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

DATELINE: BEACON, N.Y., March 12

 BODY:
From the Depression through the booming 1980's, crowds of men and women wearing blue coveralls thronged each day to the sprawling factory on the riverfront here. Around the clock, they printed, cut and folded colorful cartons for Ritz crackers, Milk-Bone dog biscuits, Oreo cookies and other products of what once was the National Biscuit Company.
The presses rumbled so loudly, former workers recall, that a teen-age worker named Sally, with a nice soprano voice, used to sing her lungs out at one bench but could be heard only by the three women standing next to her. 
 In a couple of years, crowds will return to the glass-roofed brick building after its decade of dormancy. But this time, they will most likely be wearing stylish black. The industrial clang of old will be replaced by studied silence as visitors shuffle past sculptures of glowing fluorescent tubes and rust-orange slabs of steel, 450-foot-long pieces of Andy Warhol Pop Art and century-old Hudson River landscapes.
On March 8, the Dia Center for the Arts, a private group that exhibits art in converted Manhattan warehouses, in the high desert of New Mexico, at a firehouse in the Hamptons and at other unorthodox sites around the country, announced plans to create a giant new museum in the old factory building -- with nearly twice the gallery space of the Museum of Modern Art. The site is 50 miles north of New York City on the east bank of the Hudson River, a few steps from the Metro-North stop.
The changes in the factory reflect the changing fortunes of Beacon and the Hudson River Valley. Prosperity used to come from riverside docks, railroad lines and the harnessed energy of tumbling tributaries. Now, local officials and business owners hope it will return in the form of tourism.
For Beacon, the museum should provide the final impetus for renewal, said Clara Lou Gould, the Mayor of this city of 13,000 people, which has no hotels and only one bed-and-breakfast.
The city, with a racially diverse mixture of middle-class and poor families, has long labored to emerge from a postindustrial slumber that has left the river end of Main Street largely boarded up. A recent wave of renovations of Victorian homes has helped. Then, several years ago, came "Nobody's Fool," a Paul Newman film that injected money and revived interest a bit.
But nothing has happened on a scale like this, Ms. Gould said. The art center predicts that the museum will draw 60,000 to 70,000 visitors a year once it opens in the spring of 2001. "It's kind of mind-boggling," she said.
The factory's previous owner, the International Paper Company, had been trying to sell it for several years, with an asking price of about $2 million. Ms. Gould said there had been inquiries from a fish-farming company and other businesses, but nothing seemed promising until a year ago, when the Dia center first considered the site as a home for most of its extensive art collection. In the collection are many unwieldy works, including a series of steel shapes by Richard Serra weighing a total of 750 tons.
Michael Govan, the director of the art center, recalled how he followed the factory watchman into the main printing hall, with its football-field breadth and acres of glass skylights facing north -- designed so the printers had the best light.
"When I walked in that door," Mr. Govan said, "my initial reaction was, if I were going to build a museum from scratch, I would build it just like this. Concrete and steel. Wood floors. Space between columns. Perfect light. A Metro-North train stop."
Dia's staff had been considering other buildings as far afield as North Adams, Mass., but nothing compared to this, he said, adding, "The whole thing was clear in one fell swoop."
But there were also buckets and drums brimming with water dripping from the roof, warped floorboards, broken windows, and walls shedding so many flakes of paint that they resemble a Jackson Pollock.
Nonetheless, within a few days, Mr. Govan began praising the site to trustees and Dia's stable of artists. In the final deal, the building is being donated by the paper company. Most of the estimated $20 million cost of transforming the 70-year-old structure into a museum will be paid through donations, with about $2.8 million coming from state and local economic development and arts programs, Mr. Govan said.
Uphill from the factory at the east end of town, where antiques shops and bakeries have sprouted over the last few years, the museum was just about the only topic of conversation.
A few residents bemoaned the loss of about $25,000 a year in property taxes from the 26-acre factory tract once it is owned by a nonprofit group. But many merchants echoed the views of Mayor Gould about the economic benefits.
Sheila Wicklow, a co-owner of the Little Pie Shop and the president of the Beacon Business Association, said the Dia center had shown a commitment to public schools in Manhattan. "Now, schools here will have this in their own backyard," she said.
At Beacon's other art institution, the Tallix Foundry, the staff said the museum would perfectly complement its work. As he wove his way through a crazy assemblage of giant and tiny bronzes of horses, heroes, frogs, eagles and abstractions, Peter S. Homestead, the president of Tallix, said museum visitors would also want to see the foundry.
"There, they can go and see the pieces hanging on the wall," he said. "Here, they can see them being made. It's a perfect fit."
For the moment, at least, the 540-foot-long printing plant, with stalks of milkweed sprouting from its foundation, remains a ghostly vestige of the past. It fell on hard times in the mid-1980's, when Nabisco merged with the R.J. Reynolds tobacco conglomerate to become RJR Nabisco and began trimming costs and sold the plant, former employees said. In 1991, the large bronze main doors closed forever. A few years later, the doors themselves were stolen.
Now, rail tracks come to a dead end at an empty loading dock. Clocks on different floors are stopped at different hours. In the high-ceilinged basement, echoes bounce cathedral-like through a forest of more than 100 soaring concrete columns. "This is where they used to teach you how to drive a forklift," said Arcangelo Formichelli, the factory's 63-year-old watchman, who ran printing presses there from 1957 to 1990.
Upstairs, he walked across the broad wooden floor of the cutting and creasing room, then pointed to the spot where women once put the little red strings on the boxes of Animal Crackers shaped like circus railroad cars. Near the workers' entrance, he paused by a row of lockers covered in peeling paint, saying, "This one was mine."
He said it was tough to watch a building that was so important to the community slide into disrepair. "This place bought me two houses and helped me raise six kids," he said.
He professed no familiarity with modern art, certainly not with the works of some of the artists in the Dia collection, like the earth-filled rooms of Walter De Maria.
But that did not matter, he said. "One way or the other," Mr. Formichelli said, "it'll be great to see this building open up again."

HEADLINE: Brazilian Economist Killed In Waldorf-Astoria Attack

BYLINE: By GINGER THOMPSON 

 BODY:
The man killed Saturday at the Waldorf-Astoria was identified yesterday as a well-to-do Brazilian economist who ran agricultural projects in the Amazon rain forest, owned a popular antiques store and traveled the world several times a year, the police and his relatives said.
The victim was Joao Saboia, 56, a resident of Belem, a city on the northern coast of Brazil. His throat was slashed and his face was badly cut and bruised, the police said. They refused to provide details about Mr. Saboia or the circumstances of his death, but in a telephone interview from Belem, his nephew Carlos Saboia, 32, said the police told relatives that about $50,000 was missing from the hotel room. 
 "He traveled all over the world, at least five times a year," Carlos Saboia said. "But he really loved New York. That makes this even more sad, because it happened in his favorite city."
It was not unusual for Mr. Saboia to travel with a lot of cash, his nephew said. He said his uncle had stopped in New York on his way to Atlantic City, where he was well known as a high-stakes gambler and was often invited as a special guest by casino managers.
"The police told us that whoever did this had a fight with my uncle and then took everything," Carlos Saboia said. "They said that they did not know who did it, but that it could have been someone who works at the hotel."
Joao Saboia (pronounced joh-OW sah-BOY-ah) was single and had no children, relatives said. His eldest brother died of cancer two months ago. "We were trying to recuperate from my father's death, and now this," Carlos Saboia said. "We are just in total shock. Everyone loved my uncle."
Relatives described Joao Saboia as a "very influential economist," and they said that he and his staff advised corporations interested in establishing farming or industrial projects in the Amazon.
Carlos Saboia said the police told the family that they discovered Mr. Saboia's body about 5:30 P.M. Saturday after travel companions reported that they had not seen him for several hours. When officers went to his room, a "Do Not Disturb" sign was hanging on the door.
Relatives also were told that this was the second attack within a year at the Waldorf-Astoria, visited by the world's most prominent dignitaries and long a symbol of New York's opulence.
Last June, a 37-year-old guest was injured in a stabbing by a homeless youth he had invited to his room.
Police officials said they had no suspects in Mr. Saboia's killing and had made no arrests. An operator at the hotel said the manager would not speak about the incident.
Mr. Saboia's relatives are scheduled to arrive in New York tomorrow -- with free accommodations offered to them by the Waldorf-Astoria -- to discuss the slaying with the police and hotel officials. "We want to know what happened," Carlos Saboia said.
Guests at the hotel expressed shock about the killing in their midst.
"I was worried about walking last night to make a show," said Sue Schmitt, of New Albany, Ind., who spent Saturday evening at "The Phantom of the Opera." "But I guess I was really safer on the streets than I was in the hotel."
She and her daughter Julia had come to New York to celebrate Julia's 13th birthday. "It's really scary," Julia said, referring to the killing. "I had nightmares all night."
In the lobby bar yesterday, Kathy and Bob Foster of Dallas seemed to shrug off the incident after hearing about it from a reporter.
"We tend not to worry about things," said Mr. Foster, 77, decked out in a pinstripe suit with a striped tie and matching handkerchief. "When you're old, most people are really nice to you."

HEADLINE: How the U.S. Can Do Right by Central America;
Stability in Salvador

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Although the relative peace of El Salvador's recent presidential election is indeed worth celebrating (news articles, March 8 and 11), long-term stability there will require solution of the country's underlying economic difficulties, not just the casting of ballots.
In a 1998 epidemiological study by Physicians for Human Rights, my colleagues and I found that the living conditions of many beneficiaries of postwar land distribution programs are little better than those of prewar landless peasants, with a high prevalence of childhood malnutrition. 
 As long as poverty continues to affect a large portion of the Salvadoran population, the risk of recurrent civil strife cannot be discounted, and human suffering will persist.
 
PAULA BRENTLINGER, M.D.
Boston, March 11, 1999

HEADLINE: In Angler's Freezer Since '62, Fish May Refute 'Extinction'

BYLINE: By PAM BELLUCK 

DATELINE: CONNEAUT, Ohio

 BODY:
Call it nostalgia. Or sentimentality. Or call it an uncanny prescience.
Jim Anthony himself is not exactly sure why he kept a certain fish in his freezer for 37 years, carefully re wrapping it every so often and making sure that his wife did not let it thaw every time she defrosted the freezer. 
 Somehow, Mr. Anthony, a 63-year-old barber in this working-class town on the shores of Lake Erie, had a feeling when he caught the fish, a blue pike, back in 1962, that someday somebody might be interested.
"I kept telling my wife it was more valuable as time went on and that's why we needed to keep it," Mr. Anthony said. "It's hard for me to explain, but that blue pike meant a lot to me."
All of a sudden, nearly four decades later, Jim Anthony's blue pike means a lot to other people, too. It has become the central clue in a compelling scientific detective story, one that some scientists hope will have an extraordinary ending: the return of an extinct species.
Blue pike, native only to Lake Erie, were once so prevalent there that they spurred a booming commercial fishing industry in the 1930's and 1940's, catering to demand for the mild, meaty taste of the bright blue fish. But in 1975, blue pike were declared extinct, a casualty, scientists say, of pollution, over-fishing and habitat changes.
Since then, fishermen have occasionally reported seeing what looked like blue pike in smaller lakes in Canada and elsewhere. Some Lazarus-like resurrection? More plausible was the theory that during the blue pike heyday, people transferred small batches of fish from Lake Erie to smaller lakes and they never died out.
Still, fish biologists generally assumed that those blue fish were really a type of walleye, a common fish in Lake Erie, and not the true blue pike. But they could not be sure. They could find no specimens of blue pike preserved in such a way that DNA could be extracted and compared with the DNA of other fish.
And they were intrigued by the possibility that blue pike still existed.
"If we could find and verify the survival of the blue pike, then we could restock them in Lake Erie," said Dieter N. Busch, a fishery biologist who helped spearhead the research as chief of the Lower Great Lakes Program of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service.
Mr. Busch said blue pike had been sorely missed, both for environmental reasons (it filled an ecological niche as one of the few Lake Erie fish to spawn in deep water) and economic reasons (he estimates that the return of blue pike to their previous levels would add more than $150 million to the lake's fishing industry).
"The species was such a valuable species," Mr. Busch said, "it was worth getting an answer."
Research was going slowly. Scientists had blue pike from museums, but they were preserved in formaldehyde, which makes DNA hard to extract. They had scales from blue pike used in unrelated earlier studies, but that DNA was disappointing, too.
Fortunately for science, Mr. Anthony, while snipping hair, chatted to customers about "the blue pike generation." That was the golden age of blue pike, when Mr. Anthony's father sold piles of them from his fish markets in Conneaut (pronounced KAHN-yaht) and popularized the "fish sandwich without bones." After school, Jim pulled on rubber boots and got down to scaling and cleaning fish.
Mr. Anthony, a burly, self-effacing man who worked as a fisherman for his father until the blue pike population started to dwindle in 1957, told his barber shop customers about the 15-inch blue pike he caught with a simple hook, line and night crawler in 1962. Even then, he knew the fish was rare and kept it alive in a bucket while he contacted state wildlife agencies. He offered them the fish but they declined. One agency suggested he release it back into the lake, and he tried, but it was already too weak and died.
Mr. Anthony's wife, Mary Lynn, accepted the fish preservation routine graciously, realizing it was important to her husband. Sometimes while defrosting the freezer, she either moved the fish to another freezer or piled frozen foods on top of it.
"All my customers knew I had a blue pike in my freezer," Mr. Anthony said in his white ranch house not far from the great lake. "They thought I was nuts."
One day last year a customer brought him a local newspaper article about scientists trying to determine whether any blue pike still existed. Mr. Anthony called one of the scientists, Carol A. Stepien, an ichthyologist, or fish zoologist, at Case Western Reserve University in Cleveland and offered up his fish.
"It don't look bad for 30-something years in the freezer," Mr. Anthony said. "Except for a little freezer burn."
Dr. Stepien was more concerned with what was on the inside.
As it turned out, "It has great DNA," she said. The research "would be very difficult without his fish."
Dr. Stepien's crew is proceeding systematically, first trying to determine whether the original blue pike is in fact a separate species from the walleye. If the two fish are too closely related, then the walleye might have interbred with the last of the blue pike, making it unlikely that any original blue pike still exist.
Dr. Stepien says she will not disclose her final conclusion until a scientific conference in May. Mr. Busch, however, who now works for the Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission, is bolder.
"We are confident that blue pike are a separate species," Mr. Busch said.
The next step, he said, is searching for "suspect blue pike" in various lakes (so far, there have been rumors of blue pike in Ontario, Minnesota, Pennsylvania and Tennessee). Fishermen have sent putative blue pike to Dr. Stepien and to the Fish and Wildlife Service, but the DNA of those fish will not be tested until the first phase of the project is complete. Mr. Busch even has a fish someone sent him eight years ago that he says has telltale signs of blue pikeness: a pointy nose, large eyes and a smaller size than a walleye.
"When I unwrapped it, my stomach jumped," Mr. Busch said. "I have seen hundreds of walleye and this was different."
If the scientists find living blue pike, they will focus on ways to reintroduce them to Lake Erie. The lake is cleaner now, but there would have to be an adequate food supply -- the lake herring the blue pike ate tapered off decades ago and Mr. Busch said they might have to restock that, too.
All of this is somewhat controversial with some fishery managers and the fish and wildlife agencies in the states with a border on Lake Erie: Ohio, Pennsylvania and New York. They are concerned that before any fish is reintroduced, there is solid proof not only that the fish are blue pike, but that they will not interbreed with walleye or invade the walleye's habitat.
"We would love to have them back, but we want the original ones and that's the key," said Roger L. Knight, supervisor of the Sandusky Fish Research Unit of the Ohio Division of Wildlife. "You can build false hopes and there may be pressure to stock blue fish in Lake Erie, even if we're not sure they are the original blue pike. We're not about to introduce another strain of walleye into our lakes where our walleye are doing fine."
Mr. Anthony knows the investigation could take years, but he is hopeful it will find that the fish of his childhood is still around somewhere.
He winces to recall the waning years of the blue pike, when the fish his father's workers caught contained no eggs or eggs that were deformed.
After he caught his blue pike in 1962, the year after his father died, he tried to conjure up ways to keep the breed from disappearing.
"Every time I'd meet a politician, I'd say, 'Just get me permission to set a net and catch some blue pike and try spawning them in holding tanks,' " said Mr. Anthony, who could no longer set nets because he had given up his commercial fishing license. Later, Lake Erie commercial fishing was banned for a while because of mercury.
"Maybe they didn't think blue pike was really going to die out," Mr. Anthony said, "but I couldn't understand why they weren't doing anything about it."
Since he bequeathed his frozen blue pike, Mr. Anthony has visited Dr. Stepien's lab a couple of times.
"It might sound corny, but I had a lot of feeling in that fish -- it's a part of my life," he said. "Now, they call it the 'Anthony fish.' I like that."

HEADLINE: Fleet Financial to Buy BankBoston in $16 Billion Stock Deal

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY L. O'BRIEN

 BODY:
Fleet Financial Group plans to acquire the BankBoston Corporation for $16 billion in a deal that will create the eighth-largest bank in the country and the pre-eminent bank in New England, the companies said yesterday.
The new bank, which is to be based in Boston and will be called the FleetBoston Corporation, will have such a stranglehold on consumer accounts in states like Massachusetts, according to lawyers specializing in banking law, that Federal antitrust law will require large sales of bank branches there and elsewhere in New England. 
 The transaction will most likely involve a significant number of job cuts and layoffs throughout New England, anywhere from 2,500 to 5,000, according to people involved in the deal, though the exact number of job cuts could not be determined. Fleet and BankBoston now employ about 50,000 people combined.
If shareholders and regulators approve the deal, the merged bank will still lack the heft necessary to join the ranks of the nation's new banking titans that have been created by a wave of mergers. With about $178 billion in assets, the new FleetBoston will remain a quarter to half the size of Citigroup, the BankAmerica Corporation, the Chase Manhattan Corporation and the Bank One Corporation. That raises the possibility that the new bank could be involved in another big merger in the next few years.
The boards of both banks approved the deal after meeting yesterday afternoon.
The banks renewed discussions about a merger about six weeks ago. Earlier talks fell apart last year.
Fleet will exchange 1.1844 of its shares for each BankBoston share, valuing BankBoston at about $53 a share, or about a 15 percent premium above BankBoston's closing price on Friday of $46.9375 a share. Shares of Fleet rose 12.5 cents on Friday, to $44.75. Both issues trade on the New York Stock Exchange.
BankBoston shares have been trading well below their 52-week high of $59.0625 because of investor concern about the bank's heavy exposure to volatile economies in Brazil and Argentina. BankBoston executives have repeatedly noted that the bank turned in a record performance in Latin America last year and that they expect to make a substantial profit in the region this year, too.
Even so, a combination with Fleet will further insulate BankBoston from financial problems related to any economic downturns in Latin America.
Last year, Fleet had operating earnings of $1.6 billion on revenue of $7.14 billion. BankBoston posted operating earnings of $792 million on revenue of $4.4 billion in 1998. The merged bank will have about 20 million customers.
"I think that, execution issues aside, this might be a terrific deal," said Diane Glossman, an analyst with Lehman Brothers. "They have strengths in divergent areas, and if they combine correctly they could have significant opportunities to boost revenue."
Terrence Murray, the 59-year-old chairman and chief executive of Fleet, is to be chief executive of the merged bank for the next two years.
After that, Charles K. Gifford, the 56-year-old chairman and chief executive of BankBoston, will succeed Mr. Murray as chairman of the merged company.
Fleet, which grew rapidly through a series of mergers from its original base in Providence, R.I., has 1,200 consumer branches reaching as far south as New York and is the country's sixth-largest commercial lender. It is also one of the biggest mortgage lenders in the country.
Fleet also owns Quick & Reilly, the nation's third-largest discount brokerage firm, and provides investment management services for both individuals and institutional clients, with more than $74 billion in assets under management. It also own the AFSA Data Corporation, one of the largest processors of student loans.
Last year, Fleet bought a large credit card portfolio from the Advanta Corporation, but recently sued Advanta, contending that Advanta overstated the value of that business. Fleet says that Advanta did not disclose coding errors that resulted in excessive interest charges of at least $3.9 million, which Fleet had to repay. Advanta has said that the lawsuit has no merit.
Fleet's mix of businesses has been criticized by analysts and advisers as something of a hodgepodge, but the bank has focused more closely recently on performance and turned in strong results last year, when many other banks had difficulty meeting earnings goals. Its credit card and commercial lending businesses did particularly well last year.
BankBoston, which has a blue-chip, Brahmin lineage, has a well-regarded management team and has been praised as a friendly, supportive company for employees, with relatively little turnover among its work force. It has also established a strong record on community outreach programs.
Last year, however, was a difficult one for BankBoston. It was buffeted by trading losses, the untimely and expensive acquisition of the Robertson Stephens investment banking firm and a financial scandal involving millions of dollars stolen from its private banking division. The downward pressure on its stock had made the bank a more vulnerable takeover target.
BankBoston has a charter dating from 1784 and once numbered Paul Revere among its clients. The bank is an unusual hybrid of old-fashioned banking, corporate lending and stock underwriting, married to extensive Latin American operations.
About 20 percent of BankBoston's profits come from its Latin American operations; the bulk of the bank's profits, about 67 percent, come from its corporate banking and regional banking businesses.
BankBoston's consumer banking business has been hobbled by problems related to the acquisition of Baybanks three years ago, a situation that Fleet and BankBoston must avoid if they want to integrate their operations successfully.

HEADLINE: Training for a Presidential Race

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE with RICK LYMAN 

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex.

 BODY:
He is the early favorite for the Republican Presidential nomination, but even Gov. George W. Bush of Texas concedes that his foreign policy experience goes no farther than Mexico. Kosovo? Not even on the radar screen. And he has never had to worry about the future of Social Security.
Rushing to fill in his blank slate on pressing issues of the day before the campaign swings into full gear, Mr. Bush has embarked on a cram course that could be titled "What you need to know to run for President." 
 After winning a second term last November, Mr. Bush began summoning dozens of the nation's brightest thinkers around a table in the Governor's Mansion for sober-minded tutorials. Politicians in both parties said they had never seen such a comprehensive and elaborate undertaking, particularly this early in a campaign. There may never have been a "serious" candidate who needed it more.
The endeavor is intended to counter what are widely seen as among Mr. Bush's biggest vulnerabilities: that he lacks experience beyond Texas and that he has not articulated a grand view of what he would do in the White House. It was no accident that in their announcement speeches last week, Elizabeth Dole and former Gov. Lamar Alexander of Tennessee emphasized their credentials on national issues.
Mr. Bush's visitors defended the Governor as a quick study. "Nobody knows everything about what goes on in the world, so you've got to find out," George P. Shultz, Secretary of State under President Ronald Reagan, said recently as he sat back in his rocking chair with a State Department seal at his office at Stanford University, where he is a fellow at the Hoover Institution.
Mr. Bush's ability to draw big names -- all of whom, in the beginning, paid their own way to Austin -- is not simply testament to the Governor's personal appeal or skills at outreach. Self-interest is at play as well: Academics like to be asked for advice, particularly by a politician who is leading in the polls and who might someday be in a position to appoint them to something. What for Mr. Bush is a tutorial might serve as an audition for his tutors.
There is also the prestige factor. "They come back and say, 'Well, I was just down in Austin,' " said Martin Anderson, an economist at Stanford University and an official in the Reagan Administration. Participants have been plucked from around the country, but there is particularly heavy representation from the Hoover Institution.
Al Hubbard, an Indianapolis business executive who coordinated the early meetings for Mr. Bush, said people were invited to Austin "under the condition that they would be supportive of him" and all but one person accepted.
The deep conversations about policy are all the more surprising because -- fairly or unfairly -- Mr. Bush is known more for his hands-on governing style than for his intellect. He has never been known for savoring the minutiae of policy like President Clinton. "Having known George as a student, I'm shocked, and his professors would be shocked," said Mr. Hubbard, a classmate of Mr. Bush at the Harvard Business School. "He wasn't a great student. But he's the most conscientious politician I've ever worked with."
Lawrence B. Lindsey, a former member of the Federal Reserve Board who was on President Reagan's Council of Economic Advisers and is Mr. Bush's chief outside economic adviser, described him as "a very good and patient student."
The sessions started informally after the election and they have become more organized in the past few months. Besides Mr. Lindsey, who invites economic experts to the meetings and structures the agenda, Mr. Bush has named Mayor Stephen Goldsmith of Indianapolis to preside over domestic policy, while Condoleezza Rice, the provost of Stanford University, oversees foreign and military policy.
The meetings are often convened in a formal, deep blue dining room in the Governor's mansion, and sometimes in a smaller, sunny conservatory. They usually include just over half a dozen experts in a field and are scheduled for three hours but often last longer.
To all but the most devout policy wonks, the conversations can be eye glazing. According to an agenda of a health care briefing that Mr. Goldsmith presided over on Feb. 18, six minutes were allocated for introductory remarks and 25 minutes for a discussion of the financing system and the delivery systems, with such topics as "trends in patient care: acute to chronic conditions, diffusion of technology, rise of pharmaceutical therapy."
Then a 30-minute discussion of philosophy, including "What level of care are we prepared to guarantee?" Then 50 minutes on the uninsured, and 50 minutes on the "anxious insured." Mr. Goldsmith was to close with a 20-minute review of matters for further discussion.
Several participants said in interviews that the discussions were framed less around how the Governor should respond to a particular question on the campaign trail and more around how he would tackle the matter as President.
"It's more like a very interactive seminar than people sitting around giving formal talks," Ms. Rice said. The Governor, she said, "is not somebody who puts on airs or attempts to appear imperial, so there's a kind of easiness about the conversation. Sometimes you get a bunch of foreign policy experts together and they talk on a plane where nobody asks the basic questions. He'll drive you back to the basic question."
When the end of the cold war came up, she said, Mr. Bush asked: "What does America's role really mean to you? What did we mean when we talk about the expansion of NATO? What is the military of the future going to look like?"
In conversations about economics, participants said, Mr. Bush always returns to job creation. "What can I do to make higher paying jobs?," said John B. Taylor, an economics professor at Stanford. "That's a bottom line for him."
The experts said Mr. Bush appeared confident and did not pretend to know more than he does. Like Ronald Reagan, Mr. Anderson said, "He has no problem talking to people who were smarter and quicker. There are other candidates who don't like to do that."
While they described Mr. Bush as smart and disciplined, many participants said he obviously still had a lot to learn.
"He still has some growing to do," said Michael Boskin, a Stanford University economist and former chief economic adviser to President George Bush who organized some of the early meetings. "But he's become the most impressive Presidential or potential Presidential candidate that I've seen in decades."
Seeking to portray himself as more conservative than his father, Mr. Bush has stayed clear, at least publicly, of many of the former President's top advisers. Even after hours of meetings, several participants who know his father were hard-pressed to distinguish their philosophies.
Asked if the Governor was more conservative than his father, Mr. Shultz said, "Out of the blue I would say that. But then if you said, 'Why?' I wouldn't have a good answer."
The visits have ignited a firestorm of gossip in academic and political circles about how people are angling for posts in a Bush Administration. But participants said the preening is kept to a minimum, though experts sometimes compete over who brings the most colorful graphics. "You could think about the jobs available: budget director or Treasury Secretary or national security adviser. I haven't participated in lists of names of who would be good for things," Mr. Taylor said. Referring to Mr. Bush, he added: "I don't know if he's done that. He's probably thought about it."
Though Mr. Bush's visitors do not dare speculate openly about their futures, they clearly delight in the attention. When Ms. Rice, a national security official in President Bush's Administration, was shown an editorial in the Stanford University student newspaper with the headline, "Secretary of State?" she gasped, "My God!"
Moments later, Ms. Rice, who is stepping down as provost, retreated to a position of studied nonchalance. "Certainly, nobody's asked me to be Secretary of State," she said. "And I'm a terrible long-term planner."

 CORRECTION:
An article on Monday about the prospect of a Presidential campaign by Gov. George W. Bush of Texas described a series of tutorials aimed at helping him study issues he would face. As published, the article included an opinionated sentence casting doubt on his mastery of those issues.
The sentence was sent as a message between editors after the article was written, and the reporters were never aware of it. The comment was typed in a nonprinting computer script, but converted into print through a command error.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Yields at 3-Week Lows, With Favorable Inflation News Seen

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices rose for a second day, pushing yields to the lowest in almost three weeks, as investors bet that economic reports this week will point to subdued inflation and slowing growth.
"The market's going to see some good news," in the reports this week, said Alan Day, who helps manage $4 billion at Stratevest Group in Burlington, Vt. "There's no threat of rising rates of inflation."
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 2/32 , to 96 1/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.52 percent, from 5.51 percent Friday.
Trading volume was the lightest this year, according to GovPX Inc., a bond pricing service.
Traders and investors will be paying close attention to February figures on industrial output, due today, and consumer prices, the most widely watched measure of inflation, to be released Thursday. Economists expect production to be unchanged and prices to rise just one-tenth of 1 percent.
"After weeks of relentlessly strong data, we have the prospect of some softer economic reports," said Dana Johnson, the head of research at First Chicago Capital Markets Inc. "That'll put a positive underlying tone to the fixed-income market."
Gains in Treasuries may be limited as expected bond sales by the AT&T Corporation and the Peco Energy Company draw investors' attention from Treasuries, traders said.
AT&T is preparing to sell as much as $6 billion of bonds in coming days in what would be the second-largest corporate issue ever.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Dow Climbs 82.42 Closer To 10,000 as Nasdaq Rises

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Stock prices rose sharply yesterday, swept higher by a couple of big merger announcements, enthusiastic buying of technology shares and an optimistic earnings forecast from UAL, the nation's biggest commercial airline company.
The advance pushed two major market measures -- the Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index -- to new records. 
 Although the Nasdaq composite index failed to set a new high, it was the session's best-performing index.
Even small stocks, which have done dismally this year, had a good day.
"Given what has been happening in the U.S. economy, you have to be very positive on the market," said Jack Shaughnessy, the chief investment strategist at Advest Inc.
The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 82.42 points, or 0.8 percent, at 9,958.77. Despite the run-up, the Dow never seriously challenged the 10,000 mark. In the session, it rose as high as 9,970.15. Still, it was the first time the blue-chip index had closed above 9,900, and eclipsed its previous high of 9,897.44, set on March 11.
"In my view, the 10,000 level for the Dow is largely an irrelevancy," said Peter Canelo, a United States investment strategist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. "The key drivers for the market are a tremendous economy without any inflation."
Meanwhile, the S.& P. 500 rose 12.67, or 1 percent, to 1,307.26. That gain passed the previous record of 1,297.68, which was also established on March 11.
Strong buying of technology and Internet shares powered the Nasdaq index to a gain of 49.91, or 2.1 percent, to 2,431.44. And the Russell 2000 index of small-company stocks gained 2.46, or 0.6 percent, to 400.84.
Two big merger deals -- Fleet Financial's acquisition of BankBoston and DuPont's takeover of Pioneer Hi-Bred International -- were important positives.
While BankBoston only gained 1/8, to 47 1/8, and Fleet lost 2 9/16 , to 42 3/16 , the deal refocused attention on consolidation in the financial services industry and pushed the prices of a number of big institutions sharply higher.
Merrill Lynch gained 4 7/16 , to 91 11/16 , on rumors that Chase Manhattan might be looking to acquire the nation's biggest brokerage firm. Chase lost 3/4, to 87 1/4.
J. P. Morgan, a Dow component and a company that in the past was mentioned as a possible takeover candidate, was the best-performing part of the blue-chip index yesterday, rising 3 3/8 , to 125 3/8 .
Meanwhile, Pioneer Hi-Bred, the world's largest seed-corn company, rose 4 1/16 , to 38 3/8, after it was announced that DuPont had agreed to buy the 80 percent of the company it does not already own for about $40 a share in cash and stock.
DuPont was the worst-performing component of the Dow, falling 1 1/2, to 56 1/4.
The earnings announcement from UAL, which said it expected first-quarter earnings to exceed expectations by 24 percent because of strong domestic business, powered the entire airline sector higher.
UAL, the parent of United Airlines, gained 6 11/16 , to 73 3/4; US Airways rose 2 7/8, to 55 3/8; AMR, the parent of American Airlines, jumped 3 3/4, to 61 3/4, and and Delta Air Lines rose 5, to 69.
The gains helped to push the Dow Jones transportation average up 4.2 percent. Even with the big rise, that index is still trading almost 8 percent below the peak it set in April 1998.
Given the strength in the economy, Mr. Canelo from Morgan Stanley Dean Witter said that first-quarter earnings could well be strong across a wide swath of industries.
"I don't feel the consumer is slowing down at all," he said. "That should be a positive for the overall economy and should lead to strong earnings across the board, with the exception of some basic industries and energy, which will suffer due to tough comparisons from a year ago."
In technology, Netscape Communications rose 6 1/8, to 91. It was announced on Friday that America Online had won antitrust clearance from Federal regulators to complete the $8.98 billion acquisition of the top maker of Internet software. America Online rose 5 7/8, to 102.
Among large-capitalization technology companies, Microsoft gained 5 11/16 , to 165 7/8; Dell Computer rose 1 9/16 , to 43 3/4, and EMC jumped 41/16 , to 116 5/16 .
TheStreet.com's Internet sector index rose 36.83, or 6.5 percent, to a new high of 604.83.
"These stocks look expensive, but they have looked that way since they were trading at half of what they are now," said Michael Molnar, a managing director in retail sales and trading at Salomon Smith Barney.

HEADLINE: Medicare Panel Chief Doubts He'll Find Votes for Change

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 15

 BODY:
The chairman of a bipartisan commission studying the future of Medicare made a last-ditch effort tonight to salvage his proposal for radical changes in the health insurance program for the elderly, but he said he did not know if he could round up the necessary votes in time for the panel's final meeting on Tuesday.
Moreover, the chairman, Senator John B. Breaux, Democrat of Louisiana, said President Clinton had given him no assistance in trying to get those votes. Mr. Breaux needs support from at least one of the President's four appointees on the 17-member commission, but Mr. Breaux said he had not secured support from any of them. 
 "Do I wish the President had come out and endorsed this proposition?" Mr. Breaux asked. "The answer is yes. Am I disappointed if he doesn't? The answer is obviously yes."
Under Mr. Breaux's proposal, the Government, instead of paying separately for each medical service, would offer a fixed amount of money to each beneficiary. The beneficiary could use the money to buy private health insurance, through a managed care plan, or to enroll in the traditional fee-for-service Medicare program.
The commission, which was created by a 1997 law plans to vote on Tuesday on its final recommendations to insure the long-term solvency of Medicare. The panel has gone two weeks beyond the March 1 deadline for its final report. Medicare is expected to run short of money just as the first of 76 million baby boomers turn 65, in 2011.
Administration officials and liberal Democrats in Congress predict that the commission will end its work with 10 members supporting the Breaux plan and 7 opposed. Under the law that created it, the commission needs 11 votes for any recommendation to the President and Congress.
To win support from Democrats, including Mr. Clinton's appointees, Senator Breaux is proposing to offer Medicare coverage of prescription drugs as a new benefit. The Government would pay all the costs of such drugs for people with incomes up to 35 percent above the official poverty level (incomes up to $10,568 a year for an individual and $13,334 for a couple).
Health maintenance organizations and other private health plans would have to offer drug coverage to Medicare beneficiaries, but they could charge extra. The original fee-for-service Medicare program would also offer prescription drug coverage, through arrangements with private insurers, but the Government would not subsidize the cost.
In purchasing drugs for millions of Medicare beneficiaries, Mr. Breaux said, the Government would pay "prices commonly available in the market, without recourse to price controls." Drug companies adamantly oppose price controls, saying they would choke off the revenues needed to finance research and reward investors.
Two of President Clinton's appointees -- Stuart H. Altman, a professor of health policy at Brandeis University, and Laura D'Andrea Tyson, former chairwoman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers -- have praised some features of Mr. Breaux's proposal, including its potential to save money by stimulating competition in the Medicare market. But they have also insisted that Mr. Breaux clarify many details of his plan.
Another Clinton appointee, Bruce C. Vladeck, the Federal official in charge of Medicare from 1993 to 1997, has led opposition to Mr. Breaux's proposal, saying it would shred the guarantee of health benefits for some of the sickest, most vulnerable people in America.
Representative Bill Thomas of California, the leading Republican on the commission, said he was disappointed that Mr. Clinton had stayed aloof from the panel.
"We have Republicans, we have Democrats," Mr. Thomas said. "We have members of the House, we have members of the Senate. We have members of the public, and we have members of the private sector all in support of this plan. The only group that hasn't given us one vote is the President's appointees."
White House officials responded today that although they had often consulted with the President's appointees, the commission members were free to vote as they chose on the proposals. And, the officials said, the White House will not comment until Mr. Clinton reviews the panel's final report.
Mr. Breaux and Mr. Thomas said they would translate the Breaux plan into legislation and try to push it through Congress this year, regardless of whether it is formally endorsed by the commission.
The plan is supported by all eight Republican members of the commission and by two Democrats, Mr. Breaux and Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska.
Mr. Breaux's plan would gradually raise the eligibility age for Medicare, to 67 from 65, over 24 years, from 2003 to 2027. People age 65 or 66 who could not obtain private insurance would be allowed to purchase Medicare coverage under rules to be specified in the future, Mr. Breaux said.
His proposal would also extend provisions of the Balanced Budget Act of 1997 that curbed the growth of Medicare payments to doctors, hospitals, home health agencies and nursing homes.
The staff of the commission estimated that Mr. Breaux's plan would not produce significant savings in the first five years, but would save a total of $100 billion from 2005 to 2009. Then, it said, the savings would gradually increase, so that in 2030, Medicare spending would be $600 billion less than now anticipated: $1.6 trillion, rather than the $2.2 trillion envisioned under current law.

HEADLINE: El Paso Energy to Buy Sonat, Creating Gas Pipeline Giant

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: HOUSTON, March 15

 BODY:
The El Paso Energy Corporation agreed today to buy a rival, Sonat Inc., for $3.9 billion in stock and $1.9 billion in assumed debt, creating the largest interstate natural gas pipeline company in the United States.
El Paso will exchange one of its shares for each share of Sonat. The transaction values Sonat at $35.75 a share, a 32 percent premium to its closing price of $27.125 on Thursday, the day before the company's stock started to rise on speculation about the purchase. 
 The deal will let El Paso expand in the electricity business without merging with a utility, as other gas companies have done, analysts said. Sonat's pipelines provide gas to fast-growing markets in the Southeast, including Florida. El Paso, based in Houston, can build gas-fired power plants along those lines. Sonat is based in Birmingham, Ala.
"El Paso is getting pipelines in an area it doesn't have them now, which should provide a good platform to continue their power plant projects," said Mark Easterbrook, an analyst at Dain Rauscher Wessels.
The bid comes a month after the Southern Company in Atlanta, the largest publicly traded United States power company, ended talks to buy El Paso. Those talks fell apart after the chairman of El Paso, William Wise, demanded to be chief executive of the new company when Southern's chief executive leaves, people close to the negotiations said.
In an interview, Mr. Wise said the purchase would save $60 million a year beginning in 2000. Some jobs will be cut after the acquisition, though Mr. Wise did not give specific figures. El Paso will take a charge of $200 million to $300 million before taxes to account for some of the costs of the deal.
The companies said the acquisition would raise earnings and cash flow of the combined entity in 2000, the first full year of the merger.
The high premium that El Paso is paying is an indicator of how strongly El Paso wants to stay independent, analysts said. Buying Sonat makes El Paso big enough to fend off hostile bids, said Michael Barbis, an analyst with Warburg Dillon Read.
Shares of El Paso fell $3.6875, or 10.3 percent, to $32.0625, as investors reacted to the size of the bid. Sonat fell 43.75 cents, to $29.625.
Mr. Easterbrook suggested that one reason shares were falling was that investors were worried about the financial prospects of Sonat's oil and gas exploration business.
Earlier this month, Sonat said it would take a first-quarter charge of about $200 million, or $1.81 a share, to write down the value of reserves because of low oil and gas prices. Inflation-adjusted oil prices have been at their lowest levels since the Great Depression most of this year.

HEADLINE: Spending by Insurers Pushes Albany Lobbying to Record

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

DATELINE: ALBANY, March 15

 BODY:
An unsuccessful bid by life insurance companies to loosen regulations on their industry helped to push spending on lobbying in the Statehouse to another record last year, according to a report issued today.
Over all, expenditures by lobbying clients increased by 7 percent last year over 1997, to $55 million, the report by the Temporary State Commission on Lobbying said. 
 The New York Life Insurance Company, in what was believed to be a record for a lobbying campaign in Albany, poured more than $1.8 million into its effort to change state regulations that restrict the ability of some life insurance companies from selling off a partial ownership stake to stockholders.
The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company came in fourth in the commission's rankings, spending more than $600,000.
Neither of the insurers was in the top 10 in lobbying expenditures in 1997, the commission's records showed.
The two insurance companies, as well as some smaller rivals and an industry trade group, were lobbying last year in support of insurance legislation proposed by Gov. George E. Pataki. The bill died after opposition by the Democratic majority in the State Assembly, which contended that it would allow the life insurance companies to sell stock without adequately compensating insurance policyholders.
Bill Werfelman, a vice president at New York Life, said a sizable part of its lobbying expenses went for advocacy advertisements intended to muster public support for the legislation.
"It's safe to assume that this was a special circumstance for New York Life," Mr. Werfelman said, noting that the company was no longer pursuing the legislation and expected its lobbying expenses to plummet this year.
Besides the spurt in spending by the life insurance industry, the report by the commission showed that health care groups, trade associations, labor unions and banks continued to dominate spending on lobbying, which has generally risen at more than the rate of inflation over the last two decades.
The figures without a doubt underestimated the efforts to influence the state government, largely because the definition of what constitutes lobbying is hazy. Some clients choose to report rigorously any spending relating to the state government, including money allocated for items that might also be considered public relations or legal work. Others hew to a less strict definition. Moreover, under the law, clients do not have to report expenditures for lobbying on state contracts.
And the report today did not mention the other weapon in the arsenal of interest groups: campaign contributions. For example, the state teachers' union, which perennially is in the top five in lobbying expenditures, has given roughly $300,000 a year since 1995 to the campaign committees run by the legislative leaders. That is on top of an annual average of $650,000 that the union has spent on lobbying, state records showed.
As in 1997, the top two lobbying firms were Wilson, Elser, Moskowitz, Edelman & Dicker, whose chief lobbyist is Kenneth Shapiro, a former senior aide to the Assembly Democrats, and Davidoff & Malito, whose activities in Albany are led by Robert Malito, who has close ties to the Republican majority in the State Senate.
Both firms are also major campaign contributors.
The biggest increase in business was reported by Albert J. Pirro Jr., whose lobbying fees rose 53 percent, to more than $550,000. Mr. Pirro, the husband of Jeanine F. Pirro, the Westchester County District Attorney, was indicted last month on Federal tax charges. He has pleaded not guilty.
As lobbying commission members released the report, they once again requested that the Legislature tighten the state's lobbying rules, a call that was echoed by a coalition of advocacy groups.
The law authorizing the commission expires this year, but lawmakers have repeatedly rebuffed proposals to give the commission permanent status and more enforcement power, and to require lobbyists to disclose more information about their activities.
"We ask our state leaders to act favorably upon our legislative proposals," said the panel's chairman, Bartley F. Livolsi, "so that the commission can cross the bridge into the next millennium equipped and prepared to monitor 21st-century lobbying."

HEADLINE: Democrats Pick '00 Site: Los Angeles

BYLINE: By DON TERRY 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, March 15

 BODY:
Evoking the glories and the ghost of John F. Kennedy, the Democratic National Committee announced today that it would hold its national convention here in the summer of 2000.
In coming to Los Angeles for the first time in 40 years, the Democrats are hoping that history will repeat itself. In 1960, John F. Kennedy, then a senator from Massachusetts, won the Presidential nomination here and went on to become an icon. 
 The city's selection had been widely known since last week, so today's official announcement was a time for the people who brought the Democrats to town to take a bow.
The newly elected Democratic Governor of California, Gray Davis, said the convention and the state's new earlier primary would help give California "unrivaled clout" and show that "Los Angeles is back, having weathered riots and recession, floods and fire."
Eli Broad, a billionaire businessman and a leader of the effort to bring the convention to the city, said it would create jobs and pour $150 million into the city's economy.
The Republican Mayor of Los Angeles, Richard J. Riordan, was beaming about the prospect of so many Democrats coming to town.
"Democrats are almost as good as Republicans," Mayor Riordan said after the news conference. "Right now, I'm in love with the Democrats for picking Los Angeles."
Joe Andrew, the national chairman-designate of the Democratic National Committee, said Los Angeles was selected for several reasons, including the "vibrancy and diversity of the people" and the election of Mr. Davis, the first Democratic governor in California in 16 years. Mr. Andrew added that Mayor Riordan, "a man who has reached across the divide of partisan politics," had also played a major role.
Finally, Mr. Andrew said, Los Angeles was selected because of a partnership among business, politicians and civic leaders.
Convention organizers say the private sector is committed to providing $28.1 million of the $35.3 million cost of the convention.
"The citizens of California," Mr. Andrew said, "will get the benefit and not the burden."
The convention will be held at the new 900,000-square-foot Staples Center, which is to be completed this fall. The center is downtown, a few blocks from Skid Row, which was crowded with homeless people today.
Bob Erlenbusch, executive director of the Los Angeles Coalition to End Hunger and Homelessness, said he did not expect the convention to have much economic impact on the people who live so close to Staples Center. During the 1984 Summer Olympics and the Pope's visit four years later, Mr. Erlenbusch said, there were countless "horror stories" of homeless people being swept off the streets by the police.
The Rev. James M. Lawson Jr., a leader of the civil rights movement and now the pastor of the Holman Methodist Church near the convention site, said there was no doubt that some ordinary people would get jobs because of the convention.
"But the convention will not effect any long-term change in Los Angeles," Mr. Lawson said.
But Joel Kotkin, a senior fellow at the Pepperdine Institute for Public Policy, said the coalition that helped bring the convention to Los Angeles was an example of a new direction for the city.

HEADLINE: One of 2 Teams in Genome-Map Race Sets an Earlier Deadline

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS WADE 

 BODY:
The date for completing the first draft of the human genome, the three billion units of DNA held in every human cell, has been moved up to the spring of 2000, the publicly financed consortium sponsoring the work announced yesterday.
If met, the new date set by the consortium -- the National Institutes of Health, the Energy Department and the Wellcome Trust of London -- could allow the public venture to claim some measure of victory over its commercial rival, the Celera Corporation of Rockville, Md. Celera, headed by Dr. J. Craig Venter, has said it will produce a substantially complete, accurate human genome sequence by the end of 2001. 
 Dr. Venter said in response to yesterday's development that he had not changed his goals and that the public consortium's announcement had "nothing to do with reality."
"It is projected cost, projected timetables," he said.
Until the formation of Celera last May by the Perkin-Elmer Corporation, an instrument-making company based in Norwalk, Conn., the public consortium had aimed to finish the complete genome by 2005. Then, in the fall, the consortium said it could crank out a first draft of the genome by December 2001. The new target cuts even that ambitious goal by some 18 months.
The genome sequence is expected to become the nucleus of medicine, because it represents the programming for the human organism. Most diseases are caused to varying extents by bugs in this programming, which are the mutations that affect each individual's genetic endowment.
Participants on both the public and private teams believe that the intense competition between them has forced faster progress than if either team were working by itself.
"If we lose that pressure, we wouldn't be seeing such good reciprocity between the public and private efforts," said Dr. Richard Gibbs, head of the sequencing center at the Baylor College of Medicine in Houston, who works with the consortium's team.
Referring to the pressure that Celera's mere existence has created for the genome efforts of the National Institutes of Health, Dr. Norton Zinder, biologist at Rockefeller University and a member of Celera's board, said, "The Venter-Hunkapiller initiative will cause the DNA of the human genome to be made available from the N.I.H., without Celera's having to do a line of sequence." Dr. Michael W. Hunkapiller is the Perkin-Elmer executive responsible for design of the company's widely used DNA sequencing machines.
The draft that the consortium says it can complete by the spring of next year is intended to reflect all human genes, estimated to number about 100,000, and most of the long intervening stretches of DNA that lie between them. Much of the genome is in the form of repetitive sequences that are hard to decipher and have no known functional significance because they are not part of the genes. Such regions that are not completed now will be done later.
Almost 60 percent of the genome will be sequenced by the national institutes' university-based centers, 10 percent by the Energy Department's laboratories, and 33 percent by the Sanger Center near Cambridge, England.
The Federal Government's share of the human genome project was intended to cost $3 billion over 15 years. But Dr. Francis Collins, director of the institutes' part of the project, said the actual amount spent on production-scale sequencing would be much less. He expects the international consortium's cost of preparing the draft sequence to be $280 million or less, comparable with Celera's costs.
Until now, the national institutes have financed eight university-based centers to generate human DNA data. But Dr. Collins announced yesterday that new money would be focused on the three most productive centers, those headed by Dr. Robert Waterston at the Washington University School of Medicine in St. Louis, Dr. Eric Lander at the Whitehead Institute in Cambridge, Mass., and Dr. Gibbs at the Baylor College of Medicine in Houston.
The new focus may give the institutes' decentralized system a helpful edge in competing with the monolithic but nimble Celera. Dr. Lander said economies of scale were readily apparent in centers that had 100 of the latest-model DNA sequencing machines, a capacity that is to be reached soon by the Sanger Center, Washington University's and his own.
An early test of strength may come with Celera's pilot project, that of sequencing the entire genome of the Drosophila fruit fly, a standard laboratory organism. Dr. Venter, Celera's chief, said he hoped to complete the sequence in three to six months.
