HEADLINE: China's Premier Stresses Cooperation for U.S. Visit

BYLINE: By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL 

DATELINE: BEIJING, March 15

 BODY:
Less than a month before he leaves for a state visit to the United States, the blunt-speaking Prime Minister of China, Zhu Rongji, laid out his agenda today for what promises to be a turbulent trip, saying the two nations would continue to cooperate despite renewed friction on issues ranging from human rights to charges that China stole nuclear secrets.
"Of course it will not be easy for me to go to the United States in such an atmosphere," Mr. Zhu said at a news conference. But he quickly added: "My goal is to let you vent your anger and complaints and to tell you the truth -- and to regain the momentum of building a strategic partnership between China and the United States." 
 In an unscripted 90-minute meeting with reporters after the adjournment of Parliament, Mr. Zhu covered a range of topics including plans to open his country's markets further, the arrest of pro-democracy advocates and China's unyielding opposition to a proposed regional missile defense system that could potentially include Taiwan.
None of the positions presented by Mr. Zhu were entirely new, although some fresh tidbits were offered, like China's willingness to relax restrictions on foreign investment in its banking sector. More important, the news conference marked the first time that many positions had been stated directly by a top Chinese leader.
And Mr. Zhu's casual style made the serious conflicts percolating between the two nations seem more like spats between old friends.
In the last six weeks, the United States Congress has accused China of stealing American nuclear secrets, trying to illegally import military hardware from the United States and violating a United Nations Human Rights Covenant it signed just last year.
Mr. Zhu acknowledged that relations between Beijing and Washington had lost "momentum" since President Clinton's ebullient state visit to China last summer.
But his underlying theme, that the two nations could cooperate despite their considerable differences, echoed that of Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright when she visited Beijing last month. And in general, Mr. Zhu's statements were more measured than recent Chinese Government pronouncements, which have lambasted the United States as "hypocritical" on human rights and denounced spying charges as fabrications by enemies of China.
The news conference was broadcast live, just after China's Parliament approved a host of reports and constitutional amendments sponsored by the Communist Party.
While Parliament inevitably passes such motions by huge margins, debates at committee meetings have become increasingly lively. And the meeting this year provided some unusual excitement as two Government reports on China's legal system presented a frank picture of widespread abuse and corruption. A constitutional amendment that elevated the status of the private sector was at least a symbolic victory for China's emerging business class.
But it was Mr. Zhu's meeting with reporters that carried the day. His chief portfolio is economic reform, but the session today provided a glimpse of how he handles foreign relations, less familiar waters that he will have to navigate in the United States.
Mr. Zhu scoffed at the spying charges that have riveted both the United States Congress and media: that a Taiwan-born scientist passed on secret information enabling China to modernize its nuclear arsenal. The charges both underestimate the American Government's ability to keep secrets and Chinese scientists' ability to make discoveries, he said.
"China is fully capable of developing any military technology," he said. "It's only a matter of time."
He said the charges had grown out of "internal struggles in the United States." Evoking the McCarthy era in the United States and the Cultural Revolution, he warned that both countries had known "periods where everyone was afraid of being accused by everyone else, and we should never forget that."
Mr. Zhu's mood turned more serious as he discussed proposals for the United States and Japan to build a missile defense system for East Asia that might eventually include Taiwan. He dismissed American news reports that China has 600 missiles trained on Taiwan. "How could they know that?" he said. "Even I don't know that!"
Fifty years after Chinese Nationalist forces fled to Taiwan, Beijing still regards the island as a renegade province and American military aid there as interference in China's internal affairs.
Mr. Zhu also rehearsed answers to the human rights questions that will certainly come up during the trip next month. Although Chinese officials have long insisted that human rights policies are strictly internal affairs, Mr. Zhu expressed what appears to be at least a superficial willingness to hear opposing views.
"We welcome foreign friends criticizing us in our work, but don't be impatient," he said, noting that he has grown accustomed to "friends from abroad pulling out lists" of pro-democracy activists whom they want released from jail.
But as Mr. Zhu briefly lit into such activists, it was clear that the two sides shared little common ground. "Don't support these so-called pro-democracy activists," he said, warning that they would bring neither democracy nor rule of law to China.
On economic policy, he reiterated that the Government would not devalue its currency and would no longer prop up insolvent companies.
He talked of China's renewed eagerness to get into the World Trade Organization this year. American and Chinese officials are now negotiating furiously to this end, in the hopes that even a embryonic deal will provide a happy note to what many expect could be a dissonant visit to America.
Mr. Zhu suggested that China would be willing to open its telecommunications and banking sectors somewhat to gain admission -- a tantalizing prospect for foreign investors -- though he refused to go into details.
He said that after years of discussion, the two sides had recently made substantial progress, although differences remained. "The black hair has turned gray, and it's time to conclude these negotiations," he said.

HEADLINE: Gore Offers a More 'Livable World' With Some Tinkering

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: DES MOINES, March 15

 BODY:
Vice President Al Gore began laying out a platform today for his all-but-announced Presidential candidacy, appealing to harried suburbanites and promising to create a more "livable world."
Mr. Gore offered a continuation of President Clinton's policies, with only minor tinkering. He said, for example, that he wanted to hire enough teachers to reduce the size of classes in all grades through high school, not just through eighth grade as Mr. Clinton has proposed. He also said that he wanted to make preschool education available in all public schools. 
 But he did little to separate himself from his political benefactor today as he took one more step in his long, slow march toward a Presidential candidacy by taking his first official campaign trip, paid for by his election committee. He is not expected to announce his candidacy officially until later this year.
"I want to build on the wisdom that we've all gained in the last several years," he said at a rally in snowbound New Hampshire before flying here, paying homage to the two states that vote the earliest in the primary process.
Mr. Gore put special emphasis on what he calls quality-of-life issues -- easing traffic congestion, for example -- that some have ridiculed as un-Presidential because they are local issues, but that he defends as integral to strengthening families by creating more free time. They are also aimed squarely at an important bloc of swing voters, especially frazzled parents, who live in the suburbs and could decide the next election.
"The person who deserves to be our next President is the one who understands how tired working parents are," Mr. Gore said.
"We're seeing the daily commutes get longer and longer," he said. "And for people who don't think that it's a problem that parents are caught in traffic jams that are lengthening each day, I'll tell you, they haven't been in traffic jams and they don't know what it does to the desire to balance work and family."
He referred to the cultural battles that his wife, Tipper, fought over obscene song lyrics and said, "The V-chip is just the beginning." As he told a crowd of about 100 people here, "Let's be sensitive to the problems that real families have."
In an apparent response to criticism that he has focused too exclusively on upscale suburbanites, he made a pledge today on behalf of women and minorities. Citing the commitment of his late father, a Senator, to civil rights and of his mother to women's independence, he vowed to carry those crusades into the next century.
For all of Mr. Gore's identification with the Clinton Administration, particularly the nation's economic prosperity, he seemed quite ambiguous about how strongly to associate himself with it. He did not mention Mr. Clinton by name, and he seemed to want to create distance by describing not a policy divide but an epochal divide -- a natural break in the calendar in the year 2000 that would leave Mr. Clinton in the past and put Mr. Gore in the future.
"It's not only the beginning of a new century and a new millennium," Mr. Gore said. "It's the beginning of a whole new era in human history." He said that posed a new set of challenges with "new approaches for the new century."
Mr. Gore has spent years building up an extensive financial, political and policy network across the country, and that in-place apparatus has gone a long way toward clearing the field of primary challengers.
Today he was accompanied by Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House Democratic leader, who formally endorsed him in what the two billed as a strong sign of party unity. Bill Bradley, the former Senator from New Jersey, is the only Democrat who has entered the race, and the polls strongly favor Mr. Gore over him for the party's nomination.
But the polls are less encouraging for Mr. Gore in hypothetical match-ups against various Republicans, suggesting serious vulnerabilities in the Gore candidacy. The latest NBC/ Wall Street Journal poll showed him 18 points behind Gov. George W. Bush of Texas and 15 points behind Elizabeth Dole, the two leading Republicans.
Judith Hope, the Democratic chairwoman in New York, last week openly questioned whether Mr. Gore would be the party's best nominee, noting that Democratic Vice Presidents who have sought the Presidency have tended to lose.
Mr. Gore's media consultant, Bob Squier, said that Mr. Gore was flagging in the polls because he was still being perceived as Vice President. "He is not thought of in Presidential terms," Mr. Squier said, suggesting that campaign forays like today's, which drew the biggest press contingent of Mr. Gore's tenure, would start to change that perception.
Mr. Gore sidestepped questions about whether he was too closely linked with the impeached President. He said the campaign would be about ideas, not polls.
But Gore aides admit that he is using a series of narrowly focused, poll-tested initiatives, reminiscent of some of Mr. Clinton's micro-proposals in 1996, to appeal to voters.
With Mr. Clinton off in Central America last week, the Vice President used the empty stage of the White House almost every day to discuss topics including traffic jams, drug labels and lost bags at airports.
Aides even imitated the Clinton strategy of targeting their announcements to certain media venues to insure maximum, and sympathetic, exposure. For example, at last week's announcement on ways to ease traffic congestion, they invited traffic reporters, those who ride the choppers and describe road conditions. This guaranteed the Vice President media coverage in local markets across the country and on drive-time radio, much as Mr. Clinton in 1997 insured heavy attention for his conference on global warming by inviting more than 100 local weather forecasters to cover it.
Republicans have poked fun at Mr. Gore for directing a Presidential campaign to such seemingly small issues as lost bags at airports and such seemingly local issues as traffic congestion. Jim Nicholson, chairman of the Republican National Committee, has been particularly scathing, accusing Mr. Gore of trying to "do away with the internal combustion engine, the automobile," and calling him "an apologist for the President; he's a wasteful dreamer."
Even an airline passenger, Jim Corsetty of Rockville, Md., whose plane was stranded on a runway and who found himself on stage with the Vice President last week, expressed his astonishment that he had become an anecdote in the Presidential campaign. He introduced the Vice President as "my own personal consumer advocate."
But some Republicans think Mr. Gore might be on to something.
Bill McInturff, a Republican pollster who is working for the Presidential campaign of Senator John McCain of Arizona, said that even if Mr. Gore was talking about "microscopic" issues and sounded as if he were running for town manager rather than President, he was still controlling the policy debate.
"It's working," Mr. McInturff said with some exasperation. "You're writing a story about Gore talking about lots of popular issues. But have we really so dumbed down the office that he can be talking about traffic?"

HEADLINE: Washington's Mayor Urges Moving Its Public University, Creating Furor

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 15

 BODY:
Taking on an issue today that has always exposed the gulf between haves and have-nots in the nation's capital, Mayor Anthony A. Williams proposed moving the University of the District of Columbia from its current campus in northwest Washington near embassies and expensive homes, to Anacostia, the poorest section of the city.
While Mr. Williams suggested that the move would promote economic development in its current and proposed sites, the idea sparked instant and widespread outrage from people who insisted that it reflected an overwhelming insensitivity to the needs of low-income blacks, who regard the university as a viable way out of neighborhoods that have been ravaged by crime and drugs. 
 "Everybody is upset about this; it's awful," said Lawanda Johnson, a U.D.C. senior who attended Mr. Williams's news conference today. "People are fighting to get away from places like Anacostia. Where we go now is a way out. We don't want to go back to look at crime."
Many said the proposal would primarily benefit real estate developers who might buy the property. Mr. Williams disputed that contention, saying he was committed to keeping the university open and thriving.
The University of the District of Columbia was created 22 years ago as the city's version of a state university and an alternative for high school graduates who cannot afford more costly private institutions and for older students who work full-time. In the early years, the university's curricula expanded to accommodate almost any major imaginable, whether aviation or gospel singing, in an effort to help students earn a college degree. But the city's financial troubles in the early 1990's forced a scaling back that reduced course offerings and fueled speculation that city leaders would prefer to close a university in a predominantly white neighborhood that serves a student body that is mostly black.
Through it all, defenders of the university have contended that the need for a low-cost institution of higher learning, similar to those available to state residents, offers city residents the best chance to overcome generations of poverty. They also say the university's location has reflected a symbolic assurance that city leaders regard its students with the same respect accorded those attending private universities in the city, like George Washington, Georgetown, American, Catholic and Howard.
Campaigning here for mayor last year, his first bid for elective office after several years as the district's chief financial officer, Mr. Williams supported those perceptions and promised to keep the University of the District of Columbia as a four-year institution even though the undergraduate population fell by nearly half, to 5,029 this year from 9,179 in 1996 because of budget cutbacks.
In January, he vowed to appoint a commission to recommend improvements, and today he said the budget would include $1 million to examine the feasibility of moving the campus "to match the needs of the anticipated revised mission and to spur economic development" in Anacostia.
But the idea of moving the university, which evolved without consulting current university officials, caught the city by surprise, angering many who said the proposal reflected a larger scheme, to marginalize the university for the benefit of real estate tycoons who could make a fortune developing the property.
At a news conference today, Mr. Williams said he was committed to helping the university thrive. But as part of his first budget announced today, which reflected priorities of education and economic development, he proposed selling the university and using tax revenues from new businesses at the current location to support a new campus in Anacostia as a way to spur economic development there.
"We have to boost U.D.C. up to a higher level of performance," Mr. Williams said. "We have to think how we can do that in the overall concept of better government."
Mr. Williams brushed aside questions that suggested his proposal reflected a political naivete on his part for wading into an issue that touches raw nerves involving class and race.
He responded by pointing out that many district residents questioned his political instincts when he was a mayoral candidate. Nonetheless, he easily won the Democratic primary last year and carried every precinct in the November general election, something his popular predecessor, Marion S. Barry Jr., never did. "I didn't get elected to adjust the air-conditioning," Mr. Williams said. "I was elected to make some changes."
And to those who questioned the timing of his proposal to appoint a commission to study the university's future, after he had already determined where the future should lie, Mr. Williams took a swipe at Mr. Barry, saying, "I think it's important to send a signal that this administration is ready to wade into areas where others have feared to tread."
While many other proposals in his budget suggested that other city agencies face changes, few packed the emotional wallop of the one concerning the university.
On campus today, many students said they were angered by the idea.
"Clearly, this is nothing more than another attempt to shut us down," said Diallo Sumbry, senior class president. "If you look at our history, we had our budget cut by 50 percent, then they wanted to sell the school."
Lenox Yearwood Jr., the university's director of student life and a 1994 graduate as well as a former student government president, said: "It is racist at the core. They systematically dismantled our budget, faculty, and morale. This is back-door politics at its best.
"How would Georgetown students feel if we told them to leave their home?" Mr. Yearwood asked.
That view was shared by university leaders, past and present. Roger Wilkens, a history professor at George Mason University in Fairfax, Va., was a trustee of the University of the District of Columbia from 1986 to 1991. He lives in Washington.
He said he was disappointed by Mr. Williams's proposal, arguing that young people who have grown up with crime, drugs and shabby housing need hope. "If you create a first-rate institution in a city, then you give parents and teachers the opportunity to say to little kids, 'Look up there on Connecticut Ave. Look at where you can go in life,' " he said.

HEADLINE: Tribes Weigh Tradition Against Growth of Casino Resorts

BYLINE: By BRETT PULLEY 

DATELINE: BERNALILLO, N.M., March 12

 BODY:
With muscular yet elegant curves, the Rio Grande winds its way through the Santa Ana Pueblo reservation. Stand along its yucca- and cactus-sprinkled banks and face north from the sacred Indian grounds where the Spanish explorer Coronado once trekked, and the Sandia Mountains seem to hang like gods in the sky to the east.
Look just to the west, and the only thing hanging in the sky is a giant neon star bearing the words "Star Casino." Next to the casino, little white golf carts zip over the reservation's 27-hole championship course. And just beyond that, construction is under way on an $80 million hotel, a spa and second golf course. 
 After using casino gambling over the past several years to help reverse their fortunes, American Indian tribes like this one are beginning to build entire leisure industries on their reservations. But as the easy-living aura of vacation resorts, gambling, golf and shopping spreads across the land that Indians have cherished for generations and worked to protect from outside intrusion, concern has been growing among tribal members that their religion, culture and sovereignty are being pushed aside.
"It's like a leisure virus," said Jose Lucero, a member of the Santa Clara Pueblo tribe, whose reservation is about 60 miles north of here. His tribe is divided over whether it, too, should develop a casino resort. "We're trading our souls for money," he said. "Some tribe members say: 'Hey, it's O.K. It's glamorous.' But that's not what we are supposed to be. We are supposed to be stewards of this land. And we're not very good stewards now, allowing all of this stuff to take over."
With the desperately needed jobs and money that casinos have brought to reservations, few people in the more insular tribes have been publicly critical of casino gambling on their reservations. But a once-faint drumbeat of disdain is growing louder. Critics worry that tourists will trample across what they consider to be religious ground, that the business partnerships that the tribes are forming are increasingly being operated by outside professionals and managers.
"Our religious leaders are more or less opposed to the casino and all these companies moving in here," said Otis Leon, a member of the tribal council that governs the Santa Ana tribe. But the medicine men and other protectors of the tribe's religion and culture, he added, "are getting pushed aside in a way."
Mr. Leon, who voted in favor of the casino development, now expresses mixed emotions. "Things seemed O.K. at first," he said. "But then more of the Las Vegas types started moving in."
Despite such concerns, it is difficult to argue against what appears to be progress. Of the 22 tribes across the state, 11 operate casinos and it is estimated that they take in more than $350 million a year in overall gambling revenue. And although there is still poverty on the reservations, jobs are now available, recreation centers and libraries have been built and major investments are being made to augment the success of gambling. Several tribes are expanding their casinos and planning hotels and vacation resorts, and the tribe leading the way is the Santa Ana Pueblo.
Two weeks ago, the tribe announced a partnership with the Hyatt Hotels Corporation to build what is being billed as "New Mexico's first major golf and spa resort." The 350-room resort hotel is to occupy a picturesque section of the 61,000-acre reservation, which is located 15 miles north of Albuquerque. The tribe will own the resort and Hyatt will manage it. Also, the tribe is doubling the size of its adobe-style Star Casino and adding a Las Vegas-style theater. A retail shopping center has been proposed for a nearby section of the reservation.
Thanks to the profit from its six-year-old casino, the Santa Ana Pueblo tribe is operating a four-star restaurant on the reservation, next door to its golf course and luxurious clubhouse. This year, the tribe will be host to golf tournaments including the United States Women's Amateur Public Links Championship and the PGA Western Club Championship.
As the tribal members who are leading the development boom see it, they are doing more than investing the casino's profits to increase economic opportunities. Facing obstacles like ongoing attempts by gambling opponents to have the casinos closed and a possible recommendation to Congress by the National Gambling Impact Study Commission that the casinos be taxed, the tribe says it is creating a leisure industry that can survive even if the casinos do not. "There are so many attacks on Indian casinos," said Roy Montoya, who as chief administrator of the 690-member tribe is in charge of all business development. "What the new resort represents is another step toward self-sufficiency."
Within the tribe, where most decisions are made by councils composed of men, the progression from subsistence agriculture to private business has created two camps. The traditionalists are leery of opening their boundaries to outside interests, and the business leaders like Mr. Montoya are pushing to expand.
As the profits from gambling began to add up, "we considered two approaches," Mr. Montoya said in an interview in his plain but comfortable office on the reservation. "Some people said: 'Stash the money. Don't do anything with it.' But we chose to put these different ventures in place."
The culture and religion, Mr. Montoya said, will be strengthened by the economic growth. "Our culture and religion was very strong when we got our subsistence from farming right here on the reservation," he said. "Then when the economy started changing and Dad had to go off the reservation to work, things got weak. But with jobs on the reservation now you have more time to spend with your family and in 15 to 20 years, the religion and culture will become stronger again."
The business-oriented tribal members seem to be winning. When the tribal council discussed the proposed Hyatt, some members bristled at building the resort just a half-mile from "The Snake Head," one of the reservation's ancient religious sites.
"But the business types said they needed that site next to the river, overlooking the mountains," said Mr. Leon, whose grandfather held the revered religious title of medicine man. The business interests prevailed. Mr. Leon said: "The religious people are upset with us. They worry that the public will wander over the reservation."
One plan for the Hyatt resort that might appease the religious leaders is a small museum with exhibits depicting the tribe's history.
 Two weeks ago at the Taos Pueblo reservation, 70 miles north of Santa Fe, tribal leaders approved a plan to buy a nearby hotel and meeting center and move the tribe's casino to the site, which would become a part of the tribe's reservation. But not everyone is happy about the growth. Jerome Marcus, a 38-year-old member of the tribe and former security officer at the casino, said that as the casino has prospered he has witnessed a slow deterioration of tribal values. "I've noticed a complete lack of participation in ceremonies and understanding by our people, especially with diversions like the casino," he said.
Still, the benefits from the development are evident in the opportunities that have been created.
Recently, at the Isleta Pueblo reservation, 10 miles south of Albuquerque, Aaron Dailey, a 16-year-old tribal member, was busy washing golf carts at the lush golf course just across State Highway 47 from the tribe's casino. Although he has been playing golf less than three years, Aaron already carries a 10 handicap and the golf professionals operating the course have high hopes. "The tribe is trusting us to come in and operate their business enterprises and train their people," said Brent Townsley, a teaching professional at the course. "But our goal is to see someone like Aaron take this course over and become the head pro."
Nevertheless, the phalanx of corporate interests, lawyers, accountants, casino managers and investment advisers who swirl around the reservation is unnerving to some. "They're taking a lot of the control of the economic development on the reservation out of the hands of the tribe itself," said Tim Giago, a syndicated columnist and member of South Dakota's Oglala Lakota tribe. "I'm amazed that many of the tribes have turned into what they've deplored all their lives. They're bureaucracies and they're being run by attorneys and accountants -- white attorneys and accountants."
But Roy Montoya appears to be in control of the Santa Ana businesses. One day recently, he walked into a closed-door meeting of casino executives to have a word with the casino's general manager. Minutes later, he was at the reservation's planning offices, interrupting another meeting of architects and developers who all popped to their feet, smiling broadly. "We own everything, 100 percent," Mr. Montoya said. "All of these people are on contract, just like out in the rest of the world."
Mr. Montoya oversees a staff of more than 400 employees, and in two years, when current development projects are complete, that number is projected to reach 700 -- more employees than tribal members. "When I started this job in '84 I had nine employees and I was just called Roy," said the 58-year-old Mr. Montoya. "Now people call me sir. But I'm still Roy."

HEADLINE: Traveling Companion Is Sought In Killing at the Waldorf-Astoria

BYLINE: By ANDY NEWMAN 

 BODY:
Investigators are seeking the traveling companion of a Brazilian economist who was found murdered Saturday in his room at the Waldorf-Astoria, a police official said yesterday.
A hotel surveillance videotape shows the companion entering the economist's room with him hours before the body was discovered and then leaving the room alone some time later, said the official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. 
 The 56-year-old victim, Joao Saboia, used to introduce the man as his nephew, but they were not related, the official said. He has probably fled the country and returned to Brazil, the official said, adding that the police had notified the authorities there to look for him.
About 5:30 P.M. on Saturday, after Mr. Saboia had missed an appointment to meet friends, the police found him with his throat slashed and his head bruised, with a possible skull fracture. His family has said $50,000 that Mr. Saboia had been carrying was missing.
Mr. Saboia's family has said that he was a high-stakes gambler who frequented Atlantic City and often traveled with a lot of money. Mr. Saboia, a resident of Belem in northern Brazil, had planned to attend Saturday night's Holyfield-Lewis heavyweight title fight at Madison Square Garden.
The death was believed to be the fourth homicide in the 68-year history of the Waldorf-Astoria, at Park Avenue and 49th Street. It was also the second attack within a year. Last June, a 37-year-old guest was injured in a stabbing by a homeless youth he had invited to his room.

HEADLINE: Clinton to Offer Debt Relief Plan for Poor Nations

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 15

 BODY:
President Clinton will propose extensive debt forgiveness on Tuesday for some of the poorest nations, agreeing to relieve repayment obligations of some countries in Africa and other regions if they enact broad reforms, Administration officials said today.
Mr. Clinton is to announce the program during a meeting here of African finance and foreign ministers. 
 But it will require approval by Congress, other donor nations and multinational institutions like the International Monetary Fund. Those negotiations could easily take a year or more. The fund has traditionally been reluctant to endorse such programs for fear they breed expectations among borrowing nations that if they wait long enough, they will not have to repay their loans.
But pressure has grown to provide relief to countries that must commit huge portions of their budgets to repayment, leaving little for education, health care or basic services.
While details are vague, the plan would expand the number of countries that could benefit from debt forgiveness to nearly 50, from 41. Countries like Ghana, Congo, Laos and Honduras could benefit, but only if they met certain economic targets that have yet to be set.
American officials said the United States is willing to forgive debts of more than $3 billion if other donors -- who are owed nearly $70 billion -- agree. But the impact on the Federal budget, the White House said, would be less than $200 million. While the accounting is complex, most of the debts have been written off as uncollectable, so the added cost to the Government of full forgiveness is considered relatively small.
While the Administration has often spoken of debt forgiveness for countries moving toward reform, it has never before proposed a broad change in the rules.
Part of the proposal calls for the I.M.F. to sell part of its gold reserves, given to it more than 50 years ago when the fund and the World Bank were formed. Interest from investing the proceeds of that sale could be used to pay off some of the money owed to the fund. Past calls to sell the gold have been in vain.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Two Agencies In Acquisitions

BYLINE: By Patricia Winters Lauro 

 BODY:
Two agencies are expanding through acquisitions.
Epsilon Data Management in Burlington, Mass., acquired Cohn Godley Norwood in Boston, an agency with billings estimated at $42 million from clients like Liberty Financial, Pro Player and Salomon Smith Barney. Terms of the stock and cash transaction were not disclosed. 
 Cohn Godley will be renamed CGN Marketing and Creative Services and become a wholly owned subsidiary of Epsilon, which includes among its owners an investment group headed by Robert Mohr and the American Express Company. Ben Godley remains president and chief executive and Paul Norwood remains executive vice president and creative director.
And Imation Internet Studios in Minneapolis, an Internet consulting, design and engineering agency with clients like General Motors and Meredith, is being acquired from the Imation Corporation in Oakdale, Minn., by two Imation Internet executives, Scott Litman and Dan Malen. Terms were not disclosed.
Imation Internet will be renamed Imaginet, its name before being acquired by Imation in 1997. Mr. Litman, 32, will be president and chief executive and Mr. Malen, 33, will be vice president and chief operating officer. In a related deal, Imaginet will acquire the interactive marketing division of Gage Marketing Group in Minneapolis; terms of that transaction were also not disclosed. The 12 employees of the division will join Imaginet.

HEADLINE: A Project 30 Years in the Making;
Durst Tries to Revive Father's Dream, Decades Later

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
More than 30 years ago, Seymour B. Durst set his sights on a dingy block at the eastern edge of Times Square.
He dreamed of bulldozing the transient hotels, tenements and decrepit buildings to make way for skyscrapers on 42d Street, between Broadway and the Avenue of the Americas. Pedestrian plazas would wind between the towers and old Broadway theaters in a modern version of Rockefeller Center. But when landowners set their prices sky-high and a recession struck in 1973, Mr. Durst abandoned his dream and with it, much of his drive to be a New York developer. 
 Even as the Avenue of the Americas has become a canyon of corporate skyscrapers and Times Square has been made safe for Disney, this block, from 42d to 43d Streets, has hardly changed. But now, Mr. Durst's son, Douglas, a taciturn 55-year-old, stands closer than even his father did in 1970 to developing this haunted stretch and carving his own name into the New York skyline.
He controls about 85 percent of the block. He is completing a 1.6 million-square-foot tower on state-owned land at the western end and has plans for a $650 million, 50-story tower for the rest of the block, possibly for the newly combined Nasdaq and the American Stock Exchange.
But first, he, like his father, must contend with four other landowning families whose lives have crisscrossed the block for three decades. It is a part of the age-old struggle between a developer and holdouts in New York that has earned a place in the city's culture through cartoons, songs and even a 1965 Broadway musical, "Skyscraper." Its history is replete with not only the economic vagaries that can undo real estate projects but also the feuds and scandals that wreak just as much havoc.
"It's a fascinating story," said Gordon McCollum, a retired real estate broker who played a role in the block's tortured history. "The block encapsulates everything about New York real estate. It's a real drama."
His father's role in that historical drama is very much on the mind of Mr. Durst. "I would like to complete something he started," he said. "It's a spot that itches, that you're always trying to get to."
This is a block where apple orchards gave way to pawnshops, the Times Square Bathhouse for Women, the Hotel Diplomat, Toffinetti's restaurant, the Xenon discotheque, Jimmy Glenn's Times Square Gym and Peepalive, a live sex show.
In recent months, Mr. Durst has renewed talks with the four other landowners. The Brandts own what used to be called the Pix Theater, one of 150 movie theaters the family once operated up and down the East Coast. Joseph Bernstein and his family, which had their own dreams of building office towers and hotels on the block, own three parcels on 42d Street and a fourth on the Avenue of the Americas.
Susan Rosenberg owns the small building at the southwest corner of 43d Street and the Avenue of the Americas where her late father, Harry Goldberg, opened a pawn shop in 1948. And finally, there is Richard M. Maidman, who owns the Remington Building, a dingy 19-story building that is vacant except for Fun City, a pornographic video store opened in the 1970's.
After three decades of on-again, off-again negotiations, they are like sumo wrestlers wrapped in headlocks, but unable to take down their opponent. Every owner wants to be the last in line to make a deal on the theory that that will get the highest price. But city and state officials have said they will condemn the block if the Nasdaq commits to moving there, a threat that could bring all the parties to the bargaining table.
"I get calls all the time from people who want to buy," said Ms. Rosenberg, who recalled that her father admired Seymour Durst, though the two never did cut a deal. "When there's something serious, we'll see what happens."
Seymour Durst, who died in 1995, first landed on the block in 1967, buying a building that was home to White's Sea Food Restaurant, which served a great clam chowder and dinner for $6. After developing office towers along Third Avenue in the 1950's, he jumped to the dowdy West Side, where land was cheap and ripe for development.
He would become known both inside and outside real estate circles as something of a philosopher, a man who enjoyed writing letters to editors and who stuffed his East Side town house with more than 10,000 books, maps and prints on city history. He also won some notoriety for erecting a neon sign on the Avenue of the Americas that still displays the national debt, second by second.
"His philosophy was that patience made a great investment," Mr. McCollum said. "It was almost artistic the way he would assemble these plots."
Seymour Durst eventually put together 10 acres between 42d Street and 47th Street from Broadway to the Avenue of the Americas for his grand vision of 10 soaring towers over a revived Times Square. On 42d Street itself, he had acquired much of the block, or negotiated deals to buy out his neighbors, including Mr. Maidman and the Brandts.
"I've walked 1,000 miles to assemble some sites," he said at the time. "I go back and then back again to a prospective site, sometimes every day, for that's a way to get to know the area and to talk with people in it."
But in 1973, overbuilding and a recession forced him to give up his dream. He lost a $400,000 deposit on the Maidman parcel and blamed holdouts for soaring land prices and the lack of progress in Times Square.
"It was a bitter disappointment to him," Douglas Durst said. "He became increasingly negative on development."
Over the next 22 years, Seymour Durst would build only two more office towers: 1155 Avenue of the Americas and the United States Trust Building, 114 West 47th Street.
Other developers had no more luck in developing the block. Robert Campeau, the mercurial Canadian tycoon, bought several parcels in 1981 and offered Mr. Durst $60 million for his property. But Mr. Campeau then lost interest in building an office tower and offered to sell his land for $11 million to the Bernstein brothers.
The deal came up as Joseph and Ralph Bernstein bought a development site from Seymour Durst at what is now 1177 Avenue of the Americas. They offered the Campeau land to Seymour Durst, who declined, offering instead to lease them all his property. The Bernsteins promptly hired architect I.M. Pei to design a 72-story tower with 2 million square feet.
But at the last moment, Mr. Durst scuttled the 42d Street deal, after news reports disclosed that the Bernsteins had acted as agents for Ferdinand Marcos, the Philippine dictator who looted his country's treasury to buy New York real estate. The Bernsteins never forgave Mr. Durst.
In 1987, it looked like the Dursts would jump back into the development game. Douglas Durst negotiated a tentative deal with Morgan Stanley to build a headquarters for the investment bank. It was going to be his first solo project since joining his father in the early 1970's, despite Seymour's advice to the contrary. A week later, the stock market crashed. "They called me the next day saying the world had changed; the project was dead," Douglas Durst said.
In 1990, a similar deal between the Dursts and the Chemical Bank also collapsed. Little happened on the block until 1995, when Douglas Durst opened negotiations with city and state officials about building what became 4 Times Square, the 48-story tower that will be home to Conde Nast Publications and the Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom law firm this summer. With the city still reeling from a recession, the project seemed a daring, even foolhardy, move by the usually conservative Durst family.
It was a stunning turnabout for the Dursts, who had long opposed the proposed office towers in the Times Square project. They had argued that these subsidized skyscrapers would compete with their own buildings and stifle development in the area. Yet after a decade of legal wrangling, it was Mr. Durst who would build the first tower.
"That was very bold," Mr. McCollum said. "I don't think his father would have ever made that move. I think Douglas has a more modern touch."
But it may take more than that for Mr. Durst to complete a deal on the remaining two-thirds of the block. The developer has met separately with each landowner, though no one is willing to discuss the talks.
For Mr. Durst, there are a thousand and one calculations, both economic and political. The more he pays for the land, the higher the rents he must charge and the less likely he is to find a tenant. He needs to sign a deal with a tenant to show he is serious, but no tenant wants to sign a contract without being certain the developer can deliver the land. The Nasdaq has indicated it wants to make a deal on 42d Street. Mr. Durst has also talked to Pfizer and PriceWaterhouseCoopers.
At the same time, the Giuliani administration has encouraged Mr. Durst to develop a 2 million-square-foot tower and a 1,500-seat Broadway theater, according to real estate executives involved in the project.
City and state officials have said they are willing to use the condemnation process to assemble the block for the Nasdaq, a threat that would eliminate the need for protracted negotiations but could spark a long court fight from Mr. Maidman.
Mr. Durst and Mr. Maidman have tangled recently at the Board of Standards and Appeals, where Mr. Durst has opposed Mr. Maidman's request for a variance to drape a 14,250-square-foot sign on his 19-story building. Mr. Maidman says he needs the money, while a lawyer for Mr. Durst, Irving Gotbaum, contends that the landlord is "only trying to boost the value of the property in anticipation of a sale."
Mr. Maidman set his price at a deal-breaking $20 million, quadruple the amount paid for two parcels Mr. Durst acquired last year. One executive at the Durst Organization suggested that Mr. Maidman might be seeking revenge on Mr. Durst because he believed the developer double-crossed him on a parking lot deal in the 1980's.
In the end, Peter R. Hauspurg, chairman of Eastern Consolidated Properties, a real estate consultant who has represented the Bernsteins since 1985, said he believes there will finally be a deal for the block, but not without more Sturm und Drang over at least one of the cutout parcels remaining on the block.
"I expect the pieces to fall into line at this point," Mr. Hauspurg said, "although I doubt that Richard Maidman will settle until Douglas is actually pouring concrete around Richard's cutout."

A brief history of Durst real estate deals on the block bound by 42d and 43d Streets, between Broadway and the Avenue of the Americas.
 
1967 -- Seymour Durst buys 104 W. 43d, the first of many parcels his company will own on the block.
 
1973 -- Durst drops the option to buy four parcels to add to its growing ownership of lots.
 
1986 -- Joseph and Ralph Bernstein acquire four parcels and try to lease Durst's property, but Durst backs out at the last minute.

1990 -- The Dursts try to build a headquarters for the Chemical Bank on the east side of the block, but the deal collapses.
 
1998 -- Douglas Durst begins negotiations to build a $650 million tower for the newly combined Nasdaq and American Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: LEADING SENATORS DEMAND U.S. LIMIT HELP FOR BEIJING

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 15

 BODY:
Influential Senators threatened today to block the Clinton Administration's leading diplomatic effort to improve fast-deteriorating relations with China, and they urged the suspension of some scientific exchange programs.
Jesse Helms, a North Carolina Republican, and Ernest F. Hollings, a South Carolina Democrat, said they would move to stop any effort by the White House to help China become a member of the World Trade Organization this year, reflecting Congressional anger over President Clinton's response to suspicions that China stole nuclear secrets. 
 And the Republican chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, Richard C. Shelby of Alabama, urged the President or Energy Secretary Bill Richardson to put a moratorium on visits by scientists from countries like China and Iran to American national weapons laboratories, and on reciprocal visits by American scientists to foreign installations.
"Our labs are not as secure as they should be," Mr. Shelby told reporters after an hourlong closed meeting with the director of Central Intelligence, George J. Tenet. "This perhaps is just the tip of an iceberg."
The Energy Department last week fired a Taiwan-born scientist at Los Alamos National Laboratory for security breaches, after the F.B.I. questioned him in connection with the suspected theft of nuclear weapons designs. Investigators say they believe that the scientist, Wen Ho Lee, gave the Chinese sensitive information on nuclear detonations during a visit there for a 1988 seminar. Mr. Lee has not been charged with any crime, but is the prime suspect in the case. Prime Minister Zhu Rongji of China scoffed at the spying charges, saying that his country is fully capable of developing nuclear technology on its own. Page A8.
Members of the House and Senate have criticized the Administration for not tightening security quickly enough and failing to keep Congress adequately informed about the seriousness of the possible breaches at Los Alamos.
David C. Leavy, a spokesman for the National Security Council, said tonight that the Administration would work with Congress to resolve the World Trade Organization issue, but he rejected Mr. Shelby's proposal. "There's no evidence the visitors' program has contributed to any damage to national security," Mr. Leavy said.
The double-barreled attack from Congress came as Mr. Richardson and Mr. Tenet, in separate closed briefings, tried to contain the political fallout from the Administration's handling of the spy case by explaining steps the Administration has taken to prevent thefts.
Mr. Tenet announced that a retired four-star admiral, David E. Jeremiah, would head an independent panel of experts to review the possible harm to national security resulting from suspected thefts that took place in the 1980's and were discovered by nuclear arms experts at Los Alamos in 1995. Admiral Jeremiah is likely to report by early next month.
But even as the Administration stepped up its defense of its response to the spy case, the White House took a body blow on its trade policy with China. The warning from Mr. Helms, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, and Mr. Hollings, the ranking Democrat on the Commerce Committee, was issued in a letter sent to all senators.
"The continuing problems with Chinese human rights violations, espionage and possible technology transfers," they wrote, "suggest that this is not the appropriate time for China to enter the W.T.O."
Only two weeks ago, in Beijing, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright assured China's leaders that the question of whether China was ready to enter the World Trade Organization -- a decade-long aspiration for China and a move that could prove enormously beneficial to the country's economy -- would be decided solely on commercial grounds. It would not hinge, she said, on China's human rights record or other issues.
But in recent weeks it has become increasingly clear that even if that is the Administration's plan, the atmosphere in Congress is rapidly changing. And Congressional approval will be necessary, because China's entry would require a major amendment of the law that allows Congress to review, each year, whether to extend "most favored nation" trading status to Beijing.
"This has become a poisonous issue," one of the President's top economic advisers said the other day. "And it could blow up the whole deal, if there is a deal."
The letter from Senators Helms and Hollings, which was reported in today's Wall Street Journal, mirrors conditions that the House Democratic leader, Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, has made and portends a tough fight for China to join the World Trade Organization this year.
Even as anger in Congress grows on the trade front, there is greater anxiety over security at Los Alamos and other national weapons laboratories. The labs had long resisted F.B.I. and Congressional pressure to tighten their security policies.
The Energy Department, which oversees the labs, has been lax in its supervision. The department, for instance, never filed a Congressionally required annual report in 1998 on the status of security at the labs.
Shortly after taking over as Energy Secretary last fall, Mr. Richardson learned of the urgency of the spy case and reinstated background checks on all foreign visitors, but it was a move the F.B.I. had recommended 17 months earlier.
Mr. Shelby was unmoved today, saying, "The President or the Energy Secretary should put a moratorium on the exchange of people coming into our labs, and our scientists going to their labs, and perhaps giving them information."
Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, the Intelligence Committee's ranking Democrat, distanced himself today from Mr. Shelby's suggestion of a moratorium, saying, "It's not a situation where foreign visitors are the problems -- it's the employees."
The Energy Department, in a statement tonight, said rigorous screening and security measures were in place to insure that foreign visitors could not gain access to classified material.
But Mr. Kerrey expressed concern over security at the laboratories, even with the improvements Mr. Richardson has put in place, including doubling the counterintelligence budget.
"I no longer have any sense of security that we're doing the right thing," Mr. Kerrey told reporters after meeting with Mr. Tenet. "What I have right now is a considerable amount of nervousness over our counterintelligence efforts and their effectiveness."
As Senate Republicans pounced on the spy case as evidence that the Administration's policy of engaging China turned a blind eye to national security, a top Republican commentator, William Kristol, accused Congressional Republicans of hypocrisy.
"Republicans have largely supported the President and Sandy Berger on engagement and trade above all else in China," Mr. Kristol said today, referring to the President's national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger. "Ultimately, it looks like, hey, something hit the headlines and let's take advantage of it."

HEADLINE: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW JERSEY;
Bill Is Introduced To Give Tax Rebates

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
Legislation was introduced yesterday that would carry out a $1 billion property-tax rebate outlined by Gov. Christine Todd Whitman in January.
The bill, introduced by State Senator John J. Matheussen, Republican of Washington Township in Gloucester County, would reimburse families for school property taxes paid on their first $45,000 of income. 
 The program, which is expected to be signed into law by April 15, would be phased in over 5 years, resulting in a rebate check averaging $120 in its first year and $600 when complete, Mr. Matheussen said in a statement. He said the program would be paid for with increasing revenues resulting from the strong economy, and would not require an increase in the state income tax.

HEADLINE: Agency to List Pacific Salmon As Threatened

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: SEATTLE, March 15

 BODY:
Federal officials will formally declare on Tuesday that nine wild salmon species in the Pacific Northwest are threatened with extinction, the first listing under the 26-year-old Endangered Species Act that affects an entire urban region, a Government official said.
But while that announcement deals with fish, it is people -- especially the three million in the greater Seattle area -- who will have to face the consequences of halting the decline of these once mighty salmon runs. 
 They will almost surely pay more in taxes, to acquire land around waterways and to buy out floodplains so rivers can reclaim areas where the salmon once spawned. They are already being urged by their local leaders to stop using fertilizers and pesticides, voluntary efforts that may eventually become mandatory, county officials said today. They will probably face sharp new restrictions on building, especially near streams and other waterways.
And at the heart of all these measures will be these questions: Will people decide that these are all steps toward a better quality of life in a region already consumed with worry that its lavish natural splendor is under attack? Will they find, as Mayor Paul Schell of Seattle likes to put it, that "in working together to save the salmon, it may turn out that the salmon saves us"? Or will listing the salmon as threatened species, which in many ways dwarfs the impact of the 1990 listing of the northern spotted owl that set off its own environmental controversy, provoke a backlash against the Endangered Species Act?
The law allows officials more time to develop protections for species listed as "threatened" than it does for those with the even more serious classification of "endangered."
 Officials from Gov. Gary Locke on down have been formulating plans for months in anticipation of the announcement, and they will now be forthcoming.
Under the Endangered Species Act, unless steps are taken to protect the affected species, governments and even private citizens can face criminal penalties. But so far, unlike the spotted owl fight, in which many leaders in logging and timber towns bitterly opposed the listing and even mocked the owl, there has been little opposition to the proposed listing. And no one is belittling the salmon, a symbol of the region.
The salmon species, including the Puget Sound chinook, or king salmon, have been hurt in all ways by human development in recent decades, by pollution and runoff that includes sewage and chemicals from fertilizers and by construction that in many cases has simply closed off waterways. Farther inland, their runs have been significantly reduced by the huge dams that provide the region's famously cheap and abundant hydropower.
"Our goal is recovery of the salmon," said Ron Sims, the King County Executive, who oversees an area that includes the city of Seattle and who has repeatedly said that he believed residents here were willing to pay more and take other steps to protect the fish. "However, our ultimate purpose is to restore our environment so that we may provide for the coexistence of people and fish in the Pacific Northwest."
The announcement on Tuesday, by the National Marine Fisheries Service, will extend Endangered Species Act protections on wild salmon found in nearly every watershed in Washington State, as well as in parts of the Willamette Valley in Oregon. The fish include the Puget Sound chinook, the Lower Columbia River chinook, Upper Columbia spring chinook, Lake Ozette sockeye, Hood Canal summer chum, Lower Columbia chum and the mid-Columbia steelhead. Decisions were delayed for six months on four other salmon runs in California and Oregon.
Federal officials said today that they believed that salmon restoration could amount to "life by a thousand stitches instead of death by a thousand cuts." But the devil will be in the details, and some political and business leaders have said some contemplated steps were far too Draconian to pass public muster.
The state Agriculture Commissioner, Jim Jesernig, said recently that state officials were already getting "beaten up by all sides," by Indian leaders and environmental groups who believe that the most likely measures will not do enough to protect the salmon and by homebuilders and farmers, some of whom, Mr. Jesernig said, were already calling state officials "jack-booted Nazis."
For now, many local officials here said they were convinced that there was a way to help the salmon and help people at the same time, especially since many people here list "runaway growth" or "sprawl" as one of their dominant concerns. And the officials think there is a way to do it without the legal rancor that has attended species listings.
"We've looked very hard at many of those cases," Tim Ceis, director of the Endangered Species Act policy coordination office for King County, said today. "The lawyers were the ones making the money. Nobody was spending any money on the fish."
But lawsuits may be inevitable, from both sides. The state's Building Industry Association, representing developers, says the salmon issue is being used to stop growth and that the most likely proposals for building restrictions show that local regulators have "lost all common sense." With the Seattle metropolitan area projected to add as many as one million people in the next 25 years, some skeptics say the fish do not stand a chance.
Environmental groups, on the other hand, say the issue can be a winner for both sides.
"Special-interest defenders of the status quo who oppose real action to save salmon would have you believe the listings will produce a shattered economy, a Cuba-on-the-Sound," said Tim Stearns, executive director of Save our Wild Salmon, an environmental group. "That kind of thinking is laughable, and in fact, the opposite is true. If our Governor and state Legislature get serious about salmon restoration, we would see enormous gains in our quality of life and real economic benefits."
While the restrictions are likely to place new limits on fish catches in many Washington rivers, they are not likely to change the diets of Pacific Northwesterners or anyone else in the United States who fancies the taste of salmon: most salmon eaten in this country is flown in from Alaska, or raised in domestic pens here, or in Canada and South America.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

CORRECTION-DATE: March 17, 1999, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about threats to Pacific salmon misstated the planned classification of the fish. Federal officials proposed to declare that eight of nine wild salmon types in the Pacific Northwest would be listed as threatened species. Only one type, not all, would be listed as endangered. The Endangered Species Act allows officials more time to develop protections for species listed as threatened than it does for those with the more serious classification of endangered.

HEADLINE: POLL IN NEW YORK FINDS MANY THINK POLICE ARE BIASED

BYLINE: By DAN BARRY with MARJORIE CONNELLY 

 BODY:
In the aftermath of the shooting death of Amadou Diallo, fewer than a quarter of all New Yorkers believe that the police treat blacks and whites evenly, with blacks in particular viewing the police with fear and distrust, according to a New York Times poll.
Nearly 9 out of 10 black residents questioned in the survey said they thought the police often engaged in brutality against blacks, and almost two-thirds said police brutality against members of minority groups is widespread. More than two-thirds of blacks said the policies of the Giuliani administration have caused an increase in police brutality. 
 The survey suggests that police matters and race relations -- along with a growing dislike for the assertive style of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani -- have combined to give him the lowest job-approval rating of his five-year tenure, 42 percent, reflecting a sudden, precipitous drop in his popularity. Just five months ago, a New York Times/CBS News poll found 63 percent of city residents approved of Mr. Giuliani's performance.
But since then, one issue has overshadowed all others: the death of Mr. Diallo. The 22-year-old African immigrant was hit with 19 bullets during a 41-shot fusillade fired by four white police officers as he stood in the vestibule of his Bronx apartment building in early February. Mr. Diallo was unarmed and had no criminal history.
The shooting has since become the focus of a grand jury investigation, and has prompted protests and rallies that continue, organized by black leaders who charge that it reflects a persistent and dangerous distrust of minorities by white police officers. It has also led to sustained criticism of Mr. Giuliani's tough-on-crime policies and his perceived failure to establish working relationships with many of the city's elected black officials.
Mr. Giuliani, who is considering a run for the United States Senate, has countered that the city's sharp reduction in crime and its improved economy have benefited the city's black and Hispanic populations, and that his critics are engaging in race-baiting. Although he has defended the police in general, he has repeatedly expressed his regrets over Mr. Diallo's death. On Sunday, he and Police Commissioner Howard Safir attended a prayer service in Brooklyn that was held in his memory.
But the results of the latest survey suggest that the city's black and Hispanic residents do not think the Mayor has done enough to control the police or improve the city's tenuous race relations. Sixty percent said that in his public responses to the Diallo shooting, Mr. Giuliani had made matters worse. That figure includes 47 percent of white residents, 61 percent of Hispanic residents and 79 percent of black residents.
The results point to a sharp disparity between blacks and whites over how the police have affected their sense of personal safety. A third of blacks said they had been in situations where they feared a police officer, while only 11 percent of whites said they felt that way. In contrast, 62 percent of whites said they had been in situations where they felt safer in the presence of a police officer, while 57 percent of blacks said they never felt that way.
Speaking for Mr. Giuliani, his press secretary, Colleen Roche, suggested that the poll results exaggerated the reality of attitudes in the city. "The poll numbers seem to be driven by false perceptions about police brutality, due in large measure to the intense media and public scrutiny of the Amadou Diallo case," she said. "The fact remains that the New York City Police Department is among the most restrained in the nation. As times passes and perspective returns, the poll numbers will once again reflect reality."
But James Taylor, 59, a black man from Brooklyn who participated in the survey, disagreed when called after the poll was completed. The police "don't give the minority neighborhoods a chance to explain themselves," said Mr. Taylor, a food production worker. "They will stop you for no reason and ask for identification. Giuliani may not be responsible for this kind of behavior on the part of the police, but he can certainly do something about it. He could start by not always taking the side of the police."
The New York Times poll was conducted by telephone last Monday through Sunday and surveyed 915 adult residents of New York City. The margin of sampling error for all New Yorkers is plus or minus three percentage points; for white residents it is five percentage points, and for black or Hispanic residents it is six points.
The poll included some encouraging indicators for Mayor Giuliani. Half of those questioned said that life in the city has improved in the last four years, a figure that was nine points lower than five months ago, but still significantly better than the 34 percent in a March 1997 poll. Residents also overwhelmingly approve of the Mayor's handling of crime, although that support dropped 20 points in five months, from 82 percent to 62 percent.
"He cares about the welfare of the people," said Linda Glaze, 39, a white housewife from Staten Island. "He's more than a politician. He's looking out for the people in terms of the economy, jobs, education."
But when asked to cite the worst thing that Mr. Giuliani has done as Mayor, 22 percent cited his handling of the police; 15 percent of whites and 28 percent of blacks cited that issue. The only other category to receive a double-digit response, 11 percent, was Mr. Giuliani's outspoken personality; 15 percent and 10 of blacks felt that way.
Also, in the five months between the two most recent polls, the perception of Mr. Giuliani as "a tough leader" has dropped from 50 to 42 percent, while the perception that he is "too abrasive" has risen from 37 to 47 percent.
The poll also conveyed a concern among residents about the behavior of the police that is more pronounced than the reaction that followed another notorious encounter: the alleged brutalization of Abner Louima, a Haitian immigrant, by police officers in a Brooklyn station house in summer 1997.
Forty-seven percent of those surveyed last week said that the policies of the Giuliani administration had caused police brutality to increase, compared with 31 percent who answered the same question in October 1997, shortly after the Louima case became public and just before Mr. Giuliani was overwhelmingly re-elected to a second term.
In addition, 70 percent of those polled recently said the police "often engage in brutality" against blacks, compared with 53 percent who felt that way in October 1997. Two-thirds said the police also brutalize Hispanic people; a similar question was not posed in 1997.
By comparison, only 12 percent said they believed that the police brutalize whites.
Overall, more than half of those recently surveyed said they believed that the police used excessive force, rather than necessary force. But again, their attitudes seem shaped by race. A third of whites say the police use excessive force, compared with three-quarters of blacks and two-thirds of Hispanic people.
In addition, 43 percent said they thought that police brutality directed against minority residents is widespread. But only 24 percent of white residents felt that way, compared with 63 percent of black residents and 55 percent of Hispanic residents.
The poll also demonstrated thelink between the Mayor and law enforcement, a link that he has nurtured for most of his public career. While the survey reflected the public's interest in reducing crime, with 20 percent saying it should be the Mayor's top priority, 19 percent said police behavior should be his main concern instead. That represents a sharp spike from the 4 percent who answered the same way in October 1997, after the Louima case.
"I don't think the police are compassionate enough, especially toward minorities," said Robert Altym, 48, a white hardware technician from Queens. "They don't hear them when they ask them a question. I don't think the police are as familiar or comfortable with the ethnic diversity of the city as much as they should be."
He added, "I think the Mayor has to insure that the police are trained more with this in mind."
But Peter Young, a Coney Island securities salesman who would not give his race over the phone, said he sympathized with the police. "In terms of brutality, I think some of it is exaggerated," he said. "When your life is on the line, you have to be extremely cautious. I'm not condoning brutality, but in many cases the criminals are better armed than the police themselves. Sometimes being over-cautious makes you do things you don't intend to."
 
How the Survey Was Conducted
The latest New York Times Poll was based on telephone interviews conducted March 8 to 14 in all parts of New York City with 915 adults. That included 414 white, 257 black and 234 Hispanic New Yorkers. Interviews were conducted in either English or Spanish.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was selected by a computer from a complete list of city exchanges. The exchanges were chosen to insure that each area in the city was represented in proportion to its population. For each exchange, the telephone numbers were formed by random digits, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. Within each household, one adult was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent for the survey.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of telephone lines into the residence, and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to race, Hispanic origin, sex, age and education.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results based on such samples will differ by no more than three percentage points from what would have been obtained by seeking out all adult New York City residents.
For smaller subgroups the potential sampling error is larger. For example, it is plus or minus five percentage points for whites, six points for blacks, and six points for Hispanic New Yorkers.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll. Differences in the wording and order of questions, for instance, can lead to somewhat varying results.

The chart should have included a footnote stating this limitation.

HEADLINE: Business Travel;
It's no accident that many of the faces in airport departure lounges are looking younger these days.

BYLINE: By Joe Sharkey 

 BODY:
RUTH STANAT talks fast, but this probably comes naturally for someone who has visited more than 100 countries on business in the last couple of years.
"There is no time anymore!" she gasped the other day from her office in Fort Wayne, Ind. "I just jumped off the plane from Geneva, and I hit the deck running. I can't even look at the schedule. Back and forth to San Francisco for two hours! I recently had a meeting in Washington, which I had to leave in the middle of, to go to Montreal." 
 Ms. Stanat, 51, is the president and founder of SIS International Research, a business planning and market research company with offices in 18 countries. A former senior executive at Chase Manhattan Bank and the Mars Corporation, Ms. Stanat has also managed to write two books, often working on airplanes or in airports. The most recent is "Global Jumpstart: The Complete Resource for Expanding Small and Midsize Businesses," with Chris West as co-author (Perseus Books, 1999).
While never leisurely, business travel has become more frantic with the accelerating speed of globalization, Ms. Stanat says. She chuckles now to think that she was once able to "drag my kids all around the world" and even enjoy an occasional carefree weekend in London. Now, especially with cellular phones and the Internet, she says, it's always a business day somewhere.
One of the consequences of this is that business travel is increasing in both volume and pace. "With the good economy, companies want their people on the road," said Christine Levite, a vice president at American Express. American Express estimates that United States companies spent $175 billion on travel and entertainment in 1998, up from $165 billion in 1997. And it is no accident that a lot of those faces in departure lounges are looking younger these days.
"Rather than just sending someone to Paris, a company will now send someone to four or five other countries in the European Union, and possibly to Prague and Budapest, too," Ms. Stanat said. "After about 10 days of this, most people are totally burned out. Companies are throwing so many young people out on the road because kids are resilient. They're usually not strapped down with families, and, hey, maybe it's their first time in Paris. They're willing to fly coach."
But there are limits even to youthful patience on the road.
The scene: Newark International Airport, AMR's American Airlines, Gate 30, last Thursday night. Flight 1535 to Miami has already been rescheduled five times from its original 6:20 P.M. departure time. There being few social lubricants as effective as adversity in the face of a common enemy, strangers have begun gathering in knots, muttering darkly to one another about what they say is a lack of reliable information about their flight, which American agents maintain has been delayed by that hardiest of excuses, "bad weather in Dallas."
At 9 P.M., after still another delay, Robert Rossi, a burly 28-year-old real estate salesman from Summit, N.J. who says that he travels 40 to 50 times a year on business, decides that he isn't going to take it anymore, not silently at least.
"Why do they keep lying to me?" he bellows, raising both arms and addressing the crowd. "They threatened to call the police because I'm complaining!"
Once, fellow travelers would have kept their eyes downcast at such a scene, like subway riders avoiding a panhandler. But Mr. Rossi's outburst actually elicits general approval from the crowd. One frustrated passenger puts in: "I'd call this a fly-by-night operation, but they aren't even doing that." Says another: "I just came in from in Dallas. The weather is fine in Dallas, just a little overcast."
Around 9:30, a group of Port Authority police officers, alerted to potential rebellion, is summoned to the departure gate. "There must be 15 police officers with clubs," marvels Joe Abelleira, a marketing executive with the Cordis Corporation.
Calm restored, the plane finally arrives for a 10:58 departure that will put passengers into Miami around 2 A.M. Oddly, the official reason for the late flight has now changed, at least on the American Airlines automated telephone flight-information system, which insists that "air-traffic control delays" were responsible for the problem with Flight 1535.
