HEADLINE: About New York;
For Students, The Work Is in Albany

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ 

 BODY:
THE mushy mounds of slush and snow outside Hunter College on Monday morning were enough to prompt any self-respecting student to look forward to the rituals of spring break. Enticingly, a chartered bus awaited them on Lexington Avenue. A few students groggily went on board and settled into the seats in anticipation of their trip.
Of course, like many students enrolled in the City University of New York, they were too busy juggling work, school and sometimes family chores to have the time or money for a Florida respite. They were trekking north, to Albany. This might strike CUNY's critics as another example of the system's failings: Don't these students know enough geography to go south for a break? 
 They, along with several professors and administrators, were traveling north because they have tired of seeing their school's reputation heading south in the debate over the City University's problems. They were appealing to state legislators to block proposed cuts in the state's Tuition Assistance Program and to add $87 million to CUNY's budget, financing that they said was needed to hire more teachers, improve overburdened facilities and keep up with inflation.
The towers of the state's legislative complex appeared coldly intimidating, which only spurred some students to go on the lobbying trip. They wanted to put a human face on the numbers that get tossed about in the budget process, as well as show that they were not apathetic.
"We can't afford to give in by not pressuring our representatives to represent CUNY," said Julio Arroyo, a senior majoring in political science and language arts. "We're realistic. Sometimes you don't get what you want. That's part of the process. But we shouldn't lose the desire to try. That's an important message itself. We understand that young people, students, feel disenfranchised when they look at what they have to come up against. That should not be an excuse."
There is a ritual element to this, especially in this season, when various interest groups play tag-team lobbying with legislators. The Hunter College delegation departed from its routine of just sending students and faculty to meet with lawmakers. The delegation also kept a constant presence in a corner of the Legislative Office Building's indoor terrace with an exhibit of various programs and piles of fliers that showed how the school's graduates were being accepted into medical school and graduate programs, as well as faculty lectures on how its research helps the city in health and law enforcement.
The visits with lawmakers were brief and polite. Some listened intently and asked a few questions, while others could not wait to launch into discussions about all they were doing to help CUNY. The students themselves were eager to tell how previous cutbacks have resulted in too many students crammed into classes and not enough new books in the college library. Heather Perkins, a senior, explained how the increasing use of low-paid, part-time adjunct professors affected her studies.
"For once in my college career I would like to get a paper back with more comprehensive comments than 'Interesting, please expand,' " she said. "You have 35 students in a class, each writing 10-page papers, and the professors are adjuncts who don't have office hours and don't have the time to sit down and say more to you."
MANY of the students said the frequent calls to get more of them to graduate in four years failed to acknowledge how cutbacks have led to fewer offerings of required classes and how their job schedules prevented them from being able to attend the few that are offered. Catherine Reyes, a junior who transferred to Hunter from a private college in Virginia, told legislator after legislator that she has yet to be able to check a single book out of the library. Many of the books, she said, were either unavailable or being repaired.
Ms. Reyes was also concerned about repairing another kind of damage: that of the image of Republicans like herself. She had heard the Mayor and the Governor attack CUNY, so she was initially skeptical when she transferred to Hunter to save her parents the expense of private college tuition.
"People are ruining our reputation," she said. "I am impatient with Republicans who have given people such terrible ideas about CUNY. My experience has been great. I've learned more in two semesters at Hunter than before in a private college."

HEADLINE: How Jews Turn Houses Into Homes on West Bank

BYLINE: By DEBORAH SONTAG 

DATELINE: ELI, West Bank, March 16

 BODY:
From this entrenched Jewish settlement on a bluff above the Palestinian territories, the vista is dotted for miles around with what the Israelis call "facts on the ground."
Almost every hilltop bears a scattering of mobile homes, evidence of the continuing and willful expansion of the Jewish presence in the West Bank. 
 The hills are truly alive with the sound of hammers, buzz saws and bulldozers as Israelis -- with the help of Palestinian laborers -- dig into the land. They aim to sink their roots as deeply as possible in the hope that the acres they occupy now will never be turned over to the Palestinian Authority.
"When they built the hill, we climbed on up," said Oria Levinstein, 17, whose family moved from Eli, which is almost suburban, into a tin shack on a barren hillside nearby. "We felt like pioneers. At first it was horrible -- no water, no electricity. But now we have our trailers, and it's gorgeous. Look at this view! At night you see all the land of Israel. What, we should let the Arabs have it?"
For months Palestinian leaders have criticized the growth of Jewish settlements in the West Bank, particularly in the rocky hills between the Palestinian cities of Ramallah and Nablus.
And in the last few days, American diplomats have turned up the pressure on Israel to contain the expansion, butting heads with the Israelis in a war of words played out through the media.
Last weekend Dennis Ross, the American envoy to the Middle East peace talks, in an unusual public rebuke, called increased settlement activity "very destructive to the pursuit of peace."
On Monday Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, defying the American criticism, visited a West Bank settlement and vowed, "We want it to be bigger."
Today the American Embassy in Tel Aviv issued a pointed statement in response. "We have been troubled by Israel's expansion of existing settlements well beyond their periphery," said Larry Schwartz, the embassy spokesman. "These activities prejudge and predetermine issues that were to be reserved for permanent-status negotiations by changing realities on the ground."
The embassy statement was issued as Mr. Ross was flying to Madrid to see the Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat, in a meeting scheduled at the last minute. Mr. Ross was expected to press Mr. Arafat to delay a declaration of statehood beyond May 4, when the original Israeli-Palestinian peace accord expires.
Some Palestinian officials said they believed that the American criticism of Israel was timed to make Mr. Arafat more receptive.
The most recent Israeli-Palestinian peace memorandum, negotiated at the Wye Plantation in Maryland last fall, prohibits both sides from taking unilateral actions to jeopardize their understanding. The Americans, who brokered the agreement, see both a May 4 statehood declaration by Mr. Arafat and continued settlement expansion by Israel as unilateral acts that would violate the Wye accord.
The Israelis contend that they are expanding settlements based on the natural growth of the 140 communities; they say the settlements are theirs to expand until the future is decided in the final-status negotiations, which have not yet begun. Indeed, Foreign Minister Ariel Sharon counseled the settlers last fall to make haste by "grabbing hilltops" before land was turned over to the Palestinians.
But the Americans and the Palestinians contend that the expansion is carving out new Jewish communities, either by occupying new land or by turning makeshift communities into more established settlements by replacing trailers with houses.
"If we close our eyes to these facts on the ground, they will become a reality we cannot negotiate away," Ahmed Qurei, the speaker of the Palestinian Legislative Council, said at a recent meeting. "We cannot sit in our houses and watch the bulldozers."
In fact, though, Palestinian protests have been restrained. When one Palestinian legislator suggested forbidding Palestinian laborers to work on the settlement projects, another scoffed, saying, "Not until they have an economic alternative, like our own construction projects."
The American Embassy closely monitors settlement activity, but does not release any data.
But Israeli and American peace groups say 16 new settlements have risen in the five months since the Wye accord was signed at the White House. The trailer communities, blocks of white rectangles atop the highest hills, are as conspicuous as the banks of new house frames that stand beside the established communities.
"The system is very simple," said Mossi Raz, the general director of Peace Now in Israel. "The settlers go to a hill, most of the time next to the settlement where they live and in some cases outside the boundaries. They put up some trailers. They build a road to the place. And nobody does anything about it, not the police, not the army."
For the last five years, the settler population has grown by about 9 percent a year, to 170,000 Jews living amid Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza. Peace Now says the vacancy rate in the established settlements hovers around 8 or 9 percent, negating the argument that there is need to expand.
But Pinchas Wallerstein, the chairman of the Yesha Council, the umbrella settlers' group, said the empty residences represent natural turnover. He also said he hoped to see faster growth after the end of this school year.
"I hope it will increase by 11 or 12 percent this year," he said. "But I don't know that there are a lot of people who will be willing to pay $100,000 for a house in the middle of an area where the political situation is unstable. I can give them a narrow caravan, but if they want to live in a permanent house, they have to pay for it."
Mr. Wallerstein discounted most of the new hilltop communities. "They are not expansion," he said. "They are very young fellows or families who stay there to make a point, but the living conditions are too difficult. There is growth in the settlements, but it is not in the hills. What is important to us is to grow in a way that connects areas of Jewish sovereignty."
He cited as an example a six-month-old outpost of four families between Eli and Shilo, called Givat Harel, in an area at the center of the West Bank that is experiencing the greatest growth.
Eli is 14 years old and home to 400 families, both religious and secular, about 20 percent of whom are new immigrants. A sign at the foot of the hill promises houses "With Cable!" whose prices start at $49,000. The town director, Lior Shtul, boasts of the short commute to Jerusalem and Tel Aviv.
"There are those who come here for quality of life, and those who come for that plus ideology," he said. "Both ways, we grow. We continue to build. This government comes and this government goes, and nothing changes but what sits on the ground."

HEADLINE: Irish Leader Who Grew Into Eloquence

BYLINE: By JAMES F. CLARITY 

DATELINE: DUBLIN, March 16

 BODY:
When he was campaigning for election as Prime Minister in 1997, Bertie Ahern was disdained by many voters and politicians as a lightweight who had risen from the working class of Dublin and still spoke with a distinct North Side accent, which turned "th" sounds into D's.
He lacked gravitas, his detractors said, and would be something of an embarrassment representing Ireland among better-spoken Presidents and Prime Ministers. 
 Mr. Ahern acknowledged with some humor that he had trouble pronouncing words like "growth" and brushed up his diction. He won the election, narrowly, and when he meets President Clinton at the White House on St. Patrick's Day, accompanied by Celia Larkin, his partner of 10 years, his better-spoken opponents will be back here, restless and relatively powerless in the Parliamentary minority.
Mr. Ahern, whose tongue rarely fails him now, ignores what his supporters call "the chattering classes" of Dublin 4, an affluent and well-educated section on the South Side.
When he returns home next week, Mr. Ahern, 47, may be on the verge of making Irish history as the Prime Minister to preside at the completion of the Northern Ireland peace agreement and the official end to 30 years of sectarian violence in the predominantly Protestant British province.
But he may also be forced out of office and into an early election by a growing corruption scandal involving some of his allies in the Fianna Fail (Warriors of Destiny) Party.
Before he left Dublin last week, he sounded distinctly statesmanlike on the peace effort, saying:
"If the new agreement succeeds, it will see the two traditions working together both in Northern Ireland and on the island for the first time in 200 years. Every right-thinking person wants to see the back of conflict for good and to create a new and happier future for all."
Back home nobody is worrying about his accent or about the fact that he is not married to his partner, Ms. Larkin. His 10-year relationship with Ms. Larkin, a former Fianna Fail worker, has never become a serious political issue here. But his other political problems are real.
To form a coalition Government in 1997, he needed the support of the smaller Progressive Democrats Party. The prospects for a full five-year term were good. The economy was booming, and in a month Mr. Ahern had helped broker a cease-fire by the Irish Republican Army.
That paved the way for the accord in April to give minority Roman Catholics in Northern Ireland added power and to give overwhelmingly Catholic Ireland added influence in the affairs of Northern Ireland.
Then late last year, Mr. Ahern was suddenly reminded that political trouble was as easy to find as the rain. Some of his party's most prominent elected officials were accused of having taken huge bribes from executives.
One businessman, former Prime Minister Charles J. Haughey, who had fostered Mr. Ahern's career and once called him "the most devious and cunning of them all," was shown to have amassed wealth, impossible on an elected official's salary, including horses, a yacht, a farm and his own island off the coast.
Mr. Haughey, according to testimony, had received nearly $3 million from Dunnes, the largest chain of department stores in the country.
His coalition partner, Mary Harney, leader of the Progressive Democrats, which split from Fianna Fail 14 years ago over corruption, said she might quit the Government. That would lead to an election well before the constitutional deadline of mid-2002.
A majority of Irish people appear to believe that although Mr. Ahern is personally honest and lives modestly, he must answer for the past corruption of his party. Many people apparently feel that as a high party official, and a professional accountant, he had to have had some knowledge of what Mr. Haughey and other colleagues were up to.
A political consultant and a former ranking Foreign Ministry official, Fergus Finlay, said that to survive Mr. Ahern might have to find another coalition partner in the next election.
"Bertie Ahern," Mr. Finlay said in an interview, "has made a genuine effort to clear up his party's act and turn Fianna Fail into an organization other parties can do business with. But he's trying to do all that without confronting the ghosts of his party's past. And that's a recipe for failure."
Mr. Ahern would, of course, disagree. In the midst of the disclosures about some of his former allies, he said: "I am a credible person. I am an honest person."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES;
Gold Plunges After Clinton Suggests Sales by the I.M.F.

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
The price of gold plunged yesterday after President Clinton suggested that the International Monetary Fund should sell some of its gold reserves to help reduce the debt burdens on the world's poorest nations.
The proposal is not new, but had been set aside several years ago, in part because of the opposition of Germany. But after the election of the new Chancellor, Gerhard Schroder, the sentiment changed, opening the way to put the plan back on the table. 
 Then President Jacques Chirac of France suggested Monday that France could support I.M.F. gold sales for the same cause, aligning another major player -- and one-time opponent -- behind the sales.
Still, the sharp drop in gold's price yesterday and Monday seemed to indicate that a lot of investors had forgotten that selling I.M.F gold was a possibility, although the United States has supported sales for some time and other countries had brought up the subject again recently.
"The strange thing is that the I.M.F. story wasn't fully in the price," said Philip Klapwijk, a managing director of Gold Fields Mineral Services Ltd. of London, which produces some of the most closely watched research on gold.
"Sales are quite probable, but in the future," he said. "There is a lot of preparation that would be required."
The price of gold for April delivery on the New York Mercantile Exchange fell $3.70 an ounce, or 1.3 percent, to $283.90. On Monday it dropped $5.80 an ounce. From its recent high of $295.50 an ounce Thursday, the price of gold is off 3.9 percent and not that far from the 19-year low it hit in August.
What this proposal will do for the longer-term price of gold is uncertain, but it does not look positive.
I.M.F. gold sales would require approval of Congress and of other nations in the I.M.F. In addition, the I.M.F. would be expected to sell the gold in the most orderly fashion possible, if the plan was approved, to limit its impact. And it would be some time -- maybe a year -- before gold sales could occur.
However, the threat of the sale would hang over the market, making it harder for good news to lift the price. The threat of gold sales by the world's central banks has had a negative impact on the price of gold over the last several years.
"I was surprised the amount of impact merely the speculation had" on the price of gold, said George Milling-Stanley, manager of gold market analysis at the World Gold Council.
The I.M.F has about 103 million ounces of gold and under the Clinton Administration proposal about 5 percent, or 5.2 million ounces, would be sold. That is equal to about 6 percent of total mine production.
Mr. Clinton and Mr. Chirac said the money from gold sales should be used to expand a program of debt relief for a group of 41 of the world's poorest countries, known as Highly Indebted Poor Countries, or H.I.P.C. With the additional money from gold sales, the countries in that group could be expended to 50.
Mr. Clinton, who made his proposal before a group of African government officials, including representatives of highly indebted countries, said he wanted "extraordinary relief for countries making extraordinary efforts to build working economies."
Traders said that some other downward pressure on gold came from the fact that big speculators who had been betting that the price of gold would fall had just recently backed off those positions. That buying back of gold is what helped push the price up about $8, to $295. With this negative news, there was an opening for them to sell again.

HEADLINE: Fewer Fall Behind on Mortgage Payments

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 16

 BODY:
The number of American borrowers who fell behind on their mortgage payments declined in the fourth quarter, according to a survey by the Mortgage Bankers Association of America.
The delinquency rate fell to 4.24 percent in the October-December period, the association said. That is down from the rate of 4.37 percent in the third quarter and from 4.36 percent in the fourth quarter of 1997. 
 "A robust economy, booming stock market and the lowest mortgage interest rates in 30 years have been principal factors behind the improvement in the delinquency situation," said Paul Reid, the executive vice president of the Mortgage Bankers Association.
The findings mean that payments on 4.24 percent of the 23 million loans in the association's survey were overdue by at least 30 days in the fourth quarter. The delinquency survey, which tracks homes that have one to four units, covers about one-half of all residential mortgages.
The biggest regional drop in delinquencies occurred in the South, where the rate dropped to 5.11 percent from 5.29 percent.
Rates in the Northeast and North Central states dropped to 4.02 percent and 3.62 percent, respectively, from 4.18 percent and 3.78 percent, in the fourth quarter.

HEADLINE: Commercial Real Estate;
Purchase of One New York Plaza Reflects Toronto Company's Role

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER 

 BODY:
The decade of the 1980's looms in the history of Manhattan real estate as the era of the Japanese. Their money poured in through acquisitions of such trophy office properties as Rockefeller Center, the Exxon Building at 50th Street and the Avenue of the Americas, and Tower 49, at 12 East 49th Street.
Conceivably, the current period will look to future observers like the era of the public real estate company, as opposed to the family-owned development companies that historically were the principal owner-operators of Manhattan commercial property. Usually organized as real estate investment trusts, these regionally or nationally oriented companies have arrived with two feet in the Manhattan market, particularly since 1995. Investment partnerships backed by Wall Street opportunity funds have also been major buyers. 
 The latest sale to a public company with a national focus involves the TrizecHahn Corporation, a company based in Toronto with ownership interests in 65 million square feet of space in 119 properties in the United States, Canada and Europe, including 9 in New York City. TrizecHahn went into contract late last month to buy the fully leased 2.4-million-square-foot office building known as One New York Plaza, a 50-story tower completed in 1961 at the lower tip of Manhattan.
The seller was Chase Manhattan Bank, the initial major tenant and later the owner, and the price was $390 million, among the largest amounts paid for a Manhattan building in the last two years. That represents a price of $162 a square foot, roughly half the cost of replacing such a building. Chase undertook a major modernization program after signing Prudential Securities in 1992 to the space that the bank vacated in a move to Metrotech in Brooklyn.
TrizecHahn is not alone among the big publicly owned buyers of major Manhattan buildings since 1995, a year that marked the end of both the real estate recession and New York State's 10 percent tax on capital gains realized when investment property sells for more than $1 million. The tax was enacted in 1983 under Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and raised millions for the state initially. But ultimately, it worked mainly to inhibit sales.
Among the big publicly owned buyers in the last two years have been Vornado Realty Trust of Saddle Brook, N.J., which bought One Penn Plaza, off 34th Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, for $410 million last year; Boston Properties, the buyer of 280 Park Avenue, at 48th Street, the Bankers Trust Building, for $321 million in 1997, and Equity Office Properties Trust, based in Chicago, which acquired the Worldwide Plaza office building at Eighth Avenue and 50th Street for $578 million last October.
TrizecHahn was formed as the Trizec Corporation 35 years ago to develop Place Ville-Marie, the Montreal version of Rockefeller Center. Trizec evolved into a major United States and Canadian real estate owner-operator, encountered financial troubles in the early 1990's, went through a bankruptcy restructuring and emerged from it in 1994. Two years later, when its principal investor, the Canadian entrepreneur Peter Munk, merged it with his holding company, the Horsham Corporation, it changed its name to TrizecHahn, reflecting its holdings of regional West Coast malls developed by Ernest Hahn. The malls were sold last year for $2.5 billion.
The sale proceeds fueled TrizecHahn's office acquisition program. In New York City, its purchases have included 110 William Street, the 850,000-square-foot building at John Street downtown, a deal that closed in December, and a 50 percent interest in three major properties developed by the now-dissolved Swig Weiler & Arnow partnership: 1114 Avenue of the Americas (the W.R. Grace Building, at 42d Street), 1411 Broadway (the World Apparel Center, at 40th Street), and 1460 Broadway, at 41st Street. The Swig family remains its partner in the latter three.
At 1460 Broadway, occupied mainly by small textile tenants, the law firm of Skadden Arps Slate Meagher & Flom signed a lease last fall for 190,000 square feet, with 100,000 square feet to be ready this year and the rest over seven years as leases expire. The space will be used for back-office operations supporting the firm's main operation in the 4 Times Square building, now under construction at Broadway and 42d Street.
At One New York Plaza, where the major tenants besides Prudential Securities are Goldman Sachs & Company, the investment firm, and the law firm of Fried Frank Harris Shriver & Jacobson, no major leases come due until 2004. "We're making a long-term investment in a trophy property with first-rate tenants in downtown Manhattan," said Douglas Winshall, senior vice president of TrizecHahn in charge of its Northeastern properties.
The largest re-tenanting effort that TrizecHahn has taken on in Manhattan has been at 110 Williams Street, which had 200,000 square feet vacant when the sale closed last December. The building was part of a national portfolio of 10 properties that TrizecHahn bought from Equitable Life last year for $570 million. A lease for 50,000 square feet with an unidentified New York City agency is pending, Mr. Winshall said.
The World Apparel Center, at 1411 Broadway, is known as the premier showroom building for women's sportswear and bathing suits. Its largest tenant, the Jones Apparel Group, expanded in the building to 180,000 square feet last year from about 120,000 square feet, Mr. Winshall said.
Another TrizecHahn property is 1065 Avenue of the Americas, a 625,000-square-foot building at 40th Street. It was bought in late 1997 from Swig Weiler & Arnow for $59 million and was 90 percent occupied then. With the building fully leased now, its new arrivals include GeoCities, an Internet company; the inspector general's office of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, and the Rodgers & Hammerstein Organization.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Inflation Optimism Helps to Push 30-Year Treasuries' Yield Lower

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Bond yields dropped to their lowest point in three weeks yesterday, aided by optimism that inflation will not accelerate and, to a lesser extent, by comments by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, suggesting that the central bank will not raise short-term interest rates.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 2 2/32 , to 96 23/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction of the price, fell to 5.47 percent, from 5.52 percent on Monday. 
 Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, expects that Fed policy makers will not change interest rates when they meet March 30. "The economy's impressive strength will prevent the Fed from easing," he said, "while the auspicious inflation environment and global financial fragility argue strongly against any policy tightening."
Mr. Fine also believes that bond yields will hover around 5.5 percent for a while as fears of a Fed tightening dissipate.
Several reports yesterday pointed to solid economic advances. Housing starts declined just six-tenths of 1 percent in February, to an annual rate of roughly 1.8 million units, after setting a 12-year high in January. The levels of both housing starts and building permits in the first quarter are on track to significantly exceed those of the fourth quarter, Mr. Fine noted. A tapering of house construction is invariably a prelude to a slowdown in economic activity, so the robust performance of starts and building permits suggested continued momentum in the months ahead.
Industrial production rose two-tenths of 1 percent last month and manufacturing output also rose two-tenths of 1 percent -- its fifth consecutive monthly advance, and now up 2.4 percent year over year.
Mr. Greenspan spoke to the Independent Bankers Association of America meeting in San Francisco, where his remarks seemed to focus more on downside risks, providing only a marginal lift to the market.
Stocks also bolstered bonds as the Dow Jones industrial average surpassed 10,000 points for the first time in intraday trading; it closed lower, though, at 9,930.47. Traders speculated that some investors switched their allocations from stocks to bonds.
Gains could be limited in the days ahead, though, as several corporate debt issues are expected to be priced. Fannie Mae, among other borrowers, plans to sell as much as $13 billion of debt, and the AT&T Corporation expects to sell $5 billion to $6 billion in bonds.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
For Mexico, An Economy With Gusto

BYLINE: By JULIA PRESTON 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, March 16

 BODY:
The menu was eggs with hot chili sauce, and the mood had a certain zing as well. Top executives from foreign companies had breakfast today with President Ernesto Zedillo and told him that they planned to spend $10 billion this year on factories and other projects in Mexico, matching last year's direct foreign investment despite continuing uncertainties about Latin America.
A chipper speech by Mr. Zedillo and the satisfied applause of his audience showed how far Mexico had come in its efforts to separate itself in international investors' minds from other, more troubled Latin countries since economic crisis shook much of the region last year. 
 Foreigners' preference for Mexico has been felt in the stock and currency markets as well as in longer-term investments. Recently, the demand for pesos from investors has lifted Mexico's currency to levels not seen since before the global economy began to waver last year.
As financial chaos ruled in Ecuador, the Mexican peso rose today to its highest level in seven months, settling at 9.665 to the dollar. The stock market here also continued to climb, with the benchmark index rising 120.49 points, or 2.53 percent, to 4,890.39. The index has gained 48 percent since Brazil's currency, the real, suffered a steep devaluation in January, setting off a new round of worries about Latin American markets.
Mexico has attracted investors' attention because of the combination of disciplined fiscal policies enforced by Mr. Zedillo, a Yale-trained economist, and close ties to the thriving United States economy, which absorbed more than four-fifths of Mexico's exports last year.
"Mexico is a clear safe haven" for stock market investors, said Michael Gavin, director of Latin American research at Warburg Dillon Read. "Most investors know that Mexico is no longer an oil-based economy. It is clearly an economy linked to the United States," he said.
Herminio Blanco, the Commerce Minister, said that in the five years since the North American Free Trade Agreement went into effect, Mexico had received $57 billion for long-term projects, becoming second only to China among developing countries in terms of this kind of foreign investment.
Bernd Leissner, president of Volkswagen de Mexico, said the company planned to increase production this year by 55 percent compared with 1997 levels and to raise exports by 80 percent. The Volkswagen A.G. unit has invested $1 billion in its plants in the state of Puebla to build the new Beetle.
Mr. Leissner said that the North American trade pact and a similar one that Mexico is negotiating with Europe have made auto exports much easier, allowing Volkswagen's Mexican operation to "join the major leagues of our industry worldwide."
In 1998, when oil prices plummeted and world markets wobbled, Mr. Zedillo made three pre-emptive budget cuts to keep the deficit at a maximum of 1.25 percent, as he had promised. In Brazil, the Latin American country with which Mexico is most frequently compared, President Fernando Henrique Cardoso has battled a fractious Congress and moved more slowly on fiscal reform.
Mr. Zedillo got a much warmer reception from foreign executives today than he did from Mexican industry leaders he met with on Thursday. Mexican businesses remain hampered by a lack of credit and are wrestling with declining export sales because of the peso's strength.
In an unscheduled proposal, which put Mr. Zedillo uncomfortably on the spot, Eugenio Clariond Reyes Retana, president of the Mexican Businessmen's Council, urged him to convert to a dollar-based economy.
Mr. Zedillo, though, made it clear that he had no plans to abandon his policy of a virtually free-floating peso.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
The Dow Briefly Breaks 10,000 Before Retreating

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
The Dow Jones industrial average continued flirting with the 10,000-point mark yesterday, and even crossed it for a short time. But it reversed its early climb and ended the session lower.
Broader market averages were mixed. 
 The Dow, made up of 30 of the best-known names in corporate America, poked through 10,000 at 9:50 A.M., soon after trading began on the New York Stock Exchange, and rose as high as 10,001.78.
But the index pulled back and closed at 9,930.47, down 28.30 points, or nearly three-tenths of 1 percent, on the day.
While 10,000 is an eye-popping number, analysts noted that in percentage terms the rise from 9,000 was less significant than any of the other 1,000-point gains the average has recorded during its long bull run, which began in 1982.
"While people are transfixed with the prospect of all those zeros, what is most impressive is not the level itself but the length of this bull market," said Christine A. Callies, chief investment strategist at Credit Suisse First Boston.
The rise in the Dow, she said, "represents a complete shift from inflation-hedge assets like houses and gold mines to assets that thrive only when inflation is under control and Government fiscal policy is being reined in."
"Once those goals have been achieved," she added, "the equity gains tend to be smaller."
Indeed, market technicians and portfolio strategists have been concerned for some time that the rise in the Dow and other market gauges has been led by a relative handful of stocks. That narrowness, they contend, is a warning sign for the future.
"The lack of breadth in the market worries me to death," said Henry Herrmann, chief investment officer at Waddell & Reed, an investment firm in Overland Park, Kan., which manages more than $27 billion. "The market's internal technical factors just don't look good."
Yesterday's action fed this sort of concern. On both the New York Stock Exchange and the Nasdaq market, declining issues outnumbered those that advanced.
For the most part, stock traders tended to ignore a good day in the bond market as interest rates fell.
Well-known technology shares did better for a second consecutive session. But bank stocks, which rallied on Monday, fell back yesterday.
Trading volume on the Big Board was relatively modest, just shy of 752 million shares. On the Nasdaq market, 977.2 million shares changed hands.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, which set a closing high on Monday, slipped 0.90 point, to 1,306.36. The Nasdaq, which has risen more than 11 percent this year, gained 7.83 points, to 2,439.27.
But the Russell 2000 index of smaller-company shares, a laggard for nearly a year, fell 1.67 points, or four-tenths of a percent, to 399.17. The American Stock Exchange composite index fell 4.60 points, to 716.31.
"We are fully invested in small and mid-cap stocks and are beating ourselves in the head every day," Mr. Herrmann said.
Two financial stocks, those of American Express and J. P. Morgan, were the biggest drags on the Dow. American Express, which has been among the market's best performers so far this year, fell 2 3/16 a share, to 123 9/16 . Morgan dropped 1 3/8, to 124.
Merck & Company, the drug giant, was the best-performing Dow stock; the company's shares rose 1 5/8, to 85 7/8, after the company received Government approval for expanded use of an anti-cholesterol drug.
Among big technology stocks, Intel gained 2 1/2 a share, to 120 3/8. A report released late Monday showed that semiconductor sales rose 1.2 percent in January, to $11.1 billion, compared with $10.97 billion in the month a year earlier as rising demand in Europe and much of Asia offset lower sales in North and South America. Microsoft rose 3 3/16 , to 169 1/16 . And Cisco Systems gained 1, to 106.
Flashnet Communications, an Internet service provider, more than doubled in its first day of trading, closing at 43 5/8, after coming to market priced at 17.
With the exception of Hewlett-Packard and I.B.M., technology stocks are absent from the Dow. But some market strategists said that recent weakness in technology issues boded well for stocks.
"Technology stock prices peaked on Feb. 1," said Thomas M. Galvin, chief investment strategist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. "But even though technology has been in the penalty box, the market has been able to hit new highs. Bond yields are stabilizing because of no apparent signs of inflation, and now earnings are beginning a cyclical recovery. The bull market is back in business."
Mr. Galvin, clearly optimistic about the market's prospects, projects the Dow will not flirt with the 10,000 level for long. By the end of the year, he expects the average to be at 11,000.

HEADLINE: Letting Little Go to Waste;
An Enterprise Evolves From the Byproducts of Industry

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
Over a decade ago, Michael R. Daley was touring a plant that burned old tires for energy when he learned that it paid haulers to cart away gypsum, one of its byproducts. Mr. Daley was astounded: Gypsum, he knew, is used in plaster, toothpaste, paints, even molds for false teeth. So Mr. Daley set up shop near the plant to collect and resell the gypsum.
Since then, his company, Triad Energy Resources Inc., has grown into a successful small enterprise, all by setting up next to corporations and finding uses for their wastes. Triad makes soil additives from the C & H Sugar Company's sugar-filtration byproducts in Crockett, Calif. It turns leftover skins and seeds from Australian wineries and fruit processors into fertilizer and compost. And it is now contracting with fish processors in Oregon to turn their detritus into fertilizer and fish food. 
 "If companies were smart, they'd all locate near sources of waste," Mr. Daley said.
Corporate America is, in fact, catching on. More and more companies are buying their neighbors' wastes or selling their own. And a growing number of economic development agencies and private developers are building "eco-industrial parks" -- eco-parks for short -- for this purpose.
Some are doing it to attract jobs, others to reduce trash flows, still others simply to make money. But all are working on the principle that one company's waste can be its neighbor's raw material. And they are taking advantage of the fact that many wastes that cannot be recycled back to their original uses can still be profitably used as materials for other products.
"A park that makes environmental and economic sense is an idea whose time has come," said Dustin Bielagus, a developer who is building an eco-park in Londonderry, N.H.
Eco-parks are rising in Mississippi and Mexico. They are on the drawing boards in Puerto Rico and Mesa del Sol, N.M. The Dow Chemical Company is building one near its plants in eastern Germany.
In California, local officials plan an eco-park in Oakland, while the Cabazon Band of Mission Indians is looking for companies to set up at its trash-to-energy plant near Palm Springs to extract materials from the trash before it is burned.
While the environmental movement spawned the idea of such industrial symbiosis, it is no longer the primary force. "People realize that where materials are thrown out, there is money to be made," said Kevin Taylor, coordinator of the California Materials Exchange Program, a state group that brought Triad and C & H together.
There is money to be saved as well, added Reid Lifset, who edits the Journal of Industrial Ecology. "Companies are always looking for cheaper ways to procure raw materials," he said, "and the more they hear about eco-industrial parks, the more light bulbs go off."
The idea of selling and buying wastes is not new, of course. The Environmental Protection Agency lists about 40 government-subsidized waste exchanges. But now more entrepreneurs are becoming involved, charging companies for listing available wastes or waste-product needs.
"Valuable waste materials should not be consigned to subsidized exchanges whose funding can get cut," said William Sloan, who just started Millennium Exchange Ltd., a for-profit, Web-based waste exchange.
Even the terminology reflects the private-sector thrust, said Julie Rhodes, executive director of the Reuse Development Organization, a clearinghouse for information about re-using materials.
"People call them materials exchanges now, not waste exchanges," she said. "The whole idea is to think of waste as having value."
Still, most existing exchanges ignore location when they match waste sources with users. Factor in the cost of shipping waste, and the economics of selling it becomes shaky. But put companies next to one another, and the economics works.
"It's a lot cheaper to transport used lumber from next door than it is to truck wood down from a forest," said Ann Schneider, director of recycling programs at the University of California at Santa Cruz.
That is the type of argument that the Energy Answers Corporation, a resource recovery specialist in Albany, is using to woo companies to set up near the trash-to-energy plant it wants to install in Rio Pedras, near San Juan, P.R. Patrick F. Mahoney, president of Energy Answers, said he was close to persuading a paper company to reopen an abandoned plant on the site because it could recycle waste paper coming in and use cheap energy from the trash being burned. He said he was also talking to steel and concrete companies about using scrap steel from the trash and the fly ash that is left after combustion.
"We can put the companies close enough to get the materials by conveyor belt," Mr. Mahoney said.
Despite the proselytizing, eco-parks are not an easy sell. When a company is picking a site, a chance to lower disposal or materials costs pales next to considerations like availability of workers, taxes and nearness to customers. The sheer logistics of figuring out the proper mix can be daunting.
"We thought we could handpick a perfect assortment of businesses that would move right in, but it just doesn't work that way," said Michael Krause, executive director of the Green Institute, a nonprofit developer that just abandoned the idea of using guaranteed waste exchange as a draw for an industrial center it is building in Minneapolis.
And even if the companies come, who is to guarantee that none will move or change their products or go belly up?
"The minute one company changes its processes, the whole industrial ecosystem gets screwed up," said Stuart L. Hart, a professor of strategic management at the University of North Carolina's Kenan-Flagler Business School.
Not even environmentalists are unequivocal in their support. Nancy B. Hirshberg, director of natural resources at Stonyfield Farm Inc., fought to make waste exchange a requirement of the park that Mr. Bielagus is building next to Stonyfield's yogurt plant in Londonderry. But she is having second thoughts.
"Creating a market for wastes could create a disincentive to eliminate them," Ms. Hirshberg said.
Indeed, Mr. Bielagus acknowledges that his ideal tenant would generate no waste. And Ned Hall, an executive vice president of AES Enterprise, a company that operates power plants and will anchor the park, says the park's green premise has not stopped local residents from yelling, "Not in my back yard."
All told, the numerous ifs and buts have created a Catch 22: developers do not want to invest millions in setting up an eco-park until they have successful models to follow, yet such models will not dot the landscape until a few more pioneers take the plunge.
"It won't be a major trend until people see more good examples," said Nabil Nasr, director of the National Center for Remanufacturing and Resource Recovery at the Rochester Institute of Technology.
An example of sorts does exist in Kalundborg, Denmark, where companies have been using the principle for more than 20 years. But Kalundborg was not built for that purpose; it had a lucky confluence of companies that started to use one another's wastes after environmental regulations banned their disposal methods.
"Kalundborg was a wonderful accident," said Edward Cohen-Rosenthal, director of Cornell University's Work and Environment Initiative.
That accident may, in fact, have been replicated in Tampico, Mexico. Some 25 companies, all within a 40-mile radius, recently hired the Bechtel Corporation's consulting arm to identify their wastes. Bechtel found 44 waste streams, and one chemical plant is already using a pigment plant's waste ferric chloride as a water purifier, while a manufacturer of industrial gases is exploring ways to use carbon dioxide that is going up a smokestack.
"They are looking first to see what they can exchange among themselves, and then for what kinds of companies they will woo," said Paul Worhach, a Bechtel senior engineer.
Companies and developers in less industrialized areas do not have that luxury. So they are plunging feet first into courtship.
The Mississippi Economic and Community Development Department recently wooed a power plant to its new Red Hills Ecoplex in Choctaw County -- in the heart of lignite coal mining territory -- in part by pointing out the availability of on-site coal and water.
The plant will not start operating for two years, yet Robert T. Smira, the agency's deputy director, said he was close to leasing space to a brick maker that would use the clay left over from coal mining. The mining company, which normally uses the clay to fill in the holes its strip mines leave, will instead use the fly ash the power plant spews out. More fly ash will go for building roads, replacing the gravel that Choctaw now pays to haul in. And Mr. Smira is also trying to interest a wallboard maker in the fly ash.
That takes care of the solid stuff. Steady streams of water, at various temperatures, flow in and out of power plants, too. The eco-plex will have a greenhouse, a fish farm and a few food processors, all either feeding water to the plant or taking it. The greenhouse and a dry ice company will probably use the carbon dioxide from the plant's stacks.
That kind of everything-but-the-squeal setup attracted the AES power plant to Londonderry. A sewage treatment plant nearby will provide cheap water. Heated water coming out of the power plant will be piped first to other factories that can extract some of the heat, then back to the treatment plant. AES also expects to sell steam it would otherwise vent to the air.
In theory, it is an unbeatable system -- but no one knows how many manufacturers will respond. Other eco-park developers feel more comfortable casting a wider net for tenants, then offering incentives for them to use one another's wastes.
The Sustainable Technology Park Authority, a nonprofit organization, is building an eco-park in Cape Charles, Va., that welcomes any tenant that promises to operate along strict environmental rules. As tenants move in, it will use lists of their byproducts to woo others. But now it simply offers rent reductions to companies that exchange wastes.
"We aren't setting up the whole park around that," said Timothy E. Hayes, the agency's executive director. "But we hope that the availability of cheap materials will be an incentive to come here."

HEADLINE: Tax Cuts and Painful Reductions Proposed in G.O.P Budget

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 16

 BODY:
Republicans laid out a budget proposal today that makes good on their promises to cut taxes and increase spending on the military and education, but at the cost of deep cuts elsewhere.
Their plan is the Republican response to the budget proposal sent to Congress last month by President Clinton, and like the White House plan it makes shoring up Social Security the nation's top fiscal priority in an age of emerging surpluses. 
 The Republican plan was introduced today in the Senate Budget Committee, and a similar version is to be taken up on Wednesday by the House Budget Committee. While it is likely to prove no more than the opening Republican negotiating position, it makes clear that the surplus will not mute the debate over how to capitalize on the nation's prosperity.
Pete V. Domenici, the New Mexico Republican who is chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, said the plan would provide a tax cut next year of $15 billion and possibly more if the strong economy continues to generate higher-than-expected tax revenues.
The tax cuts would grow to $778 billion over the next decade. That is enough for the tax-writing committees in the House and Senate to choose among a variety of tax-cutting options, but probably not enough, Mr. Domenici acknowledged, for the 10 percent across-the-board reduction in income tax rates that Republicans had hoped to make the centerpiece of their agenda.
Seeking to blunt attacks from Mr. Clinton and Democrats in Congress that Republicans are shortchanging Medicare, Senator Domenici said his plan would set aside $133 billion over the next decade to cope with a variety of contingencies, including the possibility that an overhaul of Medicare would require an infusion of money.
The proposal would increase Pentagon spending by $18.2 billion, to $290 billion, reflecting an insistence among Republicans on rebuilding what they see as a dangerously run-down military.
In an attempt to neutralize a traditionally Democratic issue, the plan calls for a $3.3 billion increase in Federal spending on education next year, to a total of $103 billion.
But to allow the spending increases on the military and education while also meeting another bedrock Republican pledge -- to remain within the tight spending limits set out in the 1997 bipartisan budget deal -- the plan would require slashing spending on a wide array of other programs.
To stay under the cap on programs that receive annual appropriations -- $536 billion for next year -- the plan requires discretionary spending cuts of $14.7 billion next year, which some members of both parties said could well prove politically impossible. The plan would require even bigger cuts in the two subsequent years: $15.4 billion in 2001 and $22 billion in 2002.
The plan, if it is adopted by both the House and the Senate, would not become law but would be the guideline for the annual tax and spending bills Congress will take up this year. It is not binding but suggests specific cuts that the appropriations committees could consider in reconciling the demand from both parties for new and expanded programs with the painful discipline of the spending caps.
The proposal suggests that spending on environmental programs, for example, be reduced to $21.5 billion next year, from $23.9 billion this year. It would reduce spending on science, including NASA, to $18 billion, from $18.8 billion this year. It would shrink spending for agriculture to $14.3 billion next year, from $16.8 billion, and would not renew billions of dollars in emergency aid Congress gave farmers last year.
Mr. Domenici called the plan "a good start on wisely and effectively using projected surpluses into the next century."
But the Budget Committee's senior Democrat, Senator Frank R. Lautenberg of New Jersey, attacked the proposal, as did the White House.
"In order to fund an irresponsible and exploding tax cut, it fails to commit a single penny to securing Medicare and it requires discretionary cuts in the first few years that could not realistically be put together without serious reductions in key areas like education, health and environment," said Gene Sperling, the Administration's economic policy adviser.
Mr. Domenici said he hoped the committee would complete work on the plan this week and send it to the Senate floor for a vote next week. Last year, Mr. Domenici feuded over budget priorities with his counterpart in the House, Representative John R. Kasich, the Ohio Republican. But this year, the two men are working closely together to keep the party united as they head into months of negotiations with the White House on taxes, spending, Social Security and Medicare.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Brazil Stocks Defy Recession's Damage

BYLINE: By SIMON ROMERO 

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil, March 16

 BODY:
After spending much of 1999 so far straddling the line between pessimism and panic, Brazilian markets are staging a cautious rally that may be the first sign the economy, Latin America's largest, is starting to creep its way out of recession.
The benchmark Bovespa stock index, the main barometer of investor sentiment, moved today into positive territory measured in United States dollar terms. And when measured in the Brazilian currency, the real, stocks have risen 57 percent in two and a half months. 
 The last two days have been notable, with the Bovespa index gaining 8.77 percent on Monday and a further 2.35 percent today, to close here at 10,658.39.
The real, which spent much of January and February battered by concern over a possible return in Brazil to the turbulent times of hyperinflation, has strengthened nearly 15 percent in the last two weeks to settle in New York today at 1.87 to the dollar.
The improvement is partly the result of investor optimism after pledges by foreign financial institutions to renew credit lines totaling about $23 billion to Brazilian borrowers over the next six months. The foreign banks acted after pleas by the new president of this country's central bank, Arminio Fraga, a former fund manager for George Soros.
Lending rates, though, remain extremely high by world standards. Today, Bloomberg News reported, the overnight futures contract for May rose to 42.06 percent from 41.49 percent on Monday. Bonds were mixed, with the widely traded "C" bond yielding 16.04 percent.
But the signs that inflation may not be accelerating as fast as once feared have helped alleviate some investor concerns. "We're witnessing a shift in sentiment from very dark forecasts to a scenario of a long, slow recovery," said Octavio de Barros, chief economist here for Banco Bilbao Vizcaya. Mr. de Barros, like most other economists at large banks, said he saw the brunt of Brazil's economic difficulty occurring in the first half of the year, with a recovery, if an anemic one, starting late this year or early in 2000.
Banks' willingness to keep lending to some companies came on the back of an endorsement last week by the International Monetary Fund of the Government's plan to narrow the budget deficit. The I.M.F. agreed to provide a $9.3 billion installment from its $41.5 billion aid package, some of which the central bank can spend to combat currency speculation. "There's a realization in the markets that the recession we're experiencing is preparing us to emerge stronger, with a more vibrant export sector and improved public accounts," said Fernao Bracher, president of Banco BBA-Creditanstalt, in a telephone interview from Paris.
The Brazilian currency, though recently improved, has lost 35 percent of its value since the Government abandoned market support for it two months ago. Yet the severity of the recession brought on by devaluation is one of the main reasons why some analysts foresee resumed growth so soon. Dampened activity -- with economists forecasting output to shrink as much as 6 percent in the first quarter -- should translate into lower consumer demand for most goods, keeping inflation in check.
The likelihood that inflation will not gallop out of control, as it did in the early 90's, when price increases of 60 percent a month were common, allows consumers and companies to plan with more certainty. The Government's pledge not to let salaries be regularly adjusted for inflation provides additional assurance, said Julio Ziegelmann of BankBoston.
Still, it is too early to tell whether the new-found optimism on trading floors foretells any change in the bleak economic reality that many Brazilians are expected to confront in coming months.
Unemployment, hovering near a record at 8.4 percent, is seen rising as high as 10 percent in the next few months. And according to a study by Marcio Pocmann, an economist at the University of Campinas, per-capita income should fall 6.4 percent this year, steeper than declines in recessions in the 80's and early 90's.
"The stock market is not that accurate an indicator," said Guido Mantega, an economist affiliated with the opposition Workers Party. "People are getting poorer."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Unexpected Profits for Credit Suisse

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: ZURICH, March 16

 BODY:
Credit Suisse Group, Switzerland's No. 2 bank, reported higher-than-expected second-half profits today, helped by growth in money management and private banking that more than compensated for investment banking losses in Russia.
The company earned 700 million Swiss francs, or $475 million, equivalent to 2.6 francs a share. That compared with a loss of 1.37 billion Swiss francs, or 5.2 francs a share, in the second half of 1997. Credit Suisse First Boston, its investment bank, had a second-half loss of 1.272 billion francs, limiting full-year profit to 3.1 billion francs. 
 Credit Suisse, UBS and other Swiss banks are increasingly focusing on asset management and private banking, drawn by the steady earnings they offer, after losing hundreds of millions of dollars in riskier businesses such as emerging-markets, fixed-income and equities trading last year.
Credit Suisse shares rose 9.5 francs, or 3.8 percent, to a six-month high of 259 on the Swiss Exchange.
Credit Suisse First Boston's higher-than-expected loss in the second half was attributed to the financial crisis in Russia that sent stock and bond markets tumbling and caused the value of its investments to plummet.
The investment bank is the largest creditor among a group of Western banks holding $15 billion in defaulted Russian Government debt.
At the end of February, its Russian exposure was $1 billion, of which 61 percent was covered by reserves.
Exposure to other emerging markets included $1.296 billion in Latin America, $1.181 billion in China and Hong Kong, and $1.370 billion in Eastern European nations, Credit Suisse said.
Credit Suisse's 1997 profit of 397 million francs reflected a 1.4 billion franc charge to integrate the Winterthur Insurance Company, which it bought for about $10 billion last year, and to include the units of BZW Ltd. it acquired last year from the British bank Barclays P.L.C. for $255 million.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Daiwa Expects Big Loss
 TOKYO, March 16 (Bloomberg News) -- The Daiwa Securities Company, Japan's second-biggest brokerage firm, said today that it expected to lose 105 billion yen, or about $875 million, on cutting back business overseas.
Most of the pretax loss comes from Daiwa's withdrawal from activities in the United States and Britain and from selling off trading positions, the brokerage firm said. The loss was 54.7 billion yen more than Daiwa said in January that it would lose on reorganizing overseas.
All three of Japan's big brokers -- the Nomura Securities Company, the largest; Daiwa, and the Nikko Securities Company -- have cut back on their businesses abroad to focus on the domestic market. Daiwa began shutting down branches and cutting jobs last September.
The Tokyo-based brokerage firm expects to lose about 61 billion yen scaling back in Europe, 41 billion yen in the United States and 3 billion yen in Asia.

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Ads to Trumpet Whitman's Tax Plan

 BODY:
With a possible Senate run in store for Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, the New Jersey Republican State Committee yesterday announced a $153,000 television and radio campaign in support of the Governor's property tax relief proposal.
The Republican state chairman, Chuck Haytaian, denied yesterday that the 30-second television commercials and 60-second radio spots, which are to begin broadcasts in New York, New Jersey and Philadelphia today, were essentially Whitman campaign ads paid for with state party funds, commonly known as soft money, although he acknowledged that there could be a residual benefit for Mrs. Whitman if the property tax relief proposal is passed. 
 "If there's a residual, we're talking about next year," he said. "And this year, it will, hopefully, help the Republicans in the Assembly, because we have Assembly elections this year. It's a good program."
The plan, which would be phased in over five years, would provide homeowners with a total of $1 billion in property tax reimbursements by the fifth year. Mrs. Whitman outlined the plan in January, and a Republican State Senator, John Mattheussen, introduced legislation for it on Monday.
Democrats who responded to yesterday's announcement focused their criticism on the merits of the tax plan, not on whether the advertising campaign was intended as an early Senate boost for Mrs. Whitman.
"I'm assuming that the ad is not saying anything about the fiscal imprudence of promising people five years of tax relief," said Jim Florio, who was defeated by Mrs. Whitman in his bid for re-election as Governor in 1993, and is seeking the Democratic nomination for Senate. Mrs. Whitman, on a trade mission in South America, said she would announce whether she would run for the Senate after she returned on March 29.
Mr. Florio and others, including the State Democratic Chairman, Thomas P. Giblin, said that the plan assumes that the economy will continue to grow for at least five more years and thus pay for the property tax reimbursements without raising income or sales taxes.
Mr. Haytaian said property tax relief would be one more promise that Mrs. Whitman would keep, in addition to the income tax cut she heralded to help her unseat Mr. Florio. But Democrats repeated their criticism that the income tax cut merely led to property tax increases, and said that this pledge could be beyond Mrs. Whitman's control to keep.
"These are the good times," Mr. Florio said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Dow Crosses 10,000 Mark But Retreats for the Day
The Dow Jones industrial average continued its flirtation with the 10,000-point mark, even crossing it briefly. But it reversed its early climb and ended the session down 28.30 points, or three-tenths of a percent, to 9,930.47. 
Broader market averages were mixed, with the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index edging down 0.90 point, to 1,306.36. The Nasdaq composite index rose 7.83 points, or three-tenths of a percent, to 2,439.27. Page C11.
 
Bond yields dropped to their lowest point in three weeks, aided by optimism that inflation will not accelerate and short-term interest rates will remain steady. C11.
 
The price of gold plunged after President Clinton suggested that the International Monetary Fund should sell some of its gold reserves to help reduce the debt burdens on the world's poorest nations. C10.
 
Workers to Share Goldman Wealth
Goldman, Sachs, Wall Street's last big private partnership, detailed its plans to go public and offered a glimpse of how it will divide as much as $24 billion in projected net worth. For the general partners who own the firm, the average value of their shares will reach about $50 million. But employees below that level will share a $5 billion windfall, secretaries, janitors and word processors included. A1.
 
Coca-Cola's Marketing Costs Rise
In its annual report, Coca-Cola said it spent more than $1.2 billion on marketing and other support for its largest bottler, Coca-Cola Enterprises. That's nearly twice what it spent the year before on the bottler, which handles the bulk of Coca-Cola's volume in the United States. That expenditure helped raise case volume in the United States by 6 percent, but the marketing costs were keenly felt at Coca-Cola, which turned in one of its most lackluster performances in years in 1998. C2.
 
S.E.C. Weighs Disclosure Rule
Federal securities regulators, concerned that some investors may be getting key stock information before the rest of the market, are considering tightening disclosure rules so that companies will be forced to announce news to all investors at the same time. C2.
 
T.W.A. Names New Chief Executive
Trans World Airlines said William F. Compton, the carrier's president, would take over as chief executive in May, succeeding Gerald L. Gitner, who will remain as chairman. The move comes at a time when T.W.A. has been losing money while the industry has had record profits for four consecutive years. C8.
 
Brazilian Markets in Cautious Rally
After spending much of 1999 so far straddling the line between pessimism and panic, Brazilian markets are staging a cautious rally that may be the first sign the economy, Latin America's largest, is starting to creep its way out of recession. C4.
 
Saks Earnings Meet Expectations
Saks, the owner of Saks Fifth Avenue and other department stores, said that its fourth-quarter earnings rose 26 percent, meeting Wall Street estimates. But the company warned that this year's profit might be less than expected as it integrates chains it has acquired. Shares of Saks fell $1.5625, to $28.9375. C8.
 
Nine West Group, the women's shoe company, said it lost $7.3 million in the fourth quarter and would close its 9 & Company chain. C2.
 
Credit Suisse Group reported higher-than-expected second-half profits. C4.
 
Mexico Makes Case for Investment
Mexico has been able to separate itself from other, more troubled Latin countries since economic crisis shook the region last year, luring back investors. Foreigners' preference for Mexico has been felt in the stock and currency markets and in longer-term investments. C4.
 
Positive Report for South Korea
South Korea is the only sizable Asian economy that appears to be pulling out of economic crisis, although its unemployment rate has risen and shows no sign of declining, the International Labor Organization said in a study. C10.

HEADLINE: Albany Democrats Urge 4.6% Budget Increase

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, March 16

 BODY:
The Democrats who control the Assembly called today for a 4.6 percent rise in state spending, more than double the increase Gov. George E. Pataki has proposed, setting the boundaries for another fierce budget fight.
Mr. Pataki assailed the Democrats' plan as irresponsible, raising the prospect that like last year, he might veto most of the money the Legislature adds to his proposed budget. Mr. Pataki has proposed a $72.66 billion budget for the fiscal year that starts April 1, while the Assembly Democrats describe their plan as $2 billion higher. 
 Most of the difference lies in the Democrats' rejection of Mr. Pataki's proposed cuts in health care and education. Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver said his house's plan "rejects the devastating cuts that would have been funded on the backs of our children and on the backs of working families and senior citizens."
After an 8 percent increase in the budget last year, when he was running for re-election, Mr. Pataki has called for a 1.8 percent rise this year, vowing to keep the increase within the rate of inflation, despite a $2 billion surplus.
Democrats charge that the Governor is trying to impress conservatives in other states as he looks toward a possible campaign for national office next year.
The plan released today is just the Democrats' opening bid, but the gap between it and the Governor's proposal fed a growing resignation here to the prospect of a late budget for the 15th straight year.
Mr. Pataki; Joseph L. Bruno, the Republican majority leader of the Senate, and Comptroller H. Carl McCall, a Democrat, all predicted today that a budget would not be passed by April 1.
When asked about the Democrats' plan, Mr. Pataki said, "We have not seen anything to remotely justify the level of spending we're seeing from the Assembly."
But Mr. Silver, a Democrat from Manhattan, said tax revenues were growing so quickly that his plan would set aside $1 billion from the current surplus for future needs and still run up an additional $1.3 billion surplus next year.
The Senate's Republican majority has not released a detailed budget plan, but Mr. Bruno said today that his house would seek about $800 million, or 1.1 percent, more than the Governor, putting the two houses $1.2 billion apart.
Budget negotiations between the two houses are stalled on the fundamental question of how much money is available, and have not yet even touched on how it will be spent. Mr. Silver said he would name members of budget conference committees on Wednesday, leaving just two weeks in the fiscal year for the committees to strike deals.
Until 1997, the Governor and the two legislative leaders met privately to reach a compromise budget. Then last year, the Legislature met in conference committees to hash out a budget publicly, without the Governor.
But Mr. Pataki demonstrated, by broad use of his line-item veto power, that the new process had freed him from the need to compromise, greatly increasing his power over the budget.
Mr. Silver says he remains committed to conference committees, which rank-and-file Assembly members enjoyed because it gave them more say in the process. But aides say he is still searching for a way to avoid a repeat of last year, slowing talks with the Senate.
The April 1 deadline carries new weight this year, because the law passed in December that gave state officials a pay raise also requires that legislators' salaries be withheld as long as the budget is late. If the budget is more than a few weeks late, the delay in being paid could present a serious hardship for many lawmakers, adding to the pressure to reach a settlement.
The Assembly Democrats proposed adding $1.1 billion to the Governor's budget for Medicaid, the health insurance program for the poor. Most of that is a reversal of cuts the Governor had proposed, rather than new spending.
They also called for $645 million more than Mr. Pataki did for aid to local schools, including restoration of some cuts. In all, the Democrats want a $900 million increase over last year, or more than 7 percent, in school spending.
The Democrats are also seeking $291 million more than the Governor for the State University and City University of New York systems. But again, much of that would simply reverse cuts Mr. Pataki has proposed, particularly in tuition assistance to poor students.
In other areas, the Assembly plan rejects Mr. Pataki's call for a new state prison, but embraces the Senate Republicans' support for an expanded tax credit for the working poor.
The Democrats said their overall budget, including Federal aid for programs like Medicaid and welfare, is $74.66 billion, a 4.6 percent increase from the current year. The portion generated by the state, through taxes and other sources, is $50.9 billion, they said, up 5 percent.

HEADLINE: In a Surprise, Factory Output Had a Slight Gain in February

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 16

 BODY:
Industrial production unexpectedly rose in February, led by a fifth consecutive monthly gain in factory output, and construction of new homes stayed near a 12-year high, the latest signs the economy is surging as it heads into its ninth year of expansion.
"We're starting to hit on all cylinders" after a year of weak export demand, Paul Kasriel, an economist at the Northern Trust Company in Chicago, said today. "Manufacturing is coming back. That was the weak link in 1998." 
 Industrial output rose two-tenths of a percent last month, the Federal Reserve said. Analysts were predicting production would be unchanged, as it was in January. The plant-use rate, which measures industrial capacity in use, fell a tenth of a point, to 80.3 percent in February, the lowest since August 1992 and a sign that inflation-causing production bottlenecks are unlikely to develop.
Housing starts fell six-tenths of a percent in February, to an annual rate of 1.799 million units, not far from the 12-year high of 1.810 million in January. Moreover, starts of single-family homes rose 1.1 percent last month, to a rate of 1.413 million, the strongest pace since December 1978, the Commerce Department said.
The ability of American workers to produce more at less cost is fueling the expansion, Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, said today. That puts him among those who say that one-time benefits from lower oil prices and low-cost goods from overseas are not the only reasons inflation is staying low.
"These accomplishments are doubtless partly the result of influences that may prove transitory, but a number of fundamental strengths imply more lasting benefits," Mr. Greenspan said in a speech to the Independent Bankers Association of America in San Francisco.
The Fed's industrial production report showed that manufacturing output advanced two-tenths of a percent in February. Mining output rose four-tenths of a percent, its first increase in a year. Output at utilities decreased six-tenths of a percent.
Production of durable goods rose five-tenths of a percent last month after rising two-tenths of a percent in January. Output of nondurable goods fell two-tenths of a percent in February after falling one-tenth of a percent in January. Business equipment output, including computers, rose two-tenths of a percent.
A key question for housing in the months ahead is the recent rise in mortgage rates. The average 30-year mortgage rate rose last week to 7.11 percent, the highest level since the third week of May last year, according to Freddie Mac.
