HEADLINE: MEDICARE PANEL, SHARPLY DIVIDED, SUBMITS NO PLAN

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 16

 BODY:
A Federal advisory commission searching for ways to preserve Medicare disbanded tonight in disagreement, just three hours after President Clinton denounced its proposed report and said he would devise a plan of his own as an alternative.
The commission ended its work without endorsing any recommendations to avert a financial crisis in the program, which provides health insurance for 39 million Americans who are elderly or disabled. 
 The 17-member commission, headed by Senator John B. Breaux, Democrat of Louisiana, fell one vote short of the 11 votes needed to approve a final report. Ten commission members -- 8 Republicans and 2 Democrats -- voted for major changes that would convert Medicare into an arena for competition among public and private health plans. Sad but not surprised, Mr. Breaux said, "We have advanced the Medicare debate in a very significant way."
Congress created the commission in 1997, expecting that it would propose the difficult and perhaps politically unpopular choices needed to insure the program's solvency.
Medicare will almost certainly become an issue in the next Presidential campaign. Democrats can portray themselves as defenders of Medicare, offering new coverage for prescription drugs, while Republicans will criticize Mr. Clinton and other Democrats as thwarting efforts to stave off the insolvency of the Medicare trust fund.
Senator Breaux and Representative Bill Thomas of California, the leading Republican member of the commission, said they would keep fighting for their proposal, under which the Government would offer a fixed amount of money to each beneficiary to purchase a public or private health plan.
Until today, Mr. Clinton had studiously refrained from commenting on the work of the commission. But late this afternoon, less than an hour before the panel began its final session, Mr. Clinton went to the South Lawn of the White House and criticized the proposal supported by 10 of the 17 commission members.
Mr. Clinton said the proposal, drafted by Mr. Breaux and Mr. Thomas, "does not provide for an adequate, affordable prescription drug benefit" for the elderly and disabled. Moreover, he said, the proposal could increase the number of Americans without health insurance, by raising the eligibility age for Medicare to 67 from 65, and could cause excessive increases in premiums for people who remain in the traditional Medicare program.
Finally, Mr. Clinton said that Mr. Breaux's plan was unacceptable because it did not include the President's proposal to earmark 15 percent of any future budget surpluses for the Medicare program. Independent experts agree that Medicare needs "substantial new revenues" to provide for the baby boom generation, Mr. Clinton said.
After thanking the commission for "valuable work," Mr. Clinton said he would devise his own proposal, and he said he hoped Congress would approve it this year, but he gave no details of what he had in mind.
"I want an agreement this year," Mr. Clinton said. "I am going to do my dead-level best to get it done."
Mr. Clinton spoke out after it became clear that members of Congress from both parties were faulting him for the commission's failure to agree on any recommendations.
The Senate Republican leader, Trent Lott of Mississippi, said Mr. Clinton "chose to kill the Medicare commission's bipartisan recommendations one-half hour before the commission was scheduled to meet." But Barry Toiv, a White House spokesman, said Mr. Clinton did not try to influence commission members "one way or the other."
Medicare costs are growing faster than the available revenue, and many lawmakers see an urgent need to repair the program because the the trust fund that pays hospital bills is expected to run out of money in about a decade.
Mr. Clinton appointed 4 of the 17 commission members. All 4 voted against the Breaux-Thomas proposal, though 2 of the 4 said they saw some merit in it. The other commission members were appointed by the Speaker of the House, the Senate Republican leader and the Democratic leaders of the two chambers.
One of the Clinton appointees, Prof. Stuart H. Altman of Brandeis University, said Mr. Breaux's plan did too little to find additional revenue for Medicare and to guarantee affordable drug coverage.
"We do need more money in this program," Mr. Altman said. "We need it sooner rather than later."
Another commission member, Laura D'Andrea Tyson, the former chairwoman of Mr. Clinton's Council of Economic Advisers, said she supported efforts to inject competition into Medicare. But Ms. Tyson said such competition could never produce enough savings to solve Medicare's financial problems.
Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, acknowledged that the commission was influenced by politics, but he declared: "Thank God for it. That's the exercise of free men and women doing the business of their Government." Unfortunately, he said, "the proposal before us would convert Medicare from a universal guarantee to a Government voucher for private insurance."
Senator Breaux disagreed. "This proposal is not a voucher program," he said. "It is not an end to Medicare as an entitlement."
The chairmen of the House Ways and Means Committee and the Senate Finance Committee said they would hold hearings on the Breaux-Thomas proposal. And Mr. Breaux said the full Senate would probably support much of the proposal. But the outlook for action in Congress is murky, unless Republicans agree to Mr. Clinton's proposal to use some of the projected budget surplus.
Mr. Thomas said the proposal to earmark some of the surplus for Medicare was a bookkeeping gimmick. "The President's proposal is likely to create a public misperception that something meaningful is being done to reform the Medicare program," Mr. Thomas said.
Many health policy experts say Medicare will eventually need additional revenues, beyond the current sources of money, which include premiums paid by beneficiaries, workers' payroll taxes and general revenues from the Treasury. But Newt Gingrich insisted that his appointees promise not to vote for tax increases. And the commission did not seriously consider tax increases.

HEADLINE: An Expensive Fish

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: SEATTLE, March 16

 BODY:
In a sense, what is most remarkable about the Federal Government's announcement today that it would list nine types of salmon under the Endangered Species Act, a move that will force new building restrictions and raise taxes across the Seattle area and elsewhere in the Northwest, is how little controversy it has stirred -- so far, anyway.
But this new application of the law, the broadest in the statute's 26-year history in terms of both geography and the effect on a human population, is almost certain to become a test of the willingness of an entire urban region to pay large sums of money and perhaps even sacrifice some growth for what has become a political battle cry: the control of "sprawl." 
 The effort to restore the once-vigorous runs of the Puget Sound chinook and other salmon is really a cause that combines elements of a customary environmental crusade with those of the more recent drive against rampant growth -- the kind of concern that tops Vice President Al Gore's "livability agenda," which he hopes to make a centerpiece of his Presidential campaign. Restoring the salmon will entail cleaning up the waterways that snake all over the Puget Sound region, promoting and preserving green space and open space, limiting the creep of suburbanization -- the things that people seem to clamor for in opinion polls.
Those polls indicate overwhelming support here for doing whatever is necessary to save the salmon, which are running at a fraction of their historic peaks. A big rally on the eve of today's long-awaited announcement drew Seattle's Mayor and other top local officials, all in support of the fish. "What's good for salmon is good for people," one placard said.
But the effort could well mean measures that might not prove so popular, particularly in the long run. Fertilizer use could be banned in some areas, and residents' use of water might be limited. And it will cost hundreds of millions of dollars, perhaps more, to preserve crucial land.
So what now seems a popular move could well prompt a severe backlash against the Endangered Species Act and those local officials who must adopt the required restrictions.
"Really, what's involved here is that for the last 100 years, as we developed out here, we sort of forced the salmon to adjust to us," said William D. Ruckelshaus, a Seattleite who was Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency in both the Nixon and Reagan Administrations and now heads a business round-table group on salmon. "Well, now we have to figure out how to adjust to the salmon. At this juncture, there is tremendous enthusiasm for that, enough political support to cause politicians here to feel comfortable in taking some pretty extraordinary steps."
"But it could all evaporate," Mr. Ruckelshaus added. "It could turn into a fight and a struggle. I don't think it will, but it could."
Others say there is reason to be skeptical.
"The old Clinton slogan was 'putting people first,' and now the Gore slogan is 'putting salmon first,' " said Alex Castellanos, a Republican political consultant, referring to Mr. Gore's advocacy of salmon restoration and his recent promise of $100 million in Federal aid as part of what he and the President called "a new partnership for salmon recovery."
The general idea "sounds good to people, so of course they'll say they're for it," Mr. Castellanos said. "Even so, here's what always happens: The best day is the first day it's announced. After that, when you get to putting the price tags on it, there's just a steady, steady erosion. After a while, people begin to ask, 'Well, what else could you do with this money?' What if the question becomes, Do you save salmon or do you save seniors?"
And even if public support does hold, still others wonder whether the salmon runs can really be nursed back to health. The Seattle-Tacoma region already has nearly three million people, and it continues to grow; some projections call for a population growth of one million in the next 25 years.
At a briefing on Monday, the King County Executive, Ron Sims, a Democrat who is a strong proponent of salmon restoration plans and a potential candidate for the Senate next year, said economic growth and saving the salmon were not incompatible. "We're not going to tear down the Seafirst Bank building," Mr. Sims said of a dominating skyscraper here, "and replant it with Douglas fir. The key will be to make sure we're smarter with the land mass that's available. This area is going to have to become greener."
If it grows by one million people, though, it is hard to see how it can.
Under the Endangered Species Act, local officials must now work in the coming months to develop plans for restoring the salmon runs. If there is no improvement, local governments and eventually even private citizens could face Federal sanctions.
For the moment, the support for salmon protection efforts is sufficiently broad that announcements about the listing today were attended by political figures, environmentalists and business leaders like Steven Rogel, president of the Weyerhaeuser Company, the timber concern, whose headquarters are just outside Tacoma.
"Today's listings means that all of us are going to have to do our fair share to solve the salmon crisis," Mr. Rogel said. "Forest landowners are ready to go."
As a result of the listing, the logging industry is facing potential restrictions that could protect hundreds of millions of dollars' worth of trees close to waterways. The industry is already pushing for a reduction in excise taxes that could offset at least part of that loss.
In the end, the key to a successful protection effort may be a feeling among all parties that they are being affected equally.
"If people are convinced that this whole thing really is a partnership, that everybody is doing their fair share, then I think you could continue to see a lot of support," said Robert E. Gogerty, a consultant here who has advised both businesses and political candidates. "But if they think they're bearing the brunt of it, then you could see a rebellion."

HEADLINE: Forbes Declares Candidacy On Internet and the Stump

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 16

 BODY:
Renouncing the traditional brass bands and patriotic bunting, Steve Forbes, the multimillionaire publisher, today became the first Presidential contender to formally announce his candidacy on the Internet.
Mr. Forbes, in his second try for the Republican Presidential nomination, cast himself as unconventional and future-oriented, telling viewers who clicked on his sleek, unadorned Web page, "You and I are entering the information age -- and the Washington politicians are stuck in the Stone Age." 
 Although he has barely broken stride since his defeat in 1996, Mr. Forbes used his remarks to try to reshape his image as a candidate with bucketfuls of money and a lackluster speaking style whose trademark is a flat tax. While he still champions the tax, he did not dwell on it today. Instead, he devoted his speech to his newly burnished credentials as an outspoken backer of religious conservatives and a foe of abortion -- as well as his concerns about the global economic crisis.
"Now," he said, "the central questions of the year 2000 campaign clearly are these: Do you trust the establishment politicians to protect your economic security and give you more freedom and more control over your life? Do you trust them to defend your values and protect the first and most important freedom of every child: the freedom to be born?"
"Do you trust them to confront the atrocities in China, end Saddam Hussein's reign of terror and deploy a real missile defense system to protect our children?" he continued. And, eagerly lambasting the Democrats, Mr. Forbes added, "Do you trust other politicians to clean out the corruption and sleaze of the Clinton-Gore Administration?"
Despite his relentless campaign schedule, Mr. Forbes, who is 51, has thus far languished in the shadows of two better-known prospects: Gov. George W. Bush of Texas and Elizabeth Dole. As they did four years ago, many Republicans question whether a bland business executive who has never been elected to anything can capture the party's nomination.
Yet, particularly after his performance in 1996 -- when he lavished more than $35 million of his fortune on his campaign -- no one doubts Mr. Forbes's staying power in the primary season. And no one doubts his potential to shape the dialogue significantly.
Although Mr. Forbes was a fleeting sensation in 1996, registering high in the polls when he first unleashed his television blitz and scoring victories in the Delaware and Arizona contests, he placed fourth in the pivotal Iowa caucuses and New Hampshire primary. But his hard-hitting advertisements -- opponents called them mean-spirited -- came close to ravaging the candidacy of Bob Dole, who ultimately became the Republican nominee.
As Mr. Forbes did last time, he plans to forgo Federal spending limits and dig deep into his family fortune to finance most of his campaign. Mr. Bush is the only other contender who is thinking about eschewing spending limits. So even if the other candidates' money dries up, Mr. Forbes can run television advertisements till the bitter end. And his more than ample resources have helped him lure some of the most skilled party workers, including Steve Grubbs and Nancy Streck, both Iowa operatives who had been courted aggressively by other campaigns.
In an interview, Mr. Forbes disputed that he was drawing staff members more because of his bankroll than the appeal of his candidacy.
"We compensate people according to responsibility and ability," he said. "And being of Scottish descent, I'm not going to spend a penny more than necessary. The key is having the message and getting it out to the voters. But money alone won't win it for you."
Mr. Forbes said he believed he was better positioned than in 1996 because then he did not enter the race until late 1995.
"We did not have the opportunities, except very, very late to set up the grass-roots organizations in early states," he said. "People are going to have a better feel of what we're proposing than in the short period of '95 and '96."
Mr. Forbes has refashioned himself, too. The most striking change is that he has assiduously courted social conservatives and emphasized abortion and other social issues he neglected four years ago. At the very least, the changed emphasis has neutralized many religious conservatives who opposed him in 1996.
He has also emphasized other issues, including allowing workers to divert part of their Social Security taxes into individual investment accounts and providing parents with vouchers for private schools.
"Do you know what astounds me?" Mr. Forbes asked in his Internet remarks. "More young people believe in U.F.O.'s than believe that they're going to collect Social Security when they retire."
By announcing his "information-age campaign" on the Internet, Mr. Forbes sought to add another fresh dimension to his candidacy. While every major Presidential campaign has a Web site, the Forbes organization is promising bells and whistles, including the beaming of photographs, live, from the stump.
After his unconventional announcement was posted on the Web site, www.forbes2000.com, Mr. Forbes staged a conventional rally that drew about 50 people on the steps of the Capitol in Concord, N.H., where he retreated to his signature issue of a flat tax that would tax all wage income at 17 percent. He signed a pledge promising not to raise taxes -- the first rule of politics in New Hampshire -- and challenged other candidates to do the same.
Mr. Forbes's remarks were disrupted by a few hecklers, some wearing fur coats, who called themselves Billionaires for Forbes. But he tried to turn his fortune into a virtue, saying, "I'm the only only who is not beholden to the Washington culture of special-interest lawyers, lobbyists and lifetime politicians."
The message seemed convincing to Ginny Burke, a former state legislator from Bedford, N.H., who traveled to Concord on this blustery day to show her support for Mr. Forbes.
"I think he's following common sense," Ms. Burke said. "He doesn't owe anything to anybody. He doesn't have to try to please the lobbyists to raise money, and I think that, unfortunately, most candidates do."
Roger Stone, a veteran Republican strategist who is not affiliated with any campaign, dismissed Mr. Forbes's candidacy. "He's substantially less relevant than he was four years ago -- protest and reform type candidacies tend to do a lot less well in times of economic prosperity," Mr. Stone said. "Secondly, his chameleon-like change into a religious right candidate is not very credible. This is a guy who was pro-choice just a few years ago."
Mr. Stone said that while Mr. Forbes "can play again the role of damaging the eventual nominee," he would ultimately realize that "he's throwing good money after bad."
Still, most Republicans -- and certainly his rivals -- are taking Mr. Forbes much more seriously than four years ago, when his declaration of candidacy drew little attention. At the time Mr. Dole, hardly threatened, welcomed Mr. Forbes into the race with a quip: "I think it will help the economy."

HEADLINE: School for Violent Students Faces Objections in Queens

BYLINE: By VIVIAN S. TOY 

 BODY:
The Board of Education hopes to place 100 of the city's most violent students in a new school inside the former Swingline factory in Long Island City, Queens, but residents and local officials worry that such a school would hamper the neighborhood's budding resurgence.
School officials are negotiating a lease to transform about a third of one floor in the defunct stapler factory into a Second Opportunity School for troubled middle and high school students from throughout Queens. The school, which would house students who have taken weapons to school or who have been involved in serious assaults, would be the third of six that Chancellor Rudy Crew plans to open in the city. The plans for the school were first reported yesterday in Newsday. 
 Long Island City residents and local officials said yesterday that they were angry that school officials did not discuss the plans with the community before entering into negotiations for the space. In addition to concerns about bringing potentially disruptive students into the neighborhood, they said, they fear that the school would take space that could be used to attract manufacturers.
"This is an area that is already oversaturated with high schools," said City Councilman Walter McCaffrey, who represents Long Island City, adding that there are seven high schools within a 10-block radius of the Swingline building. "Are we killing off economic development by putting a high school in space that should be used for private commerce?"
For decades, Long Island City had seen factories close and jobs disappear. Only recently have smaller manufacturing companies started to replace the old assembly lines that once ran around the clock.
Dr. Crew proposed Second Opportunity Schools in 1997 as a replacement for the Crossroads Academy, which since 1995 has brought the school system's most violent students under one roof in the Bronx. The Chancellor had said he hoped that creating special schools closer to the homes of those students -- in the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens -- would increase their chances of succeeding in school, but his plans have been stalled by the difficulty of finding appropriate locations.
"It is always difficult to find space in urban settings, that goes without saying," said Chiara Coletti, the Chancellor's spokeswoman. "And then we've had the added component of community opposition to these types of schools in particular."
She said the schools are designed to be small academies that use a relatively large adult staff to work with a small number of students. The two schools that have opened in the Bronx, for example, have 1 teacher for every 15 students, compared with the citywide average of 1 teacher for every 34 high school students, as well as a host of counselors to deal with the students' many needs.
"These are very small schools with very close supervision, and frankly, that's not threatening," she said. "We also must remember that these are still children and we have an obligation to educate them and prepare them for life."
Cathryn Keeshan, co-president of the United Forties Civic Association, which represents the area around the Swingline factory, said school officials should have laid out their plans to neighborhood groups to allay their fears.
"This has not been adequately discussed with the community at all," she said. "It would be wrong for me to form a judgment that these kids are going to be disruptive because I don't have the adequate information. But if they haven't responded well to other youngsters, you have to wonder: Will they harass or taunt people going into the area?"
Mr. McCaffrey said he hoped to get assurances from the Board of Education that the school would not take in more than 100 students and that the students could be brought to the school by school bus to avoid further taxing subway and city bus lines. He has also asked that the students use a back entrance to the building on Skillman Avenue, away from the Y.M.C.A. that just opened last month across the street.
Larry Smith, a spokesman for Sholom and Zuckerbrot, the leasing agent for the new owners of the Swingline building, Stellar Management of Manhattan, said the factory's four floors would be rented to three or four tenants, most likely industrial companies. He said the owners would decide on whether to lease space to the Board of Education within the next month. He said converting 30,000 square feet of the building's 285,000 square feet into a school would probably cost the city about $1 million.
A spokeswoman for the Museum of Modern Art in Manhattan said the museum was negotiating to buy a Swingline factory annex south of Queens Boulevard. But she said having a Second Opportunity School across the street would not be a concern for the museum because the museum planned to use the site for storage and offices, not as a public space.

HEADLINE: New Sports and Retail Complex Is Proposed for the Meadowlands

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

DATELINE: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., March 16

 BODY:
Even as the Nets and Devils develop plans for new arenas elsewhere in the state, the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority today proposed building a new $212 million home for the teams in the Meadowlands and replacing the existing arena with a giant entertainment complex.
The proposed basketball and hockey arena would be built alongside Giants Stadium, while the 18-year-old Continental Airlines Arena would be demolished. As part of creating what the Sports Authority called a "sports epicenter," the new retail and entertainment complex would feature halls of fame, sports restaurants like ESPN Zone, movie theaters and retailers like Nike Town that allow patrons to try out the sporting goods. 
 Even though the Sports and Exposition Authority, a quasi-public agency that runs the sports complex, made an elaborate presentation in describing its effort, the plan serves mainly as the Meadowlands' opening bid in determining a future home for the Nets and the Devils.
It comes a week after John McMullen, the owner of the Devils hockey team, released his own plan for a $350 million hockey arena and entertainment complex in Hoboken. Raymond Chambers and the other new owners of the Nets have said they intend to move the basketball team to a new arena in Newark as part of a plan to revive the state's largest city.
"There'll be discussions with the two franchises to see whether this vision is part of their future," said Dennis R. Robinson, president of the Sports Authority. "I think this plan creates the ultimate sports and entertainment destination that would benefit all the teams. It's up to them."
If the Nets and Devils leave the Meadowlands, Mr. Robinson said that the Sports Authority would still demolish the Continental Airlines Arena and develop the retail and entertainment complex.
Howard J. Rubenstein, a spokesman for the Nets, declined comment. Mr. McMullen was out of town and could not be reached for comment.
Mr. Robinson said that Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's first goal was to insure that New Jersey remained home to the Nets and the Devils, as well as the Giants, the Jets and the MetroStars soccer team, all of which now play in the Meadowlands.
In recent months, the Nets have tried to woo Mr. McMullen, but he has steadfastly resisted any notion of moving the Devils to Newark. Still, there are ample political and economic reasons for the teams to cooperate, be it in Newark, Hoboken or the Meadowlands.
Sports analysts say that an arena is economically viable only when it is used by more than one team.
At the same time, it is unlikely that Mrs. Whitman will provide state aid for more than one arena. Although each project would involve at least some private financing, the teams and the Sports and Exposition Authority want the state to provide highway and other transportation improvements.
"You can't build two single-team arenas; the Governor's pretty firm about that," said Raymond H. Bateman, chairman of the Sports Authority.
The Nets contend that any transportation improvements in Newark, unlike the Meadowlands, would also benefit local commuters. A Newark arena would also be close to mass transit, highways and downtown development opportunities.
"There's a broad public benefit in Newark," said one business executive who supports the Nets' move and who spoke only on the condition of anonymity. "On any given night, try finding a parking space for dinner in Hoboken, let alone a sports event."
Designed by Ronald F. Turner, a principal at NBBJ of Los Angeles, the proposed sports arena would seat 18,436 fans for hockey and 19,136 for basketball. The most significant features of the sleek oval structure are mainly about increased revenue for the teams and higher costs for the fans: as many as 100 luxury suites (up from 29 at the Continental Arena), 2,666 premium seats and a private club.
Michael Rubin, a sports and entertainment consultant with MRA International in Philadelphia, said the 600,000-square-foot retail and entertainment complex he designed would be a centerpoint for the teams that make their home at the Meadowlands complex.
"This is the last best site to create a sports themed entertainment and leisure destination," Mr. Rubin said.
Preston Robert Tisch, co-owner of the Giants, welcomed plans to demolish the Continental Arena. "It just doesn't work in today's world," Mr. Tisch said. "It's an underused piece of land. You need more boxes, restaurants and income coming in."
Both buildings would be privately financed, but the Sports and Exposition Authority said the state would consider about $72 million in parking garages and traffic improvements to local highways.
Mr. Robinson said the proposal was building on a 23-year record of success at the Meadowlands complex, which had $116 million in gross ticket sales last year and generated an estimated $1.4 billion in economic activity.
But that does not mean that the Meadowlands Sports Complex is a moneymaking operation. The complex once generated surplus revenue for state coffers after paying operating expenses and debt service.
But in recent years, the state has had to provide tens of millions of dollars to cover shortfalls, because of a decline in the popularity of horse racing and because of competition from Atlantic City casinos. In 1999, the Sports Authority expects that it will need about $29 million to break even.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Unemployment Milestone

 BODY:
New Jersey's preliminary unemployment rate for February was 4.1 percent, its lowest level in a decade and the first time it has dipped below the national rate since 1991, the State Labor Department announced yesterday.
The rate, which may later be adjusted up or down depending on additional employment indicators, declined steeply from January's level of 4.4 percent, said Kevin Smith, a spokesman for the Labor Department. He said the state posted a net gain of 9,200 jobs last month, with the strongest gains in health care and social and business services. "All these numbers are subject to change," he said, "but these look pretty good." 
 It was in July 1989 that the state last had a monthly rate of 4.1 percent, Mr. Smith said.
Preliminary unemployment figures for October had placed New Jersey's rate one-tenth of one percentage point lower than the nation's, but adjusted figures later reversed the order. This time, Mr. Smith said, the state was three-tenths of a percentage point lower than the nation's February rate of 4.4 percent, and state analysts are confident that even the adjusted rate will be lower than the national one.
The last time the state's unemployment rate was below the nation's was in 1991, during a recession -- the state rate of 7.1 percent dipped below the national rate of 7.2 percent.

HEADLINE: Russia to Offer U.S. Deal To End Iran Nuclear Aid

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, March 16

 BODY:
Russia has offered to curtail nuclear cooperation with Iran if Washington ends sanctions against two leading Russian nuclear research centers, Russia's Atomic Energy Minister says.
The proposal comes as Prime Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov prepares for critical talks in Washington next week on security issues and Russian appeals for billions of dollars in credits from the International Monetary Fund. 
 The minister made the disclosure in an interview on Monday.
The aim of the Russian proposal is to remove a major irritant in relations with the West and unlock valuable contracts to the nation's hard-strapped nuclear institutes.
Senior Clinton Administration officials said that Yevgeny Adamov, the Atomic Energy Minister, had presented the plan to American officials last week and that the two sides are trying to hammer out an agreement by the Primakov meeting.
"It would help with the overall tone of our relationship," an Administration official said. "Adamov is taking the initiative and appears to have Primakov's support. But we still have a paper to negotiate."
Mr. Adamov's proposal addresses one of Washington's main fears: that Russia may expand its nuclear cooperation with Teheran. Russia is already planning to build several nuclear power reactors at Bushire in Iran. While American officials object to that project, they are even more worried that Russia will also provide Iran with heavy water and graphite reactors, which are useful in producing plutonium for nuclear bombs.
Fears that Russia might be broadening its nuclear trade with Iran to include heavy water and graphite technology led the United States in January to impose sanctions against the Scientific Research and Design Institute for Power Technology, also known as Nikiet, and the Mendeleyev University of Chemical Technology.
Russian nuclear cooperation with Iran is also a major Israeli concern.
The sanctions were an especially embarrassing for the Russians since Mr. Adamov used to be the head of the research institute.
"Nikiet is really at the center of our concern," said an American expert. "It is the principal Russian entity that could provide assistance beyond Bushire. If we can address Nikiet we have made a very significant step."
Mr. Adamov's plan, in theory, would do precisely that. Mr. Adamov said he wanted to sign a document in Washington affirming that the institute has cut off all contact with Iran.
In return, the United States would lift sanctions against the institute. A similar agreement, Mr. Adamov said, could be worked out for Mendeleyev University.
A procedure would be established to discuss future disputes about the provision of Russian nuclear technology to Iran, according to Mr. Adamov's proposal. But Russia would not abandon its plan to build reactors at Bushire.
Mr. Adamov said he had already instructed the institute to sunder its ties with Iran. American officials said, however, that there were signs the contacts were continuing.
Strapped for cash and eager to maintain a modicum of cooperation with Washington, Iran is just one nuclear issue where the Russians are hoping for a breakthrough.
A compromise also has already been worked out concerning 16 advanced I.B.M. computers the Russians obtained in 1996 in violation of American export controls. The Russians obtained the computers using Moscow-based middlemen and installed them in the closed city of Arzamas-16, a design center for Russia's nuclear arsenal.
The Clinton Administration initially asked that the computers be returned. Under the compromise, the computers have quietly been moved from a military site to a civilian site within the city: a building used by Sberbank, a Government bank.
The computers are to be used for civilian purposes like the development of commercial software, according to the new arrangement. The compromise plan was overseen by Siegfried Hecker, the former director of the Los Alamos National Laboratory, who quietly visited Russia to help put it in place.
American officials hope to work out a similar arrangement for an SP-2 I.B.M. computer, which American officials suspect has also been delivered to Arzamas, for a high-performance computer system from Silicon Graphics, which is at the nuclear design center at Chelyabinsk.
There has been progress on other fronts as well. Officials hope to conclude arrangements that would ease the sale to international companies of billions of dollars worth of low-enriched uranium derived from Russian nuclear warheads. An agreement was worked on in 1993 but has been thwarted by commercial and legal problems.
Iran, however, has been the most contentious issue. There is no surprise why the Russians are anxious to see the sanctions lifted. If they are not removed, the sanctions would deprive Nikiet of several million dollars worth of work, a considerable setback for the cash-poor institute.
Washington also has an interest in resolving the issue. The institute, which designed the type of reactor involved in the accident at Chernobyl, is helping to improve the safety of Russia's nuclear power complex, a task Washington has supported.
United States Energy Department officials have been so worried about the safety implications of the sanctions that they secretly appealed to the White House, asking that some exceptions be made so that important safety work could go forward, American officials said.
Russia has also taken some steps to cut off contracts on the sale of missile technology to Iran, but much more needs to be done, American officials said.
One issue is whether the institute has, in fact, stopped its contacts with Iran, as Mr. Adamov contends it has.
Explaining the contacts, Mr. Adamov said the institute had prepared a contract for the sale of a research reactor to Iran. Mendeleyev University, he insisted, has provided some basic unclassified information on heavy water technology, while recommending that Iran purchase a light-water reactor.
Mr. Adamov said that the Russian Government had rejected his proposal to sell the research reactor to Iran and that the institute no longer has dealings with the Iranians. That, he insisted, should lay the basis for an agreement in Washington.
"I do believe in American pragmatism," he said. "This is a chance to check if these people are pragmatic, though I am afraid of some angry people in the State Department. They are somewhat narrow-minded."

CORRECTION-DATE: March 19, 1999, Friday

 CORRECTION:
A headline on Wednesday about a Russian effort to end United States sanctions on two Russian nuclear research centers, imposed because of concerns about aid to Iran, misstated the Russian offer. Russia offered to curtail nuclear cooperation with Iran, not to end it.

HEADLINE: Why We Shouldn't Write Off Russia

BYLINE: By Anatol Lieven; Anatol Lieven is an editor at the International Institute for Strategic Studies and the author of "Chechnya: Tombstone of Russian Power."

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
When the Russian Prime Minister, Yevgeny Primakov, visits Washington next week, he and President Clinton will have to confront this incongruity: The International Monetary Fund needs to renew lending to Russia not so Russia can finally reform itself, but mainly so that it can repay the I.M.F. It's an absurd situation, but international finance is like that.
The I.M.F. suspended its loans to Russia last year after Russia's devaluation and partial default, and after a long record of false promises and failed reforms. Now the I.M.F. is deciding whether to release the rest of the $22.6 billion in loans. Without the money, there is no chance whatsoever that Russia will be able to repay the approximately $4.8 billion it owes this year to the fund and the World Bank. 
 Russia's failure to pay its loans would mean a collapse of relations with both the I.M.F. and the World Bank. In the longer term it would contribute enormously to cutting Russia off from international investment. Except as an exporter of raw materials, Russia would be largely isolated from the world economy. Moreover, the West would have lost one of its few remaining levers to influence Russian behavior on the world stage.
Russia would join the exclusive club of only seven countries that have ever defaulted on their debts to the main international financial institutions. Of these seven, four -- including Iraq and Sudan -- are considered "rogue" states, and three -- Liberia, Congo and Somalia -- are "failed" states.
And this reality should indeed be the West's bottom line when it comes to deciding whether to support continued I.M.F. lending in spite of Russia's appalling record of economic management. There are two key questions. Is it in our interest that the Russian central state should collapse? And do we think -- as do many Republican politicians, like Representative Benjamin Gilman of New York, chairman of the House International Relations Committee -- that Russia's international behavior has already been so bad that the United States should in effect classify Russia as a "rogue" state and actively welcome its isolation?
The answer to both questions should be no. We cannot now "win" Russia, either as a successful convert to free market reform or as an obedient member of an American-led international security order. Probably we never could. But we can still help the Russian central state retain some form of effective power over its territory, and we can still keep Russia from going "rogue."
First of all, though, we need to shed the hypocritical illusion that I.M.F. decisions on lending to Russia (or to certain other countries, like Ukraine) are, should be or have been dictated chiefly by the I.M.F.'s own rules. By those criteria, for years now Russia should not have received a cent.
It is no secret that the chief reason the I.M.F. lent to Russia in 1995 and '96 is that leading Western governments insisted on it. Much I.M.F. lending in the past cannot really be said to have been to Russia as a country -- it was to the Yeltsin regime, especially in the run-up to the 1996 elections.
As a result, the I.M.F., willingly or unwillingly, turned a blind eye to two utterly disastrous policies intended to win Mr. Yeltsin those elections: the huge grant of tax breaks and exemptions to businesses, regions and municipalities, and the "loans for shares" program under which leading bankers were given Russia's most valuable oil and minerals companies for a fraction of their value, in return for their financial and political support for President Yeltsin. These two policies lie at the heart of the collapse of Russia's revenue-raising capacity, and the West's acquiescence -- or even complicity -- in them gives the I.M.F.'s current calls for tougher Russian budgets and taxation a bitter ring.
In any case, greater budgetary austerity and serious economic reform are for the moment virtually impossible: wages to state employees are up to a year in arrears, and the armed forces, health service and educational system are all crumbling. The patience of the Russian people is legendary, but further cuts may lead to political destabilization and the destruction of what central influence remains over important provinces, which depend on subsidies from Moscow.
The state does of course desperately need to raise more tax revenue and stop the leaching away of state money through corruption. But rhetorical promises of tax reform made to the I.M.F. and the West are meaningless when many tax inspectors also work for organized crime. In addition, cutting down the ability of the "oligarchs" to extract financial support from the state (in the form of bailouts, for instance) is essential, but it would involve great dangers for Russia's political stability, since they still hold substantial power.
Thus building up the state's capacity to again play an effective economic role will be the work of years. During that time, even successful economic reform would yield little in the critically important area of direct foreign investment, given Russia's record and the general international mood regarding emerging markets.
So for the foreseeable future, the most important task of the desperately sick central state will be simply to survive. And there can be no doubt that it is in our interest that it do so. It is a cliche but a true one: the greatest dangers for the West today come not from Russian strength but from Russian weakness. When, for example, American politicians of both parties stress our critical interest in the security of Russia's nuclear weapons and materials, they are doing no more than pointing out an obvious truth.
As to the argument that Russia is already in effect a rogue state, this collapses as soon as Russia is compared with the real rogues. Russia in the 1990's did, after all, withdraw its troops from the areas of greatest Western interest, Central Europe and the Baltic states. It has reached a peaceful compromise with its most important neighbor, Ukraine. And it has neither sponsored international terrorism nor invaded an independent neighbor. Although much of Russian foreign policy may well have been deeply irritating to the United States, it is not clear that in practice it was more hostile to real American interests than the policies of, say, India, with whom the United States nonetheless maintains pragmatic, useful relations without either illusions or hysteria.
Finally, it is worth noting that some of those who seem intent on flogging the half-dead Russian bear -- Henry Kissinger and Zbigniew Brzezinski, for instance -- also advocate amicable American relations with China. But the events of recent weeks suggest that China will be no friend of the United States any time soon. In such a climate, driving Russia away from the West would violate the rules of geopolitics as laid down by Dr. Kissinger himself; indeed, an alliance between Russian military technology and Chinese numbers would be one of the few things that might in the long term prove a real threat to American hegemony.
This makes it worth our while to prevent Russia's isolation -- and if that requires more money from the I.M.F., that is really not a large price to pay.

HEADLINE: GAME THEORY;
On 2067 Battleground, 1999 Political Passions

BYLINE: By J. C. Herz; E-mail address: Herz@nytimes.com

 BODY:
THE year is 2067, and the United Nations Starship Unity hurtles through space. Behind it: Earth, ravaged by war, famine and disease. Ahead: a planet orbiting Alpha Centauri, where humankind can make a new start. Aboard: thousands of cryogenically frozen men and women with the skills to create a new society.
Of course, things go disastrously awry. A reactor malfunction destroys the ship's communications equipment and thaws the passengers ahead of schedule. Aboard a damaged ship, with no way to re-establish contact with Earth, the command team argues about how best to proceed. Without consensus, chaos ensues. Factions consolidate around the seven most powerful leaders, each of whom has a different vision of how society should function in the new world. As the planet rises in the near distance, the ship splits along ideological lines, with each faction boarding a separate landing pod to the planet's surface. 
 Thus begins Sid Meier's Alpha Centauri, a strategy game that marries Sim City to Frank Herbert's "Dune." Unlike most strategy games, in which all players have the same agenda (economic dominance or military conquest), Alpha Centauri simulates a complex competitive world where agendas often diverge.
Each faction plays by a different set of rules, based on its values, economic behavior and political philosophy. The Gaians, for instance, are die-hard Greens led by a lissome Scottish botanist. Appalled by the environmental atrocities on Earth, they are determined to live in harmony with the planet. They are incredibly good at harnessing natural resources in a sustainable fashion. They are fabulously efficient and highly democratic. They are also pacifists. That becomes a problem.
Contrast that with Morgan Industries, led by a Namibian diamond tycoon whose only goal is untrammeled economic growth. The Morganites' values are corporate, and their ideology is unfettered laissez-faire capitalism. They require lots of resources to sustain their high standard of living, and a healthy police force to keep the underclass from burning down their luxury high-rises. But they don't like war either. It's bad for business.
War is no problem for the Lord's Believers, a fundamentalist group whose leader hails from the Christian States of America. Hostile acts against nonbelievers send morale through the roof. But because its value system is based on faith, rather than knowledge, the group has trouble developing new technology.
At the University of Planet, new technology is a way of life. Led by a Russian cybernetics genius, these are the hackers, the techno-utopians and pure scientists with fast network access and really cool toys who believe that research and development will solve everything. Open networks accelerate the pace of discovery. Unfortunately, they also make those discoveries easy to steal, but hey, information wants to be free.
In the Human Hive, an atheist, totalitarian collective, information is never free. By order of Chairman Sheng-Ji Yang, private property and civil rights have been abolished. Any individual sacrifice is justified for the greater good. Housed in underground fortresses, the Hive is a paragon of centralized control: xenophobic, disciplined and heavily armed.
In contrast, the Spartan Federation, rallied by the ship's chief of security, is a highly decentralized group of paramilitary survivalists whose only binding philosophy is the right to bear arms.
And finally, there is the Peacekeeping Forces, whose East Indian commissioner hews to the United Nations' humanitarian, democratic ideals -- and battles the plague of bureaucratic inefficiency.
As the leader of any given faction, you explore the planet, build cities, conduct research and confront other groups. You may resolve the inevitable conflicts diplomatically. If you are suitably equipped, you may also wipe rival factions off the face of the map. You can violate treaties. You can lie. You can commit atrocities, if you're willing to make enemies and incur sanctions. You can spark dissent. Or you can cooperate to achieve a higher goal -- engineering a global trade agreement, solving an environmental crisis or pulling off a project that no single group can achieve on its own.
How you play depends on what you're trying to win. You can win a standard military victory by conquering everyone. You can win a diplomatic victory by getting yourself elected planetary governor. Or you can achieve economic dominance by cornering the world energy market. Alternately, you can shoot for Ascent to Transcendence, the ultimate stage of human evolution -- a spiritual triumph that requires staggering amounts of technology.
When different players strive for different kinds of victory, the game becomes something more than king of the hill or Monopoly. It gets complicated -- and interesting. There are natural alliances and natural antipathies and shifting constituencies, sudden betrayals and conciliatory back-scratching. There are questions about expediency and questions about trust, particularly when you're playing against other human beings in real time -- or on-line games that involve a combination of human beings and computer opponents.
"On line, people mostly gang up on the computer," said Mr. Meier, who has only recently turned to science fiction after designing historical simulation games like Gettysburg and Civilization. "They band together to beat the artificial intelligence. And then when they've beaten the computer, they'll go after each other.
"But sometimes, maybe they're so invested in building these cities and getting their societies up and running that they don't want it to end. But when someone wins, by conquest or ascent or whatever, that's it, the game's over. The world goes away. So someone says, 'Hold off, I'm working on a really cool technology right now, let's just keep it going.' If someone looks like he's going to win militarily, they just all keep him from doing that. They agree not to end the game."
In on-line geopolitics, sometimes a stalemate is as good as it gets.
 
Alpha Centauri, developed by Firaxis, published by Electronic Arts; CD-ROM for Windows 95 and 98; $49.95.

HEADLINE: Fed Sees Continuing Strong Growth With Low Inflation

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 17

 BODY:
The economy's run of strong growth and low inflation shows few signs of changing, the Federal Reserve's latest regional survey showed today.
The Fed cited rising consumer spending, higher vehicle sales, expanded manufacturing, gains in construction and a pickup in business lending as evidence that the eight-year economic expansion continues. 
 If anything, what little inflation there is may be abating. "Low commodity prices and a perceived lack of pricing power by firms helped keep prices stable during January and February," said the report, commonly known as the beige book. Prices were "generally steady" in all districts, except for that served by the Dallas Federal Reserve Bank, where "price declines outnumbered price increases."
At the same time, the Fed said companies reported difficulty finding qualified workers and said wages were rising faster than in previous months. The survey also showed "some further gains in economic activity in January and February, despite weakness in agriculture and a few manufacturing industries."
The report found strength in consumer spending and said retail sales were "substantially higher than a year ago." At the same time, "inventories were balanced and in line with future sales expectations," the report said.
The regional outlook is based on reports from the Fed's 12 district banks. It is published eight times each year. The latest edition was compiled by the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond based on data collected before March 8.
The report will help form the basis for discussion on the target interest rate on overnight loans between banks at the March 30 meeting of the Fed's policy-setting panel, the Federal Open Market Committee.
Among the few trouble spots the report cited, it noted that "foreign competition and low energy prices depressed textile, apparel and energy-related industries."
In addition, it said, "agriculture continued to be plagued by low farm commodity prices, and an increasing number of farmers were under financial stress."
In one inflation-related comment, the report said, "finding qualified workers has become more difficult in several districts, and reports of faster wage increases were more widespread than in recent months." Still, it said, "several districts said that businesses remain reluctant to press for price increases."
The economy will grow at a 2.5 percent to 3 percent pace this year and the Consumer Price Index will rise by 2 percent to 2.5 percent, the Fed said. In addition, the central bank expects the unemployment rate to stay close to its current level throughout the next two years, ranging between 4.25 percent and 4.5 percent.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Protecting a patient's rights without inviting lawsuits.

BYLINE: By Michael M. Weinstein 

 BODY:
WHO should control patient care -- doctors at the patient's bedside or doctors working for the patient's insurance company? The Senate Labor Committee appears poised to answer "neither" when it votes this week on patient protections.
The committee plans to turn the ultimate decision in cases where bedside physicians and insurance companies disagree over to expert panels, some at faraway academic medical centers. Exactly how to carry out external review remains controversial. But if the idea is handled creatively, it could sweep away the brawl over legal liability that doomed last year's efforts to pass a patients' "bill of rights." 
 Democrats and Republicans acknowledge the need to respond to patient complaints that health plans persistently deny them reimbursement for necessary medical care. The number of such complaints is small, but the ones with merit can reflect callous behavior by health plans. The Democrats have led the way in proposing changes. Until now, they have focused on giving patients covered at work the right, largely prohibited under current law, to sue health plans for economic and punitive damages. But that almost certainly won't fly, given that a Republican-controlled Congress is highly unlikely to approve what would amount to a trial lawyers relief act.
So what's the alternative? Some advocates admit privately that the right to sue may not be necessary, at least for the near future, if Congress passes two other provisions as part of an overall bill. The first would guarantee that patients could appeal denials to an outside panel of experts. The second, recently proposed by two Senators, Jack Reed, Democrat of Rhode Island, and Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon, would have states set up networks of counselors to guide patients through appeals to their plan and to external panels.
Though the principle of mandatory external review garners bipartisan support, actual proposals do not. The Democrats propose defining medically necessary care in law, using what might be called a prudent doctor test: Is the doctor following generally accepted principles of professional medical practice. The Democrats would prohibit plans from arbitrarily interfering with the decision of the treating physician. What could be wrong with those standards?
"Plenty," replies Karen Ignagni, president of the American Association of Health Plans, which represents about 1,000 private managed-care plans. She says the Democratic language, though saying it leaves the decision up to expert panels, "in fact stops them, as well as the health plan, from reviewing whether decisions by physicians are medically appropriate."
Dr. Robert H. Brook of RAND Health recently testified, after reviewing dozens of studies, that "20 to 30 percent of the care given to patients is unnecessary," yet "patients do not receive perhaps as many as one-third of services they should receive." Ms. Ignagni fears that the Democrats' bill would insulate customary, often wasteful, practices from challenge.
Mary Nell Lehnhard of the Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association, agrees. "If the plans are forced to prove that each inappropriate treatment is in fact inappropriate, we will turn back the clock to the days of unnecessary overtreatment and unchecked medical inflation," she says.
So how should expert panels make decisions in a world where physician practices vary widely? Should the burden of providing proof be placed on the plan or the physician? Because scientific evidence is often indecisive, the side that bears the burden of proof may often lose the appeal.
David Richardson, president of an organization that performs external review for Medicare enrollees and private plans, would ordinarily allow plans to choose treatments from among those customarily practiced unless the panel found that the treatment was inappropriate.
The bill proposed by James M. Jeffords of Vermont, the Republican chairman of the Senate Labor Committee, answers the question by not answering the question. He would not define medical necessity or place the burden of proof on either side, essentially leaving it up to the expert panels to decide by a preponderance of the scientific and medical evidence, however murky.
The new wrinkle in the debate is the emergence of managed-care leaders who embrace external review. President Michael Stocker of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield of New York State says that external panels of experts can be trusted to make the right decisions if they are held up to professional scrutiny because "there usually is general agreement." Dr. Arthur Leibowitz, medical director of Aetna U.S. Healthcare, which already offers enrollees the right to external appeal, agrees, though he opposes Federal mandates.
Mandating external appeal is only part of the solution, Senator Wyden says. The Reed-Wyden bill, supported by patient advocates like Ron Pollack, executive director of Families USA Foundation, would turn money over to the states to set up networks of counselors to help steer patients through appeals. The idea, Mr. Wyden says, "is to intervene early, resolving modest-sized grievances in a nonadversarial way before they mushroom into huge grievances that need costly litigation." Supporters of the proposal expect it to soften the controversy over litigation by largely eliminating the need to take health plans to court if and when Congress makes that possible.

SECTION: Section A; Page 22; Column 2; National Desk 

LENGTH: 505 words

HEADLINE: Raise in the House May Be Desirable, but a Vote on It Isn't

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 17

 BODY:
There are few things members of Congress want more than a raise and little they like less than to be seen voting one for themselves.
This year Representative Bill Thomas, the California Republican who is chairman of the committee that sets the rules for expense accounts, began shopping around for a way to solve the conundrum. 
 Mr. Thomas proposed having his committee change the rules so that representatives, if they chose to, could pocket a portion of their expense accounts tax free in the form of a $125 per diem. The matter would never have to come to a vote.
But The Hill, a weekly newspaper about Congress, got wind of the plan and published an account of it today. By this afternoon, it stood about as much chance of being carried out as a surtax on comb-overs.
"This dog ain't going to hunt," said a top staff assistant who had taken soundings on the issue.
Mr. Thomas, who heads the Committee on House Administration, did not return telephone calls. He issued a statement tonight saying that his committee would consider the per diem proposal only if it had the approval of the leadership of both parties. Which by then it clearly did not.
John P. Feehery, a spokesman for Speaker J. Dennis Hastert, said the Speaker had not endorsed the plan.
Laura Nichols, a spokeswoman for Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the Democratic leader, said Mr. Gephardt had told the Speaker he would think about the proposal but would support it only if a vote was allowed.
In 1989, Congress thought it had solved the pay problem once and for all.
Under a measure passed that year, lawmakers became entitled to an automatic annual raise -- 0.5 percentage points less than the employment cost index, a measure of inflation that many businesses use to give their workers cost of living raises.
For a few years, this worked. But almost every year since 1993, one representative or another has proposed that the raise be blocked. That required a vote. And except for 1997, the lawmakers denied themselves the automatic pay increase.
Representatives and senators now make $136,700 a year. They also get an expense account, or representational allowance, that ranges from $859,000 to $1.3 million. The money is used for rents and other office expenses, air fares home and other costs.
The actual amount is based on factors including how far their district is from Washington and how much it costs to rent office space in their districts.
Under Mr. Thomas's plan, representatives would have been permitted to dip into this account and pay themselves $125 every day the House was in session. If the House met 160 days during a year -- an average of four days a week for 40 weeks -- that would amount to $20,000.
Per diems are common practice in state legislatures, where salaries are generally lower. In his statement, Mr. Thomas said he had often been asked by colleagues why the House did not have a similar allowance.
"It is a good question, which is why members of both parties have discussed this," he said.

HEADLINE: Worldwide Chip Sales Up 1.2% in January

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: SAN JOSE, Calif., March 17

 BODY:
Worldwide semiconductor sales rose 1.2 percent in January from a year earlier, as rising demand in Europe and much of Asia offset lower sales in the Americas.
Chip sales for January rose to $11.1 billion from $10.97 billion in January 1998. Sales for the month were 1.9 percent less than December. January sales are usually lower than those in December, according to the Semiconductor Industry Association. 
 Sales in the Americas fell 2.7 percent in January from a year earlier. European sales rose 2.8 percent, while sales in Asia other than Japan were up 9.1 percent, the association said. Sales in Japan fell 2.5 percent.
The association's president, George Scalise, said in a statement that in Asia "economic reforms brought on by the financial crisis are taking effect."
"January's sales," he said, "reflect a continuation of the strength of semiconductor sales that began to emerge in the fourth quarter."

HEADLINE: Russia's Patchwork Economy;
KoreanCompanies, Chinese Workers and U.S. Entree

BYLINE: By RUSSELL WORKING 

DATELINE: VLADIVOSTOK, Russia, March 17

 BODY:
It is well after dark on a recent evening, but the red brick garment factory on a bluff overlooking the Sea of Japan is ablaze with light. From inside the building comes a haunting song, unfamiliar in this overwhelmingly Russian city: the seamstresses are singing in Chinese.
Of the many incongruities born of the increasingly complex global economy, this may be among the strangest. For here at Russia's eastern extremity, Chinese workers labor alongside Russians making clothes for a South Korean company, which put its factory here partly to do an end run around United States quotas on apparel imports. 
 And Russia, which had visions of reinventing itself as a world-class market economy, now finds itself in the company of nations like Indonesia and El Salvador, attractive to outside investors in part for its rock-bottom wages. Seamstresses here often work six days a week, and for as little as 11 cents an hour.
The factory is owned by S. H. International, one of a growing number of South Korean companies making clothes in Russia, in this case T-shirts and sweatshirts, that often end up in American stores like the Gap.
Similar factories have popped up in 10 cities in the Russian Far East, from the hardscrabble town of Partizansk, where three of the four coal mines have closed in the last two years, to Vladivostok, a port city of 700,000 that until 1992 was off-limits to foreigners.
American apparel companies have long farmed out work to manufacturers in low-wage countries. But in an elaborate global system known as the Multi-Fiber Arrangement, which is supposed to be dismantled by 2005, the United States, like Europe, established restrictions on imports from countries whose exports were thought to threaten the domestic apparel industry. South Korean textile companies, limited by American quotas for decades, have sent their cloth to be sewn in faraway factories in the Caribbean and Latin America, which face no such quotas. But now South Koreans are finding a new place to set up shop.
"Through other countries such as Russia you can enter the United States essentially through the back door," said Charles Kernaghan, director of the National Labor Committee, an industry watchdog group based in New York.
For Russia, the apparel companies are a double-edged sword. They provide jobs in a region desperate for investment, and in some cases they reopen closed Soviet-era factories. But some critics fear that the presence of Chinese laborers living on factory grounds is an invitation for the sweatshop conditions common to many South Korean factories in Latin America.
"There's not much good in the whole arrangement, but there's a deficit of jobs here," said Aleksandr Prosekov, deputy chairman of the Committee for Industry in the Primorye Regional Administration, which includes Vladivostok. "At least they pay salaries regularly."
The United States is unlikely to object to the imports from Russia. A Commerce Department official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said the practice was legal as long as there was "substantial transformation" of the clothing in Russia. Furthermore, she said, the United States will not impose any serious quotas on Russia as long as imports do not harm American industry. While the United States does set limits on imports of women's and girls' coats, there are no such limits on the production of clothing of the sort made here, polo shirts, sweatshirts and sweaters, which is growing domestically as well.
Vladivostok is only 440 miles from Seoul, South Korea, but it offers a bargain-rate work force. The average hourly cost of an apparel industry employee in South Korea in 1998 was $2.69, including wages, taxes and benefits, according to industry figures. Though that seems stingy compared with the $10.12 United States average, the average Russian hourly cost is just 56 cents.
The Russian figure is less than half that of Guatemala, where the majority of sewing factories are owned by South Koreans, and comparable to China's, where employers say apparel workers cost an average of 43 cents an hour. But exports from Russia, unlike those from China, face few trade restrictions.
These figures, low as they are, probably do not reflect the true take-home pay, according to the National Labor Committee, which has studied wage rates in China and Latin America. And Eastern workers earn far less than the industry averages for Russia. Russian seamstresses at S. H. International, for example, earned 21 cents an hour on average when the regional administration's Committee for Industry last surveyed local wages in October. The average Chinese worker at S. H. earned 11 cents an hour. S. H.'s general director, Hak J. Lee, declined to discuss specific figures at the factory.
The issue of outsourcing -- farming out work to outside manufacturers -- is a sensitive one for American companies, which have been criticized over labor practices of their producers abroad. A Gap Inc. spokeswoman, Kristy Van Koughnet, declined to answer questions about the company's suppliers in Russia and said that questions relating to employment practices should be addressed to the factories in Russia. "Anything about where we outsource is considered proprietary information," she said.
After a reporter asked about conditions in Russian factories, Gap sent officials to look at several sites. At a plant in Partizansk, workers then began receiving free lunch in the canteen, and the company increased wages. After the raise, one worker said she received $49.56 for a month that included several six-day work weeks.
The apparel makers have set up shop in unlikely places. Partizansk, a town of 65,000 three hours by car from Vladivostok, might not seem an ideal multinational manufacturing and trade center. Pensioners wheezing from black lung disease pick through heaps of stones outside abandoned mine shafts, looking for coal to burn.
But the Seoul-based Seishin Apparel Company bought and remodeled a bankrupt Soviet-era clothing factory there in 1997 for $760,000 to expand sales in America, its general director, Joo In Ha, said. The Russian subsidiary, Koruss, sold $1.68 million worth of sweatshirts, dresses and polo shirts to Gap in 1998.
Vera Karas, a manager at Koruss, said the regional administration initially resisted the company, fearing it might exploit workers. "But that's not going to happen," she said. Ms. Karas, who worked at the factory when it was Russian-owned, said that the Korean owners treated employees well and hired some Russian managers, like her. Since last May, she added, wages have more than doubled. (When figured in dollars, though, they have actually fallen as the ruble collapsed.)
Some 600 cutters, seamstresses and others work at tables in Koruss's warehouse-sized rooms, cutting piles of fabric and sewing dresses, sweatshirts, sweaters and polo shirts. Most of them are Russian women; some of the new hires are Chinese. They regularly work five 9- or 10-hour days, and often spend Saturdays at the sewing machines as well. Koruss employees are paid extra for overtime work, but at S. H. International in Vladivostok, workers said their overtime pay an hour was less than their regular hourly pay.
While filling a big order in November, Koruss employees worked several seven-day weeks, they said. (Ms. Karas said this was untrue.)
"You can only go to the toilet when a bell rings," said a 19-year-old former Koruss employee who quit after a month. "If they catch you talking, you get in trouble." She added: "Sometimes we didn't leave until 7 P.M. For those who have families, I don't know how they do it."
Some employees, however, say the work is very welcome. Lyubov Vonyagina, 54, a veteran seamstress, is part of a team that must produce 1,900 T-shirts a day. When they fall short, they stay late. Still, Ms. Vonyagina says she is not overworked, and she scoffs at younger workers who complain. "They aren't used to hard work," she said.
The decision to hire Chinese workers has stirred up anger in some factory towns. City officials in Artyom, 22 miles north of Vladivostok, have criticized a request by Newmax Apparel of South Korea to hire 75 Chinese workers, the daily Vladivostok newspaper reported on Tuesday. Officials also asked the company to double wages and stop requiring seamstresses to work overtime.
In Partizansk, Koruss imported 75 ethnic Koreans from northeastern China because, said Mr. Joo, the general director, there are simply not enough skilled workers in Partizansk to fill orders. But some townspeople are hostile to the idea.
"We don't need the Chinese here," said Lyudmila Samoilova, 43, a single mother of five who runs a newspaper kiosk across the street from Koruss. "There aren't enough jobs for our own people."
Nina Gudozhnikova, director of the Partizansk office of the federal employment service, worries that because Chinese workers at home put in 12-hour days and get only two days off a month, the South Korean factories in Russia will impose similar schedules on its workers. Still, she approved the factory's labor agreement because the women of Partizansk need jobs. "I signed this agreement with serious doubts," she said.
In Vladivostok, at S. H. International, which is owned by the Sunghan Company, 384 Russians work alongside 218 Chinese employees, according to Sergei Kurakin, chairman of the regional Committee for Industry. Two women from Liaoning province in China said they lived on the plant site and worked about 10 hours a day. Like many Chinese traders and workers in the Russian Far East, they say they will be here only for a short time.
Russian workers said the Chinese struck for two days in December because of low wages. But the Chinese, who said they could get in trouble for talking about their work, declined to discuss the matter. "Basically, I came to Russia out of curiosity, as well as to earn some money," one seamstress said.
At a time when most unpaid Russian workers survive on what they can grow in their gardens or borrow from their pensioner parents, many seamstresses are grateful that South Korean companies are investing in the region. Others say they simply must take whatever work they can get. A 30-year-old mother of two complained of a dirty work environment, and a boss who blocked the doors at S. H. and refused to allow employees to leave at the end of their shift.
Mr. Lee, the general director, said, "I didn't do that." Like other South Korean companies, S. H. said it followed Russian labor laws.
In any case, the worker who complained plans to keep showing up on the job. "We have no choice," she said. "We either have to sit at home and go hungry, or go to work in these conditions."
