HEADLINE: Renault Offer To Nissan Is Questioned

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, March 17

 BODY:
Having failed in previous international mergers in the United States and elsewhere, Renault S.A. is encountering considerable skepticism in financial markets following the French auto maker's offer for a large stake in heavily indebted Nissan Motor Company of Japan.
Credit rating agencies said today that they were reviewing Renault's finances, the company's stock fell sharply and investors questioned whether the proposal Renault announced on Tuesday would solve either company's problems. 
 While Mack Trucks has done fairly well since Renault bought it nearly a decade ago, a planned merger with A.B. Volvo fell apart in 1993 after Swedish managers complained that their French colleagues were pushing them around.
Renault's most notable failure in an auto marriage came when it took control of the American Motors Corporation in several stages in the early 1980's. Cultural differences produced managerial chaos. Then Renault sold the company to the Chrysler Corporation in 1987, just a few years before the sport utility vehicle boom made American Motors' Jeep brand one of the most valuable businesses in the auto industry.
Gerald Meyers, a chairman and chief executive of American Motors who quit in 1982 after clashing with Renault, predicted today that Renault and Nissan would not be able to work together. "I can't think of any two cultures that are in more conflicts than these -- they're both not interested in somebody else's ideas," he said.
There is also the question of what Renault sees in Nissan that other auto makers have already dismissed as unworthy of their time. DaimlerChrysler quit talks with Nissan a week ago.
The Ford Motor Company held talks with Nissan about taking a stake earlier this year, but the two sides never even reached the point of exchanging detailed financial information, said auto executives who insisted on anonymity.
Ford's wariness about Nissan reflects the American auto maker's suspicion of Japanese auto maker finances in general. Ford bought 25 percent of Mazda in 1979, but only after increasing its stake to 33.4 percent in 1996, and installing some of its own executives to help run Mazda, did Ford discover that Mazda's dealerships had incurred enormous debts for which Mazda was liable, the auto executives said.
Renault's stock fell 6.2 percent today in trading in Paris, following its announcement late Tuesday that it would seek to buy 35 percent of Nissan, and reportedly offering $5.3 billion for it. Renault's shares have tumbled 28 percent since the company confirmed on Jan. 18 that it wanted to invest in Nissan.
One of the main concerns among credit rating agencies in their review of Renault is Nissan's debt load. Scott Sprinzen, the managing director for auto ratings at Standard & Poor's, said that the agency had concerns about "the extent to which Renault could benefit from an investment in such a financially weak company, and whether the two companies working together could effect an operational turnaround at Nissan."
Estimates of Nissan's debt start at $20 billion but run much higher because no one outside the company knows its full liability for borrowing by various Nissan affiliates. Nissan's shares also fell 1.7 percent in Tokyo today as investors fretted over how long it would take the company to find a partner.
Another issue for auto industry experts today lay in Renault's willingness to take a stake in Nissan without divulging any plan for combining activities and cutting costs. To increase their profits significantly, the two companies must combine vehicle development programs, auto parts purchasing and their distribution of cars and other vehicles, said John A. Casesa, an auto analyst at Schroder & Company.
"To take advantage of four million units of volume, the two companies really have to become one," Mr. Casesa said. "That'll mean head count reductions, a lot of management reshuffling."
Yet Nissan and Renault are each approaching the deal as a way to avoid cutbacks while retaining separate management structures. The French Government owns 44.2 percent of Renault, and the French transport minister, Jean-Claude Gayssot, portrayed the potential business combination today as a way to avoid reductions in staffing.
"I have no concerns about decisions over merging or restructuring," he said. "My concern is that the potential to develop our businesses and our activities should translate into a strengthening of those activities and in the defense and promotion of employment."
Acquiring a large stake in Nissan would make Renault less reliant on the French market. Renault is only now developing sport utility vehicles and luxury sedans, the two market segments in which other global auto makers are making most of their profits, and could tap Nissan's experience in both classes of vehicles. Nissan also has more factories than it needs, and some of this extra capacity could be used to sell Nissan cars through Renault's extensive distribution network in France and elsewhere.
The most profitable auto market in the world now is in the United States, because of the strong economy. But Renault only sells Mack trucks here, and it's unclear to what extent Nissan's American operations will help Renault.
Nissan lost nearly $700 million here last year as it relied too heavily on discounts and offered small, fuel- efficient vehicles that did not sell well because of cheap gas prices.
Nissan's American operations plan to introduce six new or redesigned models later this year and have already reduced inventories and limited discounts, which should make the operations break even this year, said Jason Vines, a company spokesman. But Mr. Casesa said that while Nissan's coming cars were better designed, stiff competition would make a quick financial improvement difficult.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
Signs of Healing in Emerging Markets

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
It is like the tree falling in the forest when no one is around. But quietly, some emerging stock markets have turned around after a year in which their sector dropped 25 percent as a whole and some individual markets plunged more than 40 percent.
The Mexican stock market is up 26 percent this year in dollar terms. In India, the market is up 20 percent, also in dollars, while South Africa is up 13 percent. Even Brazil is rebounding for American investors. Its Bovespa index is up 57 percent in local terms and has just moved into the positive category in dollar terms. Three-quarters of one percentage point is not much, but it's far better than the more than 29 percent decline the market rebounded from in January, when the Brazilian currency was devalued. 
 In their local currencies, all four markets are above or near where they were before the Russian debt crisis in August. And when the performance numbers for the first quarter come out, these and other markets are going to be at the top of the list, and the secret will be out.
This rally may not -- and maybe should not -- attract individual investors right away. Last year, according to AMG Data Services, investors pulled $4 billion out of emerging market mutual funds and have withdrawn another $585 million so far this year.
But money managers may have to take a look soon, even if they don't rush in, just because the returns are so fat.
Jay Pelosky, the global emerging-markets strategist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, argues that managers of global equity funds should consider returning because the extreme volatility in emerging markets, which helped lead to major losses the last year and a half, has begun to decline. In other words, the waters are less turbulent.
Just this week, he recommended moving more money into Brazil, pushing the investment there above Brazil's share of the Latin American market. Earlier this year, he moved to a similar position in Mexico.
"We are still at the cusp of the turn," he said, adding that this year's rallies have so far been propelled by local investors and some speculative money.
So if these money managers do come back, Mr. Pelosky said emerging markets would get a big boost. That is because this is so-called nondedicated money -- the money that does not have to be in emerging markets -- rather than the funds whose mission is to buy stocks there.
Global money managers, he said, should be looking for value stocks, the well-run companies whose prices have been beaten down too far in the indiscriminate flight from Latin America. "There are highly qualified companies that have been battle-tested," he said.
So far, however, he said his clients were still being cautious. "Some are looking and some are kicking the tires," he said. "Some are buying a little, but not much."
Many money managers, he said, are still asking "what kind of damage can emerging markets do to me, not what kind of opportunities there are."
Diego Espinosa, co-manager of the $1.6 billion Scudder Global Fund, is one of those money managers who is again thinking about emerging markets. While he is not jumping in at all, he is kicking the tires, which is a change for him.
What is moving Mr. Espinosa is a marked change in the atmosphere in emerging markets in just the last month and a half, probably best dated from the appointment of Arminio Fraga Neto, a former manager of one of George Soros's biggest investment funds, as the new president of the Brazilian central bank.
From the fear of debt defaults in January, Mr. Fraga and the Brazilian Government are now entertaining proposals from American investment bankers on how to go back to the global bond market to raise new and needed capital. Mexico and Argentina have had successful bond sales. And the two other major Latin American economies have dodged any downdraft from Brazil, so far. "There seems to be some sort of decoupling going on," said Desmond Lachman, director of emerging-markets economic research at Salomon Smith Barney.
"The stabilized environment has allowed us to look at stocks in the region on a bottom-up basis," Mr. Espinosa said. This is a stock-by- stock approach that is still cautious, looking for undervalued stocks but precluding any big immediate moves. And he is still uncomfortable in Brazil.
Before the Asian financial crisis and the subsequent Russian financial crisis sent emerging markets reeling, money managers thought of these markets as a group or, in investment jargon, an asset class. At that time, getting into emerging markets was buying the asset class. The choice was being in emerging markets, not being in a particular stock. Money moved faster that way.
And at that time the emerging- market asset class was thought to be good for the diversification of a portfolio. Emerging markets could be generally counted on to be contrarian, so they would go up when other markets were falling.
But now, Mr. Espinosa said, emerging markets seem to be following the rest of the world's markets, especially when they decline. And that means there is no diversification benefit in emerging markets, which had helped offset the higher risk of being in them. "We have not got the diversification benefit we expected," he said.
What would be ideal, Mr. Espinosa added, would be to have stronger worldwide growth, which is always good for emerging stock markets, and a return to the benefits of diversifying into those markets.
But until then, he will be looking stock by stock, which means his return may be much slower than Mr. Pelosky would hope.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

House Votes to Put Limits on Steel Imports
The House voted decisively to limit steel imports, ignoring opposition from the Republican leadership and an almost certain veto by the White House, which argues that the measure would violate world trade agreements.
The bill -- the first major trade measure of the new session of Congress -- directs the United States to limit annual steel imports from other nations to about 29 million tons of steel. It would be up to the Administration to decide whether to do so through quotas, tariffs or voluntary agreements. Page A1. 

Global Crossing to Buy Frontier
Global Crossing of Bermuda, a new international communications carrier, said it had agreed to acquire Frontier, which serves almost one million telephone customers in 13 states, for $10.8 billion in stock. Just three weeks ago, Global Crossing hired as its chief executive Robert Annunziata, who had run AT&T's business services unit after selling his previous company, Teleport Communications Group, to AT&T for more than $11 billion. C2.
 
Kodak to Sell Copier Operations
Eastman Kodak, which has long viewed its copier business as a liability, said it would sell most of its copier manufacturing operations to a German company. C5.
 
Airbus to Postpone Reorganization
Airbus Industrie, the passenger jet consortium owned by four European companies, will not transform itself into a single corporation this year, its chief financial officer said. C4.
 
Stocks Back Off From 10,000
Stocks fell a day after the Dow Jones industrial average briefly topped 10,000 points for the first time. The Dow fell 51.06 points, to 9,879.41. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 8.54 points, to 1,297.82. The Nasdaq composite index slipped 10.30 points, to 2,428.97. In the bond market, Treasury prices fell as the yield on the 30-year issue rose to 5.50 percent, from 5.47 percent on Tuesday. Prices fell on concern that $15 billion of corporate debt sales would draw demand away from Treasury securities in coming days. C8.
 
Donaldson, Lufkin Making Its Mark
The investment bank Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, which rarely holds a top spot among mergers-and-acquisitions advisers, has made an impressive showing so far this year, advising on several recent high-profile deals. The company's shares, which fell $3.0625, to $65.75, in part because of uncertainty about plans for a stock that tracks its on-line business, are up 39 percent since January. C2.
 
Fed Survey Sees More Growth
The economy's run of strong growth and low inflation shows few signs of changing, the Federal Reserve's latest regional survey showed, citing rising consumer spending, expanded manufacturing, gains in construction and a pickup in business lending. C6.
 
Olivetti Adds to Takeover Offer
Olivetti sweetened its $60 billion takeover offer for Telecom Italia by proposing to buy back 30 percent of the phone company's savings shares if its hostile bid succeeded. C5.
 
Magazine Stripped of Nomination
The American Society of Magazine Editors has stripped a magazine of nominations for the society's National Magazine awards for not complying with guidelines regarding the separation of advertising and editorial content. This Old House was to receive one nomination for the coveted category of general excellence and one for design. C7.

HEADLINE: The Big City;
Call to Resist Easy Promises Of Milk Cartel

BYLINE: By JOHN TIERNEY 

 BODY:
IT'S not surprising that dairy farmers would like New Yorkers to pay more for milk, or that politicians want to oblige the farmers. But why are environmental groups supporting this cause when it may end up harming the environment even more than consumers?
New York farmers want to join the Northeast Interstate Dairy Compact, a New England group that sets milk prices. Urban politicians and consumer groups have opposed the cartel, arguing that the burden of higher milk prices -- perhaps 15 cents a gallon on average -- would fall most heavily on poor families with children. But the farmers recently prevailed in the State Legislature, and are now seeking final approval from Congress. 
 The cartel has been championed by Gov. George E. Pataki and other upstate Republicans, who have set aside their own professed belief in the free market. The cartel is also being supported by some Democrats, including Senator Charles E. Schumer, and an array of environmental groups like the Adirondack Council, the National Audubon Society, the Natural Resources Defense Council and the Sierra Club.
"Dairy farms provide cultural and natural landscape preservation," said David Miller, the executive director of the New York State office of the National Audubon Society. "We want to protect them against suburban sprawl and preserve habitat for birds and other species."
It's true that New York has been losing dairyland -- about five million acres since 1960, according to Nelson Bills, an agricultural economist at Cornell University. But most of the abandoned pastures have reverted to brushland and forest, which environmentalists can hardly consider less "natural" than farmland.
"Environmentalists in the cities don't have very clear thinking on this issue," said William Parment, a Democratic Assemblyman and former dairy farmer from rural Chautauqua County who has opposed the dairy cartel. "It's difficult to believe if you're looking around the George Washington Bridge, but the largest change in land use this century in New York State has been from farm field to forests."
What about the minority of dairy farms near cities that might be converted to malls and subdivisions? If the citizens of those communities deem it vital to preserve those farms, they could use general tax revenues to buy development rights from farmers, especially the small farmers that environmentalists want to keep in business. That approach seems more equitable and direct than raising milk prices, which essentially forces consumers to pay a regressive tax that goes mostly to the owners of large farms.
AND the higher prices may well mean less farmland, because consumers would respond by buying less milk. If New Yorkers' milk consumption declined by 1 percent to 2 percent, as economists have projected, the resulting milk glut would render superfluous perhaps 10,000 acres now used by dairy farmers.
In the long run, the dairy policies advocated by environmentalists could even contribute indirectly to the destruction of tropical forests, according to Dennis T. Avery, the director of global food issues for the Hudson Institute, a conservative public policy group in Indianapolis.
"The more that the states and the Federal Government intervene in agriculture," Mr. Avery said, "the more difficult it becomes for the United States to demand that other countries open their markets to our farm products. That's bad news for tropical wildlife. If there were free trade, the countries that are now cutting down tropical forests to create low-quality farmland would instead be buying grain and dairy products from America."
Environmentalists often disdain America's factory farms in favor of the agriculture practiced by traditionalists in the Adirondacks and peasants in the tropics, but those farmers need much more land to grow food. Mr. Avery calculates that the increased efficiency of modern farming has saved an area of land equal to the combined size of Europe, the United States and South America.
"Old MacDonald's farm couldn't feed the planet's population without destroying virtually every square mile of wildlife habitat," Mr. Avery said. "Environmentalists and dairy farmers ought to be increasing trade instead of creating cartels. Rather than raising the price of milk for children, New York farmers should be exporting the milk so India doesn't dispossess the Bengal tiger."

HEADLINE: Japan's Trade Surplus Fell 35.4% in February

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Thursday, March 18

 BODY:
Japan's merchandise trade surplus fell 35.4 percent in February from January as exports declined while imports rose.
The trade surplus fell to a seasonally adjusted 855.2 billion yen, or $7.2 billion, the Ministry of Finance said. Economists polled by Bloomberg News had forecast a 22 percent decline. Compared with the corresponding month last year, the surplus dropped 26.9 percent, to 934.2 billion yen, only the second decline in 23 months. 
 Japan's trade surplus shrank in February from a year earlier as exports to Asia, the United States and Europe all fell. Strong exports to the United States and Europe last year cushioned the impact of plummeting shipments to Asia. Yet slower export growth to Europe and a gradual increase in imports as domestic production picks up should restrain growth in the surplus this year.
"The surplus is probably still slowly heading up but at a much more moderate rate of increase than we saw through last year," said Richard Jerram, head economist at ING Barings Securities Japan, before the figures were released.
The strong yen late last year will likely take a toll on Japanese exports in the second half of 1999, Mr. Jerram said. The dollar plunged 26 percent from Aug. 11 to a low of 108.89 yen on Jan. 11. Currency movements take about a year to affect trade flows, economists say. The dollar was today quoted at 118.18 yen.
In February, exports fell 12.3 percent -- the fifth consecutive monthly drop -- led by declining shipments of steel, semiconductors and cars. By volume, Japanese exports fell 7.4 percent, declining for the 10th consecutive month.
Imports fell 5.7 percent from February last year, in spite of a rise of 1.8 percent in shipments to Asia, the first increase in 14 months. Japanese companies imported more office machinery from Asia.

SECTION: Section A; Page 24; Column 1; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: Saving a Regional Icon

 BODY:
The Federal Government's decision on Tuesday to order new protections for nine threatened salmon populations in the Pacific Northwest is just the beginning of what could be the biggest and most expensive rescue effort in the 26-year history of the Endangered Species Act. It is an effort worth making. The decline of the once-great salmon runs of the Pacific Northwest ranks high among the ecological blunders committed in the name of economic growth. The time has surely come to correct that mistake.
What makes the challenge uniquely interesting is its reach. Salmon spawn throughout the Pacific Northwest, so any effort to save them will have to be regional in scope. The effort will inevitably require higher taxes to clean hundreds of waterways and buy open space in crucial watersheds. It will impose tough restrictions on new construction, farming and logging, and may even require the costly decommissioning of Federal and private dams that impede salmon runs but have also long supplied the Pacific Northwest with cheap power. 
 The early response from local politicians and citizens has been extraordinarily positive. One reason is that the salmon is not only economically important to the Pacific Northwest but is virtually a cultural icon. Beyond that, many local residents are consumed by fears that development will someday destroy the natural beauty that surrounds them. A save-the-salmon effort, with all the restrictions that implies, is thus seen as a timely antidote to shapeless sprawl. As Seattle's Mayor, Paul Schell, noted, "as we work to save the salmon, it may turn out that the salmon save us."
But this battle has a very long way to go. It is one thing to preach salvation. It is quite another to pay the price when the controls kick in -- when farmers have to stop using pesticides, when developers have to stop building in sensitive watersheds, when loggers have to stop cutting trees along salmon-bearing streams. Today's euphoria could easily become tomorrow's backlash.
There are also many questions surrounding the Federal commitment. Washington moved to protect the salmon only because environmental advocacy groups threatened to sue if it did not -- an exact replay of the campaign to save the spotted owl. By listing the salmon as threatened, the Clinton Administration has now saddled itself with an even more onerous responsibility -- insuring that Washington and Oregon develop an effective plan to save the fish. Vice President Gore has promised a special appropriation of $100 million to underwrite a "cooperative restoration effort." But if the states falter, Washington would be obliged under the Endangered Species Act to step in with a variety of legal and regulatory weapons that, in effect, could halt development in its tracks.
An early test of this commitment will come in the next few months when the Administration delivers its long-awaited proposal for restoring several species of salmon in the Snake River that were listed as endangered or threatened back in 1991 and 1992. Some scientists believe that these species will never recover unless the Federal Government dismantles or at least modifies eight dams on the Snake and Columbia Rivers -- a strategy unalterably opposed by many big consumers of electricity and by Washington's powerful Republican Senator, Slade Gorton.
The Administration may find other ways to restore the freshwater flows essential to the salmon's survival. But what matters here is the end result -- recovery. How the Administration responds will tell much about its long-term dedication to the other species listed this week.

HEADLINE: BY A WIDE MARGIN, THE HOUSE VOTES STEEL IMP ORT CURB

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 17

 BODY:
The House voted decisively today to limit steel imports, ignoring opposition from the Republican leadership and a White House warning that the measure would violate world trade agreements.
The 289-to-141 vote -- one short of the two-thirds margin needed to override a Presidential veto -- displayed the division in the Democratic Party over Mr. Clinton's free trade policies as well as the appeal of protectionism to Republicans from Rust Belt states. All but 13 House Democrats deserted the Administration. And 91 Republicans, a surprisingly large number, broke from their party's traditional free-trade position. 
 The bill, the first major trade measure of this session of Congress, directs the United States to limit steel imports from other nations to their average monthly volume for the three-year period ending in July 1997. It would be up to the Administration to decide whether to use quotas, tariffs or voluntary agreements to achieve such a reduction, which could approach 30 percent.
The day's debate and offstage lobbying showed the strange coalitions that have developed over trade policy as well as the growth in protectionist sentiment. When a measure to give the President broad power to negotiate trade deals -- the so-called fast-track authority -- was defeated last year, 71 Republicans voted against it. Today, 20 more Republicans took a stand against unfettered free trade.
With world demand hurt by the Asian financial crisis, foreign steelmakers have sold their products at low prices. The American industry has seen a drop in business while imports rose 33 percent in 1998 before starting to subside in December.
Last month, the Clinton Administration said it would impose tariffs to punish Japan and Brazil for dumping steel in this country at prices below cost and negotiated an agreement with Russia to limit imports.
The stricter limits passed by the House today are unlikely to become law. The bill's fate in the Senate is uncertain, and a Presidential veto is considered likely. In a letter to House members, the White House chief of staff, John Podesta, acknowledged the steel industry crisis but warned that the measure "constitutes a violation of our international obligations" under the World Trade Organization and "is not in our nation's economic interest." He said Mr. Clinton's senior advisers would recommend that he veto the bill.
This vote, though, showed how difficult it will be in this Congress to pass the long-sought measure to give the President the power to negotiate trade agreements and submit them to Congress for a vote without potentially crippling amendments.
Representative J. Dennis Hastert of Illinois, the House Speaker, also opposed the bill as a violation of free trade. But its supporters had enough backing probably to be able to force a vote, and Mr. Hastert let the measure come to the floor. His spokesman, John P. Feehery, said that some Republicans "were pushing very strongly for a debate, and we also wanted to avoid the other parliamentary shenanigans."
The Ways and Means Committee, which strongly favors free trade, reported the bill to the full House with the recommendation that it be defeated.
Pat Buchanan, the G.O.P. Presidential aspirant who has challenged the party's establishment, wrote to House Republicans on Tuesday urging them to support the bill to "regain the loyalty of working Americans."
And Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the Democratic minority leader, spoke out in favor of the bill, giving a hint of the debate that might have been if he had chosen to challenge Vice President Al Gore for next year's Democratic Presidential nomination.
Unions are also working hard for the bill, and the United Steelworkers had several hundred rank-and-file members on hand for the final push. In the last few months, steelworkers have written to Congress and held rallies around the country. Industry and union representatives have complained to the Clinton Administration about the dumping of foreign steel.
"An economic collapse has swept the globe," Mr. Gephardt said, "first striking Asia, but now impacting Latin America and other developing countries as well."
During the debate over special aid from the International Monetary Fund to stabilize these economies, he continued: "I warned that import surges would result from the Asian economic crisis and that a plan needed to be in place to combat unfair imports. Unfortunately, no such plan was forthcoming."
Mr. Gephardt said 10,000 steel jobs had been lost to imports, adding that the United States "should not be forced to unilaterally take in a massive global import surge."
Several senior Republicans argued against the bill, which was sponsored by Representative Peter J. Visclosky, Democrat of Indiana. They contended that the American economy was thriving because of the new markets provided by international trade. They also said the limits proposed could hurt other United States manufacturers by raising steel prices and cutting off the supply of specialized steel products that were only available through imports.
Representative Bill Archer, Republican of Texas, the chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, said that the President and his advisers had studied the steel situation and chose not to set quotas.
"The President's logic is clear," Mr. Archer said. "If the U.S. were to set up trade barriers now in our fragile world economy, we could have a much bigger problem on our hands that would affect thousands more American jobs and threaten our economy. In addition, we would set a terrible example for countries in real economic trouble -- countries whose leaders are under tremendous pressure to retaliate against American-made products."
But Rust Belt Republicans as well as Democrats took the side of the steelworkers and the industry. "We're going to stand up for Main Street today, not Wall Street," said Representative Bob Ney of Ohio. "That's why this bill is here. We're here because thousands of steelworkers and citizens would not let this issue go, would not let this issue die."
The limits in the House bill would reduce steel imports by 12 million tons a year from 1998 levels, while still allowing about 29 million tons of steel into the country. At the height of the import surge in 1998, 41 million tons of steel was being imported annually.
The Administration argued that the bill violated United States obligations to the World Trade Organization because it would impose a global limit on imports, instead of using existing tools such as tariffs to fight an illegal dumping of imports.
But confronted with the vote, Charlene Barshefsky, the United States trade representative, said, "While we oppose this legislation, we are going to work with the Congress to address this issue."
The Administration hopes eventually this session to muster support for an alternate approach to the steel crisis and to support a bill sponsored by Representative Sander M. Levin, Democrat of Michigan, and Representative Amo Houghton, Republican of New York. Their measure would change the trade law to make it easier and quicker for the Administration to take action in cases of import surges.

HEADLINE: House Panel Passes Blueprint For Tax Cuts and Spending

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 17

 BODY:
The House Budget Committee passed a Republican tax and spending blueprint tonight, sweeping aside objections from Democrats who said the plan promised too much in tax cuts and did too little to deal with the looming problems in Social Security and Medicare.
The party-line vote of 22 to 18 came after another day of partisan clashes over how the nation should take advantage of its improving fiscal outlook. The Senate Budget Committee also moved toward approval of the Republican plan, with a vote expected on Thursday. 
 The full House and Senate plan to take up the Republican budget next week. With approval likely in both chambers, Congress appears headed toward months of battles with the Clinton Administration encompassing both the annual tax and spending bills and efforts to shore up Social Security and Medicare.
The budget outline approved by the House Budget Committee tonight provides for a tax cut of at least $15 billion next year and nearly $800 billion over the next decade. It would increase spending for the military and education, but to remain with the tight spending limits imposed by the bipartisan 1997 balanced budget deal, it would scale back a broad array of other programs.
The plan would also require that all excess revenue generated by the Social Security payroll tax -- $1.8 billion over the next decade -- be set aside by Congress and used only for reducing the Federal debt or to pay for a change to the retirement system, such as the establishment of individual investment accounts.
Eager to establish their credentials for fiscal responsibility, Democrats have also pledged to stick to the spending limits, constraining their ability to attack Republicans as slashing domestic programs.
Instead, Democrats have been hammering at the Republican plan as failing to set aside for Medicare any specific amount of money out of the projected non-Social Security surplus of almost $800 billion over the next 10 years. The budget proposed last month by President Clinton set aside $350 billion over that period to help keep Medicare, the health insurance system for the elderly, from going broke as the population ages.
The Administration also opened an attack today on the Republican proposal to lock away the Social Security surpluses by writing into law a gradual reduction in the amount of public debt the Government could have outstanding.
In a letter to Democratic leaders in Congress, Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin said the Republican "lockbox" plan could leave the Treasury unable to refinance debt or issue new debt in an unexpected economic downturn. As a result, Mr. Rubin said, he would recommend that Mr. Clinton veto the bill.
In both the House and Senate committees, Democrats offered proposals that would have blocked or reduced the Republican tax cuts, but were thwarted on party-line votes.
The budget resolutions making their way through the two chambers will not become law and are not subject to a veto. But they set the priorities for the tax-writing and appropriations committees as they develop legislation over the rest of the year, and they amount to a detailed agenda for the Republican-controlled Congress.
The biggest hurdle facing the Republican plan may come not from the White House, but from the difficulty Congress will have in voting to cut dozens of popular programs at a time when the economy is strong and projections of future surpluses continue to grow.
Even Republicans on the appropriations committees are skeptical that they can pass bills enacting deep spending cuts. Both parties are hopeful that projections of next year's surplus will be increased in coming months, and in both parties there is a growing sense that the most likely way out of the problem is a deal late in the year that would split any fiscal windfall between spending and bigger tax cuts.
For today, though, Republicans were eager to proclaim that their budget delivered on all counts: saving Social Security and Medicare, maintaining fiscal discipline but spending more where the money is needed most.

HEADLINE: Politically and Technically Complex, Medicare Defies a Sweeping Redesign

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 17

 BODY:
Ira C. Magaziner, the politically tone-deaf architect of President Clinton's ill-fated health plan, and Senator John B. Breaux, the deal-making chairman of a commission that failed to find a solution to Medicare's financial woes, share what might be called the hubris of health care reformers: the belief that they could devise an all-encompassing scheme to redesign a huge swath of America's health care system.
Both failed spectacularly. Their efforts suggest that piecemeal, incremental changes are the only ones feasible at the moment, given the political and technical complexity of the subject. 
 The 17-member Medicare commission expired on Tuesday, one vote short of the 11 needed to endorse any formal recommendations to Congress or the President. Mr. Breaux, a Louisiana Democrat, said he would continue his effort to inject free-market competition into Medicare, and even a harsh critic of the plan, Senator John D. Rockefeller 4th of West Virginia, said today that some version of it might eventually "land on the President's desk."
Mr. Breaux's proposal for Medicare and Mr. Magaziner's plan for the entire health care system were both built on the idea of "managed competition": the Government would set rules for private health plans to compete, in the hope that they would offer more benefits and higher-quality care at lower prices. Health maintenance organizations would compete against traditional health insurance plans, which pay a fixed fee for each service.
Mr. Breaux and Mr. Magaziner would both have offered new benefits, including drug coverage, while creating strong incentives for subscribers to choose lower-cost plans.
The failure of these efforts suggests again the difficulty, maybe even the futility, of comprehensive proposals to overhaul the way health care is financed and delivered.
But the complexity of health care and the rapid pace of medical discoveries also make it difficult for Government to regulate this market.
"It is absolutely impossible to micro-manage health care in the 21st century" as Congress has required, Mr. Breaux said, noting Medicare's convoluted formulas to pay doctors, hospitals, nursing homes, H.M.O.'s and home health care agencies. The promise of simplicity is one reason for the appeal of the plan that Mr. Breaux drafted with help from Representative Bill Thomas of California, the panel's leading Republican.
"There are at least 10,000 Medicare reimbursement codes for hospital and physician services, and there are more than 3,000 counties in the United States," said Len M. Nichols, a health care economist at the Urban Institute. "It's very difficult for Medicare to get 10,000 prices right in 3,000 counties. It would be simpler for the Government to learn how to pay the right price for a package of services. The Breaux plan promised to move in that direction, but it didn't specify enough details to engender a consensus that we were ready to move now."
Supporters of the Breaux-Thomas plan say it will use the magic of the market to save money, encouraging greater efficiency among providers of health care.
But anyone who thinks Federal regulation would vanish under Mr. Breaux's plan is dreaming. Senator Breaux would create a powerful new Government agency, the Medicare Board. The board would negotiate with health plans, approve their benefits, determine the Federal payment to each plan and compute the premiums charged to beneficiaries.
For those who want to redesign Medicare, the thorniest issue is how to provide a new prescription drug benefit. Of the 39 million Medicare beneficiaries, more than 6 million are in H.M.O.'s, and most of these H.M.O.'s already offer drug benefits.
Democrats in Congress say drug coverage must also be available to people in the original fee-for-service Medicare program. But that makes drug companies nervous because it raises the possibility that Medicare would regulate drug prices. Judith H. Bello, executive vice president of the Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America, said she had not seen any proposal for drug coverage that relied adequately on the market.
Medicare costs are growing faster than revenues, and the gap will widen as baby boomers become eligible for Medicare after 2010. But Congress usually responds only to pressing problems, and Medicare's financial troubles seem less urgent today than in 1997, when Congress created the Medicare commission.
Medicare spending rose last year just 1.5 percent, the smallest increase since the beginning of the program in 1965. Nancy-Ann Min DeParle, the head of the Medicare program, said this was "probably an aberration," reflecting a decline in the use of home health care and a reduction in fraud and abuse.
President Clinton, Senator Breaux and many Republicans are talking about comprehensive changes in the structure of Medicare. But Congress will have its hands full fixing the law it passed in 1997. That law was intended to create new health insurance options for the elderly and to entice more H.M.O.'s into the Medicare market, under a new program known as Medicare+Choice.
Many H.M.O.'s unexpectedly pulled out of Medicare or reduced their service areas, causing confusion and alarm for more than 440,000 beneficiaries.
In announcing that he would offer his own proposal to revamp Medicare, Mr. Clinton said: "We must find agreement this year. Medicare is too important to let partisan politics stand in the way of vital progress."
The outlook for action is unclear, but one thing is certain. Politics will pervade the debate. It could be no other way in a program that spends more than $200 billion a year to care for 39 million people.

HEADLINE: Our China Policy Is Based on Wishful Thinking

 BODY:

To the Editor:
The problem with the Clinton Administration's China policy isn't that it's "running on automatic pilot" toward engagement (editorial, March 14), but that it's based on wishful thinking characterized by triangulation and crisis response. 
 While the goal remains largely unchanged from President Richard M. Nixon's when the United States first opened serious relations with China, this Administration talks a lot about constructive engagement but delivers little. Legions of dedicated public servants burn the midnight oil trying to deal with the consequences of optimistic political and economic positioning. Los Alamos is simply the most recent example.
The story resonates because all Americans can easily grasp the contradictions that the Administration refuses to acknowledge.
Technology transfer and theft of American nuclear secrets aren't the real problem; the wishful thinking that drives the Administration's actions is.
 
RICHARD CASEY
Alexandria, Va., March 14, 1999

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Still Places Environment Last

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Gov. Tom Ridge's call for a Republican model of environmental stewardship (Op-Ed, March 15) compares the Federal Superfund program, which has cleaned only 13 of the 111 Superfund sites in Pennsylvania, unfavorably with the state's land recycling program, which has put 350 polluted sites back to use in four years. 
 There are two important differences between these programs. Superfund sites are highly contaminated and pose an immediate threat to human and environmental health; brownfield sites -- industrial sites with suspected contamination -- do not. Superfund requires permanent remedies; state brownfield programs provide for use-based remedies that permit contamination to remain.
The new G.O.P. identity the Governor proposes looks a lot like the old G.O.P. identity that values the economy over health and environmental protection.
 
SARAH S. GARDNER
Princeton, N.J., March 15, 1999

HEADLINE: New Video Releases

 BODY:

Pleasantville
Attached to the placid 50's scene he sees on reruns of his favorite 50's show, a high school student named David (Tobey Maguire, left, with Marley Shelton) and his unwilling, very 90's sister, Jennifer (Reese Witherspoon), get sucked into that world through their television set. Inside the tube, Dad (William H. Macy) yells the inevitable "Honey, I'm home," and Mom (Joan Allen) obligingly has those artery-clogging meals on the table at 6 sharp. Chafing at the sterility, the liberated Jennifer shakes up the young set, and even David sees the need to introduce change and passion. Pleasantvillers either go along or resist, but by then, Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times, an ingenious fantasy has "seriously belabored its once-gentle metaphor and light comic spirit." 
1998. New Line. $107.37. 123 minutes. Closed captioned. PG-13. Release date: March 23.
 
Mighty Joe Young
After his mother is shot by hunters who want to pack him off to a zoo, a baby gorilla called Joe escapes and grows tall in the bush. That's 15 feet tall, a good height for theme park planners. Cared for by a leggy blond naturalist named Jill (Charlize Theron), Joe eventually gets flown to Los Angeles after a well-meaning zoologist (Bill Paxton) convinces Jill that the gorilla would be better off in a specially prepared natural habitat (or as natural as it gets in Los Angeles). Joe, however, gets upset and goes on a mild rampage in a film that "is essentially 'King Kong' for kids. Very young kids" (Stephen Holden).
1998. Disney. $24.99. 114 minutes. Closed captioned. PG. Release date: March 23.
 
The Best Man
To help her bourgeois father with his money problems, the beautiful Francesca (Ines Sastre) agrees to marry a sleazy, affluent older businessman (Dario Cantarelli) who can brighten the financial situation. The year being 1899 and the place a small northern Italian town, the situation necessarily puts restraints on the young woman, who tries to leverage herself out of her intolerable predicament by attaching herself to the best man (Diego Abatantuono). As it examines the bartering of ripe flesh for property, Pupi Avati's film makes a "fascinating, microscopically detailed study" (Holden).
1998. Universal. $99.36. 101 minutes. Italian with English subtitles. PG. Release date: March 23.
 
Living Out Loud
Freshly divorced and desperately needing direction, Judith (Holly Hunter) pours her heart out to everyone she meets. Soon she is taken under the wing of a cabaret singer (Queen Latifah) who helps change her life and a kindly doorman (Danny DeVito) who turns out to be a kindred spirit. Richard LaGravenese's film gets too ardently introspective at times, but Ms. Hunter imparts "intelligence, thwarted passion and obvious depth of feeling" (Maslin).
1998. New Line. $105.77. 93 minutes. Closed captioned. R.
 
Straight to Video
 
Other new titles of interest, some of which may have had a theater release at one time, appeared on television or been issued on videocassette in earlier editions.
 
BROTHER. The setting is 1990's St. Petersburg, but the feel is 30's gangster movie. Intent on getting his little piece of the pie, a young hoodlum freshly discharged from the Russian Army joins his brother, a contract killer, and plunges into intimidation and murder in a city torn by gang warfare and rampant crime. In Aleksei Balabanov's film, the mood is stark and the effect "terrifically stylish," Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times. 1997. $79.95. 96 minutes. Russian with English subtitles. No rating.
 
COMING HOME. In a mini-series drawn from a novel by the British romance writer Rosamunde Pilcher, a young girl comes of age in England before and after World War II. Emily Mortimer, Katie Ryder-Richardson, Peter O'Toole and Joanna Lumley star. 1999. Four cassettes. $59.95. 205 minutes. Information: (800) 999-0212.
 
CARLA'S SONG. Ken Loach's film follows an unemployed Scottish bus driver who gets a lesson in C.I.A.-sponsored treachery and atrocities when he accompanies his suicidal girlfriend to her native Nicaragua during the fighting between the contras and the Sandinistas. 1998. Fox Lorber $89.95. 127 minutes. No rating.
 
PAUL MONETTE: THE BRINK OF SUMMER'S END. In Monte Bramer's documentary, the gay activist and author of "Borrowed Time: An AIDS Memoir" and "Becoming a Man: Half a Life Story" movingly lives out his days (he died of AIDS four years ago). 1998. $39.95. 90 minutes.

HEADLINE: MOVIE GUIDE

 BODY:

Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 9.
 
Now Playing
 
* "AFFLICTION," starring Nick Nolte, James Coburn, Willem Dafoe, Sissy Spacek and Mary Beth Hurt. Directed by Paul Schrader (R, 114 minutes). Mr. Nolte is devastating in the performance of his career, as Wade Whitehouse, a New Hampshire loner fighting a losing battle with demons from his past. Foremost among them: Mr. Coburn, terrifyingly authentic as the drunken, abusive father who long ago cowed his sons into submission. As directed by Mr. Schrader, this pure, unfettered adaptation of Russell Banks's novel starts on a deceptively ordinary note, then escalates into inexorable fury. Every little detail matters. Ms. Spacek and Ms. Hurt expertly play the women who trigger Wade's crisis (Janet Maslin). 

* "ANALYZE THIS," starring Robert De Niro and Billy Crystal. Directed by Harold Ramis (R, 110 minutes). The title, concept and teaming of these co-stars are all funny before the lights go down, so think of this comedy as an offer you can't refuse. Cast as a mobster whose confidence is shaken, Mr. De Niro is hilarious simply by playing his role halfway straight, in classic goodfella style. His mobster finds just the right comic foil in Billy Crystal, as the psychiatrist who utters the immortal: "When I got into family therapy, this wasn't the family I had in mind." There's a lot more where that came from in this breezy comic treat (Maslin).
 
"BABY GENIUSES," starring Kathleen Turner and many toddlers. Directed by Bob Clark (PG, 94 minutes). One way to get through this guaranteed 100 percent laugh-free comedy is to wonder whether it really is the worst film you've even seen. Probably not, but it's pretty darn close. Woefully substandard production values give it a ghastly look, made all the worse by the grotesque computer morphing of young children into adult-style wise guys. The plotting is shrill, bordering on incomprehensible. Ms. Turner lurches through the film with a performance that just says, "Hey, it's a living" (Maslin).
 
* "CENTRAL STATION," starring Fernanda Montenegro. Directed by Walter Salles (R, 115 minutes). In this quiet, luminous Brazilian gem, a joyless older woman crosses paths with an orphaned boy. There's plenty of room for sentimentality here, but the wonder of Mr. Salles's film is all in the telling. As these characters develop a fractious bond, then embark on a road trip that takes them vividly to Brazil's hinterlands in search of the boy's father, Mr. Salles brings great tenderness and surprise to the events that punctuate their journey. Ms. Montenegro's tough bravura performance was one of last year's very best (Maslin).
 
"THE CORRUPTOR," starring Chow Yun-Fat and Mark Wahlberg. Directed by James Foley (R, 111 minutes). A conventional but above-average police drama set in Chinatown in New York City, "The Corruptor" finds the rookie cop Danny Wallace (Mr. Wahlberg) learning the ropes from his rule-bending partner, Nick Chen (Mr. Chow), who has gotten dangerously chummy with Chinatown's mob bosses. The atmosphere is gritty, the action sequences sleek and the questions the story raises about loyalty, ethics, friendship and betrayal, although familiar, are still worth bringing up. "The Corruptor" is a more effective showcase for the brooding charisma of Mr. Chow, a Hong Kong action superstar, than "The Replacement Killers," his English-language debut (Stephen Holden).
 
* "THE DEEP END OF THE OCEAN," starring Michelle Pfeiffer, Treat Williams and Whoopi Goldberg. Directed by Ulu Grosbard (PG-13, 108 minutes). Ms. Pfeiffer gives a fine, affecting performance in this adaptation of Jacquelyn Mitchard's best seller. And Mr. Grosbard carefully delineates its story of a child's disappearance and its aftermath, showing the ways that such a catastrophe affects his family. Restrained and unsentimental, this astute drama deals thoughtfully with the chasm between real and idealized family lives (Maslin).
 
"EIGHT MILLIMETER," starring Nicolas Cage and Joaquin Phoenix. Directed by Joel Schumacher (R, 120 minutes). This thriller delves into the perverse underworld of the pornography business, shocking audiences with the realization that sex and violence can be so dull. Mr. Cage, seriously miscast, plays a private detective and devoted family man who is suddenly, to his horror, drawn into the realm of porn. Naturally, this is where the film wanted to be even when its opening scenes were stuck in suburban Pennsylvania. But the story's parade of New York and Hollywood sleazeballs fails to deliver either engaging drama or heartfelt kinks. Mr. Phoenix is scene-stealingly good in a sidekick's role (Maslin).
 
* "LIFE IS BEAUTIFUL," directed by and starring Roberto Benigni (PG-13, 122 minutes). Italy's most antic funnyman dares to find humor and tenderness in the midst of the Holocaust, and his risk pays off. This Cannes prize winner is as stubbornly entertaining as its central character, a Jewish waiter named Guido who jokes his way through the nightmare for the sake of his loved ones. Daring also to combine an opening hour of romance and pranks with a more somber second act, Mr. Benigni avoids all traces of the maudlin and effectively creates a situation in which comedy is courage. In this unpretentious, enormously likable film, he shines as a father whose fibs and hilarious buffoonery know no bounds, and no fear (Maslin).
 
* "LOCK, STOCK AND TWO SMOKING BARRELS," starring Jason Flemyng, Dexter Fletcher, Vinnie Jones and Nick Moran. Directed by Guy Ritchie (R, 106 minutes). Not since "The Usual Suspects" has there been such an oversupply of cool macho schemers in a single film. And they're served up with a quick, tart economy that bespeaks the filmmaker's background making videos and commercials -- actually an advantage, for a change. There's not much beneath the surface here; what's most entertaining is Mr. Ritchie's droll, hard-boiled storytelling and the rogue's gallery of a cast that he has assembled. All the film need do is juggle assorted miscreants and four separate gangs who, figuratively speaking, can't shoot straight (Maslin).
 
"MESSAGE IN A BOTTLE," starring Kevin Costner, Robin Wright Penn and Paul Newman. Directed by Luis Mandoki (PG-13, 110 minutes). Nicholas Sparks's best-selling novel, about a lonely, sensitive man who sends a message out to sea and the lonely, beautiful woman who finds it, is now a long and soggy film. Kevin Costner crosses the line from teasingly laconic to stodgy and seems as likely to have written "Bleak House" as the love letter in question. Robin Wright Penn makes an appealing heroine, but there's not much room for real emotion in a film with the tenor of a commercial for hazelnut-flavored coffee. As the hero's crusty old father, Mr. Newman steals what's left of the show (Maslin).
 
"OCTOBER SKY," starring Jake Gyllenhaal and Chris Cooper. Directed by Joe Johnston (PG, 100 minutes). By far the most moving scenes here are home movie snippets, circa 1957, that show the real people on whom the film's characters are based. Otherwise, despite being closely based on a best-selling memoir ("Rocket Boys") by the NASA engineer Homer H. Hickam Jr., this earnest, nostalgic film has a way of seeming too good to be true. The film's simplicity is appealing, as is Mr. Gyllenhaal in the central role of a boy in a West Virginia coal mining town who becomes obsessed with rocketry. But the story, filled with father-son conflict and down-in-the-ground versus up-in-the-sky contrasts, often follows a familiar trajectory (Maslin).
 
"PAYBACK," starring Mel Gibson and Gregg Henry. Directed by Brian Helgeland (R, 110 minutes). In this inept, excessively sadistic film-noir spoof adapted from the same Richard Stark novel ("The Hunter") that inspired the 1967 genre classic "Point Blank," Mr. Gibson is a thief named Porter who retaliates with a vengeance after an attempt on his life. Determined to recover $70,000 that was stolen from him by a double-crossing partner in crime, he works his way up the pecking order of a crime syndicate, brutally dispatching all who stand in his way. The hard-boiled dialogue is ludicrous, the storytelling clunky, the acting fair to awful, the gore ankle deep. Credit the star with being able to keep a straight face through this loathsome mess (Holden).
 
* "SAVING PRIVATE RYAN," starring Tom Hanks, Matt Damon, Tom Sizemore, Jeremy Davies and Edward Burns. Directed by Steven Spielberg (R, 168 minutes). Mr. Spielberg's soberly magnificent new film is the finest war movie of our time. Turning back the clock to restore passion and meaning to the genre, he works in a spirit of urgent communication to look at war as if it has not been looked at before. Tour-de-force battle scenes are frank without sensationalism, and the same great storyteller who made you believe there was an extraterrestrial hiding in the closet has made this an irresistibly vibrant, gripping tale. Mr. Hanks continues to astonish with admirable modesty, and the rest of the casting is comparably inspired. As he did with "Schindler's List," Mr. Spielberg has made a landmark film of devastating power (Maslin).
 
* "SHAKESPEARE IN LOVE," starring Joseph Fiennes, Gwyneth Paltrow and Geoffrey Rush. Directed by John Madden (R, 113 minutes). A witty, sexy and merrily literate delight, with an exhilaratingly clever premise that only gets better as the film unfolds. The screenplay, originating as Marc Norman's brainstorm and turned by Tom Stoppard into razor-sharp dialogue reminiscent of his "Rosencrantz and Guildenstern Are Dead," dares to imagine whatever it likes about the link between Shakespeare's artistic passions and his mad yearning for a certain aristocratic beauty. Meanwhile this tirelessly inventive comedy envisions an Elizabethan theater fraught with the same backbiting and conniving we enjoy today and has great fun presenting the creation of "Romeo and Juliet," glitches and all. Mr. Fiennes and Ms. Paltrow make a fine, tempestuous duo, and she gives the first great, fully realized starring performance of her career (Maslin).
 
* "TANGO," starring Miguel Angel Sola. Written and directed by Carlos Saura. Cinematography by Vittorio Storaro (PG-13, 100 minutes). A thrilling display of tango heat and virtuosity. And it's no slight to the actors who play lovers to say that the dancing here is steamier than any kiss. In his most electrifying dance film, Mr. Saura offers transfixingly beautiful glimpses of the dance and the great range of emotions it can conjure. Mr. Storaro's dazzlingly fluid cinematography captures all the nuances this material demands. Everyone in the film is utterly consumed by tango fever; audiences will be, too (Maslin).
 
"THE THIN RED LINE," starring Jim Caviezel, Ben Chaplin, Nick Nolte and Sean Penn. Directed by Terrence Malick (R, 166 minutes). From the first frame of this huge, drifting war epic loosely derived from James Jones's Guadalcanal novel, it's viscerally clear that Mr. Malick is back. The exquisite, oddly detached visual style that made "Badlands" and "Days of Heaven" the most beautiful films of the 1970's is instantly apparent here, even if the narrative vagueness and brooding voice-overs are also familiar. The film sprawls, gets lost and occasionally delivers visual poetry, the kind that could have been greatly helped by tighter editing. Bottom line: No one who admired Mr. Malick's early work should miss this. But those expecting anything simple will not find it here (Maslin).
 
"20 DATES," starring Myles Berkowitz. Directed by Mr. Berkowitz (R, 88 minutes). The filmmaker's gimmick is to make a film about dating. His goal: to go out with 20 different women, get them on camera by any means necessary and promise to fall in love with one before the experiment is over. Mr. Berkowitz, pesty and proud of it, has absorbed enough of Jerry Seinfeld and Garry Shandling to create a diffident, nit-picking, sitcom-ready persona. But whenever his film establishes a playful mood, it's liable to do something to make you squirm. Crassness and mock candor aren't all that funny (unless they're coming from Albert Brooks, whose "Real Life" paved the way for this). And discovering that cheese makes Mr. Berkowitz constipated or that one of his dates disappoints him by not looking enough like Jessica Rabbit is more than you need to know (Maslin).
 
"200 CIGARETTES," starring Paul Rudd, Kate Hudson and Courtney Love. Directed by Risa Bramon Garcia (R, 102 minutes). This contrived but cheery party movie is the feature directing debut of a well-known casting director. And in making her film, Ms. Garcia does what she does best: cast. A group of bright young players is brought together for a largely plotless New Year's Eve, rambling around a colorfully evoked East Village, circa 1981. Essentially just a set of interwoven skits, this comedy still makes good use of the actors noted above, along with Casey Affleck as a nice-guy punk, Dave Chappelle as a cabbie full of advice and Martha Plimpton as a hopeless hostess. Ms. Hudson, who is Goldie Hawn's daughter and has her mother's grin and giggle, makes an adorable debut despite spending part of the movie with dog excrement on her coat (Maslin).
