HEADLINE: ON THE ROAD;
Sunny Stretch Around a Bay

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: TAMPA, Fla.

 BODY:
Once upon a time, when there were more orange groves than golf courses in Florida, Tampa Bay was surrounded by a series of distinct communities: industrial, ethnically mixed Tampa, white-bread St. Petersburg and its retirees from the Midwest, laid-back Bradenton and Clearwater and, down the coast a bit, artsy, cosmopolitan Sarasota, where the circus spent the winter.
"We never went to St. Petersburg," says my colleague David Rosenbaum, who grew up in Tampa in the 1940's and 50's. "We had the port and the unions and Latins; they had the beaches and tourists and shuffleboard." 
 Now, in fact if not law, it's one big metropolitan area, laced together with bridges and freeways. People watch the same television stations and root for the same professional sports teams. Many of them send their children to the booming, multicampus University of South Florida. They shop at the same enormous malls, like the the brand-new Citrus Park Town Center, until recently a pasture, which drew upward of 100,000 cars on opening day.
On the road maps, this entity of 2.5 million people doesn't exist. Only the old place names are there. But everyone calls it Tampa Bay, and it is a prototypical example of the Sun Belt's explosive growth. Its subdivisions (mostly gated now) sprawl under postcard-blue skies. Its service-based economy thrives, and cultural and sporting diversions thrive with it.
Even baseball spring training, a seasonal ritual hereabouts for decades, is attracting new interest, thanks to last season's home run derby and the sprucing up of some of the ball parks where the big leaguers strut their stuff. No fewer than six teams train in the area, including the Yankees, whose main owner, George Steinbrenner, is a Tampa tycoon. They play their springtime games at the immodestly named Legends Field at 1 Steinbrenner Drive. Summertime, and the living is easy, the Gershwins wrote; if they had lived in Tampa Bay, they might have mentioned the other seasons, too.
Hernando de Soto, historians think, was Tampa Bay's first tourist, landing near modern Bradenton in 1539 and lingering only briefly before heading west on a fruitless search for jewels and gold that ended with his death on the banks of the Mississippi in 1542.
Not much happened for the three centuries after that, until Henry B. Plant built a railroad linking the bay to the rest of the country in 1883. In 1891 he added the astonishing 500-room Tampa Bay Hotel, built in an eccentric Moorish style, with keyhole-shaped windows and 13 silvery minarets topped with golden crescents. It had telephones in the rooms, electric lights, a private casino, two ballrooms, a billiard room and a peacock park, almost making good on Plant's pledge to "turn this sandheap into the Champs-Elysees."
Tampa was the staging point for the American forces dispatched to Cuba in the Spanish-American War, and in the summer of 1898 the Tampa Bay Hotel provided a broad veranda where Army and Navy officers and assorted hangers-on could sit in rocking chairs, sipping Champagne and iced tea, waiting for orders. Lieut. Col. Theodore Roosevelt was one of them, slipping away from his Rough Riders camped on the flats east of town, as the historian Edmund Morris tells the story, to spend three nights with his wife, Edith, in one of the hotel's grander suites.
 
Monument to an Era
One hot, sticky night Roosevelt and his handpicked men rode their horses into a local restaurant.
The expeditionary force sailed away in June, its commander having received his orders to embark while coffee was being served at the hotel one evening. The hotel never recaptured the glory of the Gay Nineties, closing in 1930. But it still stands as a monument to the man who built the Gulf Coast, used partly as a municipal museum and partly by the University of Tampa.
St. Petersburg flourished, once its railroad came, by luring white-collar refugees from the cruel winters and high taxes in Ohio, Michigan and Indiana. It is one of those cities, like Des Moines, that were shaped by newspaper editors with a determination to lead. They, too, came from the Midwest: W. L. Straub, who stopped the industrialization of the waterfront, preserving it for tourism, and his successor at The St. Petersburg Times, Nelson Poynter, who campaigned hard for good government and civil rights.
 
Waterfront Museums
Three art museums have opened along the waterfront in recent years, lending a new dimension to the city and contributing to a regional surge of cultural development. Oldest is the Museum of Fine Arts, whose 20 galleries house a small but comprehensive permanent collection. Its highlights, for me, include an aggressively scarlet "Poppy" by Georgia O'Keeffe; a subtle Lely portrait of Nell Gwyn, the actress mistress of Charles II; a shimmering Monet from the Parliament series, "Effect of Fog," and a supremely 1920's portrait of Mr. and Mrs. Chester Dale, benefactors of the National Gallery in Washington, by Guy Pene du Bois.
Down the street, improbably sited next to a pleasure-boat marina, is the world's largest collection of paintings and drawings by the flamboyant Catalan Surrealist, Salvador Dali. There are plenty of "melting" watches and a telephone shaped like a lobster, the kinds of things that made Dali's fame, but the four immense "masterworks" are the star attractions. The best of them, "The Discovery of America by Christopher Columbus," pays homage to the explorer, to Dali's idol, Velazquez, and to Dali's wife and muse, Gala.
The third of the trio, the Florida International Museum, housed in a former Maas Brothers department store, is not so much a museum as a 20,000-square-foot hall for hire. It has no collection of its own, relying instead on a succession of special shows: Romanov treasures, artifacts of the Incas and, soon, roomsful of personal effects and other objects associated with John F. Kennedy.
To get to the best museum in the region, perhaps the best in Florida, you have to take a drive. Happily, you go by way of the magnificent Sunshine Skyway Bridge across the mouth of Tampa Bay. Opened in 1987, patterned after the Brotonne Bridge across the Seine near Rouen, it is supported by a single, central set of cables rather than cables on both sides of the roadway. Many consider it the most impressive span built in this country since the Golden Gate Bridge in the 1930's.
It will take you, eventually, to Sarasota, and the John and Mable Ringling Museum of Art, a spectacular Italianate bayfront building with gleaming white rooftop statues. Inside the spectacle continues; Ringling was a circus man, with little taste for understatement. He sought to stun with art as he did under the Big Top, so he bought pictures by Baroque masters like Rubens and Pietro da Cortona at a time when their exuberance was out of fashion.
Today they anchor a collection of rare originality that ranges from Guercino to Titian to Piero di Cosimo's "Building of a Palace." The high point, perhaps, is the quartet of gigantic tapestry cartoons by Rubens, bought in 1926 from the Duke of Westminster and shown in a 40-foot-high gallery.
 
Performance Time
Sarasota is also a center for the performing arts. Every February and March its opera company stages four productions, and it does not confine itself to warhorses. This year's program includes "May Night," an early, little-known, folkloric piece by Rimsky-Korsakov, based on a Gogol story.
Astonishingly for a city of only 50,000 or so, Sarasota supports a 40-year-old Equity company at the Asolo Theater, adjacent to the Ringling museum. Its current eight-month season includes new plays by Jane Martin and Richard Greenberg, as well as four one-act comedies by Shaw and plays by Wilder, Sheridan, Odets, Sherwood, Joan Littlewood, Alfred Uhry and Steve Martin.
Each June Sarasota stages a well-regarded chamber music festival, and all year long the Van Wezel Performing Arts Hall, painted a jarring shade of purple, presents an almost nightly parade of visiting musicians. Recently the Boston Pops, the Berlin Radio Symphony under Rafael Fruhbeck de Burgos and the Moscow Philharmonic have paid calls, along with the Moiseyev Dance Company, the Guarneri String Quartet and Bernadette Peters. (Next month, it closes for several months of repairs.)
In fact the whole area is on a performing arts roll, with Ruth Eckerd Hall in Clearwater, the Mahaffey Theater in St. Petersburg and the huge Tampa Bay Performing Arts Center in Tampa full to overflowing with music and drama. On a single night not long ago the local music fan could choose among Gordon Lightfoot, Tony Bennett, the Rolling Stones and the Vienna Choir Boys.
And that is not even reckoning with the Florida Orchestra, which plays a seven-month season in several halls under the music directorship of Jahja Ling, who is also Christoph von Dohnanyi's No. 2 in Cleveland. The orchestra administers to the bay the prescribed monthly doses of Mozart, Mahler and Beethoven, but this year it has also programmed works by Hovhaness, Kodaly and William Schuman.
 
An Airport's Impact
In many ways bigger has proved to be better for Tampa Bay.
Start with the Tampa airport, which must be the best in the country. Opened in 1972 and currently undergoing modernization, it is more convenient in its state of upheaval than most airports at their most settled. The main terminal is linked to four remote buildings, housing the gates, by fast two-car automated trains that run above ground, up in the sunshine, not buried in some dingy tunnel. Bright, close in, with plenty of elevators and escalators and lots of easily understood signs, TPA ought to be cloned nationwide.
Along with the climate -- the sun is said to shine 361 days a year -- the airport has helped to attract all kinds of businesses, including the Home Shopping Network and back-office operations for big financial institutions, as well as biotechnology and other high-technology companies. ("High-tech in the mangroves," a local booster calls them.) It has also brought tourists, who head west to 50 miles of beaches along the Gulf of Mexico and east to Busch Gardens, the wildly popular offshoot of the local Budweiser brewery.
 
Animal Kingdoms
You can take your wild animals in Tampa with or without roller coasters. For the purist there is the fine Lowry Park Zoo, where you can see not only a Sumatran tiger but also a rare Florida panther and a rarer Indian rhinoceros. It also specializes in the rehabilitation of the manatee, an endangered species of huge, cowlike marine creatures. Only 2,500 remain in the wild.
Busch Gardens is bigger and brassier. It has four roller coasters, which flip and plunge and twist and climb until you think you've left your insides in another time zone, and bumper cars called Ubanga-Banga. (Geddit?) Its theme is Africa, more or less, but no one is too rigorous about it; you will see koalas from Australia and elephants from India and flamingos from Chile, too. The "Nairobi" train station looks just like South Africa, not Kenya, and the dolphin show inexplicably takes place in a mock-up of landlocked Timbuktu.
But I doubt that there is anywhere else on this continent with anything to rival the hundreds of antelopes and other animals that roam more or less freely on Busch Gardens' simulation of the Serengeti Plain. Many are rarities, seldom encountered in Africa: greater kudus and blesboks, elands and addaxes, sable antelopes and magnificent roan antelopes, bred at the park. Hokey the rides may be, but the young staff members care a lot about the animals; one of them, Erin Leach, spent 20 minutes establishing for me that a spectacularly colored bird that neither of us recognized was a saddle-billed stork.
A good sequel to either Busch Gardens or the zoo is the new Florida Aquarium in downtown Tampa, an $84 million, shell-shaped extravaganza in green glass whose tanks contain exhibits of aquatic life on Florida's coral reefs, in its oceanic depths and in its streams and mangrove swamps -- everything from menacing sharks to playful river otters to darting rainbow parrotfish.
 
Questions of Identity
Not everyone is crazy about Tampa Bay's coming of age, and St. Petersburg, in particular, worries about losing its identity. Politicians there, and taxpayers, too, complain that visiting out-of-towners too often assume they are in Tampa. They grumble about politicians and reporters who came for the Vice Presidential debate in 1996, and sportswriters who come to cover the new Tampa Bay Devil Rays baseball team at the slope-domed Tropicana Field in St. Petersburg, also the site of this year's college basketball Final Four.
Tampa has lost something, too, in the regional amalgamation.
"They are turning Tampa into the customary nothing," complained the mystery writer John D. MacDonald a quarter-century ago in one of his Travis McGee novels, "Bright Orange for the Shroud." "They've opened up the center of the city into a more spacious characterlessness, and more and more they are converting Ybor City into fake New Orleans."
As usual the gloriously grumpy MacDonald overstated the case. If the post-modern skyscrapers of downtown Tampa lack architectural distinction, it is much less sterile than many late-blooming cities, and the bankers, lawyers and deal makers have to work somewhere, don't they? As for Ybor City, where Hispanic tobacco workers and Italian immigrants once lived, it has indeed turned into an ersatz French Quarter, loaded with wrought-iron balconies and chockablock with bars; on Friday and Saturday nights, it belongs to the young and the rowdy.
 
Old-Time Flavor
Only faint hints remain of the days, long before a new generation of immigrants arrived from Castro's Cuba, when Ybor City was the cigar capital of the world. Along Seventh Avenue, you can still see the Columbia Restaurant, now frequented mainly by tourists, and the neoclassical Italian Club.
But Tampa has not lost all of its authentic Latin flavor. To sample that, visit La Teresita at 3248 West Columbus Drive, a landmark Cuban-American restaurant with green oilcloth on the tables, nestled amid shabby stores selling guava turnovers and Cuban sandwiches, not far from the airport. Go for Sunday lunch if you can, eat the Capdevila family's wonderful black beans and yellow rice, with vinegary roast pork on the side, and drink a cafe con leche. (I did; it cost $8.81 with tax and tip.) And be sure to look around. The clientele is young and old, rich and poor, Anglo as well as Latino: rednecks mingling with blue rinses, young girls in communion dresses with older ones wearing skimpy crop-tops.
Nor has St. Petersburg (named by a pioneer developer for his Russian hometown) lost all its old Midwestern blandness in the rush to tomorrow. It remains a low-key place, represented by politicians like C. W. Bill Young, the chairman of the powerful House Appropriations Committee, a conservative, of course, but not the kind who goes out of his way to punch you in the eye.
If you linger a while in the vicinity of Fourth Avenue North and Fifth Street, you will see institutions that cater to the city's still sizable geriatric population: the St. Petersburg Chess Club, the St. Petersburg Lawn Bowling Club, founded in 1926, and the proudly self-proclaimed "World's Largest Shuffleboard and Duplicate Bridge Club," on the shore of Mirror Lake.
 
What's on the List for a Visit to the Tampa Bay Area? Quite a Bit, With Arts and Animals Among the Highlights
 
Here is information about visiting the Tampa Bay area of Florida:
 
Where to Stay
 
DON CESAR BEACH RESORT, 3400 Gulf Boulevard, St. Pete Beach, (727) 360-1881. Discerningly restored a few years ago, this peachy-pink neo-Moorish palace, built in 1928, offers a fine beach, a spa, tennis courts, two pools and 232 handsome rooms. If Scott and Zelda stayed there, as everyone says, they knew the town as St. Petersburg Beach; local lawmakers, no poets, later clipped off two syllables in the interests of brevity. Double room rate: $289 to $329 weekdays; $319 to $359 on weekends.
 
HYATT REGENCY WESTSHORE, 6200 Courtney Campbell Causeway, Tampa, (813) 874-1234. Facing tranquil Tampa Bay, surrounded by flora and fountains, this crisply up-to-date, 14-story, 400-room hotel stands a head or two taller than the average Hyatt. It has three top-notch restaurants; Oystercatchers, named after a clever, bivalve-loving local bird, serves the region's best seafood. Double room rate: $225 weekdays; $149 on weekends through April, then $179.
 
LONGBOAT KEY CLUB, 301 Gulf of Mexico Drive, Longboat Key, (941) 383-8821. A resort, not really a club, on the strip of land across Sarasota Bay from Ringling-town, it emphasizes sports, with 45 championship golf holes and 38 tennis courts. The 213 trim rooms have kitchens and washer-dryers. Double room rate: $220 to $335; apartments from $270 to $735.
 
RENAISSANCE VINOY RESORT, 501 Fifth Avenue N.E., St. Petersburg, (727) 894-1000. On the bayfront in downtown St. Petersburg, the Vinoy is another reborn survivor from the 1920's. Pink as a flamingo on the outside, ornate on the inside, with stenciled pecky cypress beams in the lobby, it is listed on the National Register of Historic Places. Its 360 luxurious rooms, plus pools, steam room, tennis courts and croquet lawn, attract an affluent clientele. Double room rate: $259; $139 starting in June.
 
WYNDHAM HARBOUR ISLAND, 725 South Harbour Island Boulevard, Tampa, (813) 229-5000. There's nothing too special about this modern establishment except the location, but that's very special indeed: on an artificial island, linked by bridge and monorail to skyscraper-studded downtown Tampa. The rooms are amply sized, and there's an on-site marina, if you're taking your sailboat. Double room rate: $149; $99 in April.
 
Where to Eat
 
BEACH BISTRO, 6600 Gulf Drive, Anna Maria Island, west of Bradenton, (941) 778-6444. Four good reasons to visit this out-of-the-way spot: 1. remarkable smoked salmon, which the Canadian proprietor imports weekly from J. Willy Krauch, an artisanal smoker in Tangier, Nova Scotia; 2. moist, perfectly cooked grouper, the local fish of choice; 3. a bountiful wine list, which includes Australia's prized Grange and five vintages of Chateau Pichon Longueville; 4. fabulous sunsets over the gulf. Only one quibble: Here as elsewhere in the area there is a regrettable tendency to litter plates with superfluous garnishes.
 
BOCA, 1930 East Seventh Avenue, Ybor City section of Tampa, (813) 241-2622. Boca's Nueva Latina dishes include shrimp ajillo (with garlic), exceptional flan and updated Cuban sandwiches (ham, roast pork and Swiss cheese on light Cuban bread). The surprise is the house salad, a tangy blend of field greens, manchego cheese, tomatoes and onions, dressed with a guava- and chili-flavored vinaigrette.
 
MISE EN PLACE, 442 West Kennedy Boulevard, Tampa, (813) 254-5373. Marty Blitz pioneered modern American cooking in the region, and his restaurant remains the local leader. A plate of tasty house-made charcuterie epitomizes the ambition and technical savvy of the kitchen. I was taken with a mustard-crusted rack of lamb, served on a hillock of Cheddar grits and moistened with a bourbon shallot demi-glace. The room is suave, the service less so.
 
TED PETERS SMOKED FISH, 1350 Pasadena Avenue South, St. Petersburg (727) 381-7931. This is the place, a local foodie told me, that he'd take Calvin Trillin to if he ever came to St. Petersburg. Since 1950, not long after the proprietor pulled into town from Olean, N.Y., this roadside shack has dished up definitive versions of local delicacies like smoked mackerel and gray mullet, as well as a tangy fish spread that tastes best on saltines.
 
REDWOOD, 247 Central Avenue, St. Petersburg, (727) 896-5118. Competent Pacific Rim cooking near the Atlantic rim, in a restored downtown storefront. I wish the menu featured more fish from the gulf and less marlin, albacore and yellowfin flown across the continent, but that didn't keep me from enjoying a nicely presented sashimi of rich ahi tuna coated with sesame seeds. The handsome copper bar is stocked with premium cognacs and single-batch bourbons.
 
SIDEBERN'S, 2208 West Morrison Avenue, Tampa, (813) 258-2233. For decades the only Tampa Bay restaurant with a national reputation was Bern's, known for an awesome wine list, good steaks and not much else. It carries on. But the sizzle has shifted to SideBern's, down the street, where Jeannie Pierola, a gifted young chef of eclectic bent, sets off fireworks nightly with westernized dim sum, like duck buns with vinegar syrup and crab-lobster dumplings with tamarind butter; Moroccan seared red snapper with harissa, and (homage to the older generation) a dynamic duo of short ribs and hanger steak. Selections from Bern's cellar insure that you won't leave thirsty.
 
Attractions
 
MUSEUM OF FINE ARTS, 255 Beach Drive, St. Petersburg, (727) 896-2667. Through May 31, "Treasures of Chinese Glass Workshops: Qing Dynasty Glass." Through June 13, "In the American Spirit: Realism and Impressionism." Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Sundays, 1 to 5 P.M. Admission: $6; $5 for the elderly; $2 for students; free on Sundays.
 
SALVADOR DALI MUSEUM, 1000 Third Street South, St. Petersburg, (727) 823-3767. Mondays through Saturdays, 9:30 A.M. to 5:30 P.M.; Sundays, noon to 5:30 P.M. Admission: $9; $7 for the elderly; $5 for students.
 
FLORIDA INTERNATIONAL MUSEUM, 100 Second Street North, St. Petersburg, (800) 777-9882. "Empires of Mystery," objects from the Incas and their predecessors; through May 16. Sundays through Fridays, 9 A.M. to 6 P.M.; Saturdays, 9 A.M. to 8 P.M. Admission: $13.95; $5.95 for students.
 
JOHN AND MABLE RINGLING MUSEUM OF ART, 5401 Bay Shore Road, Sarasota, (941) 359-5700. "Blurring the Boundaries: Installation Art 1969-1996," through May 2. "Restoration and Rediscovery: Craft and Materials in the Ca' d'Zan Restoration," through May 2000. Daily, 10 A.M. to 5:30 P.M. Admission: $9; $8 for the elderly.
 
VAN WEZEL PERFORMING ARTS HALL, 777 North Tamiami Trail, Sarasota, (941) 955-7676. Tonight at 8: Nikolais Dance, modern-dance group; tickets, $24 to $28. Tomorrow at 8 P.M.: Orchestra of the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden; tickets, $60 to $75; $10 student rush tickets available day of concert. Sunday at 8 P.M.: Los Angeles Philharmonic; tickets, $65 to $70.
 
TAMPA BAY PERFORMING ARTS CENTER, 1010 North W. C. MacInnes Place, Tampa, (813) 222-1000. Tonight at 7:30, tomorrow and Sunday at 2 P.M. and 7:30 P.M.: "Hollywood Nights," a cabaret performance about film history; tickets, $15 to $36. Tomorrow at 8 P.M.: "Bayou to Bourbon Street," Cajun, Creole-zydeco and New Orleans jazz; tickets, $15.50 to $29.50.
 
ASOLO THEATER, 5555 North Tamiami Trail, Sarasota, (941) 351-8000. Tonight at 8: "Ladies of the Chamelions." Tomorrow at 8 P.M.: "Abraham Lincoln in Illinois." Sunday at 8 P.M.: "The Rivals." Tickets, $12 to $38.
 
SARASOTA OPERA COMPANY, 61 North Pineapple Avenue, Sarasota, (941) 366-8450. Tonight at 7:30, Bizet's "Carmen." Tomorrow at 2 P.M., Puccini's "Rondine"; at 8 P.M., Verdi's "Luisa Miller." Sunday at 2 P.M., Rimsky-Korsakov's "May Night"; at 8 P.M., Studio Artists present ensembles and arias. Tickets: $15 to $380; Studio Artists concert, $15 to $20.
 
BUSCH GARDENS, 3605 Bougainvillea Avenue, Tampa, (813) 987-5082. Daily, 9 A.M. to 7 P.M. Admission: $40.95; $34.95 for children under 9.
 
LOWRY PARK ZOO, North Boulevard at Sligh Avenue, Tampa, (813) 932-0245. Daily, 9:30 A.M to 5 P.M. Admission: $8.50; $7.50 for the elderly; $4.95 for children under 12.
 
FLORIDA AQUARIUM, 701 Channelside Drive, Tampa, (813) 273-4000. Daily, 9:30 A.M. to 5 P.M. Admission: $11.95; $10.95 for the elderly; $6.95 for children under 12.
 
Getting There
 
From La Guardia Airport, American Airlines offers a nonstop flight to Tampa-St. Petersburg, and Midway Airlines has a flight with a stop in Raleigh. Delta Airlines and Trans World Airlines offer nonstop flights out of Kennedy Airport. For these airlines, a 14-day advance fare with a Saturday night stay-over is $190. A three-day advance fare is also $190, but travel is limited to Saturday, Tuesday and Wednesday, depending on availability. Information: American Airlines, (800) 433-7300 or www.aa.com; Delta, (800) 221-1212 or www.delta-air.com; Midway, (800) 446-4392 or www.midwayair.com; Trans World Airlines, (800) 221-2000 or www.twa.com.

HEADLINE: Mr. Spitzer's Inquiry

 BODY:
The police shooting last month of the West African immigrant Amadou Diallo is provoking ever-larger protests. Well-televised arrests at One Police Plaza trumpet the message that many New Yorkers believe the steep drop in crime has been accompanied by an increase in police harassment of minorities. Mayor Rudolph Giuliani says the demonstrations are being conducted "for a highly partisan political purpose." But it is also true that nonviolent sit-ins have become an established form of dissent when communities confront polarizing issues, and orderly protests can challenge elected officials to respond to civic concerns they might otherwise ignore. The fact that the American Jewish Committee has joined with black officials in questioning police conduct shows that worries about New York's policing practices cross racial lines.
In this context of community concern, the response of New York State's Attorney General, Eliot Spitzer, was appropriate. Mr. Spitzer announced a civil rights investigation into allegations that the police frisk many blacks and other minorities without justification. Mayor Giuliani, while angry at the demonstrators, correctly recognized Mr. Spitzer's right to conduct an inquiry. 
 The Attorney General said that during his campaign for the office last year he began hearing that New York City police were targeting nonwhites for improper searches. The complaints became more vocal and public after Feb. 4, when Mr. Diallo was killed in a fusillade of gunfire from four white police officers. A grand jury in the Bronx and Federal prosecutors are investigating the shooting. The Federal Civil Rights Commission has announced plans to hold hearings. What could distinguish the Spitzer investigation, however, is that it is focused narrowly enough to analyze police data quickly and make useful recommendations.
The Street Crimes Unit, whose officers were involved in the shooting, has been credited with lowering the murder rate by taking large numbers of illegal handguns off the street. Street Crimes police also stop many more people than they arrest, frisking 27,000 last year and arresting 4,600. The Attorney General will need to determine whether this unit has followed police guidelines, which allow frisking only if the officer "reasonably suspects" that a person could endanger police or others.
For Mr. Spitzer, who was elected last year by a slim margin, using the civil rights powers of his office to look at this crucial issue is a bold move. It would be easy for his political enemies to label this investigation as anti-police. But as Mr. Spitzer has said correctly, this inquiry, if done well, is "good for cops" because it can help rebuild the city's faith in the methods of its Police Department.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Treasuries Gain on Sign Inflation Still Is No Threat

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices rose for the second time in three sessions yesterday after a Government report pointed to tame inflation, even amid strong economic growth.
"Inflation is not going to be a problem," said Paul Van Kampen, who manages $1.3 billion of bonds at NCM Capital Management Group Inc. in Durham, N.C. Bonds hold more of their value when inflation is subdued. 
 The price of the 30-year Treasury rose 6/32 , to 96 19/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.48 percent, from 5.50 percent on Wednesday.
Consumer prices rose 1.6 percent in the 12 months ended in February. That puts 30-year yields at 3.89 percent after inflation is taken into account, near the highest since July and a level some investors find attractive.
Bond yields have fallen more than 20 basis points, or hundredths of a point, over the last two weeks as reports showing tame inflation and comments from Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, eased concern the central bank will raise interest rates soon.
That said, many investors said inflation was unlikely to go any lower.
"It's pretty clear that the economy is stronger than expected," said Kirk Hartman, who oversees $50 billion of bonds at Trade Street Investment Associates Inc. in Los Angeles. That will probably push inflation higher in the months ahead. "It's inevitable," he said.
Mr. Hartman said he favored securities like corporate bonds, which offer higher yields than Treasuries and benefit from periods of strong economic growth.
"You want to pick up excess return versus Treasuries," he said. With demand for corporate debt strong, companies including the AT&T Corporation, Federated Department Stores Inc. and Fannie Mae plan to sell at least $9.3 billion of bonds in coming days. That may limit gains in Treasuries, drawing demand away from Government debt, traders said.
Nomura Securities Inc. is also selling $2.4 billion of securities backed by commercial mortgages.
Yesterday, Peco Energy, Pennsylvania's largest utility, sold $4 billion of securities backed by a charge on customers' electric bills, the biggest such sale by a utility. The company said it plans to use proceeds in part to pay off some high-interest debt, which will result in lower electric rates.
In the largest expected sale, AT&T said it might sell more than $6 billion of bonds -- possibly topping the record $6.1 billion sold last year by MCI Worldcom Inc., the No. 2 long-distance company.

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
Jersey City Towers Broaden Lure of Living West of the Hudson

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
A 12-acre site at the southeastern corner of the giant Newport mixed-use development in Jersey City will soon be filled by the third of four rental buildings in the Towers of America complex, which is to have 1,640 units.
With all space in the first two towers rented, construction on the third, the 33-story East Hampton, began in October. Tenants have placed $100 deposits on 20 percent of the 441 studio, one-bedroom and two-bedroom apartments even before the East Hampton's white stone and green-paneled exterior is complete, according to the developer, the Lefrak Organization of Rego Park, Queens. Monthly rents for the units, with 550 to 1,200 square feet, range from $950 to $2,490. 
 The occupancy date has been pushed up by five months to August "to keep up with the demand," said Richard S. LeFrak, president of the Lefrak Organization. Construction on the final tower, with 409 units, is to start in May.
The pace of construction at the $250 million complex reflects the second round of redevelopment along the west bank of the Hudson in New Jersey since the 1991-92 recession. The activity, which resumed in mid-1995, ending an eight-year slump in construction, has picked up momentum in the last 18 months. By year's end, about 1,550 rental units, many of them in Jersey City, are to be completed along the waterfront, where the vacancy rate is 3 percent, according to the ACI Group, a real estate services concern in Jersey City.
"The trend is strong and will continue as long as there is pressure on rents in Manhattan," said Carol M. Smith, director of marketing at Marketing Directors, a Manhattan-based consulting and marketing firm. Since the riverfront units are not coming onto the market at the same time, demand is ahead of supply, she added.
The demand is coming from a broader group of renters than the young professionals who came to the waterfront more than a decade ago, said Robert P. Antonicello, president of the ACI Group. Renters now include executive couples who work in Manhattan or in the office towers at the water's edge, as well as older couples from the suburbs and some families. There is also a steady, and some say increasing, number of people moving from New York City as rents there continue to rise.
A survey conducted by the Lefrak Organization showed that more than half of the residents of Towers of America, for example, came from New York City and that 85 percent of them worked in Manhattan. Many are professionals employed in financial services, law, communications and high-technology fields and they have average annual incomes of $127,000, the survey found.
Jon-Mark Odero, 23, who lives in midtown Manhattan and works as an analyst for a financial services concern in the financial district, put down a deposit for a fourth-floor studio at the East Hampton. "For the money I'm paying, Jersey is a better deal," he said, adding that the apartment is also larger and more conveniently located to his job.
Mr. LeFrak said the broadening demand for riverside housing was tied to the growth of the waterfront as a "viable community and an acceptable alternative to Manhattan." He said his company was "bullish about the market because the local job base continues to expand."
Indeed, his company is building a 567,318-square-foot office building, the third at Newport, and has leased about 300,000 square feet to Cigna and the U.S. Trust Company. Together, they are expected to bring 1,100 workers to the riverfront.
Robert Cotter, director of planning for Jersey City, said the growth of the waterfront had brought additional amenities, like restaurants, and would bring the city its first golf course, part of the Port Liberte condominium development, 1,290 units being developed by the Applied Companies of Hoboken, N.J.
Today's riverfront rental apartments are also larger than their earlier counterparts, Mr. Antonicello said, with two-bedroom units averaging 1,200 square feet. He added that developers were also including three-bedroom apartments for couples with children, tenants who want home offices or professionals who want to share an apartment. At the East Hampton, the Lefrak Organization will combine units to create larger ones.
Along with high-rise buildings, mid- and low-rise rental complexes have been or are being built along the Hudson in New Jersey. Among the first was Avalon Cove, with 504 units in twin five-story buildings that frame courtyards. It was developed by Avalon Bay Communities, which has built rental complexes in a number of New York suburbs in recent years. Other projects under way include the Landings at Port Imperial in West New York, with 276 units in four three-story buildings, which is being developed by Roseland Properties of Roseland. In Jersey City, Mr. Cotter said, plans are advancing for 324 rental units designed to resemble brownstones.
Some developers are also building condominiums. K. Hovnanian Enterprises of Red Bank, N.J., is developing 258 such units on 14 acres in West New York. More are planned, including 800 units the Lefrak Organization is to build, in phases, on a pier jutting out to the river after the fourth rental tower at Towers of America is completed next year, Mr. LeFrak said.
While rentals dominate the waterfront, turnover rates remain consistent, at less than 20 percent a year, and prices continue to increase, according to the ACI Group. The average rent is $25 per square foot per year, compared with $40 per square foot for comparable apartments in downtown Manhattan, Mr. Antonicello said.

HEADLINE: Consumer Prices Held Almost Steady in February

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 18

 BODY:
Consumer prices barely budged in February as reductions in apparel, automobile and fuel oil costs almost canceled out small increases in food and medical care expenses, the Labor Department reported today.
The Consumer Price Index, the Government's broadest measure of costs for goods and services, rose one-tenth of 1 percent last month, matching the increase in each of the previous two months. 
 With prices rising at an annual rate of only 1.6 percent, "there is no urgency for the Federal Reserve to tighten policy in the foreseeable future," said Kevin Flanagan, an economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company in New York.
Separately, the Labor Department reported that first-time jobless claims increased by 6,000, to 298,000, in the week ended last Saturday, more than the 292,000 analysts had expected. Claims have stayed below 300,000 for seven weeks, the longest stretch since April 6-May 18, 1974.
The four-week average for claims -- a less volatile measure of employment conditions -- fell to 292,750 from 293,000.
The consumer price report showed that food prices, which account for almost a fifth of the index, rose one-tenth of 1 percent in February after increasing five-tenths of 1 percent in January. Energy prices, which account for almost a tenth, were unchanged as fuel oil prices dropped 1.4 percent while electricity prices rose six-tenths of 1 percent. Medical care costs rose two-tenths of 1 percent, led by a five-tenths of 1 percent increase in prescription drug costs.
Prices of personal computers fell 2.8 percent in February after dropping 4.4 percent in January. New and used auto prices fell seven-tenths of 1 percent, after declining four-tenths of 1 percent the month earlier. The cost of used cars and light trucks fell 1.5 percent on top of a 1.6 percent January decrease. Prices for new cars declined three-tenths of 1 percent in February.
Housing costs, which make up two-fifths of the index, increased one-tenth of 1 percent in February, led by an increase of two-tenths of 1 percent in shelter prices, which measure costs of mortgages and rent.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
Unseen Risks For a Buyer Of Nissan

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 18

 BODY:
DaimlerChrysler A.G. has been painting a grim picture of the Nissan Motor Company's balance sheet -- or rather, what is absent from it.
Since DaimlerChrysler stopped talking with Nissan last week about purchasing a stake in the heavily indebted Japanese auto maker, Renault of France has stepped forward with an offer. But investors seem more interested in why DaimlerChrysler walked away. 
 Publicly, it has been saying that it decided against taking a stake in Nissan in the interest of concentrating on the smooth integration of Daimler-Benz and the Chrysler Corporation, which combined their businesses only in November.
In private, however, DaimlerChrysler has been telling fund managers and analysts in Europe and the United States that even though it had 30 people examining Nissan's financial statements and operations for six months, it cannot say for certain that it firmly grasped the full extent of the company's potential liabilities.
DaimlerChrysler's disclosures have exposed Nissan to intense scrutiny and left many wondering whether Renault kicked the tires hard enough before making its offer on Tuesday. Renault's proposal to acquire 35 percent of Nissan, which the Japanese auto maker's board will review on Friday, could provide as much as $5.3 billion.
According to two fund managers and a fund-management analyst who have been briefed by Daimler, the more its team looked at Nissan, the more exposure there seemed to be.
"In having to defend itself, the news that's coming out of DaimlerChrysler about Nissan is not very positive," one of the fund managers said.
A person familiar with DaimlerChrysler's research suggested that Nissan's true liabilities -- not just debt but also such potential obligations as pension contributions and loan guarantees for affiliates -- were twice as great as the $21.2 billion that is publicly known.
The inconsistency in Renault's decision to bid and DaimlerChrysler's decision to withdraw has left investors skeptical, which is reflected in the depressed stock prices of Nissan and Renault. Credit-rating agencies have also expressed reservations, and financial news coverage has been muted on what would be a major foreign rescue of a leading Japanese corporation.
Instead, there is avid interest in matters like the steep erosion in Nissan's sales in Japan, the effect of the stronger yen on overseas sales, the higher-than-average interest rates Nissan is paying and the shortage in its pension fund. Some Japanese have long agonized over such things, but now these are gaining international attention.
There is little concern that Renault has the financial resources to pay for a Nissan stake -- the French company is debt-free, has ample lines of credit, and is 44 percent-owned by the French Government. Renault executives also insist they have an accurate reading on Nissan's business, including its debts.
According to a person close to the two companies' negotiations, Nissan had at first been willing to supply only limited, and opaque, information about its liabilities. But in recent weeks, it gave Renault executives answers that Renault considered satisfactory.
Although he did not offer a firm figure, this person conceded that Nissan's real indebtedness was certainly greater than the 2.5 trillion yen -- now $21.2 billion -- disclosed in the company's last annual report, reflecting the fiscal year that ended on March 31, 1998.
Nissan had an additional 1.8 trillion yen in liabilities related to its auto-leasing business for a total of 4.3 trillion yen in debt, although many analysts and auto-company executives do not regard leasing-related debt as a matter of concern.
But it is the auto maker's indebtedness outside what it is required to disclose that has concerned others, including DaimlerChrysler. Such so-called off-balance-sheet risks have long been rumored at Nissan and at other large Japanese companies, and Daimler is not the first potential buyer to have been scared away by them.
The Ford Motor Company is still smarting from the surprise it got when it increased its stake in the Mazda Motor Corporation to 33.4 percent in 1996, only to find out that Mazda's dealers had incurred enormous debts for which Mazda was liable, Ford executives have said.
Just last month, the Japanese Life Insurance Association abandoned its efforts to sell the Aoba Life Insurance Company after a big French concern, Pinault-Printemps-Redoute, cut its original bid in half. Previously, the American International Group, the insurer and financial-services company, was the leading suitor, but it walked away.
Speculation is rampant that among other things Aoba was more financially problematic than the suitors had been able to see from public documents. "No investment banker is being candid about what happened there," said Craig Chudler, an equity strategist at Nikko Salomon Smith Barney. "But I think AIG and Pinault must have seen something that shocked them."
Large Japanese companies such as Nissan are structured so that a vast galaxy of satellite companies, typically suppliers of parts and services, are locked into orbit around them by a combination of investments, loans and business relationships.
The potential liabilities associated with many of those companies -- the losses they sustain, the debts they cannot repay, the shortages in their pension funds -- often ultimately fall upon the main company but are not fully reflected in its public financial records, nor is such disclosure required.
If, for instance, the core company's investment in a satellite is now worth half what it originally paid, the decline in value is not necessarily reflected on the balance sheet.
Nissan, for instance, has 201 affiliates whose overall performance is reflected in its financial statements. Beyond that cluster, Nissan is linked to 389 companies whose fortunes are not reflected on its books but whose problems may become its own.
Keiichi Tsuboi, a spokesman for Nissan, noted that its interests in those 389 companies constitute less than 10 percent of its total revenue on a consolidated basis, a limit imposed by Japanese accounting rules.
"Of course, there are debts at the unconsolidated companies, but we don't think the total debt is significant," Mr. Tsuboi said.
As of April 1, many of the off-balance-sheet liabilities must start to appear on financial statements under new accounting rules that are expected to shake corporate Japan to its foundations -- though many obligations like loan guarantees may still remain hidden.
The new accounting rules will expose just the sort of off-balance-sheet problems that Nissan disclosed last week. Its plans to recapitalize the sales unit of its troubled truck-making affiliate, the Nissan Diesel Motor Company, further raised sensitivity to the issue of unseen liabilities.
Nissan and Nissan Diesel said they would each invest 20 billion yen ($170 million) in the unit, the Nissan Diesel Sales Company, even though Nissan's only exposure to it was through its 39.8 percent stake in Nissan Diesel. "A gap has emerged between the book value of the investment made in domestic dealerships which are owned by Nissan Diesel Motor Sales and the real value of those dealerships," Nissan said in a press statement.
The gap Nissan referred to was equivalent to roughly half the book value of the investment in the sales unit, and its magnitude surprised many analysts. Nissan Diesel sold only half as many trucks last year as the year before, leaving its dealers with bloated inventories and no way to repay their loans.
Some analysts had suspected as much, but because the sales unit is not a public company and does not disclose financial information, the analysts had no way of gauging the extent of Nissan's exposure.
"Maybe I'm just stupid, but I had no idea the losses in that business would run so high," said Peter Boardman of Warburg Dillon Read here. "Yes, it was good news in that they were able to overcome a crisis, but it also allowed the market to see how big the losses were."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
A Long-Shot House Vote to Limit Steel Imports

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE 

 BODY:
With surprising force and fury, the House's vote to limit steel imports reflects a strong sense of frustration within the domestic steel industry over low-price steel that landed on American shores during economic crises in Asia and Russia last year.
But the measure, a violation of world trade rules and a long shot at best in the Senate, would do little to help the American steel industry in the long run, even if the measure -- or a form of it -- were to be enacted. The industry is still losing about 10,000 jobs a year, is saddled with plants that are very expensive to run and is constantly buffeted by economic forces beyond its control from lands far away. 
 Oddly enough, this measure, decried as a protectionist gift to gain union votes for the 2000 election by both parties, comes as the American steel industry begins to recover from the wave of imports that drove down steel prices to 25-year lows last year. The industry is about to benefit from a growing demand for steel products from an economy that continues to remain strong.
That is the good news for the short run. Within the next year, analysts expect that there will be enough demand to keep American steel manufacturers running at full capacity. Just this month, steelmakers pushed through a price increase and have seen that imports, which last year caused havoc in steel prices, are now beginning to return to more normal levels -- in January 1999 steel imports came to 2.7 million tons, compared with 2.5 million tons the previous January.
Still, American steelmakers fear that what happened to them in late 1998, when low-cost imports from Japan, Russia, Brazil and other economically troubled countries soared to nearly four million tons a month, or nearly 40 percent of the domestic market, will happen again. They contend that the industry, which faces falling employment and marginal profitability, cannot sustain a similar blow.
For that reason, even though many in the steel industry readily admit that the House's 289-to-141 vote for import limits was largely symbolic, it represents a renewed belief in the need for protectionist measures -- a view that free-trade advocates say is dangerous and which runs afoul of the Clinton Administration's free-market views. A Presidential veto remains possible. In fact, the House-passed measure is the first in a package of about eight trade bills that the steel industry and unions want to see introduced in the 106th Congress. The measure would limit steel imports to pre-1997 levels, in violation of World Trade Organization rules.
"This measure is both symbolic and real," said Curtis Barnette, the chief executive of Bethlehem Steel, who will speak on behalf of the bill before the Senate Finance Committee next Tuesday. "We are actively working with other steel companies and the unions to carry our message as forcefully as we can. We're pleased that the House has recognized what we are talking about." George Becker, president of the United Steelworkers of America, also praised the measure. "With 10,000 steelworkers already out of work, three major steel producers in bankruptcy, another on the brink, and virtually every steel producer experiencing huge losses, action isn't an option; it's an absolute necessity," he said.
Others, however, say that the steel industry's concerns are overstated and that their approach is dangerous -- a continuation on a decades-old pattern of calling on Washington for help. "This is very blatant politicking on behalf of Congress to appeal to special interests in the steel industry and unions," said Waldo Best, an analyst with Morgan Stanley. "It creates the image that something is being done, but nothing is really being done. This is a very political piece of legislation that won't do anything meaningful for the industry."
Robert W. Crandall, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, a Washington research group, said the measure "doesn't mean much."
"There is no doubt that the surge of imports had some effects on steel makers, but this measure will have little impact on the industry in the long run," he said. "The real problem for old-line big steel is that they are being eaten alive by the mini-mills, which are making life miserable for these big guys. We are talking about a long-drawn-out end game for big steel."
In the last half-century, the American steel industry has continued to shrink; today it has about 170,000 employees compared with 500,000 in the 1950's.
And, while the steel producers complain about low-cost imports, users of steel benefit. The General Motors Corporation, for instance, opposes the limits. "We are in opposition to this resolution and think it's a rush to judgment that will probably have serious economic implications," the company said.
Overseas steel producers often operate in the same way as big steel makers here but, at times of economic turmoil in their home countries, they have shipped steel products to the United States at extremely low prices in an attempt to to stabilize their economies. These overseas producers often have far lower labor costs than in the United States.
Ken Hoffman, a steel analyst with Prudential Securities, said that by the time United States steel companies -- which have successfully filed anti-dumping suits against Brazil and Japan -- got relief in the form of high tariff protections, the crisis would have passed. Moreover, Mr. Hoffman said the House vote also reflected anti-Clinton sentiment both in the House and in the industry over the Administration's slow response.
Supporters of free trade and some steel importers were adamant in their opposition to import restrictions. "This is one of the worst pieces of legislation to come out of the House, and that's saying a lot," said Dan Griswold, associate director for trade policy studies at the Cato Institute. "There is not a steel crisis issue. Just look at the high level of steel shipments."
David Phelps, the executive director of the American Institute for International Steel, a trade group, added: "The steel industry is historically addicted to trade protection and that addiction has yet to be broken. We hope the Senate will give this ridiculous bill the indecent burial it deserves."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Silicon Valley's Awesome Look at New Sony Toy

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

DATELINE: SAN JOSE, Calif., March 18

 BODY:
On a giant video screen, a lifelike rubber duck splashed about in a bathtub fleeing from a pursuing submarine. Suddenly the drain opened and both were swept into the resulting whirlpool.
What made this demonstration today by the Sony Corporation notable was that the scene, rendered with almost perfect realism down to each reflection in each ripple in the tub, was not a movie but an interactive video game that signaled a new level of computing power for everyday consumers. 
 Sony's Playstation II, though still more than a year away from store shelves, is creating a stir here in Silicon Valley because it is the first machine to deliver graphics that until now could be produced only by supercomputers -- and at prices that will put it under Christmas trees in 2000.
Shown for the first time in the United States, to 1,000 software game developers, the machine suggested that the state of the art in computing is moving from the aisles of CompUSA to the shelves of Toys "R" Us.
Playstation II, which Sony says it expects to sell for substantially less than $500, is perhaps the most striking example yet of a coming generation of powerful computer processors that are not designed for traditional computers. Instead, they are engineered to concentrate all their considerable power on performing highly specialized tasks.
The new Sony machine will not process text or calculate a budget, but it will take a generation of youngsters to the threshhold of virtual reality.
"I think what you're seeing is the transition from people playing video games to a world where we will create our own fantasies in cyberspace," said Larry Smarr, director of the National Center for Supercomputer Applications, in Champaign-Urbana, Ill.
Playstation II was developed by Sony and the Toshiba Corporation in a joint venture that adds up to an estimated $2 billion gamble on the future of consumer electronics. Though the two companies are playing down speculation that their new chip could catapult them into competition with makers of personal computer hardware and software, many opportunities are obviously ahead for a machine that generates graphics at more than twice the speed of the most powerful engineering work stations.
The brain of Playstation II is a microprocessor that the two companies have dubbed the Emotion Engine. It is designed to draw tens of millions of tiny polygons, the building blocks of computer graphics, on a television screen every second. As a result, it renders animated graphics with the realism of the movie "Toy Story" but in what is known as "real time." That is, it creates movement, characters and entire environments on the fly in response to the movement of a joystick or other gaming device.
"Sony is clearly riding on a consumer mandate and delivering supercomputer graphics," said Richard Doherty, president of Envisioneering, a computer industry consulting firm in Seaford, N.Y. "People will buy the Playstation II just to get at the chip."
Sony executives said they intended the name Emotion Engine to convey the hope that game developers would use the chip's power to create virtual worlds rich in subtlety and nuance.
"We're hoping that you will go beyond driving and shooting and killing people," Phil Harrison, a vice president at Sony Computer Entertainment, told the developers. "We are looking for a new generation of software that has the same impact on a person as a great book or a great movie."
He said the new processor had enough power to begin to convey humanlike motions and abilities, ranging from natural movement and facial expressions to artificial intelligence like the ability to learn and to recognize speech.
The Emotion Engine is the most recent example of a reversal under way in technological development. For decades, the most advanced consumer electronics were technologies that trickled down from the world of supercomputing, the Departments of Defense and Energy and NASA. That process has been turned on its head, mostly by the economics of the consumer electronics industry, which has evolved from a beneficiary of cutting-edge computer engineering to its driving force.
Since the end of the cold war, increasingly powerful computer products have begun showing up first in consumer applications. For graphics and related multimedia processing, for example, the Emotion Engine is significantly more powerful than the Intel Corporation's newest Pentium III microprocessor and has more than twice the graphics power of the most powerful Silicon Graphics work station, the benchmark for graphics computing power.
Yet, benchmarks and flashy graphics do not guarantee success in a computer. Indeed, Silicon Valley is littered with news releases from companies that promised to shake up the world with ever-faster computers. The vast majority failed to leave the laboratory and "auger in" to the market, in local parlance.
The Emotion Engine is unlikely to suffer that fate, if only because of the market muscle behind its developers. Still, production in quantity awaits the completion of a modern semiconductor plant that Sony and Toshiba expect to go on line next year.
What is more, some analysts questioned Sony's announcing Playstation II before it is available. It will arrive on the market later than its main competition, the Sega Dreamcast machine, which was recently introduced in Japan.
Sony executives went to some pains today to assert that their new machine was not a competitor to Wintel, the combination of the Microsoft Corporation's Windows operating system and Intel's Pentium microprocessors that dominates the personal computer industry.
"There are certain things the PC does really well, such as running as a server and displaying Powerpoint slides," said Mr. Harrison, the Sony Computer Entertainment executive.
Still, the company has given every indication that it envisions a new computing world that has little to do with the office desktop. In this world, brilliant graphics and mathematics-intensive tasks like voice recognition will matter most. And it is in this world, Mr. Harrison said, that the Emotion Engine will excel.
But it is clear to computer designers that the potential for Sony's computer is enormous because its graphics power will be coupled with high-speed connections to the Internet through cable and satellite links.
While company executives were coy about that possibility, they did announce that the Playstation II would incorporate ports for the two fastest communications channels available today -- Firewire and the Universal Serial Bus. It is also noteworthy that the machine will ship with the industry-standard slots for connecting peripherals like modems, network cards, hard drives and flash memory to laptop computers. Firewire is evolving as the standard for connecting a new generation of digital video cameras.
These features could make Sony a powerful competitor to Microsoft if software developers begin to abandon the personal computer platform when creating their newest and most advanced applications.
"This machine heralds the merger of film, television and the video game businesses," said Stewart A. Halpern, a Wall Street analyst at ING Baring Furman Selz.
Others are already looking to take Playstation II beyond games.
"This is the first credible alternative to the PC for reaching people on the Internet," said Carl Malamud, chairman of Invisible Worlds, an Internet software company in Redwood City, Calif.

HEADLINE: Millions Are Problem Gamblers, Report Says

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 18

 BODY:
More than 5 million Americans are pathological or problem gamblers, and 15 million more are at risk of becoming just like them, said a study released today that was conducted for the National Gambling Impact Study Commission.
Despite that finding, the study said that the economic impact of the problem gambling was "relatively small." 
 A second report, also released today as the commission began two days of meetings in Washington, estimated that 1.8 million American adults as well as up to 1.1 million American adolescents ages 12 through 17 engaged in severe "pathological" gambling each year.
The commission has three months to finish a wide-ranging report on gambling for Congress, and the extent of compulsive gambling in the country is just one of several open issues. Yet gambling addiction is the most contentious topic.
The report said the annual economic cost of problem gambling was about $5 billion in legal fees for divorce, court and jail costs for arrests, lost wages and bankruptcy.

LENGTH: 1084 words

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
U.S. TRADE DEFICIT SOARS AS IMPORTS INCREASE SHARPLY

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 18

 BODY:
As American exports continued to fall, the United States trade deficit jumped to a monthly record of nearly $17 billion in January, fueled by a flood of imports from China that could stir further protectionist sentiments in Congress.
Among the imports flowing into the United States, Chinese-made steel surged 65 percent from December. On Wednesday, the House of Representatives overwhelmingly passed a bill that would sharply limit steel imports, a movement that may gain momentum now that China is joining Japan, Brazil and Russia on the list of nations pouring inexpensive steel into the American market. 
 The figures were released today just as China and the United States entered a critical phase in negotiations over China's push to enter the World Trade Organization, which sets the rules for international trade. China wants the international prestige that comes from joining the trade organization and would also get a measure of protection against trade barriers to its exports.
Intense talks are under way in Geneva over the terms of China's entry in hopes of reaching an agreement before the Prime Minister of China, Zhu Rongji, visits Washington in early April. The deadline has breathed life into talks that have sputtered for a decade.
One American negotiator said this week that "we've made more progress with the Chinese in the last three weeks than in the last three years," and this morning President Clinton's top economic advisers met at the White House to assess China's intentions.
But they emerged uncertain -- both about the prospects of getting China to dismantle huge barriers and the prospects of getting any deal though Capitol Hill, where it would become instantly wrapped up in the politics of nuclear espionage, human rights violations and growing anti-China sentiment.
"Altogether, we have a mounting series of problems that are going to be difficult to manage, to say the least," Commerce Secretary William M. Daley said today.
The soaring monthly trade deficit -- after a record $170 billion deficit for all of 1998 -- considerably exceeded analysts' expectations of $14.9 billion. The $16.99 billion deficit in goods and services was the highest since monthly statistics began being reported in 1992.
The deficit in manufactured goods rose to a record $23.42 billion in January from $20.5 billion in December. The United States, however, ran a $6.4 billion surplus in services, from consulting to insurance.
But the deficit also reflected the continued strength of the American economy, which has created an enormous demand for imported consumer goods. The sharp increase occurred even though there was no rise in the value of imported gasoline and other petroleum products, now selling at prices lower than at any point in the last quarter-century.
Perhaps the most worrisome part of the report was not the rise in imports but the falloff in exports. They decreased to $76.8 billion, from $79.5 billion in the month a year earlier, led by falling demand for farm goods including corn, oil seeds and cotton and manufactured products including oilfield drilling equipment, farm machinery, aircraft and autos. Imports of goods and services rose to $93.8 billion, compared with $89.6 billion in January 1998, led by shipments of foreign autos, food and consumer goods.
So far the decline in exports has had little effect on the unemployment rate or the growth of the economy, which expanded 6 percent in the fourth quarter of last year. Except in hard-hit steel towns, booming domestic consumer demand has made up for the falloff in exports. But the numbers suggest that the United States will not have export markets to fall back on if the domestic economy cools this year.
The export figures are particularly troublesome for the White House, where officials who once proclaimed that America's surging exports were creating jobs and fueling the economy are now arguing that rising imports can be healthy, too. Today, officials cautioned about reading too much into the January numbers.
"I don't worry much about the monthly numbers of any kind," Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin said today. "We are the only major economy that is growing at a robust rate." At the same time, Mr. Rubin and other Administration officials have begun explicitly warning Europe that the United States cannot be expected to continue to absorb such a huge share of the goods the rest of the world produces.
But so far, the United States remains the world's only real engine of growth -- meaning that the trade deficit will likely swell further this year. Despite hints that a modest revival may be in the offing, Japan remains in deep recession, and American exports to Japan fell 10 percent compared with those in January 1998. Perhaps more politically important, exports to China for the month were down to $779 million from $1.35 billion in December, a tiny figure compared with imports of $5.56 billion. Put another way, the ratio of United States imports to exports with China is 7 to 1. With Japan it is roughly 2 to 1, suggesting that the problems of access to the Chinese market are far worse.
The Administration argues that a deal to get China into the World Trade Organization would solve some of those problems over the long run. It would force China to sharply reduce its protective tariffs, and it would include access to the Chinese market for American food producers, banks, insurance companies and other businesses. American computer makers are pushing hard for a deal and wrote to Congress this week urging a relaxing of export restrictions of American technology there -- something that stands little chance of happening given the politics of relations between China and the United States this week.
The combination of allegations about spying at American weapons laboratories and the rising deficit with China combine into a sense that China is intent on playing outside the rules -- and many members of Congress think that W.T.O. membership would be a reward to Beijing.
That belief could hinder any chances for a deal, a senior Chinese diplomat, He Yafei, said at a news conference today.
"I believe the political atmosphere will have a bearing on any negotiation between our two countries," he said. "Especially when some members or senators are saying, 'Even if you have a deal, even if that deal is good for the U.S. business community, we will not give China permanent normal trade relations.' "
Mr. He concluded, "That is absurd."

U.S. Trade Deficit Soars To Almost $17 Billion
The nation's trade deficit jumped to a monthly record of nearly $17 billion in January, fueled by a flood of imports from China that could stir further protectionist sentiments in Congress. 
 Among the imports pouring into the United States was Chinese-made steel, which increased 65 percent from December. Tobacco Companies Win Ohio Suit
In a significant legal victory for tobacco companies, a Federal jury in Akron, Ohio, ruled that they do not have to reimburse dozens of union health and benefit plans in that state for the costs of treating smoking-related illnesses. A verdict in favor of the union plans, which were seeking up to $2 billion in damages, could have created financial turmoil for some cigarette makers. HEADLINE: On My Mind;
A Return to India

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

DATELINE: NEW DELHI

 BODY:
When I was young in India, for four years I reported a story I wrote of as "the great adventure" and believed was one of the most important of our century.
During the decade after India became independent a half-century ago, I relished that story: Almost alone among countries newly freed from colonialism, India had chosen and kept democracy as its governance. The others mostly went quickly under hard-boot government -- Communism, Fascism, militarism, juntaism, whatever it chose to be called. 
 Each time I return, I know India's decision remains central and hopeful for itself and the world. But America and its allies think about India with a mixture of condescension and irritability at its desire to be seen and heard -- when they think of it at all.
Every Indian government has resented "India Who?" but somehow managed to carry on. For precisely a year, for instance, India has been writing some pages in its history that may shape the adventure as none since Nehru died in 1964 and his Congress Party ousted itself from power by arrogance and corruption.
The current ruling coalition, 14 parties headed by the Hindu-centered Bharatiya Janata Party, will stay in power or lose it depending on three things. One is the ability of Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee to wean his party from the wildly bigoted Hindu-first hard-liners and toward a moderation they detest. Another is his still-forming economic strategy. How far and fast will he move India from its mixture of private enterprise and strangulation by regulation toward economic openness inviting to investment?
But to move at all he will have to end the outbreak of persecution of the small Christian minority. Churches have been burned, worshipers beaten and murdered.
The police dawdle. A government investigation commission has publicly protested its lack of resources and power.
This in a country where a man once considered an untouchable is President, where people of almost every minority -- Muslims, Christians, Sikhs, Jews, Buddhists -- have reached high office, where Mother Teresa received a state funeral. It is a country where civil peace depends on the constitutional guarantees of equality among India's religions -- almost as many as the world's.
Christians are only 2 percent of India's billion people. But what one minority suffers, all others fear.
The persecution is the work of Hindu nationalists supporting Mr. Vajpayee. He will have to choose between issuing one more denunciation of the persecution and taking action that will cost him extremist backing that helped bring him to office.
All these years, India's political and religious leaders and its wealthy have failed the Indian people. For hundreds of millions, the poverty is an insult to their very humanity.
India still has enough street-sleepers to populate a sizable nation. Scores of thousands in its capital live in hovels built on stilts so that perhaps during monsoons open sewers will not flood inside with excrement.
But through it all Indians consistently insisted on their own fundamentalism -- the right to vote politicians into office, or out.
The West sometimes remembers India, as when India wins its attention by carrying out nuclear tests.
But Kosovo, Bosnia, Somalia, bananas -- those are the big "foreign" concerns for Americans. Also: Can we succeed in appeasing China, which is a perpetual threat to India? Can we make China stronger with trade that costs us military secrets and a yearly commercial imbalance of $50 billion?
Europeans at least are consistent, historically regarding Asia as a mango to be sliced up or squeezed into juice.
Strange thing -- not a Western word is said about where the world would be if Indians had chosen the Mao or Stalin way, or Saddam's. We certainly would not be one bit condescending or irritable about India.
We would be too busy worrying about how to deal with a totalitarian axis running through Asia, the Pacific, the Mideast and Eastern Europe, headquartered in Beijing, Moscow and New Delhi -- if we were allowed to deal at all.
Indians chose the freedom of democracy for their sakes, not ours. Still, it is nice to remember that choose it they did, and still are.

HEADLINE: U.S. Official Questions How Russia Used Loan

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 18

 BODY:
The Treasury Secretary, Robert E. Rubin, told a Congressional panel today that he suspected that much of the $4.8 billion in loans sent to Russia last summer by the International Monetary Fund "may have been siphoned off improperly."
It was the Clinton Administration's first public statement supporting accusations that bailout money simply helped wealthy Russian oligarchs move billions of dollars to Switzerland and other safe havens. 
 Financial regulators note that a huge flow of dollars left Russia immediately after the monetary fund's cash was delivered to the Russian central bank, suggesting investors were getting out before the ruble was permitted to collapse on Aug. 17.
The timing of Mr. Rubin's comments was particularly significant because Russia's Prime Minister, Yevgeny M. Primakov, arrives here in five days on a mission to obtain the next installment of $22 billion in loans. It is unclear whether he will succeed, though there is growing pressure on the I.M.F. to lend Russia just enough money to allow it to pay back several billion dollars that it owes to the fund in coming months.
Mr. Primakov has been publicly pushing the move, which amounts to accounting sleight-of-hand, for two months now, chiefly because it would keep Russia from formal default.
Mr. Rubin suggested today that, despite endemic corruption and Mr. Primakov's seeming inability to put together an economic plan, the United States still had an interest in financially aiding the country. The United States has the largest block of votes within the I.M.F.
"If Russia destabilizes, the costs to the United States are going to be vastly greater than anything we can think of," Mr. Rubin said.
After his testimony before a House appropriations subcommittee, Mr. Rubin once again deflected reports that he might be planning to resign. Such reports have sprung up repeatedly in recent years and resurfaced after the conclusion of President Clinton's impeachment trial.
The relative calm in the world economy has contributed to the revival of the rumors. And this week, the Treasury Department announced that Mr. Rubin would not be attending an annual meeting of Asian finance ministers in May, because the meeting conflicted with Mr. Rubin's commitments to make several commencement addresses.
In a conversation today after his appearance before the House panel, Mr. Rubin qualified his testimony by saying that "it may have been careless to use the word 'improper' " because "there is nothing improper about moving money out of Russia or any other country."
In this case, however, the capital flight may have helped buy time for a group of Russia's most powerful business executives, who wanted to convert their rubles to dollars before the ruble was devalued.
The money from the fund went to the Russian central bank. And the bank spent it to intervene in the markets and buy rubles for several weeks. Some money may also have been provided to banks, giving their clients access to dollars in return for ruble deposits. The result was that the $4.8 billion was quickly drained away, and a similar amount appeared in overseas bank accounts. This only could have been avoided with capital controls, rules that prevent taking money out of the country, which the United States has rarely supported in recent years.
"Money is fungible," said Mr. Rubin, "so it is hard to say exactly what happened to it. I can't tell you exactly what happened."
The bitter experience of last July, though, has left the I.M.F. wary about making a second loan installment. Some fear that giving Russia more money than it currently owes would invite a repetition of the capital flight. Moreover, Russia has made scant progress on economic reforms that the fund could seize upon as a reason for new loans.
The budget Russia adopted recently is considered largely unrealistic by American officials and the fund itself. There has been little progress on tax collection in Russia, the I.M.F. says, and just the other day the Russian parliament cut a value-added tax, angering fund officials.
The Russians are also angry. They argue that the fund's conditions are far too stringent and will contribute to the country's recession. The fund's managing director, Michel Camdessus, engaged in an unusual public exchange with Mr. Primakov's aides several weeks ago, and another top I.M.F. official told the Trilateral Commission here this weekend that Russia's Government is so weak that its economic commitments cannot be trusted.
Mr. Rubin, while more elliptical, made a similar point today in his testimony. "If Russia is going to have a successful economy, there are going to have to be a whole host of reforms that provide the framework for a market economy," Mr. Rubin told the House subcommittee.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Jobless Rate Edges Up

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
New York's jobless rate inched upward in February to 5.3 percent, nearly a full percentage point higher than the national average for last month, the State Labor Department reported yesterday.
Analysts said there were some positive trends in the state's employment picture last month, including a record for private-sector jobs, at 6,761,000, and a year-to-year drop in joblessless from 6.0 percent in February 1998 to 5.3 percent last month. 
 Unemployment fell nationally to 4.4 percent last month from 4.6 percent in February 1998, statisticians reported. New York's jobless rate in January was 5.2 percent on a seasonably adjusted rate.
