HEADLINE: Call by Call, Hillary Clinton Queries New York Leaders

BYLINE: By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

 BODY:
In the month since announcing her interest in a United States Senate seat from New York, Hillary Rodham Clinton has discussed her potential candidacy with more than 50 influential Democrats in the state, most often in lengthy telephone calls she placed from the private quarters of the White House.
Mrs. Clinton, over the last few weeks, talked about her possible political future with labor leaders, elected officials and Democratic party chairmen from suburban and upstate counties crucial to winning a race. She also recently entertained powerful New York Democrats and public figures at the White House, including Dennis Rivera, the labor leader. 
 Several of those who spoke with Mrs. Clinton said she did not hint at her ultimate decision, but was systematically studying the politics and issues of a state where she has never lived. A number of them said she told them that she planned to do polling and was looking for ways to raise money even before she made a decision on the race.
Many of the county officials, who seem stunned and pleased by the First Lady's attention, described their conversations about local issues with Mrs. Clinton as lengthy and very detailed.
"She's obviously been doing her homework," said Steve Pigeon, the Democratic chairman of Erie County, the state's largest Democratic stronghold outside of New York City. Mr. Pigeon said he spoke by phone to Mrs. Clinton for an hour on Monday night. "I have to explain to a lot of candidates who come to me that you can't view upstate monolithically," he said. "She already knew the vast differences."
Mr. Pigeon said Mrs. Clinton told him she did not want her delay in making a decision to undercut the ability of other potential Democratic candidates -- like Representative Nita M. Lowey of Westchester -- to raise money.
Largely because of the possible impact on other likely candidates and their ability to raise money if Mrs. Clinton does not run, many Democrats have been irked by her announcement that she will not decide until "later this year," perhaps as late as the fall. The election is in November 2000.
In an apparent response to that concern, the First Lady and her advisers are exploring fund-raising options. "She said they're looking for vehicles to raise money to be used for whoever the candidate is," Mr. Pigeon said. "I think as long as she's raising money that can be used no matter who runs, whether it's her or Nita, that can buy some time."
Election law lawyers said yesterday that such a vehicle might be a committee, allowed under Federal election law, that would raise money for an unspecified Senate candidate in donations of up to $1,000.
In making her calls, Mrs. Clinton works from a list of 200 names provided by Harold M. Ickes, a former White House official and a veteran of New York politics. Mrs. Clinton's advisers say she has methodically made her way through the Democratic power structure in New York State, reaching out not only to labor leaders and local Democratic leaders, but to fund-raisers, members of the New York Congressional delegation and leaders of black, Jewish, Hispanic and women's groups.
She has also had meetings at the White House -- yesterday with the New York City Comptroller, Alan G. Hevesi, and last Friday with New York's Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver.
Mr. Hevesi said that he and the First Lady spoke for more than an hour, half of which he said was spent discussing the case of Amadou Diallo, the unarmed African immigrant whose shooting death by the New York City police has led to protests against Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, a potential opponent of Mrs. Clinton. Mr. Hevesi said Mrs. Clinton brought up the case herself, but made no comment on Mr. Giuliani's handling of it.
Mr. Silver said he met for an hour and 45 minutes with the First Lady. In another indication that Mrs. Clinton may be positioning herself as a candidate, Mr. Silver said that she elaborated on her remarks last year that a Palestinian state was "very important" to Middle East peace.
Mr. Giuliani has called her comments "a very big mistake," and political analysts have said her remarks could give him a chance to cut into any support she has among conservative Jewish voters.
Mr. Silver said Mrs. Clinton told him that her remarks were a "reflection of her discussions" with Yitzhak Rabin, the late Israeli Prime Minister, "and that Rabin had told her that 'it was very difficult to negotiate with a nonentity.' Mrs. Clinton also said her remarks were "not inconsistent with American policy," the Speaker added.
Most upstate and suburban Democratic party officials said they came away from speaking with her believing that she would be a candidate.
"I thought I was talking to a political pro," said Steve Paquette, the Onondaga County Democratic chairman, who spoke to Mrs. Clinton for a half-hour last Thursday. "I honestly think for her to be taking the next broad step of calling folks like me, that's more than sticking your toe in the water."
Mrs. Clinton often calls at the end of the working day, sometimes after Mr. Ickes -- who now has his own Washington consulting firm -- has paved the way.
Paul Adler, the Rockland County Democratic chairman, said that last week, Mr. Ickes called him and asked him about local issues, and then Mrs. Clinton called to talk about property taxes, suburban development, the regional economy and transportation into New York City.
Mr. Ickes said that Mrs. Clinton was educating herself about New York through her phone calls, which she made alone. "She's finding out the lay of the political landscape, the lay of the issue landscape," he said.
Although most active Democratic Party workers are clamoring for Mrs. Clinton to run, many have also told her that the race will be very close and that she should expect personal attacks for her role in the Whitewater inquiry and her past spectacularly profitable trades in the commodities markets.
"I certainly indicated that it would be a tough race," said Dominic Baranello, the Democratic Party chairman of heavily Republican Suffolk County. He said he told Mrs. Clinton last week that the Republicans "would revive many of the issues we've been hearing about ad nauseam" and that "she has to be prepared to handle that."
Some local Democratic leaders say they have been taken aback by the intricacy of Mrs. Clinton's questions. "She was curious about why there was a large Jordanian population in Yonkers," said David Alpert, the Westchester County Democratic chairman, who spoke to Mrs. Clinton for nearly an hour. "I did not know the answer."
Mr. Alpert also said that he and Mrs. Clinton talked about friends and colleagues they had in common in Westchester -- Ronald H. Brown, the late Secretary of Commerce, who was a Democratic district leader in Mount Vernon in the 1970's, and Toby Nussbaum, a former county Democratic finance chairman who is married to Bernard W. Nussbaum, a former White House counsel.
The White House dinner that the President and Mrs. Clinton held for some influential New Yorkers took place March 5, in the family quarters. The guests included New York's State Comptroller, H. Carl McCall; Randi Weingarten, the president of the United Federation of Teachers; Mr. Rivera, the president of Local 1199, National Health and Human Service Employees Union; Bill Lynch, longtime adviser to former Mayor David N. Dinkins; Victor A. Kovner, a First Amendment lawyer and a corporation counsel in the Dinkins administration; and Sarah Kovner, a special assistant to the Federal Secretary of Health and Human Services, Donna E. Shalala, and Mr. Kovner's wife.
The guests were up until 1:30 A.M. having dinner and watching a movie ("October Sky"). Afterward, the New Yorkers slept at the White House. None stayed, said one sleep-over guest, in the Lincoln Bedroom.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 20, 1999, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about Hillary Rodham Clinton's preparations for a possible Senate campaign referred incorrectly to the accommodations for a group of New Yorkers who recently stayed overnight at the White House. Two guests -- State Comptroller H. Carl McCall and his wife, Dr. Joyce Brown -- indeed slept in the Lincoln Bedroom.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasuries Are Sharply Lower In Advance of AT&T Offering

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices posted their biggest loss in two weeks on speculation the AT&T Corporation would increase its bond sale from the $6 billion or more already planned.
"Everybody's going to buy it," said Closson Vaughan, who helps manage about $2.5 billion at Columbia Partners in Washington. "It will probably be upsized." He said he would probably buy some of the bonds, which will serve as bellwethers for the corporate bond market. 
 The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 29/32, to 95 22/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 5.55 percent, from 5.48 percent on Thursday.
Other companies are also selling debt, giving investors a higher-yielding alternative to United States bonds. Fannie Mae, the R & B Falcon Corporation and the Anadarko Petroleum Corporation sold a combined $3.3 billion yesterday. Wall Street firms arranging corporate debt sales often sell Treasuries first to protect against losses in case interest rates rise before the corporate sale is completed.
Investors said AT&T had received about $11 billion of tentative orders for its bonds, leading to speculation the nation's biggest telephone company might sell more debt than previously announced. The sale is likely to surpass the record $6.1 billion sold last year by the No. 2 long-distance company, MCI Worldcom Inc., investors said.
AT&T needs about $15 billion to pay for recent acquisitions, its share repurchase program and to repay existing debt, analysts said. The possibility of such a large sale is "weighing heavily on the market," said Tony Crescenzi, head government trader at Miller Tabak Hirsch & Company.
Volume was lighter than usual, as it was all week. About $41 billion of bills, notes and bonds had traded through most of the major bond brokers by 3 P.M. yesterday, 21.4 percent less than the average for Fridays the last month, according to Govpx Inc., a bond pricing service.
Fannie Mae, the biggest mortgage financier in the United States, sold $2 billion of five-year notes by expanding a $4 billion issue sold last month. R & B Falcon, the No. 4 oil and gas drilling contractor in the United States, increased its sale 25 percent, to $1 billion. Anadarko raised $300 million.

SECTION: Section A; Page 8; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 814 words

HEADLINE: Washington Journal;
Old-Fashioned Cafeteria Edging Toward Oblivion

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 19

 BODY:
How about the liver and onions for $2.25? Or fried whiting, the most expensive entree on the menu, for $3.95? For dessert, the pudding will set a diner back only 65 cents, or he can splurge, with homemade rhubarb pie for $1.65.
"Let's see, I had liver and onions, mashed potatoes with gravy, the pineapple-lettuce salad and lemon meringue pie," said John Kendrick, a retired professor at George Washington University who has been eating at Sholl's restaurants since he moved to Washington in 1941. "For all that, I think I paid $5.45. Maybe it was $5.50 but no more than that." 
 For home-style cooking, reasonable prices and a friendly atmosphere, there is nothing else in the nation's capital quite like Sholl's Colonial Cafeteria at 20th and K Streets downtown. As an old-fashioned slide-your-tray-along-and-keep-the-line-moving kind of place, there may be few like it in other big cities.
Trouble is, in a month or two, the last of the Sholl chain of cafeterias, serving institutional cuisine for 71 years, might follow the automat and tailfins into cultural oblivion.
As Washington's economic fortunes and downtown rental rates rise, the owners of the office building where the last Sholl's -- there once were eight of them -- has operated for 20 years are asking for a 20 percent rent increase above the current $20,000 a month, by early summer, to bring Sholl's more in line with other businesses in the neighborhood. Sholl's 10-year lease expired this month.
The demand has not only forced George Fleishell, 71, the cafeteria's majority owner and nephew of the founders, Evan and Gertrude Scholl, to contemplate closing the cafeteria, it has also brought sadness and defiance among devoted customers, some of whom have formed a group to fight to keep the cafeteria open.
"This is totally outrageous," said Jim McGrath, a retired analyst at the Library of Congress and chairman of the Save Our Sholl's Committee, who describes his mission as "a labor of love and a labor of anger."
Mr. McGrath has called for another strategy session on Saturday morning at the cafeteria.
"The treatment these people are getting is beyond belief," he insisted.
Brian McVay, a senior managing director for the company that manages the building, Cushman & Wakefield, said through a spokeswoman, Sheila Peck, that policy precluded him from discussing negotiations in progress.
Were it not for the ambiance and affordability of Sholl's, and its place in Washington's culinary history -- Trumans, Nixons and Carters ate at Sholl's -- few people might care about its closing. But Mr. Fleishell and his predecessors have always demonstrated a certain civic conscience, keeping prices low enough for the poorest of residents while attracting high-priced lobbyists and lawyers.
"You need a place like this in the city," said Robert Cutts, an official with the Federal Communications Commission who was eating lunch with his wife, Barbara. "It would be a loss to the city if it closed, if for no other reason people of modest means can come here to get a good meal and be treated with respect, the same as anybody else."
The same expectations have also kept Sholl's popular with people like Ted Barnhill, a professor of finance at George Washington. Mr. Barnhill eats lunch at Sholl's several times a week, drawn by the simplicity and wholesomeness of the food. "If you want to eat hearty," he said, "this is a great place."
But low prices can only account for so much. Tastes and trends change. Like most other cities, Washington is rife with ethnic and fast-food restaurants downtown, and Mr. Fleishell said he had noticed a precipitous decline in the number of meals served over the years. Since the K Street cafeteria opened 20 years ago, he said, the lunch crowd, for example, has dropped to 600 people from 1,800.
"We have raised some prices on occasion," Mr. Fleishell said. "One of the most popular things used to be filet of haddock, at $2.95. Now, it's too expensive to handle. I'd have to charge $7."
Exactly what anyone can do to save Sholl's remains a question. Harold Brazil, a member of the City Council, said he might write a letter to the owners. Senator Max Cleland, a Georgia Democrat who first visited as a student at American University, is serving as honorary chairman of the Save Our Sholl's Committee to call attention to the situation. Mr. McGrath said friendly persuasion might encourage the building owners to lower the rent increase.
Albert B. Krachman, Mr. Fleishell's lawyer, concluded that it might just come down to public embarrassment.
"With all the outflow of support, the landlords should see this as a chance to get a great public image, contribute to the community and become a hero," Mr. Krachman said. "Or they could close a public institution that's been around for 71 years, put people out and be regarded as an oppressive pariah."

HEADLINE: Paris Journal;
The Teacher in Charge Is Taught a Thing or Two

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: PARIS, March 19

 BODY:
Trying to change the education system in a country that fears any change is a thankless job, Claude Allegre, the feisty French Minister of Education, says with some exasperation.
Teaching and research in geophysics, his real profession for most of the last 35 years, were much more fun, he said over lunch with a group of foreign correspondents. 
 Eyes twinkling behind professorial rimless spectacles, hands clasped around his ample middle, Mr. Allegre, 61, looked like a man with a taste for work and joie de vivre. If schools could just teach children how to appreciate both those things, he said, they would be doing their job.
But since his old friend Lionel Jospin, the Prime Minister, picked Mr. Allegre in 1997 to run the large French education bureaucracy, he has become one of the most vilified politicians in France.
He doesn't mince words with his fellow teachers in the national system. When he took the Minister's job, he said, he saw his task as cutting out the fat. That put the more than a million teachers on their guard.
But when he criticized them for excess absenteeism and said it was a scandal that so many did not show up after summer vacation, some declared open war.
Now, "Allegre out" graffiti are plastered all over the Latin Quarter. Some 4,000 teachers took to the streets of Paris last month to demand his resignation, and one of the biggest secondary-school teachers' unions has called for a national demonstration on Saturday against legislation he has introduced to change the way French high schools, or lycees, prepare students for a university education.
Mr. Allegre takes it all in stride. "Not all teachers hate me," he said. "They see that the profession is in a period of great change, so they are anxious and defensive."
The French press often takes him to task for provocative statements, but he can't seem to help himself. "I said once that English is no longer a foreign language," he recalled with a laugh, "and did I get into trouble for that!"
It was an iconoclastic remark in a country where crusading against inroads from English is a sacred duty. "I do my bit every time I massacre the language by trying to speak it," he said modestly, in French.
Mr. Allegre, a professor's son, studied at the faculty of sciences of the University of Paris and in fact knows English well. He got a postdoctoral scholarship to the California Institute of Technology in 1964 and knows his way around places like Harvard and M.I.T. He is also a member of the American Academy of Sciences and several American professional organizations.
British and American higher education, he says, is the envy of the world. "Universities are the American education system," he said. "The rest isn't so good."
"I think our education system is still one of the best in the world, alas," he said, meaning the French system, "because the others have deteriorated even more than ours has."
But because, as he put it, "the lycee was the sickest part of our system," he began consulting teachers, parents and students soon after taking office about how to change the syllabus that leads up to the "bac" -- the baccalaureate diploma, without which no university study is possible. To get it, students have to pass a rigorous final examination that has been an annual spring ordeal dreaded by millions of families.
Five years ago, 65.5 percent did pass it. Now, partly because of juvenile delinquency and alienation among minority students of North African heritage, 62 percent of a generation has the bac.
But, Mr. Allegre pointed out, 20 years ago, only 34 percent got it. Most of the rest dropped out at 16 and entered the labor force.
"Today we generate more young unemployed people than any other society in Europe," he said. "The lycee broadened its syllabus and extended the school day, but lowered its standards and neglected the fundamentals. 'Close' isn't a good enough standard, but that's all a lot of teaching aims for."
Mr. Allegre's plan to change the system was announced in final form early this month. If approved by the French legislature, it would among other things institute individual tutorials in small groups for first-year lycee students having trouble with mathematics or French. Schools in disadvantaged areas like the heavily North African close-in suburbs of Paris would have priority.
Another part of the plan would create interdisciplinary independent study groups, guided by teachers, for students in the last two years of the three-year lycee cycle, with increased use of computers and information technology.
Special instructors -- artists for art courses, native speakers for languages -- would supplement the work of regular teachers. And new fields like physical and sports education would appeal to students turned off by the traditional curriculum of the past.
"The whole idea is to get teachers to help students," Mr. Allegre said. "In America and Britain that's understood." Here, the tradition always was that teachers taught, and students had to figure out for themselves how to learn.
"There's a great global challenge to education nowadays," he said, "and no country has really figured out the answer."
Meanwhile, Mr. Allegre said jokingly, he seizes any opportunity he can to teach physics. He was alluding to a running feud with the satirical weekly Le Canard Enchaine about a television appearance he made last month.
He had used the occasion to illustrate the inherent difficulty of mastering physics: If a beginning student was asked which would fall faster, a tennis ball or a heavy metal ball the same size dropped at the same time, he said, the answer would usually be the metal ball. "The truth is," he said, "that they land at the same time."
A few days later, the newspaper said Mr. Allegre was technically right, but only if the two balls were falling in a vacuum. Air resistance would slow down the tennis ball, it said, so the smoother, metal ball would indeed land first.
Mr. Allegre says he does not read newspapers but was alerted by his staff and sent a handwritten note to the editor, who published it on March 3. "One of your journalists thought he'd be smart and give me a physics lesson," the Minister's note read.
The acrimony continues in print, but Mr. Allegre says he doesn't mind. "I'm sure all the Canard Enchaine's readers have plunged into their physics books and are learning a lot," he said with a laugh.

SECTION: Section A; Page 14; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 575 words

HEADLINE: Realistic School Standards

 BODY:
The school standards movement is being undermined by a failure of political will. In state after state, politicians pander to the public with tough new standards and tests -- while failing to provide qualified teachers or the rudimentary labs necessary to prepare students adequately. When students fail the new tests, parents explode in outrage and the standards are eased, feeding the impression that public schooling is worthless and that some children can never learn.
New York State has embarked on a similar course. Anyone who doubts this should look at the 27 percent failure rate on a new English test prescribed by the state Board of Regents, one of five such Regents tests that students will eventually have to pass to graduate. In the near term, the state must take an active role in helping high school students who face a test for which their districts have failed to prepare them. In the long term, the state will need to embrace the broad preparation plan that the State Board of Regents recommended when it created the new standards. To do any less is courting civic disaster. 
 For most of its history, New York had a two-tiered testing system that led to two classes of diplomas. About 38 percent of high school students took the more challenging courses that led to the Regents High School Examinations, and for those who passed, the Regents diploma. But most students took less demanding courses and the Regents Competency Tests, leading to a local diploma.
The Board of Regents has scrapped the less challenging courses and tests and now wants virtually every student to take the math, science and English courses that lead to the Regents examination. The exam will initially have two passing grades, one for the Regents diploma and a lower one for the local diploma -- which will soon be phased out, making everyone reach for the Regents' mark.
The new standards do not kick in until next year. But a dry run in an English exam among current high school seniors whose results were released this week found that 27 percent across the state and 37 percent in New York City failed to achieve even the lower grade required for a local diploma. By contrast, under the old system, virtually everyone who took the weaker competency test got a local diploma. Given that next year's English test is longer and more difficult and that science and other subjects will be tested in subsequent years, the failure rates could soar much higher.
The Board of Regents hoped to avoid high failure rates by spending almost $900 million to bring all students up to speed while concentrating the bulk of that money on poor districts that have the least-qualified teachers and the worst facilities. But after welcoming the new standards and pledging to support them, Gov. George Pataki submitted a budget proposing only about $270 million and redirected much of the money toward affluent districts.
Students who do not get better preparation will fail the new tests in ever greater numbers. Those who repeat the 12th grade will make the current overcrowding problems even worse. As more students drop out and fail to get jobs, they will deaden an economy that already lags behind the nation's.
At the very least, the state should commit to furnishing all of its students with the instruction and tools they need to succeed. But doing that will require money, planning and vigorous leadership from the Governor and the Legislature.

HEADLINE: Record's Pluses Outweigh Lie, President Says

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 19

 BODY:
President Clinton said today that when the final word was written on his legacy, he would have one strike against him -- for lying -- but "hundreds and hundreds and hundreds" of pluses for the times that he was truthful and had not abused his office.
He also said that he did not have "a clue" whether his wife, Hillary, would run for the Senate from New York. But he said publicly for the first time that she had long ago suggested they move to New York when he left office, although he implied they would be spending a lot of time apart because he would be in Arkansas at his Presidential library. He said they were "working" on their marriage, which has appeared stressed over the last year in the wake of revelations about his extramarital affair. 
 "We're working hard, and we love each other very much," Mr. Clinton said today.
 At his first full-dress news conference in nearly a year, held in the formal East Room of the White House, Mr. Clinton ranged over an array of foreign and domestic issues for an hour. He sprang to the defense of Vice President Al Gore for Mr. Gore's overdrawn references in his personal biography, and he deflected a question about whether he felt betrayed by former aides who have criticized his fitness for the Presidency. His tone was generally conversational, but he became visibly testy when he was asked whether his "legacy will be about lying."
Mr. Clinton, who admitted last year that he had lied when he denied having an affair with Monica S. Lewinsky, a White House intern, said that telling the truth was important.
"And even Presidents have to do that and there are consequences when you don't," he said in an understated reference to his impeachment on charges of perjury and obstruction of justice, on which he was acquitted five weeks ago.
Then he tensed and his voice rose with anger as he asserted that on balance, he had a strong record and that reporters needed to be careful about telling the truth too.
"There will be a box score, and there will be that one negative," he said, referring to his lying under oath. "And then there will be the hundreds and hundreds and hundreds of times when the record will show that I did not abuse my authority as President, that I was truthful with the American people, and scores and scores of allegations were made against me and widely publicized without any regard to whether they were true or not."
Of those accusations, he said: "Most of them have already been actually proved false. And it's very hard to disprove every false allegation against you. But we have had more success frankly than I was afraid we would when we started. So I would hope that there would be a higher regard for truth-telling by all people in public life and all those who report on it."
He declined today to discuss one of those accusations -- by an Arkansas woman, Juanita Broaddrick, that he sexually assaulted her in 1978 while he was State Attorney General. His lawyer has denied it.
Mr. Clinton said he wanted to devote all of his time to the nation's business and would therefore refer all such questions to his lawyers. Pressed as to whether he could not simply deny the accusation, Mr. Clinton ignored the question.
Mr. Clinton has been available only briefly to reporters since the impeachment ordeal began more than a year ago. Today's news conference was one in a series of steps the White House has taken to thaw the icy relations with reporters that have marked his tenure.
He has held two off-the-record dinners with reporters, and his spokesman, Joe Lockhart, said the President would now conduct news conferences on a more regular basis.
His intention today was to present himself as back to business, and he generally avoided being drawn into the past. "I think it's best for me not to focus on that now," he said when asked for his reflections on being impeached.
He was more comfortable with the topic of his wife's political ambitions, though he said he was clueless on what she would decide. "The people she is talking to must know more than I do, because I literally don't have a clue," he said. "If you asked me today whether I thought it was more likely or not that she would run or not run, I could not give you an answer. I just don't know."
He said that long before either of them knew that Daniel Patrick Moynihan, a Democrat who is the state's senior Senator, would vacate his seat, she thought they should move to New York. Today he seemed to be trying to preempt criticism that Mrs. Clinton was a carpetbagger.
The President, who has given few hints about his post-Presidential plans, said of his wife: "She thought we should move to New York when I left the White House, knowing that I would spend a lot of time at home in my library and with the work there, but that we would also establish a home in New York."
He also explained why she would be a good representative for New York, saying: "She cares so much about the issues, especially those that have a particular impact on New York, including the education and economic issues that would be very important to the people there."
He defended Vice President Gore's recent claim that he "took the initiative in creating the Internet" and his suggestions that he spent a rustic boyhood as a farmhand in Tennessee. He actually grew up in Washington, the son of a Senator.
He "has been for 20 years one of the major architects of America's progress in technology," Mr. Clinton said.
"As far as his boyhood home, I think -- I know what you're saying," Mr. Clinton said. "You're saying, well, he went to St. Alban's and his daddy was a Senator. But it's also true that he is from East Tennessee and he did learn to do all those things he did on the farm."
He brushed aside a question about whether he felt betrayed by books highly critical of him by former advisers George Stephanopoulos and Dick Morris.
"I have absorbed no pain," he said, "since I haven't read either one of the books."

HEADLINE: Harlem Minister Urges Boycott to Protest Racism

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN

 BODY:
A prominent Harlem minister called on African-Americans yesterday to boycott two shopping districts in New York City to demonstrate their economic strength and to protest racism that included "the murderous behavior by police officers who kill unarmed blacks."
Flanked by a racially mixed group of clergy members from several Christian denominations, the minister, the Rev. Calvin O. Butts 3d, pastor of the Abyssinian Baptist Church, told reporters, "Black New Yorkers can no longer freely cooperate with a political economic system that allows the continued assault on the human rights of people of color." 
 Mr. Butts said the campaign would start immediately at two shopping districts heavily patronized by blacks: 34th Street in Manhattan and the Fulton Mall in Brooklyn. He said the boycott would be expanded in two weeks to Kings Plaza in Brooklyn, Fordham Road in the Bronx and Jamaica Avenue in Queens.
City officials said a boycott would only hurt struggling minority-owned businesses just when the city's economy is growing at a faster rate than the national average. "To now try to stop that growth and create some level of unemployment is counterproductive," Deputy Mayor Rudy Washington said. "I'm sorry that it's happening."
Although the boycott is a direct response to the shooting death last month of Amadou Diallo, an unarmed West African immigrant, by four New York City police officers, Mr. Butts said it also carried a broader message about unfair treatment of blacks by hospitals, schools and lending institutions.
At the Fulton Mall yesterday, most shoppers interviewed were unaware of the call for a boycott, and some were skeptical that it could work. "People will not pay attention to it," said Virginia Dotson, 58. "They'll come to where the bargains are."
But David Spell, 49, said he was open to the idea of a boycott. "If Calvin can organize it," he said, "I would follow. There are plenty of alternative places to shop."
Lou Carbonetti, the executive director of the Fulton Mall Improvement Association, a business group, said at least 85 percent of the mall's customers are black. "This is an emotional situation that's taken place against the city," he said. "It's not a personal thing against the mall."
Officials of the 34th Street Partnership, the business group representing the other boycott target, had no comment.
